author: L.
description: A glabrous, perennial twiner. Stems slender; branches glabrous or sparsely hairy. Leaves pinnate; leaflets 10-20 pairs, opposite, glabrous above, slightly hairy beneath. Inflorescence a dense many flowered axillary raceme. Flowers bisexual zygomorphic. Calyx small, campanulate, truncate; glabrous or sparsely silky; teeth very short. Corolla pink or white with a pink tinge. Stamens monadalphous 9 (the tenth stamen absent): ovary subsessile, ovules many; stigma capitates. Fruit a pod; seeds 3-5; bright scarlet with a black spot, some times white with a black spot.
pharmacology: Various parts, extracts and isolated principles of I11A. precatoriusI11 were subjected to pharmacological studies. The antifertility and anticancer activities were studied in greater details. The effects of the different doses of the aqueous extract of the seeds on the pregnancy of mice revealed that when given subcutaneously as a single dose prior to mating did not prevent conception but adversely affected the foetal development. Subcutaneously the LD B11100B11 was found to be 2 mg/kg, while 0.5 mg/kg was non toxic. Oral administration of 25 mg/kg of the extract caused death in 40 per cent of the animals (Desai and Sirsi, 1964). The aqueous suspension of the seeds was found to cause abortion 51 per cent of rats when administered orally at the daily dose of 125 mg/kg from day 0 to 10 of post coital period. The abortifacient activity was found to be reduced when the same dose was administered from day 6 to day 15. In failure cases (where pregnancy was not interrupted) noticeable neonatal anomalies were observed (Sethi et al., 1990). The petroleum ether and alcoholic extracts of the root on oral administration from 1-5d post coitum prevented nidation up to 100 per cent in albino rats. The alcoholic extract of the drug also showed antioestrogenic activity when injected simultaneously with oestradiol. The LD B1150B11 of the drug was found to be 2g/kg (Agarwal et al., 1970). The ethanolic extract of the air-dried powdered seeds in a concentration of 1 mg/ml/day up to 12d administered intraperitoneally exhibited antispermatogenic activity in albino rats. Oral administration of a 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the seeds (250 mg/kg) for 30 and 60d induced a total infertility in male albino rats. A protein extract isolated from the seeds showed antitumour activity on Yoshida sarcoma (solid and ascites forms) in rats and a fibro sarcoma in mice. The aqueous extract of the seeds when tested against Ehrlichâs ascites carcinoma in transplanted mouse tumours for anticancer activity was toxic and all the experimental animals died before the experiment was completed at the test doses of 3 and 12mg/kg i.p. (Pal et al., 1968). Preliminary investigations of the water soluble portion of the 90 per cent ethanolic extract of the seed kernels at a dose of 0.05-0.25 mg/ml showed spasmodic effect on different smooth muscles of rabbit, guinea pig, albino rat and dog. The extract was well tolerated up to a dose of 1.5 g/kg orally and did not produce any toxic effects (Agrawal et al., 1971). The alcoholic extracts of the seed kernel was devoid of cardiovascular actions in dogs, showed CNS depressant and analgesic activity in rats, spasmogenic effect on isolated uterine strip of guinea pig and rat, slight relaxant effect of the rat uterus in diestrous cycle, reversible relaxant effect on rabbit ileum. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) in a biological screening was found to be devoid of various activities viz., antiviral, antifertility, hypoglycaemic, diuretic and antiinflammatory as well as effects on isolated ileum, CNS and gross behavioural effect. The chemical and pharmacological studies on the plant were reviewed by Khan et al., (1991). The ethanolic extract of the seeds inhibited the growth of I11Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Salmonella paratyphiI11 A and B, I11Shigella dysenteriae I11 Sonne and Schmitzii, enteric microorganisms and pathogenic fungi I11Trichophyton interdigitale, T. rubrumI11 and I11Epidermophyton floccosumI11 in vitro. Both aqueous and ethanolic extracts were not inhibitory to I11Microsporum canis, Candida albicans, AspergilliI11 and I11Mycobacterium tuberculosisI11 H B1137B11R B11v.B11The alcoholic extract of the seeds showed slight antibacterial activity against Escherichia coli in vitro. The alcoholic extract of the seeds at a concentration of 200 mg/ ml was found to be active against I11Bacillus subtilis, Staphylococcus aureus, Proteus vulgaris, Pseudomonas aeruginosaI11 and I11Escherichia coliI11 while the hexane and the aqueous extracts were devoid of any activity. The extract of the seeds in vitro studies was found to be fungistatic at 1 per cent concentration against I11Cryptococcus neoformansI11 isolated from the brain lesion of a patient. The 80 per cent ethanolic extract of the leaves showed antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 at a concentration of 25 mg/ml using the agar dilution method. The extract, however, was inactive against I11Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosaI11 and I11Bacillus subtilis.I11 Different fractions of the seeds showed poor anthelmintic activity against earthworms as compared to hexylresorcinol, except the aqueous extract prepared by infusion which at a concentration of 0.1 per cent was found to kill all the worms in 3 min. The extract prepared by boiling the drug in water showed no activity indicating the active principal was heat labile (Agarwal, 1975). The cold alcoholic extract of seeds showed toxicity against I11Dactynotus carthamiI11 while it was inactive against I11Prodenia litura.I11 The aqueous extracts of the seeds exhibited striking effects on the mitotic and meiotic chromosomes in the testes of the grasshopper Poecilocerus pictus. Abrine, isolated from the seeds, in a dose of 5-20 ppm had a drastic effect on the population density of mealy bugs I11Maconellicoccus hirsutus.I11 The aqueous extract of unprocessed and processed (milk as well as âkanji shodhitâ) white, red and brown varieties of seeds in a doses of 0.25, 0.5 and 1.0 mg administered i.p. in albino mice were studied for their effects on CNS, besides acute toxicity. The animals fed with the unprocessed seeds in different doses showed depression on CNS activity, marked decrease in heart and respiratory rates, sluggish spontaneous activity and reactivity, elongation of the body, aggressive behaviour and coloration of skin from white to black. However, animals treated with milk processed material also showed lesser aforesaid changes but almost no change was observed in âkanji shodhitâ material. Acute toxicity studies of processed and unprocessed seeds revealed the LD B1150B11 to be 0.5 to 1.0 mg and LDB11100B11 between 1.0 and 2.0 mg/kg bw in white and red variety of the unprocessed material with both milk and âkanjiâ. The LDB1150B11 was 1.0 to 20. mg in milk and 20.0-30.0 mg/kg bw in âkanji shodhitâ seeds while LD50 was 2.5-5.0 mg/kg bw in milk and 20.0-30.0 mg/kg bw in âkanji shodhitâ seeds while LDB11100B11 was 2.5-5.0 mg/kg bw in milk and 20.0-30.0mg/kg bw in âkanji shodhitâ seeds of white and red forms, respectively (Singh Gautam et al., 1999). View Reference
chemical_composition: Two new alkaloids viz., methyl ester of N,N- dimethyltryptophan metho cation and precatorine along with abrine, hypaphorine, chlorine and trigonelline were isolated from the defatted seeds. The leaves, stem and root also furnished the above bases in varying proportions. A special feature was the occurrence of trigonelline as the gallic acid ester (Ghosal and Dutta, 1971). Preliminary studies of the stem, seeds, leaves and dehisced empty fruits of the plant revealed alkaloids in the stem and dehisced empty fruits and alkaloids and flavonoids in the seeds. The leaves did not have any alkaloids, flavonoids or saponins. The root contained sterol and terpenes. The flavones identified in the seeds were abrectorin (6, 4â âdimethoxy-7,3â âdihydroxflavone) (Bhardwaj et al., 1980) and premtorin (6,7,4â-trimethoxy -3â-hydroxyflavone ). Besides these, a glycoside, desmethoxycentuareidin 7- I11OI11-rutinoside and two novel flavone C-glycosides, abrusin (8-C- glucosyl scuteralein 6, 7 âdimethyl ether ) and its 2â - I11OI11- apioside and n-hentriacontane, pentacosanoic acid, Ã -amyrin, Ã -sitosterol, campesterol and a new compound identified as 7,9,15-trimethylehenicosane were isolated (Bhaumik, 1987). The root contained a new glycoside 7,5-dihydroxcy -6, 4â- dimethoxyisoflavone 7- I11OI11- Ã - I11DI11- galactopyranoside (Saxena and Sharma, 1999). The seeds contained a mixture of diglycoside and complex glycoside of delphinidin from which gallic acid was identified for the first time and a minor amount of I11pI11 -hydroxycinnamic acids. The seeds had 8.1 per cent moisture, 20.4 percent rude protein, 10.5 per cent pentosan and 6.40 per cent water âsoluble mucilage. Seeds yield abrins A, B and C, abralin, abrine, hypaphorine, choline, 5 Ã - cholanic acid, trigonelline and its gallic acid ester, precatorine, methyl ester of N, N-dimethyltryptophan â methocation and several amino acids, a new steroids abricin, abridin, new flavonoid-abrectorin, new triterpenoids-abruslactone A, methyl abrusgenate and abrusgenic acid. The seed oil contains palmitic, stearic, arachidic, behenic, ligroceric, oleic, linoleic and linolenic acids. Seed coats contain monoglucoside anthocyanins, abranin, delphinindin-3, 5-diglucoside, pelargonidin 3, 5 âdiglucoside and several others glucosides. Leaves contain glycyrrhizin and pinitol. The roots yielded glycyrrhizin, precol, abrol, two alkaloids-abrasine, precasine and isoflavanquinones.

author: (DC.) Willd.
description: Tree to 20 m tall; crown conical or rounded; all parts except flowers usually pubescent or puberulous; stems without spines or prickles; leaves bipinnate, petioles 1.5-2.5 cm long, with a gland above; rachis 4-12 cm long with numerous raised glands all along its upper side; pinnae 8-30 pairs, pinnules 16-70 pairs, linear-oblong, 1.5-4 X 0.5-0.75 mm; flowers in globose heads 5-8 mm in diameter, borne in panicles or racemes, on peduncles 2-6 mm long; pale yellow and fragrant; pods gray-puberulous, or sometimes glabrous, almost moniliform, dehiscing, usually 3-10 cm long, 0.5-0.8 cm wide, with 3-14 joints; seeds black, smooth, elliptic or compressed ovoid, 3-5 X 2-3.5 mm; caruncle conspicuous; areole 3.5 mm long, 2 mm wide. Seeds 66,000 to 110,000/kg.
pharmacology: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the stem bark from Tamilnadu in a preliminary biological screening revealed effect on CVS of dog/cat and diuretic activity in rat. The extract was devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, anticancer and hypoglycaemic activities and effects on CNS and isolated tissues of experimental animals. The LDB1150B11 of the extract was 40 mg/kg i.p in mice (Dhar et al., 1974). View Reference
chemical_composition: The bark was reported to contain 40 per cent of tannins (Gupta et al., 1981).

author: Forrsk.
description: A stout herb with erect stem, the older branches glabrous, the younger pubescent. Leaves 3-7.5 X 3.7 cm ovate, often caudate-aluminate, hairy on the veins beneath, base usually rounded, 5 nerved. Flowers in axillary androgynous spikes, the males few, sessile, minute, at the top of the spike, the females several, crowded at its base; bracts of female flowers large, fimbriate, 1-2 flowered. Male flowers: Sepals 4, valvate; petals and disk absent, stamens usually 8, filaments short; pistillode absent. Female flowers: Sepals 3-4, minute; petals and disk absent; ovary 3-celled; ovule solitary in each cell; styles filiform. Capsule of 3 minute 2-valved cocci; glabrous, nearly white, twisted after dehiscence. Seeds globosely ovoid.
pharmacology: The ethanolic extract of the root screening for its hypoglycaemic activity at a single dose of 250Âµg/mg revealed a 9 per cent lowering in the blood sugar in rats. The LDB1150B11 of the extract was 178mg/kg in rats (Uniyal et al., 1990). View Reference
chemical_composition: Plants contains kaempferol, sitosterol, and triacetonamine. Leaves and twig, acalyphine, acalyphamide and other amides, quinone, sterols and cyanogenic glycoside.

author: L.
description: An erect, annual herb with numerous ascending angular branches; leaves ovate, or rhomboid-ovate, acute, crenate-serrate, base cuneate; petioles long, slender. Both Male and Female flowers in axillary spikes, male flowers minute, clustered near the summit of the spike, the females scattered, 3-5 surrounded by a many- nerved bracts; ovary hispid. Male flowers: Sepals 4, petals, disk and pistillode absent, stamens usually 8. Female flowers: sepals 3-4, minute, imbricate, petal and disk absent, ovary 3-celled; ovule solitary in each cell. Capsule small, hispid, quite concealed by the bract, often only 1-seeded.
pharmacology: Four successive extracts (petroleum ether, ethanol, chloroform and distilled water) of the plant at doses of 300 and 600 mg/kg bw administered orally for 7d were tested for post coital antifertility activity in female albino rats. The first two extracts were found to be most effective causing significant antiimplantation activity. The petroleum ether extracts showed antiestrogenic activity when given with standard ethinyl estradiol, while the ethanolic extract was devoid of any activity in combination. The chloroform and distilled water extracts were found to be ineffective. The infusion of the leaves showed a positive inotropic and chronotropic activities on the frog rectus abdominis. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant in preliminary biological screening was found to be devoid of antiprotozoal, antiviral, hypoglycaemic, anticancer and diuretic activities. It also did not show any effects on isolated tissues and CNS in experimental animals. The LDB1150B11 of the extract was >1000 mg/kg i.p. in mice. The alcoholic extracts of the leaves, tender shoot and root revealed in vitro antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Escherichia coli,I11 while the aqueous extracts were devoid of this activity. The aqueous extract of the leaves were reported to have antibacterial activity against the gram positive bacteria viz., I11Bacillus subtilis, Bac megaterium, Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Sarcina luteaI11 as well as gram negative bacteria I11Salmonella typhi, Escherichia coli, Proteus vulgarisI11 and I11Pseudomonas fluorescens.I11 The extract was more active against gram positive bacteria. Other extracts also showed some activity against these bacteria. In vitro evaluation of four successive extracts of the plant viz., petroleum ether, chloroform, ethanol and distilled water, revealed varying degree of antimicrobial activity against I11Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus citreus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Proteus vulgaris, Aspergillus nigerI11 and I11Candida albicansI11. The extract of the leaves was devoid of antifungal activity against I11Curvularia lunata. I11 The extract however inhibited the mycelia of I11Colletotrichum falcatumI11 and I11Rhizoctonia solani.I11 The plant (leaves) also showed antifungal activity against I11Alternaria alternata, Drechslera speciferum, D. rostrata, D. turcicaI11 and I11Pestolatiopsis palmarum.I11 The extracts of I11A. indica, Tridax procumbensI11 and I11Azadirachta indica,I11 individually, at a concentration of 0.2 per cent in mineral base produced an antiseptic activity, comparable G (10Âµ1/ml). The three extracts in a combination, at a concentration of 0.3 per cent, however were reported to be more active than Penicillin G. C11Clinical StudiesC11 In a pilot study, conducted at Central Research Institute (Siddha), Madras, on 38 patients suffering from bronchial asthma, the aqueous extract of the plant in a dosage of 30 ml to 60 ml was given twice or thrice daily. 60 per cent of the cases were relieved from wheezing within 2 wk, while 90 per cent got relief from severe cough with expectoration. The raised eosinophil count was also normalized. View Reference
chemical_composition: The benzene extract of the plant contained S226-sitosterol acetate (Mukherjee, 1967); while the hexane and alcoholic glycoside, which yielded kaempferol on hydrolysis (Purushotaman et al.,1973). In a later study, the plant showed the presence of steroids/terpenoids, flavonoids and saponins while alkaloids, tannins and phenolics were found to be absent. The ethanolic extract of the plant was reported to contain flavonoids viz., 5,7- dihydroxyflavone (chrysin) and 3,5,7-trihydroxyflavone (galangin) (Hiremath et al., 1998) The dried and powdered leaves and twigs contained a new amide, acalyphamide isolated as its acetate along with the modified dipeptide aurantiamide and its acetate, tri- I11OI11-methtylellagic acids as its acetate, 2-methylanthraquinone, succinimide, Ã -sitosterol and its Ã -D- glucoside (Talapatra et al., 1981). The quantitative estimation of the proteins, fats, minerals, fibre, carbohydrates, calcium, phosphorus, iron and vitamin C has been done in the plant.

author: Wall. ex Baill.
description: A laxly branched perennial herb or subshrub up to 1.5 m tall.Stems puberulous or pubescent, sometimes also pilose or hirsute.Petioles up to 10 cm long.Leaf blades 3-13 Ã 1.5-9 cm, ovate, acuminate at the apex, crenate-serrate on the margins, rounded to shallowly cordate at the base, membranous, sparingly pubescent or hirsute or subglabrous on both surfaces, also somewhat puberulous along the midrib and main nerves, 5-9-nerved from the base; lateral nerves in 3-5 pairs.Stipules 3-4 mm long, filiform-setaceous, pubescent. Male inflorescence up to 12 cm long, spicate, axillary, solitary; bracts 0.5 mm long. Male flowers subsessile or shortly pedicellate; buds rounded tetragonal, glabrous, reddish.Female inflorescence up to 25 cm long and 6 cm wide, paniculate, terminal, rarely sometimes spicate and axillary; panicle branches subspicate or racemose; bracts minute, not accrescent, 1-3-flowered. Female flowers sessile or shortly pedicellate; sepals 5, 0.5 mm long, lanceolate, acute, sparingly pubescent; ovary 0.5 mm in diameter, somewhat 3-lobed, papillose and stipitate-glandular; styles 1-2 mm long, free, deeply 4-6-partite, the segments filiform, red. Fruits 1.5 Ã 2 mm, 3-lobed, granulate near the apex and sparingly stipitate-glandular. Seeds 1.2 Ã 0.8 mm, ovoid, minutely alveolate-reticulate, purplish-grey, ecarunculate.

The LDB11100B11 of the extract was found to be >1000 mg/kg i.p. in mice (Dhar et al., 1974). View Reference

author: L.
description: A small, herbaceous plant, glabrous or pubescent; roots stoloniferous. Stem furrowed, leafy. Leaves 5-15 cm long, ablong-lanceolate, 3-pinnatisect, minutely divided into linear, dentate, mucronate segments. Flower-heads corymbose ovoid, shortly pedunculate. Achenes shining.
pharmacology: Various extracts viz., chloroform, methanolic, aqueous and total aqueous extracts of the aerial parts revealed hepatoprotective activity against CC1 B114 B11 and paracetamol intoxicated liver in rats. The extracts did not show any toxicity/mortality up to the dose of 1.5 g/kg i.p. The aqueous extract was found to be the most active and was found to show a 74.76 per cent decrease in the serum glutamic-oxaloacetic transaminase (SGOT) levels and 89.48 per cent decrease in serum glutamic-pyruvic transaminase (SGPT) levels in rats (Gadgoli and Mishra, 1995). The pharmacodynamic actions of the water soluble achillin isolated from the stem of the plant were studied in different animal species. Achillin produced spasmolytic effect on intestinal muscles of rabbit, guinea pigs and this relaxant action of the gut could not be neutralized by spasmogens. No overt symptoms of toxicity were observed in albino rats in doses of 50-150 mg/kg orally. The LDB1150B11 of achillin was found to be 2.8g/kg (Tewari et al, 1974). The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant in a preliminary biological screening showed effect on CVS in cat/dog and gross behavioural effect in mice. The extract did not show any antibacterial, antifungal, antiviral, antifertility, hypoglycaemic, anticancer and diuretic activities and effect on isolated tissues of animals. The LDB1150B11 of the extract was found to be >1000 mg/kg i.p. in mice. The seed extract showed nematicidal activity against root knot juveniles of I11Meloidogyne incognita I11 (Vijayalakshmi et al., 1979). View Reference
chemical_composition: Petroleum ether extract of the stem revealed the presence of Ã âsitosterol and a lactone achillin (Tewari et al., 1974). The aerial parts revealed the presence of alkaloids and absence of flavonoids, tannins and saponins (Sharma et al., 1985).

author: L.
description: An erect .3-1 m high; or procumbent, annul or perennial herb with woody stem. Stem siff, not much branched. Leaves opposite, petiolate, entire; thick, hairy above, tomentose beneath; elliptic or obovate, 3.8-6.25 by 2.5-4.5 cm., elliptic or obovate, sometimes nearly orbicular usually rounded at the apex; petioles .6-2 cm. long. Flowers in slender, elongate terminal spikes; greenish-white, stiffly deflexed against the wooly-pubescent rachis. Spikes at first short but soon lengthen, reaching as much as 51 cm. long in fruit. Bracts .3 cm. long, broadly ovate, acuminate, membranous, aristate, persistent; bracteoles .3 cm. long, broadly ovate, concave, with a spine as long as the blade, hard in fruit, falling off with the fruiting perianth. Perianth 1-1.5 cm long, of 4-5 segments, glabrous and shining. Stamens 5, anthers 2-celled, staminodes truncate, fimbriate. Ovary oblong; 1-celled; ovule solitary; style filiform; stigma capitellate. Fruit an utricle; oblong-cylindric, thinly membranous, enclosed in the hardened perianth.

author: L.
description: Herbs with creeping and branching, aromatic root stock. Spathes leaf-like, long. Spadix long, cylindrical and broad. Flowers densely arranged.
pharmacology: I11A. calamus,I11 specially the rhizome, has significant actions on the CNS, which justifies its use in some CNS diseases in Ayurvedic system of medicine. Asarone seems to be the active principle of the rhizome. It seems to be a sedative tranquilizer with no anticonvulsant action. It has prominent antispasmodic and antiinflammatory effects besides antimicrobial, insecticidal and pesticidal actions also. The active principle responsible for the activity resided in the hydrocarbon fraction of the oil or in an oxygenated component out of various fractions of the oil tested. Acute toxicity studies with the Indian oil in mice revealed a LDB1150B11 of 0.177g/kg i.p. The steam volatile fractions of the root and rhizome prolonged the sleeping time in mice with pentobarbital, hexobarbital and ethanol. Studies on the vitro effect of the steam volatile oil on the respiration of rat brain revealed that in inhibited the oxygen uptake of brain tissues of varying degrees. The ED B1150B11 was 1:1, 980. The rate of oxygen uptake a different intervals by 100 mg of the rat brain homogenate in the presence of glucose, sodium glutamate and sodium succinate was 43.1, 34.1 and 6.7 per cent, respectively. Neuropharmacological actions of the oil (from the rhizome) revealed sedative-tranquilizing action in rats, mice, cats, dogs and forced motor activities in mice. Acorus oil investigated for its antianaleptic activity was used as a saline suspension, given 1h prior to production of convulsions in adult albino mice. At a dose of 100 mg/kg bw i.p. it successfully prevented seizures (70 per cent) in maximal electroshock seizures. The EDB1150B11 of the test drug was found to be 60.5 mg/kg bw i.p. Asarone and Ã-asarone possessed many pharmacodynamical actions quite similar to some of the well established tranquilizers. Intraperitoneal administration of a flavone (15 mg/kg in alkalinated aqueous solution) isolated from the chloroform extract of the rhizome produced profound behavioural changes in Rhesus monkey. The chloroform extracted flavone exhibited an activity similar to I11Cannabis indica.I11 The water soluble dried powder of the alcoholic extract of the root and rhizome at 10 and 20 mg/kg i.p. did not afford protection to strychnine-induced convulsions. The aqueous and alcoholic extracts of the rhizome were found to reduce the severity of maximum electric shock-induced seizures in rats but did not exhibit complete protection. The antiinflammatory activity of the boiled coconut oil extract of the rhizome was studied in rats using acute and chronic experimental models. The oral administration of 2 ml of the extract produced 45 per cent inhibition of the carrageenin-induced paw oedema, 13.6 per cent inhibition of cotton pellet granuloma formation and 61 per cent of inhibition of croton oil granuloma pouch inflammatory response in rats. The extract of the rhizome (0.5ml/kg i.p.) had significant antiinflammatory activity in acute, chronic and immunological models of inflammation and it compared well with the reference drugs (viz., hydrocortisone, phenylbutazone, flurbiprofen and cyproheptadine) in the doses used. The oil obtained from the rhizome possessed carminative properties. In moderate doses the oil produced antispasmodic action on the involuntary muscle tissue, inhibiting the excessive peristaltic movements of the intestines in rabbits and dogs. The alcoholic extract of the root and rhizome of the plant in experimental animals revealed potent sedative and analgesic properties. The essential oil and the crude alcoholic and aqueous extracts obtained from the rhizome and root showed depressant action in dogs. Asarone and the essential oil (from the rhizome) had a relaxant effect as well as antispasmodic effect against various spasmogens on the ileum of rabbit, guinea pig and albino rat, rats uterus, bronchial muscles of guinea pig, tracheal chain of dog and blood vascular muscles of rats. The essential oil of the rhizome was found to exhibit quinidine â like activity in combating auricular fibrillation (induced by either acetylcholine or aconitine), auricular flutter (produced by crush-stimulation procedure) and ventricular arrhythmias following 2-stage coronary ligation in dogs. Both asarone and Ã -asarone showed cardiac depressant activity as seen on frog and rabbit heart perfusion experiments. Ã -asarone appeared to be more potent than asarone. The 50 per cent alcoholic extract of the root exhibited a dose-dependent hypotensive action on dog blood pressure. In a preliminary biological screening, the 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the rhizomes showed antispasmodic activity on isolated guinea pig ileum and gross behavioural effect, hypothermia and analgesic activity in mice. The alcoholic, ether, acetate buffer and dilute sulphuric acid extract of the root showed activity against I11Staphylococcus aureus.I11 The alcoholic extract of the root showed marked antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Bacillus subtilis, Staphylococcus citreus, Bacillus megaterium, Salmonella paratyphiI11 A and B,I11Salm marcescens, Proteus vulgarisI11 and I11Shigella dysomei.I11 The total extract of the rhizome exhibited moderate antibacterial activity in vitro against I11Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes, Strept viridans, Diplococcus pneumoniae, Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Escherichia coli, Salmonella typhi, Salm paratyphiI11 A and B I11Shigella flexneri.I11 The effect was evident more against gram positive organisms than the gram negative organisms. The 80 per cent ethanolic extract of the root inhibited the two strains of I11Bacillus subtilisI11 and I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 at a concentration of 25 mg/ml using the agar diffusion method. The acetone extract of the rhizome had antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosaI11 and I11Klebsiella sp.I11 (Rajendhran et al., 1998). The ether extract of the rhizome in in vitro studies using the disc diffusion method revealed antibacterial activity against enteropathogenic I11Escherichia coliI11 (1.0), I11Shigella sonneiI11 (0.9), I11Salmonella typhiI11 (0.7), I11Klebsiella pneumoniaeI11 (2.2) and I11Vibrio choleraeI11 (2.0). The figures in the brackets indicated the zone of inhibition (in cms). The extract using the tube dilution method at a concentration of 125?g/ml (MIC 1:8) revealed antibacterial activity against I11Klebsiella pneumoniaeI11 and I11Vibrio choleraeI11 while it inhibited other organisms at a dose of 250?g/ml (MIC 1:4). The essential oil from the rhizome showed a week antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Salmonella typhosumI11 and I11Shigella flexneri.I11 The essential oil also showed in vitro antifungal activity against I11Aspergillus oryzae, A. nidulans, A. fumigates, Penicillium aculeatumI11 and I11Phomopsis destuctumI11 (Alankarao and Rajendra Prasad, 1981); citrus decay pathogens I11Penicillium digitatum, P. italicum, Diplodia natalensis, Alternaria tenuisI11 and I11Candida albicans, Epidermophyton cresensI11 and I11Microsporum gypseumI11 (Kapil et al., 1983). The alcoholic extract of the root showed antifungal activity against I11Aspergillus niger, Penicillium seleniumI11 and yeast Saccharomyces. The alcoholic extract of the rhizome exhibited potent antiviral in vitro against herpes virus HSV-1 and HSV-2 at a concentration well below the cytotoxic concentration. Pretreatment of Vero cells with 15Âµ/ml of the extract did not inhibit viral replication of HSV-1 and HSV-2 signifying that host cells were not affected by the extract. B-Asarone had strong inhibitory activity against the replication of both virus types although the effective concentration was only two fold less than the cytotoxic concentration level. The antiherpes factor not toxic to the host cells existed both in the crude alcoholic extract of the plant as well as Ã -asarone. The alcoholic extract of the rhizomes showed in vitro anthelmintic activity against human I11Ascaris lumbricoides.I11 The essential oil obtained from the root and rhizome showed nematicidal activity against I11Meloidogyne incognitaI11 at a concentration of 250-500 ppm. The oil obtained from the rhizomes of the plant collected from Jammu revealed 100 per cent insecticidal activity, against houseflies I11Musca domesticaI11 after 12 min. The powdered rhizome was found to be useful against bugs, moths, lice, etc. The insecticidal activity and other pharmacological activities of the plant have been reviewed by Virmani et al. (1977), Hussain and Jahan (1980). C11Clinical StudiesC11 In a preliminary clinical trial on 15 patients with moderate to severe bronchial asthma, 1 to 2 g of fresh root divided in three doses was administered by chewing method for 2-4wk. The drug was found to have antiasthmatic potential free from side effects. In another clinical trial on 147 children (age 5-11 years) having round worms infestation, calamus powder 250 mg t.i.d was given for three days. 122 patients (83 per cent) were completely cured while 25 patients (17 per cent) remained unchanged. The drug was found to be effective in the improvement of chest pain, dyspnoea on effort, reduction of body weight index, improving in ECG, decreasing serum cholesterol, decreasing SLDL (serum low density lipoproteins) and increasing SHDL (serum high density lipoproteins). I11A. calamusI11 (500 mg in a dose of 2 tablets three times a day after meal with water) given for six weeks showed reduction in the degree of severity of depression and better rehabilitation. View Reference
chemical_composition: A preliminary examination of the oil from the rhizome of the plants grown in India revealed that it was not identical to the European varieties but resembled the oils of Java varieties. The Indian oil differed from the commercial varieties of calamus oil in respect of predominance of asarone (82 percent). The commercial varieties contained 7 per cent of asarone. The oils obtained from the plants of different parts of India were analyzed by various workers for their chemical constituents. The unpeeled dry root from Coimbatore contained 1.5-3.5 per cent of the oil. The oil obtained from the rhizome from Bangalore calamenenol (5.0 per cent), calameone (1.0 per cent), S224 pinene and camphene (0.2 per cent), eugenol (0.3 per cent) and eugenol methyl ether (1.0 per cent). The characteristic odour of the oil was ascribed to an unidentified constituent (Kelkar and Sanjiva Rao, 1934). Later, presence of Ã âasarone in the oil was also reported. The essential oil was found to be an allyetrimethoxybenzene. Dandiya et al., (1959a) carried out a comparative study of the physical characteristics and properties of the oils obtained from an Indian calamus, oil obtained from a European drug and the oil from a commercial source. The European oil had a lower specific gravity, higher optical rotation and a lower refractive index than the other two samples of the oil. Fractionation of the active substance from the volatile oil of the Indian origin by gas chromatography resulted in the isolation of S224 âasarone and Ã- asarone which are the trans- and cis-isomers , respectively of 2,4,5- trimethoxy-1-propenylbenzene (Baxter et al., 1960). The synthesis of asarone from 1, 2, 4-trimethoxybenzene was reported. Chromatographic estimation of asarones in the root oil of a tetraploid variety from Jammu was carried out (Chopra et al., 1965). The oil distilled from rhizome obtained from Kashmir was found to contain in addition to asarone, palmitic acid, calamene, calamenone, calamol, azulenen and hydrocarbons. The oil obtained from the rhizome of the plants growing in Jammu region generally had similar composition. The difference in two oils reported was that the predominant constituent in the oil from the Jammu side was asarone content was found to be only 5.20per cent. Asarone, Ã -asarone, calamenol, calamene, calamene, calamenone, eugenol, methyl eugenol, S224 -pinene, two selinane type sesquiterpenes â acolamone and isoacolamone, sugars, glucosides-acorin, calameon, calamusenone, a flavone-leteolin-6, 8-C-diglucoside, new natural products acoramone, asarylaldehyde, carcinogen, Ã -asarone and epoxyisoacoragermacrone are the main chemical constituents reported from this plant. Essential oil from rhizome, calamus oil has Ã -asarone as major constituent together with calammen, calamenol and calameon. Dry rhizome contains a yellow aromatic volatile oil. Glucoside acorin. Leaves contain oxalic acid and calcium. A rapid and accurate method using HPTLC has been developed which could be used for detection, monitoring and quantification of Ã âasarone in the plant and other herbal preparations containing the plant. The proposed method is reported to be precise (average recovery = 99.6 per cent, C.V. < 0.5 per cent), sensitive, specific and reproducible. A thin layer chromatographic technique has also been described to detect the presence of the plant in various Ayurvedic preparations. The essential oil of the rhizome and leaves raised under submountain and Tarai region of Kumaun of Uttar Pradesh, now Uttranchal, and the oil from the rhizome of Bhimtal sample (in the Kumaun hills) contained (per cent) I11pI11- cymene (0.03, 0.23,-), 1,8- cineol/limonene (traces, 3.01, 0.09), dipentene (0.37, traces, 0.06), methyleugenol ( traces, 2.05), isoeugenol (25.02, traces, 2.28), methylisoeugenol (2.79, traces), calamene (3.84, traces, 5.07), asaronaldehyde (5.66, 4.95, traces), asarone (3.95, 3.84, 4.39), Ã âasarone (42.47, oils, respectively. The physico âchemical properties of the oils were also determined. The rhizome of the plants growing in Himalayan foothills especially around Haldwani yielded an oil (4.5 per cent) which on GC âMS examination revealed the presence of 8 known compounds viz., 1,8-cineole (0.19 per cent), linalool (0.19 per cent), terpinolene (0.19 per cent), S224 â terpineol (0.09 per cent), eugenol methyl ether (1.61 per cent), S224 â asarone (1.17 per cent), Ã âasarone (92.68 per cent) and S226 âasarone (2.27 per cent), besides four unidentified sesquiterpene alcohols. The dried rhizome from Almora, Pithiragarh and Jogeshwar of Kumaun hills yielded 1.0 â 1.5 per cent of essential oil. GLC analysis of the essential oil obtained from the rhizome growing in three areas of lower hills of Uttar Pradesh ( now Uttaranchal) viz., Pithoragarh, Almora and Chamoli revealed the presence of asarone (76.29 per cent, 88.64 per cent and 78.44 per cent ), methyleugenol (0.69 per cent, 0.63 per cent and 1.19 per cent) and eugenyl acetate (2.29 per cent, 1.98 per cent and 2.27 per cent), respectively in the three oils. The yield and chemical constituents of the oil obtained from plants grown on normal soils. However, the concentration of asarone oil was slightly less in oil obtained from alkaline soils (Chowdhury et al., 1997). The oil obtained from the rhizome of the plant from Sikkim in a yield of 7-8 per cent contained 85 per cent of Ã âasarone. Other constituents identified in the rhizome were a new cylclobutanolignan acoradin, 2,4,5 â trimethoxybenzaldehyde, 2,5 â dimethoxybenzoquinone, galangin (5,7 â dihydroxyflavanol ) along with sitosterol; a new natural product acoramone along with other phenyl propane derivatives viz,. isoeugenol methyl ether, S226 âasarone, Ã â asarone , S224 âasarone and asarylaldehyde. Further , two new phenyl indanes viz., Z-3-(2,4,5-trimethoxyphenyl ) indane (Saxena, 1986) and two new triterpenoid saponins 1 Ã, 2 S224, 3Ã, 19S224-tetrahydroxyurs -12-en-28-oic acid -28-O-{Ã -D-glucopyranosyl (1-->2)} Ã -D-galactopyranoside and 3 Ã, 22 S224, 24, 29 â tetrahydroxyolean â 12 âen -3-O-{ Ã -D-arabinosyl (1-->3)}- Ã -D- arabinopyranoside were characterized in the ethanolic extract of the rhizome. The petroleum ether and benzene fractions of the rhizome were reported to yield thymol, cumin and phellandrene while the chloroform fraction yielded a triterpene alcohol and a triterpene acid. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the rhizome was found to be devoid of tannis. In another study, flavonoids, alkaloids and saponins along with tannins were found to be absent while glycosides, sterols and terpenoids were found to be present. The mineral elements in the plant were found to be cadmium, manganese, nickel and zinc were also found to be present.

author: (L.) Miq.
description: A small evergreen tree with pale smooth bark. Leaves 1-foliolate; leaflets 7.5-12.5 X 3-5 cm, oblong- lanceolate or some what obovate, shortly and obtusely acuminate, entire, shining above. Flowers fragrant, in paniculately corymbose cymes. Calyx small, ciliolate. Petals yellowish-white, strap shaped curcullate, inflexed at the apex. Stamens shorter than the petals; filaments hairy at the base; anthers versatile. Disk 8- ribbed. Capsules sub-globose, 3-5 celled, rough with immersed glands, tip angled or grooved.
pharmacology: A water soluble quaternary fraction isolated from the leaves on preliminary screening revealed CNS depressant activity viz., gross behavioural changes in rats, prolongation of pentobarbitone-induced hypnosis, reduction in the amphetamine-induced toxicity and prevention of harmine-induced tremors in mice and abolition of electrically-induced convulsions in rats (Chaurashi et al., 1976a,b). View Reference
chemical_composition: The petroleum ether extract of the stem bark yielded phenolic compound acronylin whose structure was established as 2- mehtoxy-3-isopentenyl -4, 6-dihydroxyacetiohenone (Biswas and Chatterjee, 1970). 6- Demethylacronylin was also isolated along with acronylin (Banerji et al., 1973). From the hexane extract of the bark acrovestone was isolated. The hexane extract of the wood yielded Ã sitosterol while that of the leaves yielded stigmasterol. The seeds contained traces of essential oil (Krishna and Badhwar, 1948).

author: (Koen.) Link.
pharmacology: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant in a preliminary biological screening was found to be devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, antifertility, hypoglycaemic, diuretic and antiinflammatory activities and effects on respiration, preganglionically stimulated nictitating membrane, CVS and CNS in experimental animals. The extract also did not show effect on isolated guinea pig ileum. The LDB1150B11 of the extract was found to be 750 mg/kg i.p. in mice (Dhawan et al., 1977). The methanolic extract of the plant was devoid of antibacterial activity against I11Bacillus subtilis, Bac cereus, Bac megaterium, Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Escherichia coliI11 (Kshirasagar and Mehta, 1972). View Reference
chemical_composition: Preliminary chemical studies revealed the absence of alkaloids in the plant (Kshirsagar and Mehta, 1972). The ethanolic extractive of the powdered sporophytes, however, showed the presence of quercetin â 3-rutinoside (rutin) (Bhambie et al., 1972). The stem and leaves contained hentriacontane, hentriacontanol, Ã-sitosterol palmitate, Ã- sitosterol, Ã- sitosterol â Ã-sitosterol â D-glucoside and an unidentified glucoside along with glucose and fructose (Taneja and Tiwari, 1974).

author: Medic.
description: A tall shrub, 1-3 m high with many long opposite ascending branches; stem with yellowish bark, terete, glabrous. Leaves 12-20 by 3.5-6.5 cm. elliptic-lanceolate, acuminate; main nerves 10-12 pairs with reticulate venation between; perioles 1.2-2.5 cm. long. Inflorescence axillary pedunculate spikes 2.5-7.5 cm long, towards the ends of the branches; peduncles 3.7-10 c,m, stout, shorter than the leaves; bracts reaching 2 by 1.2 cm., elliptic, 5-7 nerved. Calyx less than 2.2 cm long cylindric, the upper half much laterally inflated. Corolla white, with a few irregular rose-colored bars in the throat, 3 cm. long, pubescent outside; tube 1.2 cm. long, the lower half cylindric, .4 cm. in diam., the upper half much laterally inflated; upper lip 1.9 by 1.3 cm. long, ovate-oblong, curved, obruse, notched; lower lip as long as the upper, the lobes 1.3 cm. deep, oblong, rounded, the middle lobe the broadest. Stamens 2, filaments hairy at the base. long, stout, curved; lower anther-cells minutely apiculate at the base. Ovary pubescent; lower part of style pubescent. Fruit a capsule, 1.9-2.5 by .8 cm., clvate, subacute, shortly and bluntly pointed, pubescent; solid stalk flattened, 1 cm. long. Seeds .6 by .5 cm., orbicular-oblong, tubercular-verrucose, glabrous.
pharmacology: The uterotonic activity of vasicine was studied in detail both by in vitro and in vivo methods employing the uteri under different hormonal influences and of different species of animals. The effect was maximal in prooestrus and oestrus. The response was not appreciable in progesterone dominated uterus. Vasicine in 10 mg/kg i.p. dose in oestradiol-primed (50Âµg/kg i.m., 48h previously) guinea pigs showed an abortifacient effect in 90Â±10 per cent of animals during mid and late pregnancy. The abortifacient effect of vasicine like its uterotonic effect was more marked under the priming influence of oestrogens which are known to enhance the synthesis of PGs. Synthesized vasicine and vasicinone derivatives in in vitro studies were found to have oxytocic activity at the dose above 1Âµg/ml while none of them were found to show any bronchodilatory activity up to a dose of 3Âµg/ml. The aqueous solution of the leaves at the dose of 175 mg/kg bw revealed 100 per cent abortifacient activity when administered daily to Charles Foster strain of albino rats from 5-10 of post mating period. The petroleum ether extract of the leaves 50 mg/kg bw and i.v was given after atropinization in rabbits. The expectorant action of the petroleum ether extract was compared with that of ammonium chloride and eucalyptol. Of the three, only the petroleum ether extract showed any stimulation of respiratory tract fluid (RTF). The comparative increase in the production of RTF by two standard respiratory stimulants and âvasakaâ was found to be ammonium chloride (0.4g/kg bw) 47 per cent; eucalyptol (0.184 g/kg bw) 36 per cent and the petroleum ether extract 78.5 per cent, respectively. Vasicinone isolated from the leaves had a bronchodilator action on the normal lungs and powerful bronchodilator action against the histamine-induced bronchoconstriction in guinea pigâs lungs and tracheal chain, but its action was weaker than that of adrenaline.l-Vasicinone was, however, stronger in action than the dl-form. Vasicinone was found to have a potent bronchodilatory activity in both in vitro and in vivo studies. Vasicine showed bronchodilatory activity in both vivo and in vitro experimental studies, its activity being comparable to theophylline. The antitussive activity of the plant was evaluated in anaesthetized guinea pigs and rabbits and unanaesthetized guinea pigs. When administered intravenously, the extract was 1/20-1/40 as active as codeine on mechanically and electrically-induced coughing in rabbits and guinea pigs. On oral administration to guinea pigs, the antitussive activity of the extract was similar to codeine against coughing induced by irritant aerosols. The non-nitrogenous principle obtained from the leaves as a suspension administered orally (25mg/kg) to fasting male rabbits lowered the blood sugar of rabbits for a short period of two hours. The average fall over a period of four hour was 7.5 per cent which was far less than the fall due to similar dosage of tolbutamide. Repeated oral (2.5-3.0 mg/kg for 30d) and intramuscular administration (10-30 mg/kg for 15d) of vasicine hydrochloride resulted in a dose related increase in platelet count in normal rats, mice, rabbits and dogs while a single dose treatment had no response. This increase in platelets was also associated with significant hyperplasia of megakaryocytes in the bone marrow. No effects were observed on haemoglobin level and RBC or WBC counts and morphology. Bleeding and clotting times were not significantly altered nor was there any evidence of in vivo haemolysis. The alcoholic extract of the leaves did not show antitumour activity against various transplantable tumours. The activity of the leaves (alcoholic and chloroform extracts in the form of ointment) was studied for its wound healing effects in twelve, 12-18 months old buffalo calves. A significant increase (p>0.05) in rate of healing, breaking strength, tensile strength, energy absorption and extensibility was observed up to 30d. Collagen, elastin, hydroxyproline, hexosamine and zinc in biopsy specimens significantly increased from 3rd to 30th day. Vasicinol, an alkaloid extracted from the root of the plant produced transient hypotension in cats, contraction of isolated guinea pig intestine and depression of isolated guinea pig heart, all of which could be blocked by atropine which indicated its cholinergic nature, Vasakin, the non-nitrogenous principle obtained from the leaves, had a blocking effect on the exogenous acetylcholine and adrenaline and had a strong anesthetic activity. It inhibited salivary secretion induced by pilocarpine. It had no toxic effects at a dose up to 1g/kg and did not affect behaviour or motor activity in experimental animals. Detailed pharmacological studies were carried out with the alcoholic extract of the leaves. The extract produced fall in blood sugars levels in rats. It had no significant diuretic activity in rats. It enhanced the depth and rate of respiration in dogs and a dose dependent fall in carotid blood pressure. It produced a dose dependent myocardial depression in frog without affect in rectus muscle. It produced considerable relaxation of the isolated guinea pig tracheal chain. The extract had no analgesic or anticonvulsant activity in rats. The extract was not lethal up to the dose of 100 mg/kg i.p and up to 4g/kg p.o. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) in a preliminary biological screening showed antiinflammatory activity in rat. The alcoholic extracts of the leaves and root showed antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Escherichia coli.I11 The water extract of the leaves also showed activity against I11Staphylococcus aureus.I11 The oil obtained from the leaves, flowers and root possessed significant activity against tubercle bacilli. The active substance from the leaves inhibited the growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis BB1119-4B11 (human) at a concentration of 2Âµg/ml; that of 5Âµg/ml; while the growth of BB1119-1B11 (avian) strain was inhibited completely at concentration of 5Âµg/ml. The antitubercular activity of the active principle from the leaves was half of streptomycin. The 80 per cent ethanolic extract of the leaves using the agar dilution method revealed antibacterial activity against three strains of I11Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Bacillus subtilisI11 and I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 at a concentration of 25 mg/ml. The extract of the leaves showed 10-20 mm zone of inhibition against I11Staphylococcus citriI11 and different strains of I11Escherichia coliI11 in in-vitro studies. The aqueous extract of the leaves inhibited the spore germination of the pathogenic fungi I11Curvularia lunata, Cylindrocarpon lichenicola, Fusarium solaniI11 and I11Myrothecium leucotrichum.I11 The leaves also inhibited the mycelial inhibition of I11Epidermophyton floccosum, Trichophyton mentagrophytesI11 and I11Microsporum gypseum.I11 The extract of the plant inhibited the mycelial inhibition of keratinophillic fungi I11Microsporum gypseum, Chrysosporium tropicumI11 and I11Trichophyton terrestre.I11 The crude extract of the leaf, the bark and the plant showed 20-39.9 per cent inhibition of potato virus X and 85 per cent inhibition against bean common mosaic virus. The leaves (oil) as well as the alkaloids, vasicine and vasicinone were screened for anthelmintic activity against I11Ascaris lumbricoidesI11 neuromuscular preparations. The oil caused slight inhibition of the spontaneous movements, whereas the alkaloids, vasicine and vasicinone showed no effects. The powder of the leaves (1:100) was a non-poisonous indigenous insecticide and recommended for controlling the inspect pests of stored oil seeds. Different alkaloids from the plant were responsible for antifertility and antifeedant activity against insects. C11Clinical StudiesC11 Vasicine showed uterotonic activity on human myometrium strips which was in some cases more marked than that of two known oxytocics pitocin and methergin. On myometrial strips for non-pregnant uteri, pregnant uteri during first and second trimester of pregnancy and from full term pregnant uteri, vasicine either initiated rhythmic movements in the quiescent tissue or increased the tone or the amplitude of contractions, or both. The response of the uterus to drugs depended on its hormonal status. In an uncontrolled clinical trial 60 ml of a syrup (30 g of crude drug) was given daily in four divide doses for six weeks in 20 patients of âamlapittaâ. Clinical improvement along with reduction in gastric acidity was observed in 85 per cent of the patients. The syrup also decreased gastric acid secretion in albino rats. View Reference
chemical_composition: The leaves have been found to be a rich source of alkaloids of which vasicine and vasicinone are bioactive. A number of non- nitrogenous compounds have also been isolated. The chemical investigation of the leaves was taken ups as early as 1888 by Hooper who separated the volatile and non âvolatile fractions by steam distillation of the leaves of the plant. The non âvolatile fraction showed positive tests for alkaloids and behaved as an organic acid which was named as adhatodic acid. Later isolated a solid from the leaves of the plant named as vasicine which was basic in nature. It was found to possess a slight but potent bronchodilator activity. A new quaternary ammonium based from the leaves called vasicine which was basic in nature. It was found to be a betaine. Vasicine was shown to contain a 1:3 benzodiazine nucleus. Ghose et al., (1932) later revised the structure from different places which varied from 0.54-1.10 per cent. Besides this, other parameters were also determined. Another bronchodilator alkaloid vasicinone was later isolated from the leaves. It was identified as the autooxidation product of vasicine (Amin and Mehta, 1959. An analysis of the infected leaves of the plant by fungus I11ColletorichumI11 gloeoesporioides showed that vasicinone was lost in the leaves due to the infection, while the other constituents remained unaffected. Further, a non-nitrogenous neutral principle, vasakin; (+) âvasicinone; two new pyrroloquinazoline alkaloids, desmethoxyaniflorine and 7- mehtoxyvasicinone were identified from the ethanolic extract from the leaves. The leaves obtained from different markets in India gave very poor alkaloid yield ranging from 0.28 to 0.51 per cent which was far less than the average yield (1.474 per cent w/w) of alkaloids from the leaves of big leaf variety (BLV) of the plant. The order plant (9-10 year old) of BLV showed uniformly high concentration of alkaloids with much less variation. Thus, the BLV could be utilized as suitable germplasms for cultivation of this plant (Rajani and Paundarikaskshudu, 1996). Effects of a seasonal variation on the alkaloidal contents were studied in the leaves, The maximum alkaloidal content (2 per cent) was found to be in the months of August â October of which vasicine was about 95 per cent, deoxyvasicine (3 per cent) and traces of vasicinone. The total alkaloidal content decreased after October and reached a minimum level in March, when the total percentage was about .04 per cent to 0.6 per cent. The percentage vasicine in the total alkaloidal content decreased to 45 per cent after October while that of vasicinone reached a maximum in August â September when the plant was about to flower. During I11NI11- oxides and glycosides became significant (Pandita et al., 1983). Foliar spray of gibberellic acid at a concentration of 20 mg/l increased the total alkaloidal yield of leaves, root and stem by 85 per cent, 42 per cent and 64 per cent, respectively (Pundarikakshudu et al., 1986). The total alkaloids and vasicine contents were found to occur in higher amounts in the leaves from Varanasi than reported from the plant growing elsewhere in India. The percentage of total alkaloids and vasicine was higher in August (2.20 and 2.09, respectively) and low in February (0.70 and 0.35, respectively) whereas the percentage of minor alkaloids like vasicinol, vasicinone, deoxyvasicinone and deoxyvasicine was maximum in April (0.65) and minimum from June to September (0.0.9-0.11). Foliar spray of chloramphenicol at a concentration of 50 mg/l brought a 50 per cent increase in total alkaloids (vasicine) of the leaves of younger plants (8-12wk old). In older plants, treatment with 100 and 200 mg/l of chloramphenicol exerted a positive on alkaloid formation (Rajani and Bhavsar, 1993). A method to extract, isolate and purify the alkaloids vasicine and vasicinone from the plant. Which could give higher yields and reproducible results was designed based on chromatography and spectrophotometry techniques. A method to estimate vasicine in the leaves was developed. Using this technique, vasicine was estimated in two polyherbal drug formulations âshereeshadi kashayaâ and âyastyadivatiâ as well as the leaves and stem of the plant. In another study, a rapid and accurate method using HPLC was developed for detection, monitoring and quantification of vasicine in the plant as well as herbal preparations containing the plant. The method was reported to be precise (Narayana et al., 1995). The compatability of vasicinone hydrochloride with various excipients was investigated as prerequisite to its formulation. No incompatibility was detected with the excipients like acacia, lactose, starch, gelatin and also with theobroma oil, a common suppository base. The drug showed slow degradation under humid conditions which increased with rise in temperature (Bhalla, 1981a). Useful leads for formulation of drug in oral and parenteral dosage forms were provided (Bhalla, 1982a, b). Preformulation stability studies were also carried out to reveal that vasicine stearate was found to be most stable at pH 3.8 (Gupta et al., 1984, 1985a, b). Synthesis of analogues of vasicine, vasicinone and deoxyvasicinone were reported. The structure of vasicinol isolated from the root was established as 6-hydroxypeganine. The mass fragmentation of the alkaloids vasicine, vasicinol as well as its methyl ether was also studied (Bhatnagar and Popli, 1966). The other alkaloids isolated were 9- acetamido-3,4-dihyropyrido-(3,4-b)-indole, I11OI11-ethyl- S224 âD-galactoside, 1,2,3,9- tetrahydropyrrolo (2,1-b) quinazolin-9 (1H)-one, sitosterol Ã-D-glucoside, D-galactose and deoxyvasicinone (Jain et al., 1980); vasicol (1,2,3,4,9,11-hexahydropyrrolo(2,1-b) quinazolin-3, 11-diol), vasicinone, adhatonine and vasicinolone (Dhar et al., 1981). Vasicinolone was reported as the oxidative product of vasicinol (Jain and Sharma, 1982). The total and reducing sugars present in the root and the bark were also estimated. The different parts of the plant viz., leaves, root and seeds comprised 0.22, 0.14 and 0.25 per cent, respectively, of alkaloids. The root showed the presence of saponins, while the leaves had alkaloids and glycosides. The stem was devoid of all the three. Presence of steroids/terpenoids, alkaloids and tannins, and absence of flavonoids, phenolics and saponins were reported. In another study, the leaves of the plant were reported to contain alkaloids and steroids while flavonoids, glycosides, saponins and terpenoids were reported as sugars and reducing sugars. The leaves had good amounts of raffinose and glucose, while the root had xylose. Besides sugars, vitamin B and C were found in the leaves and root, while the bark contained only vitamin C. The chemical constituents of the plant have been reviewed (Bhat et al., 1978; Suresh Kumar et al., 1981; Jain et al., 1984), The flavonoids in the leaves were identified as kaempferol, quercetin, vitexin and isovitexin while the phenolic acids were I11pI11-hydroxybenzoic acid, syringic acid andcoumaric acid. The leaves were found to contain free vitamin C and carotene. Both leaves and flowers contained the flavone, luteolin. The mineral elements of the leaves were identified as calcium, magnesium, potassium, sodium and iron. The ethanolic extract of the aerial parts yielded two aliphatic hydroxyketones identified as 37-hydroxyhexatetracont -1-en-15-one and 37-hydroxyhentetracontan -19-one, while the petroleum ether extract yielded an aliphatic alcohol characterized as 29-methyltriacontan -l-0l. The stalk, which is non-woody, was found to contain the Klason and Willslatter lignins composed of guaiacyl-, syringyl- and p-hydroxyphenyl propane building units similar to the hardwood lignins. The petroleum ether extract of the flowers contained a number of non-nitrogenous compounds viz., triatricontane, Ã-sitosterol, S224 -amyrin and Ã âsitosterol âD- glucoside; the ether extract yielded kaempferol and quercetin; the ethyl acetate and I11NI11-butanol extracts afforded kaempferol-3- Ã-D-glucoside and kaempferol -3-sophoroside. The young inflorescence yielded (Â±) vasicinone (Choudhury, 1979). Flowers in addition yielded a fat containing traces of tridecanoic and pentadecanoic acids and a new glucoside identified as 2â, 4-dihroxychalcone 4-glucoside. The fixed oil obtained from the seeds contained arachidic (3.1 per cent), behenic (11.2 per cent), lignoceric (10.7 per cent), cerotic (5.0 per cent), oleic (49.9 per cent) and linoleic (12.3 per cent) acids. The unsaponifiable matter yielded Ã-sitosterol. The fatty acid composition (wt per cent) of the seed and flower fats, as determined by gas chromatography was lauric (nil, 1.121), myristic (nil, 2.37), palmitic (4.25, 27.13), heptadecanoic (nil, 2.50), oleic (49.28, 16.58), linoleic (21.53, 13.13), linolenic (1.34, 5.53), arachidic (10.59, 8.56, nil) acids respectively. The only alkaloids found in the defatted seeds and flowers were vasicine, vasicinone and vasicinol (Kapoor et al., 1981).

author: (Roxb.) Hook. f. ex Brandis.
description: A large decidous trees with erect trunk and horizontal branches. Bark brownish-grey, thick, furrowed, young parts fubescent. Leaves 10-25 cm long, broadly ovate-orbicular, cordate at base, subacute or acuminate, glabrescent above and densely pubescent beneath; main nerves 5-7 pairs; petioles 5-10 cm long, softly pubescent; stipules oblong, obtuse, pubescent, 1.25-2 cm long. Flowers numerous in globose heads 2-2.5 cm in diam.; peduncles 2.5-5 cm long, stout, axillary, 1-3 together, each bearing 1 (rarely2) heads of yellow flowers. Calyx 0.25 cm long, hairy; lobes 5, club-shaped. Corolla 0.6 cm long; tube elongate, funnel shaped, segments 5, valvate. Stamens 5, inserted in the mouth of the corolla. Disk cup-shaped. Ovary 2-celled; ovules numerous; style much exserted. Capsule .3-.4 cm long, cuneate, densely downy, of 2 dehiscent cocci, seeds about 6 in each cell.

author: (L.) Correa
description: A small tree, armed with strong straight spines 1.25 to 2.5 cm long. Leaves 3-foliolate, leaflets lanceolate or elliptic-lanceolate, acuminate at apex. 3.75-7.5 x 2-3.75 cm, glabrous, the lateral leaflets subsessile, the terminal leaflet long petioled, gland-dotted. Inflorescence an axillary panicle. Flowers greenish-white or yellow, fragrant. Calyx small 4-lobed. Petals 4, 1.25 cm long, free. Stamens numerous, filaments subulate, glabrous free or sub-fascicled. Style short, stigma capitate or fusiform. Ovary 2-celled; cless many-ovuled. Fruit a berry 5-12.5 cm in diameter, globose; rind grey or yellowish; pulp sweet, thick, orange colored. Seeds oblong, compressed.
pharmacology: Notable pharmacological actions were antimicrobial, antigastric ulcer, antidiabetic and antiinflammatory activities. The aqueous extract of the leaves and the alcoholic extract of the fruits at a dose of 500 mg/kg fed orally to normal as well as diabetic rabbits significantly lowered the fasting glucose level (p<0.001) in normal rabbits, while in diabetic rabbits the reduction was insignificant (p>0.05). The extract of the fresh tender leaves in water or milk or juice of I11Benincasa ceriferaI11 or âkashayamâ at a dose of 8 ml/kg administered orally for 3 months showed hypoglycaemic action both normal as well as streptozotocin-induced diabetes in rabbits. The antidiabetic effect of alkaloidal extract of the leaves was studied in alloxan-induced diabetic rats. The aqueous extract of the leaves revealed both hypoglycaemic and antihyperglycaemic effects in normal and alloxanized rabbits. The crude leaf extract administered orally to streptozotocin-diabetic rats at a dose of 1 g/kg bw at 24 interval for a period of 2 wk was found to be as effective as insulin in restoring blood glucose and body weight to normal levels. The organic (250 mg dried ethanolic extract per kg bw) and the inorganic parts (90 mg pure ash.kg bw) of the leaves revealed hypoglycaemic activity in a single dose effect on the oral glucose tolerance test (GTT) in fasting albino rats. Marmin, a coumarin isolated from ethanolic extract of the roots showed antiinflammatory effect (62.5 per cent) in carrageenin-induced inflammation in rats at a dose of 1g/kg p.o. In another study, the aqueous extract of the root (5 mg/100g bw i.p. once daily) revealed significant acute as well as chronic antiinflammatory activity in carrageenin-induced rat paw oedema (p>0.01) as evidenced by decrease in granuloma weight. The ethanolic extracts of the leaves (25 and 50 mg/kg bw) when administered orally for 30d in albino rats showed a significant decrease in the weight of the testes (p<0.01 and p<0.001 for the two doses), respectively and the accessory sex organs, reduced sperm count, decreased sperm mortality and both protein and RNA contents of the testes in a dose dependent manner indicating antispermatogenic activity of the plant. The aqueous extract of the leaves revealed cardiac stimulant, smooth muscle relaxant and uterine stimulant properties while the alcoholic extract showed cardiac depressant, smooth muscle relaxant and uterine relaxant properties. âDashmula kvathaâ, an Ayurvedic formulation consisting if A. marmelos besides nine other constituents viz., I11Premna integrifolia, Oroxylum indicum, Stereospermum suaveolens, Gmelina arborea, Desmodium gangeticum, Uraria picta, Solanum indicum, S. xanthocarpumI11 and I11Tribulus terrestrisI11 produced aspirin like analgesic effect in rats. This was supported by a significant antipyretic effect and mild antiinflammatory effect in rats against carrageenin-induced oedema. Further, the âkvathaâ produced CNS depressant effect. In a preliminary survey of antibacterial substances, the alcoholic and aqueous extract of the leaves showed in vitro antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Escherichia coliI11, the alcoholic extract of the root and the aqueous extract of the fruits were found to be active against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 only. The essential oil exhibited antibacterial activity against I11Pseudomonas solanacearumI11 and I11Xanthomonas vesicatoriaI11. The oil obtained from the leaves revealed 20 and 24 per cent antibacterial activity against I11Aeromonas spI11. and I11Escherichia coli,I11 respectively. The aqueous extract of the leaves showed in vitro fungicidal action against I11Pestalotiopsis mangiferaeI11 causing leaf spot of I11Mangifera indicaI11. The methanol extract of the leaves inhibited the mycelial growth and sclerotium formation of the plant fungi I11Sclerotium rolfsiiI11 at five different concentrations. The leaf extract, however, inhibited the growth of I11Colletotrichum falcatumI11 (68.9 per cent), Rhizoctonia solani (92.4 per cent) and Fusarium oxysporum sp. lentis (90.2 per cent). The essential oil obtained from the leaves exhibited significant antifungal activity against I11Aspergillus niger, A. flavus, Microsporum gypseum, Trichophyton rubrum, Histoplasma capsulatum,I11 and I11Microsporum cookeiI11. The oil was less active against I11Nocardia brasiliensis, Phialaphora verrucosaI11 and I11Candida albicansI11 while exhibited no activity against I11Epidermophyton floccosum.I11 The essential oil obtained from the leaves inhibited ringworm fungi I11Trichophyton mentagrophytes, Microsporum audouinii, M. gypseumI11 and I11Epidermophyton floccosum.I11 The oil obtained from the leaves also inhibited the spore germination of eight plant fungi I11Alternaria alternata, A. brassicae, A. carthami, Colletotrichum capsici, Curvularia lunata, Fusarium oxysporum, F. udumI11 and I11Ustilago cynodontisI11 in a concentration of 500 ppm. The unsaponifiable matter of the seed exhibited considerable in vitro antimicrobial against various bacteria viz., I11Escherichia coli, Salmonella typhi, Salm paratyphi, Proteus vulgaris, Streptococcus faecalis, Vibrio cholerae, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Pseudomonas aeruginosaI11 and I11Neisseria gonorrhoeaeI11 and various fungi viz., I11Trichophyton rubrum, T. terrestre Epidermophyton floccosum, Aspergillus fumigatus, A. flavus, Penicillium italicumI11 and I11P. expansumI11 at different dilutions. The unsaponifiable matter was found to be more active than pure seed oil sample against all the test organisms. The ethyl acetate extract of the plant exhibited antibacterial activity against I11Vibrio cholerae, Salmonella typhimurium, Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas putidaI11 and I11Bacillus anthracisI11 and antifungal activity against I11Curvularia lunata, Aspergillus nigerI11 and I11Rhizopus nodulans.I11 The ethanolic extract of the root showed antimicrobial activity against I11Vibrio cholerae, Salmonella typhimurium, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Candida albicans, Aspergillus fumigatusI11 and I11Trichophyton mentagrophytesI11 (Pitre and Srivastava, 1987). The 80 per cent ethanolic extract of the root revealed antibacterial activity against strains of I11Escherichia coliI11 and I11Pseudomonas aeruginosaI11 at a concentration of 12.5 mg/ml and against I11Bacillus subtilisI11 and I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 at a concentration of 6.25 mg/ml using the agar dilution method, The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the fruits showed antiviral activity against Ranikhet disease virus. The extract of the bark showed antiviral activity against potato virus X (Singh and Singh, 1972) while that of the fruits exhibited interferon-like antiviral activity against Ranikhet disease virus but not against vaccinia virus. The essential oil obtained from the leaves revealed antiviral activity against tobacco mosaic virus. The unsaponifiable matter of the seed exhibited anthelmintic activity against tapeworms and earthworms. C11Clinical Studies C11 If an uncontrolled clinical trial, the leaves of the plant were macerated and given orally followed by powdered black pepper on empty stomach to 8 patients with diabetes mellitus for 15d. A significant diminution in the blood cholesterol levels with slight lowering of blood glucose levels in all patients were reported. All the patients also had a sense of well being during treatment. The efficacy of the fruits for the treatment of dysentery was tested in 25 patients. The patients were given powdered unripe fruits (5g thrice daily for 21d). Out of 25 patients, 52 per cent were completely cured, 44 per cent improved and 4 per cent remained unaffected. Its use in dysentery might be due to the presence of large amount of tannins. Fruit pulp powder was found effective on intestinal parasites particularly on ankylostoma. The drug controlled loose and irregular motion and pain in abdomen. The alkaloid, aegeline present in leaves was found efficacious in asthma. View Reference
chemical_composition: Preliminary chemical studies of the petroleum ether extract of the unripe fruits revealed the presence of marmelosin. The fruit pulp contained alloimperatorin, Ã-sitosterol and imperatorin âchemically S226, S226 -dimethylallyloxyfurocoumarin (Saha and Chatterjee, 1957). Further, a new coumarin marmelide along with xanthotaxol, Ã-sitosterol â Ã-D-glucoside, scoparone, scopoletin, umbelliferone, marmesin and skimmin (Sharma et al., 1980) The leaves yielded an alkaloid, rutacin and sterol, aegeline (Chatterjee and Bose, 1952). Aegelin, in later studies, was shown to be a neutral alkaloid and not a sterol and was characterized as (Â±)-trans-N-[Ã-hydroxy- Ã-(p-methoxyphenyl)] ethylcinnamide. Its stereochemistry and synthesis were studied in detail (Chakarvarti and Dasgupta, 1955,1956a,b). Aegelenine, another minor alkaloid was isolated from the leaves. On chemical studies aegelenine was found to be identical with halfordinol, the basic constituent of I11Halfordia scleroxylaI11. The leaves were also found to contain S226 -sitosterol (Chakarvarti and Dasgupta, 1956c). The leaves were also found to contain Ã-sitosterol- Ã-D-glucoside, marmesinin and rutin (Sharma et al., 1980); lupeol and sitosterol; condensed tannins, phlobatannis, flavon-3-ols, leucoanthocyanins, anthocyanins and flavonoids glycosides. Very young leaves contained highest concentration of tannins (8.1 per cent) where as fully ripe fruit contained only 1.5 per cent (Bajaj et al., 1975). The average tannin content in the leaves was found to be 1.21 g/100g dry matter basis. The constituents, especially alkaloids and coumarins of the bark, varied considerably with the maturity of the tree. Whereas the young bark contained umbelliferone, the old or mature bark contained in addition to umbelliferone, a different coumarin and other constituents like S226 -fagarine, marmesin, aurepten(e) and lupeol. Marmin, a new coumarin isolated from the trunk bark was initially suggested as 7-(3,7-dihdroxy-3,7-dimethyloctyloxy) coumarin, subsequently its chemical structure was revised to 7-(6â,7â-dihydroxy-3â,7â-dimethyloct-2-enyloxy) coumarin. It was also reported that with maturity of the bark the yields of Marmin and skimmianine decreased and contents of marmesin, S226-fagarine and essential oil increased. The ether extract of the immature bark contained umbelliferone, an alkaloid, skimmianine (4,7,8-trimethoxyfuroquinoline), Marmin and S226-sitosterol. The stem bark contained two new compounds marmesin-1ââ-S224-L-rhamnopyranoside and 1,5-dihydroxy-6-methoxy-2-methylanthraquinone together with lupeol and Ã-sitosterol. It also contained 5.52 per cent of tannins and 6.36 per cent of non tannins. The root was reported to contain lupeol, skimmianine and three benzo-(a)-pyrone derivatives viz., auraptene, marmin and umbelliferone. This was the first report of occurrence auraptene in this plant. In another study, different extracts of the root afforded the coumarins and the alkaloids viz., psoralen, xanthotoxin, 6,7-umbelliferone,marmesin, marmin and skimmianine. The root bark contained the coumarin, decursinol and an alkaloid haplopine while both root and the stem bark contained aegelinol (3â-epimer of decursinol). The leaves yielded 0.6 per cent of an essential oil which contained (+)-S224-phellandrene (56 per cent) as the major constituent besides cineol, citronellal, citral, I11pI11-cymene (17 per cent) and cumin aldehyde (5 per cent). The essential oils from the twigs and the fruits of the plant contained, (+)-S224-phellandrene; the oil from twigs also contained cineol while it was found absent in fruit oil (Baslas and Deshpande, 1949). The essential oil from the leaves growing in the Tarai region of Nainital contained S224-phellandrene (20 per cent), I11pI11-cymene (11.5 per cent), cineol (2.5 per cent), (+)-limonene (10 per cent), ethyl I11nI11-amyl ketone (5.25 per cent), methyl âI11nI11-heptyl ketone (3.75 per cent), citronella (10 per cent), linalool (3.75 per cent), citral (5 per cent), eugenol (6 per cent), methyl eugenol (trace), caryophyllene (7.5 per cent) and cuminyl alcohol (3.5 per cent). The physico-chemical constants were also determined (Bhandari and Gupta, 1972). The oil obtained from the leaves from Lucknow was found to contain myrcene (54.03 per cent, Ã-caryophyllene (6.17 per cent), S224-humulene (4.97 per cent), S226-terpinene (4.40 per cent), limonene (4.20 per cent), sabinene (3.40 per cent), myrtenol (2.67 per cent), (Z) - Ã-ocimene (2.30 per cent) besides other minor constituents S224-and Ã-pinene, I11pI11-menth-4(8)-en-l-ol-,8-triene, linalool, piperitone, terpinen-4-ol, piperitol, trans-carveol, p-menth-4(8)-en-l-ol, I11cisI11-carveol, sabinol, myrtenyl acetate, I11pI11-menth-l-en-3Ã, 5Ã-diol, S224-elemene, ar-curcumene and caryophyllene oxide. ?-Phellandrene reported earlier could not be detected even as a trace constituent. New naturally occurring alkaloids characterized as O-methylhalfordinol were isolated from the ripe fruits. Alloimperatorin methyl ether, hitherto unknown in the genus I11AegleI11 and I11OI11 âisopentenylhalfordinol earlier detected in the leaves were also obtained from the fruits. The unripe fruits contained marmeline identified as N-2-hydroxy-2[4-(3â, 3â dimethylallyloxy) phenyl] ethylcinnamide along with aegeline, imperatorin, alloimperatorin and xanthotaxol. Further eight new alkaloids, viz.,O-(3â,3â-dimethylallyl)- halfordinol; N-2-ethoxy-2-(4-methoxyphenyl) ethylcinnamamide; N-2-methoxy-2-[4-(3â,3â-dimethylallyloxyl)phenyl]ethylcinnamamide; N-2-methoxy-2-(4-methoxyphenyl) ethylcinnamide; N-2-[4-3â,3â-dimethylallyloxy) phenyl] ethylcinnamide; N-2 hydroxy-2-(4-(3â,3â-dimethylallyloxy)phenyl] ethylcinnamide. N-4-methoxystylcinnamide and N-2-hydroxy -2-(4-hydroxyphenyl) ethylcinnamide were isolated from the leaves. Their structure were also confirmed by synthesis (Manandhar et al., 1978; Govindachari and Premila, 1983). The heartwood contained a furoquinoline alkaloid, dictamnine; a dihydrofurocoumarin, marmesin; Ã-sitosterol; 2-(2-hydroxy-4-methoxyphenyl)vinyl acetate, xanthotaxol-8-O- Ã-D-glucopyranoside, lupeol (Jain et al., 1991); two new anthraquinones, 7,8-dimethoxy-1-hydroxy02-methylanthraquinone and 6-hydroxy-1-methoxy-3-methylanthraquinone along with marmin and xanthotaxol.

author: L.
description: A much branded annual herb to 1m high, woody at base. Leaves imparipinnate; studded with minute glandular excrescences. Leaflets alternate, 21-71, sub-sessile, linear-oblong. Inflorescence an axillary raceme; 1-4 flowered. Calyx 2-lipped; upper lip bifid; lower lip minutely 3- toothed. Corolla yellow; standard veined with purple. Stamens in bundles of 5 each; anthers uniform. Ovary stalked. Style incurved; stigma terminal. Pods jointed; joints 6-10, easily separable.
pharmacology: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract, in a concentration of 2 per cent also showed in vitro spermicidal activity against both rat and human spermatozoa (Setty et al., 1976, 1977; Dhawan et al., 1977). The leaves of the plant showed cholinesterase activity in in vivo test (Gupta and Gupta, 1977). The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant in a preliminary biological screening revealed gross behavioural effects and potentiated barbiturate-induced hypnosis in mice. The extract was devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, hypoglycaemic, anticancer, diuretic and antiinflammatory activities and effects on isolated guinea pig ileum, respiration, CVS and preganglionically stimulated nictitating membrane in experimental animals, The LDB1150B11 of the extract was 45 mg/kg i.p. in mice (Dhawan et al., 1977).
