author: L.
description: Errect annual herbs, stem erect, branched, terete, more or less hairy. Leaves opposite or alternate. 5-7.5 x 2.5-5 cm. broadly ovate, subacute, crenate and with ciliate margins, more or less hairy on both sides, base cuneate; perioles 2.5-3 cm long, hairy. Inflorescence a head; heads homogamous, in dense terminal corymbs. Involucral-bracts linear, very acute, ribbed on the back, ciliolate and with scabrous margins. Flowers pale-blue or white. Involucral bracts linear, ribbed on the back. Corolla all tubular. Anthers appendiculate at the apex, obtuse at the base. Pappus of 5 scales, aristate, dilated at base. Achenes linear, .2-.25 cm long, 4-gonous, slightly curved.
pharmacology: The plant was reported to have significant antifungal and insecticidal properties. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant in a preliminary biological screening was found to be devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, antiprotozoal, antiviral, hypoglycaemic, anticancer and diuretic activities. The extract also had no effects on isolated guinea pig ileum, respiration, CVS and CNS in experimental animals. The LDB1150B11 of the extract was found to be >1000 mg/kg i.p. in mice. The water soluble portion of the alcoholic extract of the plant potentiated pentobarbitone-induced hypnosis in mice in a dose of 1g/kg. It produced hypotensive response in dog. The extract revealed negative inotropic and chronotropic effects in doses of 10-40 mg on frogâs perfused heart which was not blocked by atropine. The extract had no analgesic and anticonvulsant activity. The essential oil in a concentration of 0.1 ml/ml caused contraction of the isolated frog rectus abdominis within 15 sec after administration. The ethanolic extracts of the root of plant in a dose of 100 and 300 mg/kg significantly reduced the carrageenin-induced hind paw oedema in rats. The extract was devoid of any appreciable activity on CNS in rats. The extract had no acute toxic effect in mice. The essential oil obtained from the plant showed antibacterial activity against I11Vibrio cholerae ogawa, Shigella shigae, Streptococcus pyogenes, Corynebacterium diphtheriaeI11 and I11Salmonella typhi, I11 while it was devoid of any activity against the potato pathogenic bacteria viz., I11Bacillus polymexa, Erwinia carotovora var. atroseptica, E. carotovora var. carotovora, Pseudomonas putida, Ps solanacearumI11 and I11Xanthomonas vesicatoria. I11 The essential oil of the plant showed antifungal activity against I11Helminthosporium turcicum, H. oryzae, Colletotrichum capsici, Pyricularia setariaeI11 and I11Fusarium moniliforme.I11 At a concentration of 2000 ppm, the essential oil exhibited strong antifungal activity against I11Epidermophyton floccosum, Microsporum canisI11 and I11Trichophyton mentagrophytes.I11 The antifungal principle was identified as demethoxyageratochromene. The leaf extract was found to be active against I11Colletotrichum falcatumI11 and I11Rhizoctonia solani.I11 The essential oil of the plant exhibited anthelmintic activity against I11Taenia soliumI11 and I11Pheretima posthuma.I11 The extract of the plant possessed insecticidal activity against I11Musca domesticaI11 (35 per cent) and I11Tribolium castaneumI11 (40 per cent). The methanolic extract of the plant in a concentration of 200-300 ppm was found to suppress the population of the malaria vector I11Anopheles stephensiI11 in higher dosage, while in lower dosage it was found to induce several developmental defects and ultimately decrease the growth index to a considerable extent. The petroleum ether extract of the leaves, flowers and buds diluted in benzene and mixed with green gram seeds at 0.5, 1.0 and 1.5 parts per 100 parts of the seeds (w/w) proved very repulsive, a potent oviposition inhibitor and a safe protectant against the infestation of pulse beetle I11Callosobruchus chinensisI11. View Reference
chemical_composition: The essential oil obtained from the plant was found to contain two new compounds identified as 7-mehtoxy-2,2-dimethylchromene and 6,7,6â7â-tetramethoxy-2,2,2â2â-tetramethyl-3â,(4â)-dehydro-3â-4S-bichroman (Kasturi et al., 1973). The fresh flowers on water distillation gave an oil in 0.2 per cent yield which was found to consist of four major and several trace constituents. These were identified as S226 -cadinene, caryophyllene, demethoxyageratochromene and ageratochromene (Sood, 1973). The oil from the flowers and leaves obtained from Indore showed the presence of S224-pinene, S226-cadinene, Ã-caryophyllene, 7-methoxy-2,2-dimethylageratochromene (60.0 per cent), 6,7-dimethoxy-2,2-dimethylageratochromene and eugenol (Sharma et al., 1980a). The hexane extract of the plant yielded a coumarin. The ethanolic extract of the plant was found to be devoid of tannins. The shoot contained saponins, flavonoids and alkaloids. The plant on extraction with ethanol, led to the isolation of twelve polyoxygenated flavones three of which were new ones, namely ageconyflavone A (5,6,7-trimethoxy-3â,4â-methylenedioxyflavone), ageconyflavone B(5,6,7,3â-tetramethoxy-4â-hydroxyflavone) and ageconyflavone C 5,6,7,3â,5â-pentamethoxy-4â-hydroxyflavone). The other nine flavonoids were identified as lindereroflavone B; eupalestin; nobiletin; 5â-methoxynobiletin; 5,6,7,5â-tetramethoxy-3â,4â-methylenedixyflavone; sinensetin; 5,6,7,3â,4â,5â-hexamethoxyflavone; 5,6,7,8,3â-pentamethoxy-4âhydroxyflavone and 5,6,7,8,3â,5â-hexamethoxy-4â-hydroxyflavone. Eupalestin was earlier reported to occur in the plant. The essential oil (0.14 per cent) obtained from the leaves and twigs from Imphal contained high amount of precocene I (leaves 23.3 per cent and flowers 25 per cent). The root oil, however, was found to contain precocene II and caryophyllene (Borthakur et al., 1987). The ethanolic extract of the leaves of the plant from South India (Tirupathi) was found to contain stigmast-7-en-3-ol in addition to quercetin, kaempferol, fumaric and caffeic acids (Nair et al., 1977). The petroleum ether extract of the leaves from Nainital (Uttaranchal) on GLC analysis revealed the following composition of sterols: Ã-sitosterol (26.7 per cent), stigmasterol (59.9 per cent), dihydrospinasterol (5.7 per cent), spinasterol (5.2 per cent), dihydrobrassicasterol (2.7 per cent) and brassicasterol (0.3 per cent) (Dubey et al., 1989). The seed oil was reported to contain palmitic, stearic, oleic, linoleic, linolenic and hexadecenoic acids.

author: Hiern.
description: Trees reaching 15 m height; young branches, petiolules and inflorescence covered with minute brown deciduous scales. Leaves altenate, imparipinnate, leaflets opposite, elliptic-oblong or obovate, usually shortly acuminate, upper surface glabrous, the lower and the nerves more or less lepidote. pharmacology: The ethanolic extract of the root possessed pronounced antiimplantation activity in female rats in the doses of 400 and 500 mg/kg as detected on the 10th day by laparotomy. The extract was also found to possess abortifacient activity in rats at the same dose levels, when administered on day 14th, 15th and 16th of pregnancy, as was evident from a second laparotomy performed on day 18th. The fruits exhibited mild hypoglycaemic activity in glucose-induced hyperglycaemia in rabbits. The essential oil from the root bark (2.5 and 5 ml/kg as an emulsion in 4 per cent gum acacia) administered i.p. showed CNS depressant action in mice as revealed by tests, e.g. pento-barbitone-induced hypnosis, motor coordination and spontaneous activity. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) in a preliminary biological screening revealed anticancer activity against PB11388B11 lymphocytic leukaemia in mice. The essential oil from the seeds in pure form as well as in various dilutions was tested for its in vitro antibacterial and antifungal activities, using penicillin and griseofulvin as standard drugs. The maximum antibacterial activity was observed against I11Staphylococcus citreusI11 and the least activity against I11Salmonella typhiI11. Mild to moderate activity was observed against I11Alkaligenes faecalis, Bacillus subtilis, Diplococcus pneumoniae, Pseudomonas pyocyanea, Staphylococcus aureus, Staph albus, Staph roseus, Streptococcus pyogenesI11 and I11Salmonella paratyphi.I11 The maximum antifungal activity was seen against I11Rhizopus oryzae, Penicillium liliacinumI11 and I11Aspergillus cervinusI11 in descending order, the activity against I11Malbranchea pulchellaI11 being least. The extracts also showed varying degree of activity against I11Aspergillus fumigatus, A. niger, Saccharomyces carlsbergensis, Candida tropicalisI11 and I11Microsporum gypseum.I11 The essential oil from the seeds was tested for its in vitro anthelmintic activity against tapeworm I11Taenia solium,I11 hook worm I11Bunostomum trigonocephalum,I11 nodular worm I11Oesophagostomum columbianumI11 and earthworm I11Pheretima posthuma.I11 The in vitro anthelmintic activity of the essential oil against tapeworms and hookworms was found to be higher than the standards, piperazine phosphate and hexylresorcinol, respectively. The oil was less active against nodular worms and earthworms compared to reference standard drugs. View Reference

author: (Roxb.) Boiv.
description: A small, much branched, unarmed tree. Young shoots clothed with yellowish-grey pubescence. Leaves abruptly 2 pinnate; main rachis densely pubescent, with a small gland about the middle of the petiole and another between the uppermost pair of pinnae; pinnae 6-15 pairs; leaflets 10-30 pairs, sessile, linear-oblong, obtuse or subacute, green and glabrous above, glaucous and more or less pubescent beneath. Flowers in globose heads; 12-20 flowers in each head. Peduncles solitary or in panicle. Calyx funnel-shaped, pubescent; teeth short. Corolla yellow, pubescent outside; lobes linear lanceolate. Stamens indefinite, monadelphous at the base, filaments pinkish, anthers minute. Ovary sessile or shortly stalked; style filiform; stigma minute, capitate. Fruit a pod. Pod stalked, thin, flat, abruptly pointed. Seeds 6-8.
pharmacology: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) in a preliminary biological screening revealed antispasmodic activity in guinea pig ileum. The extract was devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, hypoglycaemic and diuretic activities and effects on respiration, CVS and CNS in experimental animals. The LDB1150B11 of the extract was found to be 750 mg/kg i.p. in mice (Dhar et al., 1974). The alcoholic extract of the seeds showed antibacterial activity against I11Bacillus anthracis, Bac pumilus, Salmonella paratyphi, Staphylococcus albus, Xanthomonas campestrisI11 and I11Xanth malvacearumI11. The other extracts were less active against the bacteria tested (Bhatt and Saxena, 1981). The toxic effect of the oil investigated in guinea pigs revealed that doses up to 15 ml/kg bw did not cause any mortality in 72h (Chandra et al., 1956). View Reference

The bark in a preliminary chemical study was found to contain alkaloids, traces of saponins, while it was devoid of tannins. From the heartwood, two phenolic compounds, (-)-2, 3-cis-3,4-cis-3- I11OI11-methylmelacacidin as its methyl ether and 3â- I11OI11-methylmelanoxetin in addition to melacacidin and melanoxetin were isolated (Deshpande and Shastri, 1977). The fixed oil from the seeds contained myristic, palmitic, stearic, arachidic, behenic, lignoceric, oleic and linoleic acids. The unsaponifiable fraction contained Ã-sitosterol (Chandra et al., 1956).

author: (L.) Burm. f.
description: Perenial scapigerous herbs or undershrubs. Leaves, thick, fleshy, radical, ensiform in rosette with distant horny prickles in the margins. Scape 2-3 ft long, simple or branched. Inflorescence a dense raceme, 15-30 cm long. Perianth yellow or orange-red, cylindric. Filaments shortly exserted.
pharmacology: The polysaccharide (SB113B11) isolated from the juice of the leaves at a dose of 25 and 50 mg/kg administered orally revealed antiinflammatory activity in rats. The fresh juice of the leaves (0.2 ml/100 g i.p.) was studied for its antiinflammatory and wound healing in rats. Antiinflammatory activity was studied using carrageenin-induced paw edema method. Wound healing effects were studied on incision (skin breaking strength), excision (per cent wound contraction and epithelisation time) and dead space (granuloma breakings strength and biochemical parameters) wound models. The juice exhibited significant antiinflammatory activity (65 per cent) in acute inflammatory model with no significant effect on chronic inflammation. Influence of the leaf gel on the collagen content and its characteristics in healing dermal wounds was studied. It was observed that the gel increased the collagen content of the granulation tissue as well as its degree of crosslinking as observed by increased aldehyde content and decreased acid solubility. The gel obtained from the leaves administered twice a day either orally or applied topically was found to have a positive influence on the synthesis of glycosaminoglycan (GAG) components in the matrix of healing dermal wounds in rats. Preliminary screening revealed different extracts of the leaves and other parts of the plant to exhibit antifertility activity in various experimental studies. The aqueous extract of the leaves showed antifertility activity in mice and rats. The leaves revealed very little oxytocic activity in guinea pigs. The juice of the leaves at a dose of 150mg/100 g bw has oestrogenic activity in female albino rats as revealed by its effect on vaginal openings of immature rats, vaginal cornification and weight of uterus. The aqueous extract of the pulp obtained from the leaves at a dose of 200 mg/kg orally showed antiimplantation activity in 40 per cent of albino rats, Contrary to the above findings, the other group of workers did not find the antifertility activity of the leaves in their studies. The alcoholic (90 per cent), aqueous and petroleum ether extracts, the alcoholic extract (50 per cent) and the benzene extract of the leaves at doses of 100 and 150 mg/kg bw administered orally did not show any antiimplantation resorptive activity in albino rats. The aqueous extract of the leaves lowered the total cholesterol by 61.7 per cent, triglyceride by 37.8 per cent, phospholipid by 51.2 per cent and non esterified free fatty acid by 45.5 per cent (p<0.001) in Triton (WR-1339) induced hyperlipidaemia in Presbytis monkeys. In an ethnopharmacological survey for potential antihypertensives from plants, the leaf extract was investigated for its in vitro angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibiting activity. The water, ethanol and acetone extracts of leaves were found to exhibit 39, 32 and 21 per cent ACE inhibition, respectively. The pretreatment of the leaf extract of the plant at 50 and 100mg/kg doses injected i.p. for 4d before being exposed to radiations revealed radiomodifying effects of the extract on the testes of Swiss albino mice. The extract was non toxic when injected up to 800 mg/kg. In a preliminary study, the dried juice from the fresh leaves was reported to have hypoglycaemic activity in normal albino rabbits and alloxan-diabetic rabbits. The juice extracted from the leaves in a dose of 250 mg/kg i.p. revealed analgesic activity in albino rats. The 50 per cent ethanolic extracts of the plant and leaves in a preliminary biological screening were found to be devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, antiprotozoal, antiviral, hypoglycaemic and anticancer activities and effects on isolated guinea pig ileum and CNS in experimental animals. The alcoholic extract of the stem showed in vitro antibacterial activity against Escherichia coli (Singh et al., 1973). The water extractive of the plant revealed varying degree of antibacterial activity against I11Bacillus pumilusI11 (+), I11Bac subtilisI11 (+), I11Bac megateriumI11 (+), I11Bac cereusI11 (+), I11Escherichia coliI11 (-), I11Klebsiella pneumoniaeI11 (-), I11Shigella sonneiI11 (-), I11Pseudomonas aeruginosaI11 (-) and I11Salmonella typhiI11 (-). The extract showed maximum activity against I11Bacillus megateriumI11 (+). The alcoholic extract of the plant showed some in vitro antibacterial activity against I11Bacillus subtilis, Escherichia coli, Salmonella typhimurium, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Proteus vulgaris.I11 The aqueous extract was active only against I11Bacillus subtilisI11 while the hexane extract was devoid of any activity against all the bacteria tested. The leaf extracts of the plant showed high mortality of root knot I11Meloidogyne incognitaI11 and reniform nematode I11Rotylenchulus reniformis.I11 The chemical constitution and the biological activity of the plant have been reviewed by Joshi and associates (1986). C11Clinical StudiesC11 In a study involving 5000 patients of artheromatous heart disease, presented as angina pectoris were studied over a period of 5 years. There was a marked reduction in total serum cholesterol, serum triglycerides, total lipids and fasting and post prandial blood sugar in diabetic patients, and also an increase in HDL. The clinical profile of these patients showed reduction in the frequency of anginal attacks and gradually, the drugs like verapamil, nifedipine, Ã-blockers and nitrates taken for hypertension and angina control were tapered but could not be withdrawn completely. View Reference
chemical_composition: The genus Aloe is well known for the substance aloin, which is obtained from the juice of decapitated leaves. Aloin is of medical importance. Aloe contains as its major and active principles hydroxy anthrone derivatives, mainly of the aloe-emodin-anthrone 10-C-glucoside type. The major constituent is known as barbaloin (aloin) (15-40%) (8, 13). It also contains hydroxy aloin (about 3%). Barbaloin (=aloin) is in fact a mixture of aloin A (10S) [1] and B (10R) [2]. A. ferox also contains aloinoside A [3] and B [4]. Aloin A and B interconvert through the anthranol form as do aloinoside A and B (13). Chemical analyses of the Indian aloes available in the market which belong to different varieties have been carried out and there are conflicting reports regarding their aloin content. According to one study there was no aloin reported but only some resin and small quantities of anthraquinone derivatives like aloe-emodin were present. In another study, samples of Indian aloes obtained from the hilly tracts of Kerala contained 27-30 per cent of aloin which were comparable to Barbados Aloe (Mukerji and Karkun, 1950). The aloin content in the leaves of different species of Aloe revealed highest percentage (21.78 per cent) in A. vera and lowest (8.59 per cent) in A. ciliaris. The percentage of reducing sugars, non reducing sugars, gums and resins in aloin obtained from different species of Aloe were also estimated. The leaves were also found to contain malic, citric and tartaric acids along with sodium, potassium, calcium and magnesium. The barbaloin content of Indian aloes, estimated according to the method of Fairbairn and Simic, was found to be very low (4.24 per cent) as compared to other varieties. The aloeitic juice drained from the transversely cut base of the leaves contained barbaloin in the range from 2.52-13.39 per cent over a period of eight months. The market samples of aloes had barbaloin ranging from 0 to 5.7 per cent (Bhavsar et al., 1991). The free vitamin C and carotene contents of the leaves were found to be 20.0 mg/100g and 600.0 Âµg/100g, respectively. The plant was reported to contain glycosides and gum-resin mucilage (Yoganarasimhan et al., 1985). A polysaccharide (SB113B11) was isolated from the leaf juice. The method of isolation of this polysaccharide, qualitative detection of the constituent sugars and their quantitative estimation were described (Venkata Rao et al., 1976). The mucilaginous jelly isolated from the fleshy leaves of the plant collected from Kolkata was shown to be a mixture of polysaccharides (PS-A) containing mainly pectic acid along with D-galactan a glucomannan and a arabinan, The glucomannan was neither linear nor acetylated having much lower molecular weight. Controlled hydrolysis of the purified pectic acid furnished an acidic oligosaccharide containing Gal A and Gal components in the molar ratio of 5:1. It methylation analysis is showed that Gal A residues were (1-->4) linked and the Gal unit was glycosidically linked to I11OI11-3 of one of the Gal A residues other than the non reducing unit. The aqueous ethanolic composed of at least four different partially acetylated glucomannans which differed in their glucose to mannose ration and acetyl contents. Methylation and periodate oxidation studies indicated that the glucomannans were linear polymers containing (1-->4 linkages.

author: Willd.
description: A perennial, aromatic herb with horizontal rhizomatous root stocks. Leaves oblong or lanceolate, acute, glabrous, green above, paler beneath; ligule short, rounded, ciliate. Flowers fragrant, greenish-white with red veined lips, in dense-flowered panicles 15-30 cm long. Calyx loosly tubular, 3-toothed. Corolla-tube cylindric, lobes oblong, obtuse, subequal, greenish; striated with red. Stamen 1 perfect; filament flattened; anther-cells diverging at the top. Ovary 3-celled; style filiform; stigma subglobose. Fruits capsules, orange red when ripe.
pharmacology: The ethanol extract of the rhizome was tested for hypolipidaemic activity in vivo. The extraction in a dose of 20 mg/day, administered orally was found to lower the serum and tissue levels of total cholesterol, triglycerides, phospholipids and increased the serum levels of high density lipoproteins in high cholesterol fed white Wistar rats over a period of 4 wk. The water soluble fraction of the alcoholic extract of the plant was found to be active in chronic arthritis in albino rats. In an ethnopharmacological survey for potential antihypertensives from plants, based on an in vitro bioassay for angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibition, it was found that the water, ethanolic and acetone extracts of the rhizome inhibited ACE by 29, 42 and 31 per cent, respectively. The petroleum ether extract and the volatile oil of the rhizome exhibited expectorant activity in rabbits. The petroleum ether extract was more active. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the rhizome, in a preliminary biological screening was found to produce gross behavioural effect, antiamphetamine and hypothermic activities in mice. The alcoholic extract of the stem showed in vitro antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Escherichia coli.I11 The essential oil obtained from the rhizome in a preliminary biological screening revealed antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Salmonella typhosum, Vibrio choleraeI11 and I11Shigella flexneri.I11 The essential oil form the rhizome showed antitubercular activity, completely inhibiting the growth of HB1137B11Rv (human), HB1152B11RS (streptomycin resistant), and BB1119-1B11 (avian)strains, partially that of BB1119-3B11 (bovine) strain of Mycobacterium tuberculosis in a concentration of 25 ?g/ml in in vitro studies. The essential oil also showed antibacterial activity against I11Shigella dysenteriae Shigae, Vibrio cholerae, Hemophilus pertusis, Salmonella paratyphi, Diplococcus pneumoniae, Escherichia coliI11 and I11Salmonella schottmuelleriI11 in a concentration ranging from 0.4 to 0.8 mg/ml. The essential oil from the rhizome was found to be active against I11Bacillus cereus, Bac subtilis, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Staphylococcus albus, Staph aureus, Sarcina lutea, Bacillus shigella dysenteriae, Escherichia coli, Shigella boydii, Salmonella typhiI11 and I11Vibrio cholerae.I11 The essential oil from the rhizome showed 100 per cent fungistatic activity against Trichophyton mentagrophytes and Microsporum gypseum in concentrations of 1000 and 2000 ppm. The aqueous and the ethanolic extracts of the rhizome in a dose of 5-10 mg/ml showed in vitro antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Streptococcus pyogenes.I11 The alcoholic extract of the rhizome showed in vitro anthelmintic activity against human Ascaris lumbricoides. The essential oil was found to be insecticidal against housefly, I11Musa domestica nebulo.I11 C11Clinical StudiesC11 I11A. galangaI11 is one of the constituents of an Ayurvedic preparation namely ârasnadi gugguluâ claimed to be effective in the management of patients suffering from rheumatoid arthritis. View Reference
chemical_composition: In an attempt to differentiate I11A. galangaI11 (greater galangal) from I11A. officinarumI11 (minor galangal) on chemical basis, Sastry (1961) screened the two species for flavonoidal constituents and reported the absence of flavones in I11A. galangaI11, whereas I11A. officinarumI11 contained them. The essential oil obtained by hydrodistillation of the fresh flowers was found to contain sabinene, limonene, 1, 8-cineole, I11pI11-cymen-8-ol, patchoulene, (E)-methyl cinnamate, (Z)-allyl cinnamate, S224 -gurjunene and Ã-caryophyllene (Syamsundar et al., 1999). Essential oil 1, 2 (0.4 per cent) (S224 -pinene, Ã-pinene, limonene, terpinen-4-ol-, S224 -terpineol, linalool, methyl eugenol, eugenol and 1, 8 cineole). Essential oil was obtained from the rhizome in an yield of 0.04 per cent. The chloroform extract of the rhizome yielded two new phenolic constituents, I11pI11-hydroxycinnamaldehyde and di-( I11pI11-hydroxy-cis-styryl) methane (Barik et al., 1987). The ethanolic extract of the shoot revealed the presence of flavonoids, while alkaloids, saponins and tannins were found to be absent. The root contained galangin and 3-methyl galangin.Quercetin, kaempferol, isorhamnetin, kaempferide, quercetin 3-methyl ether, galangin, 1-acetoxychavicol acetate, 1-acetoxyeugenol acetate, galangal A and B, galanolactone.

author: (Burm. f.) Rosc.
description: A rhizomatous herb. Pseudostems ca. 3 m or more. Ligule 2-cleft, to 1 cm, slightly tomentose; petiole ca. 2 cm, grooved; leaf blade oblong-lanceolate or lanceolate, to 90 Ã 15 cm, abaxially pubescent, base acute, apex acuminate. Racemes erect, to 35 cm; rachis stout, densely yellow pubescent; bracteoles white, broadly elliptic, 3.5-4 cm. Pedicel ca. 7 mm, densely yellow pubescent. Calyx campanulate, ca. 1.5 cm, densely sericeous. Corolla white, sericeous; tube ca. 1 cm; lobes oblong-lanceolate, 2.5-3 cm. Lateral staminodes absent. Labellum yellow with red stripes, ovate, ca. 3.5 cm, apex emarginate. Stamen ca. 2.4 cm. Ovary villous. Capsule yellow, globose, ca. 2 cm in diam., dehiscing irregularly.
pharmacology: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant from Assam in a preliminary biological screening showed diuretic activity in rat. It was devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, antiprotozoal, anthelmintic and antiviral activities and effects on isolated guinea pig ileum, rat uterus, respiration, CVS and CNS in experimental animals. The LDB1150B11 of the extract was > 1000 mg/kg i.p. in mice (Bhakuni et al., 1990). View Reference

author: (L.) R. Br.
description: Large evergreen tree with bitter milky juice. Bark grey, rough; branches whorled. Leaves 4-7 in a whorl; 10-20 x 3.75-6.25 cm, oblong-lanceolate or obovate, dark green above, pale and covered with a whitish bloom beneath; main nerves numerous, parallel, uniting in a intramarginal nerve; petioles .6-1.2 cm long. Inflorescence a sub terminal corymbose or capitate, pubescent cyme. Flowers greenish-white; peduncles 2.5-5 cm long pedicels very short; calyx 5-lobed, pubescent. Corolla hypocrateriform; tube cylindric, villous inside, the mouth with a ring of hairs. Stamens near the top of the tube, included; anthers free, subacute. Disk 0. Carpels 2, pubescent. Ovules numerous in each carpel; style filiform; stigma minute or shortly 2-fid; fruit a pair of follicles; follicles slender, terete, 25â50 cm long pendulous in clusters. Seeds 1.25 cm long, linear-oblong, flattened, rounded and with fringe of hairs at both ends, the hairs longer than the seed.
pharmacology: Echitamine chloride obtained from the bark showed antimalarial activity in a rodent test system infected with I11Plasmodium bergheiI11 at both 320 Âµg and 1.6 mg/kg levels (Vasanth et al., 1990) while it did not affect the coagulation activity of blood in an in vitro study at various doses of 100, 50 and 25 Âµg. Echitamine chloride from the bark showed 80 and 53 per cent regression of tumours in methylcholanthrene-induced fibrosarcoma in Wistar strain of rats when given subcutaneously at the doses of 7.5 mg and 5 mg/ kg, respectively. The ethanolic extract of the leaves at a dose of 100 mg/kg/day/animal for 21d showed antifertility activity in male albino rats. The psychopharmacological action of picrinine, the major alkaloid of the flowers produced moderate to marked sedation in albino mice. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the stem bark in a preliminary biological screening revealed effect on CVS in dog/cat and anticancer activity against HIS human sarcoma in the embryonated egg. The LDB1150B11 of the extract was found to be >1000 mg/kg i.p. in mice. The 80 per cent ethanol extract of the root bark revealed antibacterial activity against cultures of I11Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Bacillus subtilisI11 and I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 at a concentration of 25 mg/ml using the agar diffusion method. However, I11A. venenataI11 revealed activity only against I11Bacillus subtilisI11 at the same concentration. The fractions containing alkanes, alkanols, sterol, as also steryl acetate, sitosteryl acetate and stigmasteryl acetate isolated from the leaf extract were found to have antibacterial activity against some gram negative and gram positive bacteria in vitro. Alkanol fraction was inactive. Sterol fraction was the most active one, exhibiting activity against both Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli. The alcoholic extract of the rhizome revealed in vitro anthelmintic activity against human Ascaris lumbricoides. The stem bark extract inhibited the potato virus X. C11Clinical StudiesC11 I11A. ScholarisI11 bark is one of the constituents of an Ayurvedic drug âAyush 64â (other constituents being I11Swertia chirayitaI11 (whole plant), I11Picrorhiza kurroaI11 (rhizome) and I11Caesalpinia bonducellaI11 (seeds) which has been reported to have antifilarial and antimalarial (Sharma et al., 1981) activities in clinical trials. View Reference
chemical_composition: The Flowers contained I11nI11-hexacosane, lupeol, Ã-amyrin, palmitic and ursolic acids (Dhar et al., 1977) and a monoterpene, I11pI11-menthane-1,2,8-triol. This was the first report in the natural occurrence of this monoterpene in the genus Alstonia. The leaves contained betulin, ursolic acid and Ã-sitosterol (Banerji and Banerji, 1977). The phenolic acids identified were vanilic, syringic, S224-resorcylic and sinapic acids. A saponin, amyrin acetate, lupeol acetate and a mixture of S224-amyrin and lupeol were isolated from the bark. The root bark yielded the neutral constituents viz., S224-amyrin acetate, S224-amyrin, lupeol acetate, stigmasterol, Ã-sitosterol and campesterol or its isomer. The root on the other hand contained S224-amyrin acetate, lupeol acetate, Ã-sitosterol and stigmasterol in poor yields. A flavone glycoside isolated from the root was characterized as 8.3â, 4â-trihydroxyflavone -7- I11OI11- S224-L-rhamnopyranoside (isookanin -7- I11OI11-rhamnoside). An alkaloidal glycoside was isolated in addition to Echitamine. Picralinol, an indole alkaloid- picrinine, Pseudoakummigine, akuammigine tubotaiwine akuammicine, hydroxy-19, 20-dihydroakuammicine from roots and alkaloids picrinine, strictamine from flowers are the chemical constituents reported from this plant. A new alkaloid (-) scholarin obtained from leaves; echitamine, new glucoside-venoterpine, glucoside triterpenes, S224-amyrin acetate, lupeol acetate from stem bark, The Chemistry of the alkaloids of the plant has been reviewed by Chatterjee et al., (1977).

author: R. Br.
description: A large shrub or a small tree upto 6.0 m in height with greyish brown bark and bright yellow hard and woody root. Leaves simple, in whorls of 3-6, membranous, 4-8 by 2-1Â¾4.5 cm, oblong-lanceolate, margins wavy, finely acuminate, main nerves numerous, close, parallel, united by intramarginal nerve; petioles 1.25-2 cm long, but obscure owing to the decurrent leaf-blade. Inflorescence a terminal sub umbellate pedunculate cyme. Flowers white, inodorous. Calyx .25 cm long; 5-lobed, triangular-ovate, acute, ciliate corolla-tube 1.25-2.2 cm long, slender, swollen at the top over the stamens. Disk of 2 ligulate glands alternating with the carpels. Carpels 2, distinct. Fruit a pair of follicles; follicles 7.5-12.5 cm long, stalked, tapering at both ends; seeds flattened, linear-oblong with a tuft of hairs at each end, the hairs shorter than the seeds.
pharmacology: In an ethnopharmacological survey for antihypertensives based on an vitro bioassay for angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibition, the water, ethanol and acetone extract of the aerial parts of the plant showed 0, 27 and 38 per cent inhibition of the enzyme. Alstovenine, isolated from the bark, at a dose of 25-30 Âµg/kg bw showed hypertensive action in chloralosed cat. The alkaloid (100-200 Âµg/50 ml) had no action on the uterine and intestinal contractions. The alkaloid also possessed neuroleptic properties. It did not show any significant potentiation on the thiopental â induced sleep in mice. Alstovenine and Venenatine, an epimeric pair if 4-methoxy indole alkaloids isolated from the bark showed significant psychopharmacological activity. Alstovenine, in lower doses exhibited monoamine oxidase inhibitor activity as characterized by its ability to potentiate hexobarbitone-hypnosis, amphetamine-toxicity, tryptamine-convulsions, prevention but not reversal of reserpine syndrome, potentiation of dopa and 5-HTP effects, morphine-analgesia and anticonvulsant effect of diphenylhydantoin in albino mice. Echitovenidine, the major fruit alkaloid showed monoamine oxidase inhibitor activity by both in vivo and in vitro tests in albino rats, albino mice and mongrel dogs. The alkanes and sterol fractions, steryl acetate, sitosteryl acetate and stigmasteryl acetate isolated from the leaves of I11A. venenataI11 and I11A. venenatusI11 exhibited similar antibacterial activity against some gram positive and gram negative bacteria as that reported from I11A. scholaris.I11 View Reference
chemical_composition: The fruit pods were found to contain Ã-amyrin and ursolic acid (Pandey and Ray, 1973) as also Ã-amyrin acetate and lupeol ester of a Ã-hydroxyacid (Pandey and Dutta, 1979). The stem bark in addition to alkaloids contained stigmasterol (Govindachari et al., 1964) and tri- I11OI11-methylgallamide with the corresponding acyl moiety being one of the synthones of reserpine which also occurs in the same plant (Chatterjee and Mukhopadhyay, 1977; Chatterjee et al., 1978b). It was believed that Venoterpine was possibly a stereoisomer of the monoterpene alkaloid isolated by earlier workers.

author: (L.) R. Br. ex DC.
description: Much-branched, prostrate or ascending herb. Branches often purplish, often rooting at the lower nodes, glabrous, the younger ones with 2 opposite lines of hairs. Leaves opposite, somewhat fleshy, linear-oblong, lanceolate or elliptic, obtuse or acute, shortly petiolate, glabrous. Flowers in axillary often clustered heads. Perianth segments 5. Stamens 2-5; filaments short; anthers 1-celled. Ovary obcordate; ovule solitary, pendulous from a long basal funicle; style very short; stigma capitellate. Fruit an utricle, obcordate, compressed with thickened margins.
pharmacology: The extract of the leaves in a dose of 200mg/g diet was reported to increase (>78 per cent) the glutathione-S-transferase (GST) activity in the stomach, liver and oesophagus in mice. Glutathione levels were also markedly elevated in the three tissues. The antioxidant activity of the leaves, expressed as Âµg of S224-tocopherol equivalent per gram fresh weight of leaves, was between 500-630. The effects of the alkaloid extract of the plant were studied in dose-dependent manner on haematological parameters, liver and kidney functions and metabolism in mice. It was observed that there was no significant effect in low dose of 55mg/kg bw. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant produced hypothermia in mice. It was devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, antiprotozoal, antiviral, hypoglycaemic, anticancer and diuretic activities and effects on isolated guinea pig ileum, respiration, CVS and preganglionically stimulated nictitating membrane in experimental animals. In a screening of the seeds growing on cattle dung for antibacterial activity, the seeds of the plant were reported to inhibit the growth of Pseudomonas cichorii. These were inactive against strains of Bacillus subtilis, Escherichia coli and Salmonella typhimurium. C11Clinical StudiesC11 The effects of feeding vegetable fibre from the leaves was studied in eight normal and six non-insulin dependent diabetic (NIDDM) volunteers and the results were compared with a control diet (diet with no vegetable fibre) and a purified fibre diet (Isabgol). A negative correlation between the level of fibre and blood glucose levels in terms of mean per cent peak rise, area under glucose response curve (AUC) and per cent glycaemic response was shown. View Reference
chemical_composition: The petroleum ether extract of the plant was reported to yield nonacosane, 16-hentriacontane, Ã-sitosterol, stigmasterol, handianol, campesterol, S224-spinasterol, oleanolic acid rhamnoside, 24-methylene cycloartenol, cycloeucalenol, lupeol, 5- S224-stigmasta-7-enol and its palmitate, and oxalic acid, saturated aliphatic hydrocarbon and ester and saturated ester (plant). Ash extractive values were also determined (Sinha et al., 1984b). The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant was devoid of tannins in a preliminary chemical study (Atal et al., 1978). The leaves on extraction with ethanol yielded a flavone glycoside, characterized as robinitin-7- I11OI11- Ã-D glucopyranoside. Leaf lipids were reported rich source of essential fatty acids and also S224- and Ã-tochpherols. The petroleum ether extracts of the root yielded lupeol (Agrawal and Jain, 1979).

author: DC.
description: Diffuse or prostrate herbs; stems numerous spreading or ascending. Leaves 1- foliolate, leaflets very variable in shape and size on one and the same plant. Flowers in elongated 6- 12 flowered racemes. Calyx glumaceous, obscurely hairy, size on one and the same plant; teeth deep; the 2 upper often connate; tube very short. Corolla hardly exerted; standard obovate or orbicular. Stamens diadelphous; anthers uniform. Ovary sessile or shortly stalked; ovules numerous; style incurved; stigma capitate. Pods erect moniliform, finely downy with minute hooked hairs.
pharmacology: The seeds of the plant growing on dung were reported to inhibit the growth of I11Bacillus subtilis, Xanthomonas campestris, Pseudomonas cichoriiI11 and I11Escherichia coliI11 (Bagchi et al., 1997). The water extract of the leaves exhibited antifungal activity inhibiting the germ tube elongation of I11Drechslera oryzaeI11 (Ganesan and Krishnaraju, 1995). View Reference
chemical_composition: The cobalt, zinc and molybdenum contents in the plant (Iyer and Satyanarayan, 1958a, b) and the copper and manganese contents in the flowering and fruiting stages were quantitatively analyzed. The iodine content in six samples of the plant was found to be in the range between 0.053 and 0.021 expressed as ppm of dry matter (Iyer, 1958). In a preliminary chemical screening, the seeds were found to be devoid of tannins, flavonoids, saponins and starch. The seeds contained proteins, pentosans and water soluble gum. The gum was reported to contain proteins (Kapoor et al., 1971; Kapoor et al., 1992).

author: Blume. ex Decue.
description: Perennial tuberous herbs (flowering before leaves, after reaching some age). Tuber depressed - globose, bulbiferous dark brown. Leaf solitary, 3-partite; segments forked. Petiole 2-3 ft long, stout, warted, dark green, with paler blotches. Spathe greenish-pink externally, base purple within. Female flowers; ovaries densely crowded, sessile depressed -globose; style stout, ascending, purple; stigma 2-3 lobed. Fruit beries, red, 2-3 seeded abovoid.
pharmacology: The tuber starch produced a decrease in tissue cholesterol, faecal sterol, biliary bile salts, triglyceride in the serum, aorta and heart and an increase in faecal excretion of bile salts and lipolytic activity. The tubers were tested for their inhibitory activity against trypsin, S224-chymotrypsin and subtilisin BPN and were found to reveal inhibitory activity against trypsin and S224-chymotrypsin. The methanolic extract of the plant affected the smooth muscle of uterus in experimental animals to a marked extent but only to a mild degree on the intestinal muscle and showed a pressor effect on blood pressure which however did not last for more than 12 min. The uterotonic activity was evident both with 90 and 10 per cent methanolic extracts. The aqueous extract but not the alcoholic extract of the stem had antibacterial activity against I11Escherichia coli.I11 The active principle isolated from the alcohol extract of the stem inhibited the growth of tubercle bacilli in a dilution of 1/5000. The hexane, aqueous and alcoholic extracts of the tubers did not show any antibacterial activity against I11Bacillus subtilis, Escherichia coli, Proteus vulgaris, Salmonella typhimurium, Pseudomonas aeruginosaI11 and I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 using the agar well diffusion method. author: L.
description: Small tree with a short crooked trunk. Leaves alternate coriaceous, obavate or elliptic; main nerves 10-12 pairs. Inflorescence a terminal panicle, the branches cymose. Flowers polygamous. Calyx 5- partite, imbricate. Disk filling the base of the cylix. Petals linear-lanceolate, deflected from the middle. Stamens 9, one longer than the other, filaments connate or adnate to the disk ovary obcordate, ovule 1. Fruit a nut, reniform, pedicel large, fleshy, in different shades of red, orange and yellow.
pharmacology: Essential oil obtained from the shell and leaves was found to be biologically active. The interesting activities were anthelmintic, antifilarial and larvicidal. Only the anthelmintic activity has been clinically tested and proved. The antiinflammatory activity of (-) epicatechin isolated from the seed coat was studied in comparison with phenylbutazone. It was found to significantly reduce the rat paw oedema induced by carrageenin. Cardol, the phenolic compound isolated from cashewnut shell, showed pronounced antifilarial activity when given orally. The mutagenicity of the petroleum ether extract of cashewnut shell was tested using Salmonella typhimurium (Ameâs test) strains TA 1535, TA 100 and TA 98. It revealed that CNSL was non mutagenic up to a concentration of 0.003 per cent (0.1 ml DMSO) with and without metabolic activation (S9 mixture). The commercially available oil derived from the shell of cashewnut was evaluated for its potency in promoting the DMBA (7, 12-dimethylbenz[a]anthracene-initiated cells into papillomas in a murine two â stage skin tumourigenesis is model system. The results revealed a weak tumour promoting effect on cashewnut shell oil as the mean tumour groups, respectively while the corresponding value was 6.6 in the positive control group. Repeated application of cashewnut shell liquid on the skin of mice daily for 11 wk caused necrotic skin lesions with granuloma formation and promoted the occurrence of polyarthritis. No malignant changes or precancerous lesions were observed in biopsied samples. The essential oil of the plant at a dose of 150 and 300 mg/kg was found to be CNS depressant. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the leaves in a preliminary biological screening showed hypoglycaemic activity in rat and anticancer activity against hepatoma 129 in mouse. The in vitro antibacterial activity of the essential oil from the leaves was studied against 4 gram positive and 18 gram negative bacteria using filter paper disc agar diffusion technique. The oil exhibited antibacterial activity against all the organisms but revealed marked activity against I11Pseudomonas mangiferae, Salmonella sp., Bacillus mycoides, Vibrio choleraeI11 and I11Xanthomonas campestris. Pseudomonas aeruginosaI11 was found to be susceptible to the oil. The essential oil obtained from the leaves was tested for its antimycotic properties against six dermatophytes viz., I11Keratinomyces ajelloi, Microsporum gypseum, Trichophyton equinum, T. mentagrophytes, T. rubrumI11 and I11T. terrestreI11. The oil was found to have moderate activity against all the test organisms in comparison to the control (1000 ppm griseofulvin). The chloroform and the methanol extracts (fractionated into acetone-soluble and insoluble parts) of the leaves revealed antimicrobial activity against gram positive and gram negative bacteria viz., I11Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Serratia marcescens, Bacillus subtilis, Klebsiella pneumoniaeI11 as well as the fungi I11Candida albicans.I11 The cashewnut shell oil was used as a mosquito larvicide against the larvae and pupae of I11Armigeres obturansI11, a culcine mosquito. The crushed aqueous extract of the ripe seed shells (03g) showed larvicidal activity against the larvae of I11Culex quinquefasciatusI11 and was found to be over 20 times higher than that of Adhatoda plant which was earlier reported to be an antilarval agent. C11Clinical StudiesC11 In a preliminary clinical trial in the treatment of hook worm and round worm infestations, cashewnut shell oil at various doses was found to cure 7 out of 10 cases of Ascaris infection. In the remaining three cases there was a substantial reduction in egg count. In another study, out of 47 cases of infection by I11Ascaris lumbricoidesI11 30 were cured with a single treatment of 5-6 g of cashew nut shell oil while in 5 more the egg count reduction was 70-80 per cent. Out of 78 cases of hook worm infection 28 were cured and 6 more almost cured by one treatment. Cardol obtained from the shell liquid was studied for its anthelmintic action. 16 out of 23 cases of Ascaris infection, 19 out of 37 cases of hook worm infection and 3 out of 10 cases of Trichuris infection were cured by single treatment of cardol at the dose of 6g in gelatin capsules on empty stomach was given to each patient. View Reference
chemical_composition: The ether soluble fraction of the cashewnut husk was found to contain D- catechin and gallic acid. Leucocyanidin was isolated from the ethyl acetate soluble portion of the husk while quinic and caffeic acids were isolated from the non-tannin portion of the husk. The ethanolic extract of the shells of one year old sample of mature cashew nuts yielded kajin, a glycoside, kajidin and gallic acid. In a ten year old sample anacardin was reported in place of kajidin. Kajidin was later identified as 3, 4, 3â, 4â-tetrahydroxdiphenic acid dilactone (ellagic acid).The ethanolic extract of the nut shells yielded a new biflavonoid glycoside, named occidentoside whose structure was established as tetrahydrohinokiflavone-C-glucoside. This was the first biflavonoid to occur with one flavanone and one chalcone unit each and the first C-glycoside in the biflavonoid series. Besides this (-)-salipurposide and Ã-sitosterol were also isolated. The acetone extract of the defatted nut shells yielded a new acylated flavanone glycoside characterized as pruning-6ââ- I11OI11 â I11pI11-coumarate [naringenin-7- I11OI11 -(6ââ- I11OI11 â I11pI11-coumaryl)- Ã-D-glucoside]. The cashewnut liquid free shells fractionated into ether soluble and ether insoluble portions yielded syringic acid and (+)-gallocatechin, respectively. CNSL was reported to be a rich source of naturally occurring phenols. The oil comprised of anacardic acid, cardol, cardanol and 6-methyl cardol besides two unknown minor substances. The chemical characterization of cardol, cardanol, and anacardic acid was studied in detail. Anacardic acid isolated from the solvent extracted CNSL was separated into saturated component and a mono-, di-, and triolefin, which were identified as l-hydroxy-2-carboxy-3-pentadecylbenzene, 1-hydroxy-2-carboxy-3-(8â-pentadecenyl) benzene; 1-hydroxy-2-carboxy-3-(8â, 11ââ-pentadecadienyl) benzene and 1-hydroxy-2-carboxy-3-( 8â, 11â, 14â-pentadecadienyl) benzene, respectively. The chemical aspects of cashewnut shell liquid were reviewed. Dipole moments of both anacardic acid and cardol; surface active characteristics of sodium salts of anacardic acid and NMR spectra of cardanol, 6-methylcardol, cardol and of monoene, diene, and triene components separated from cardanol were reported (Gedam et al., 1972). Analogues of some of the compounds of biological significance such as warfarin, phenolphthalein, salvigenin, salicylanilide, salicylamide and tetrahydroanacardic acid were prepared using the saturated phenolic components of CNSL viz., tetrahydrocardinol, tetrahydrocardol and tetrahydroanacardic acid instead of phenol, resorcinol and salicylic acid used normally for their preparation. The presence of long alkyl chain in these starting materials resulted in analogues which were expected to render the new drugs with fat-solubility and less toxicity. In an attempt to get germicidal compounds, several quaternary nitrogen derivatives were prepared from the monophenolic components viz., cardanol and anacardic acid of CNSL. Quantitative composition of the major phenolic lipids (anacardic acids, cardols and cardanols) of the apple, kernel and shell were determined at various stages of development by high performance liquid chromatography. The results suggested the possibility of a fatty acid type biogenesis of these phenolic lipids. Cardanols and cardols appeared to be genuine metabolites and not artefacts formed the corresponding carboxylic acids during isolation. The fruits were found to be devoid of bioflavonoids. The flowers were reported to yield the polyphenols viz., ethyl gallate, quercetin, hyperoside and I11mI11-digallic acid while the tender leaves showed the presence of Ã-sitosterol, ethyl gallate, hyperoside, methyl gallate, leucocyanidin and leucodelphinidin. The bark had condensed tannins, while no crystalline components were isolated. The leaves were reported to yield myricetin, agathisflavone, robustaflavone, amentoflavone, quercetin, kaempferol, apigenin and two glycosides viz., quercetin-3- I11OI11 ârhamnoside and quercetin-3- I11OI11 âglucoside (Arya et al., 1989). The essential oil obtained from the leaves on thin layer and gas liquid chromatography revealed thirty compounds in varying percentages, the major being car-3-ene- (25.78 per cent), geraniol (6.07 per cent) and carvacrol (5.94 per cent). The seed testa has been reported to be a good source of tannins. In addition, it was reported to contain (+)-catechin and (-)-epicatechin as the major polyphenols along with proanthocyanidins, leucocyanidin and leucopelargonidin. The ethyl acetate extract of the seed testa contained catechin and (-)-epiafzelechin.

pharmacology: The 50 per cent ethanolic extracts of the plant (excluding root) collected from two different places viz., Tamil Nadu and Karnataka were subjected to a biological screening. The sample from Tamil Nadu exhibited anticancer activity against LB111210B11 lymphoid leukaemia in mice showed effect on CVS in dog/cat while the sample from Karnataka revealed anticancer activity against PB11388B11 lymphocytic leukaemia in mice and diuretic activity in rats. Both the samples were devoid of antibacterial, antifungal and hypoglycaemic activities as also effects on isolated guinea pig ileum and CNS in mice. The Karnataka sample was also tested for spermicidal, semen coagulant and antiinflammatory activities in rats and effects on CVS in experimental animals, but was found inactive. The LDB1150B11 of the extracts of Tamil Nadu and Karnataka samples were found to be >1000 and 125 mg/kg i.p. in mice, respectively. View Reference

author: Wall. ex Grah.
description: A scandant shrub with hooked branches. Leaves deep green, 10-25 by 3.25-7.5 cm, oblanceolate-oblong, subacute, glabrous, shining, reticulately-veined, narrowed at the base, nearly sessile. Flowers small, caducous, in branched panicles. pharmacology: The 50 per cent ethanolic extracts of the plant (excluding root) in a preliminary biological screening revealed effect on the CVS in dog/cat and spasmolytic activity in isolated guinea pig ileum. The spasmolytic activity was confirmed in the fractionated extract. The extract was devoid of anthelmintic, hypoglycaemic, anticancer and diuretic activities and effect on CNS in experimental animals. The LDB1150B11 of the extract was >1000 mg/kg i.p. in mice. View Reference
chemical_composition: The aerial parts were reported to contain alkaloids (ancistrocladine, ancistrocladinine, ancistrocladisine, ancistrocladidine, dihydroancistrocladinine); hentriacontanol, lupeol and quercetin (Sharma et al., 1975). The hexane extracted leaves afforded octacosanol. The root was investigated in detail by Govindachari and co-workers who have reported the isolation of four novel isoquinoline alkaloids and a new naphthaquinone. Ancistrocladine, the major constituent isolated in 1.0 per cent was yield was characterized as (1,S,3S)-5Â®-(4,5-dimethoxy-2-methy-1-naphthyl)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydrao-8-methoxy-1,3-dimethylisoquinolin-6-o1 (Govindachari and Parthasarathy, 1970, 1971; Govindhachari et al., 1971a). The other three isoquinoline isolated in minor quantities were characterized as ancistrocladinine [(3S)-5(R)-(4,5-dimethoxy-2-methy-1-naphthyl)-3,4-dihydro-8-methoxy-1,3-dimethylisoquinolin-6-o1]; ancistrocladisine [(3S, 7R)-7-(4,5 naphthyl)-3,4-dihydro-6,8-dimethoxy-1,3-dimethylisoquinolin] (Govindachari et al., 1972) and ancistrocladidine [3S)-75(R)-3,4 dihydr-7-(4-hydroxy-5-methoxy-2-methyl-3-naphthyl)-6,8-dimethoxy-1,3-dimethylisoquinoline](Govindachari et al.,1973). The new naphthaquinone named ancistroquinone was characterized as 3,6-dihydroxy-2-methyl-5-methoxy-1,4-naphthaquinone (Govindachari et al., 1971c). The ethanolic extract of the root yielded lupeol; droserone (Desai et al., 1973) and I11OI11-methylancistrocladine (Desai et al., 1976). The hexane extract of the root yielded Ã-sitosterol. The detailed chemistry of the plants has been reviewed by Govindachari and Parthasarathy.

author: (Burm. f.) Wall. ex Nees.
description: Annual erect branched herbs .3-1 m high; branches sharply quadrangular, often narrowly winged in the upper part. Leaves entire, 5-7.5 by 1.25-2.5 cm, lanceolate, acute, glabrous, slightly undulate, pale beneath; base tapering; main nerver 4-6 pairs, slender; petioles 0-.6 cm long. Flowers small, solitary, distant, in lax spreading axillary and terminal racemes or panicles the whole forming a large pyramidal panuculate inflorescence; bracts .25 cm long, lanceolate; bracteoles similar or 0 ; pedicels 1-4 mm long, glandular pubescent. Calyx 5- partite; segments narrow. Corolla small, rose-colored, tubular, 2- lipped, 1.2 cm long, oblong; lower lip equal in length deeply 3-lobed, the lobes .25 cm long, linear-oblong, subobtuse, pubescent. Stamens 2; filaments flattened, hairy in the upper part anthers bearded at the base; antehers 2-celled, exserted, the cells oblong, parallel, subequal, muticous, bearded at the base. Ovary 2-celled; glabrous; style slightly pubescent; ovules 3-6 in each cell; style slender; stigma shorly 2-lobed. Capsule capsule 2 by .3 cm, linear-oblong, acute at both ends. Seeds hard, numerous, subquadrate, rugosely pitted, glabrous; retinacula lanceolate, yellowish-brown.

locations.vegetation: Tropical semi evergreen to evergreen forest

pharmacology: The aqueous extract of the plant [each 5 ml of the extract contained âkalmeghâ I.P. containing 5 per cent andrographolide (1 ml)] in a dose of 3.75 ml/kg p.o. once a day for 5d was studied on the biliary flow, liver weight and hexobarbital-induced sleeping time in rats. The extract was reported to increase biliary flow and liver weight and decreased the duration of action of hexobarbital. The oral administration of the aqueous extract of the leaves (12 mg/kg bw) to mice delayed the hepatic tumourigenic condition induced by hexachlorocyclohexane (BHC). A single dose of andrographolide (5 mg/kg orally) and âkalmeghâ leaf extract (500mg/kg orally) prevented CCIB114B11-induced changes in enzyme activities in serum and liver of rats. Oral administration of a single dose of âkalmeghâ leaf extract (0.5g/kg and 1.0g/kg) or andrographolide (5mg/kg and 10mg/kg) to adult male albino rats produced a dose-related and time-dependent characteristic activation of brush border membrane â bound hydrolases, viz., lactase, maltase and sucrase in three disaccharidases were obtained at 6h of either the leaf extract or the andrographolide administration. The leaves (0.5g/kg administered orally once a day for six days) were evaluated in CCIB114B11-induced liver damage in rabbits. There was a marked clinical recovery from liver damage and significant reduction in AST and ALT enzyme level was reported, The alcoholic extract of the leaves obtained by cold maceration at a dose of 300 mg/kg (1/6 of LDB1150B11) administered orally to albino rats for 8wk showed hepatoprotective activity against CCIB114B11-induced liver damage which was evident by morphological, biochemical and functional parameters. The antihepatotoxic activity of andrographolide (100 mg/kg i.p.) was compared with 861.33 mg/kg i.p. of the methanolic extract (equivalent to 100 mg/kg of andrographolide) and 761.33 mg/kg i.p. of the andrographolide free methanolic extract (equivalent to 861.33mg/kg of the methanolic extract) of the plant, using CCIB114B11-intoxicated rats. Biochemical parameters like serum transaminases â GOT and GPT, serum alkaline phosphatase, serum bilirubin and hepatic triglycerides were estimated to assess the liver function. The overall inhibition of CCIB114B11-induced increase in the five biochemical parameters was found to be 48.6 per cent (andrographolide), 32.0 per cent (methanolic extract) and 15.0 per cent (andrographolide-free methanolic extract). The hepatoprotective effect of andrographolide was studied on acute hepatitis induced in rats by single dose of galactosamine (800 mg/kg i.p.) and paracetamol (3g/kg p.o.). Hepatoprotective activity was monitored by estimating the serum transaminases (GOT and GPT), alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin in serum, hepatic triglycerides and by histopathological changes in the livers of experimental rats. The results confirmed the in vivo hepatoprotective effect of andrographolide against galactosamine or paracetamol induced hepatotoxicity in rats. Andrographolide showed a significant dose-dependent (0.75-12 mg/kg p.o. for 7d) protective activity against paracetamol-induced toxicity on ex-vivo preparations of isolated rat hepatocytes. Andrographolide, given by oral route, possessed dose-dependent (3-12mg/kg) activity in rats against galactosamine-induced hepatic damage. The antihepatotoxic effects of the diterpenes andrographolide (I), andrographiside (II), and neoandrographolide (III) isolated from the leaves were investigated for their protective effects on the hepatotoxicity induced in mice by CCI4or tert-butylhydroperoxide (t BHP) intoxication. Administration of an alcoholic extract of the fresh plant (25mg/kg) and two of its constituent diterpenes, andrographolide and neoandrographolide (6 mg/kg/day for two weeks) showed significant antihepatotoxic action in Plasmodium berghei K173-induced hepatic damage in Mastomys natalensis. Apigenin 7, 4-di- I11OI11 âmethyl ether, the flavone isolated from the root was tested for its antigastric ulcer property in various animal models. The animals received a suspension of the compound orally in doses of 5, 10 and 50 mg/kg. The flavone produced a significant dose-dependent antiulcer activity in Shay rats, histamine-induced ulcer in guinea pigs and in aspirin-induced ulcer in rats. Andrographolide possessed significant (p<0.05) antiulcerogenic activity at doses of 100 and 300 mg/kg bw administered orally in aspirin-induced ulceration in rats. The dry leaf powder when fed orally to male albino rats, at a dose level of 20 mg powder per day for 60d, resulted in cessation of spermatogenesis, degenerative changes in the seminiferous tubules, regression of Leydig cells and regressive and/or degenerative changes in the epididymis, seminal vesicle, ventral prostate and coagulating gland. The aqueous extract of the plant at a dose of 20 mg/100g bw orally in rats inhibited carrageenin-induced oedema (65.3 per cent) after three hours as compared to the control rats. Andrographolide was studied for its antiinflammatory activity in acute, subacute and chronic models of inflammation in rats after oral administration at doses of 30, 100 and 300 mg/kg. It significantly inhibited carrageenin-kaolin-and nystatin-induced paw oedema in rats. The plant juice (2ml/100g bw orally) showed antipyretic activity in yeast-induced pyrexia in rats. The extract administered even after 5h of year also reduced pyrexia. Andrographolide (100 and 300 mg/kg bw orally) produced a significant (p<0.05) antipyretic effect 3h of administration in Brewers yeast-induced pyrexia in rats. Andrographolide at 300 mg/kg dose administered orally showed significant (p<0.05) analgesic activity in acetic acid-induced writhing in mice and Randall Selittoâs test in rats. The water decoction of the leaves was tested both in vitro and vivo against canine filariasis. The decoction killed in vitro the microfilariae Dipetalonema reconditum in 40 min. Three injections of the extract into infected dogs at 0.06 ml/g bw s.c. reduced the number of microfilariae in blood by more than 85 per cent. The alcoholic extract of the plant exhibited significant antidiarrhoeal activity against Escherichia coli enterotoxins in animal models. The activity was further located in n-butanol fraction, which contained four diterpenes, andrographolide, neoandrographolide, deoxyandrographolide and andrographiside. Andrographolide significantly decreased degranulation of mast cells of rats and reduced liberation of histamine from the cells when tested in vitro at concentration of 30, 100 and 300 Âµg/ml. It was found to produce an increase in delayed hypersensitivity in rats. The alcoholic extract of the plant was found to possess schizontocidal activity (39.26 per cent) in vivo as well as (46.23 per cent) in vitro at a dose of 1g/kg 4d and 100 Âµg/ml. respectively against the NK 65 strain of Plasmodium berghei in Mastomys natalensis. The ethanolic extract and purified diterpene andrographolide induced significant stimulation of antibody and delayed type hypersensitivity response to sheep red blood cells in mice. The plant preparations also stimulated non specific immune response of the animals measured in terms of macrophage migration index (MMI), phagocytosis of P1114P11C-leucine labeled I11Escherichia coliI11 and proliferation of splenic lymphocytes. The stimulation of both antigen specific and non specific immune response was however of lower order with andrographolide than with the ethanolic extract, suggesting thereby that substance(s) other than andrographolide present in the extract might also be contributing towards immunostimulation. The alcoholic and aqueous extracts of the leaves showed antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Escherichia coliI11. The 80 per cent ethanolic extract of the root using the Agar diffusion method revealed antibacterial activity against a strain I11Escherichia coli I11 and I11Pseudomonas aeruginosa I11 at a concentration of 25 mg/ml. It was also active against I11Bacillus subtilis I11 and I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 in concentration of 6.25 and 12.5 mg/ml, respectively. The extract of the plant revealed antifungal activity against I11Helminthosporium sativumI11 and inhibited the mycelial growth of the keratinophilic fungi I11Microsporum gypseum, Chrysosporium tropicumI11 and I11Trichophyton terrestreI11 in in vitro studies. The alcoholic and the aqueous extracts of the plant showed antifungal activity against I11Aspergillus nigerI11 at concentration of 5 and 2.5 per cent. The effect of the alcoholic extract of the plant (at a dose of 100 mg/25g i.p. and 50 mg.25 g.i.p) on cobra venom-induced death in mice was studied. The extract prolonged the life time of venom injected animals as compared to the controls (saline). The extract prolonged the life time of cobra victims by an unknown mechanism. C11Clinical StudiesC11 A. paniculata is one of the constituents of âAyush-57â, an Ayurvedic drug containing the plants I11Plumbago rosea, Terminalia belerica, T. chebula, Emblica officinalisI11 and other constituents, which has been reported to be beneficial in some cases of vitiligo (Rao et al., 1980). View Reference
chemical_composition: Andrographolide obtained by the method of Indian Pharmacopoeia (1946) was not pure and contained considerable amount of impurities (about 33.6 to 36 per cent). Attempts were made to obtain andrographolide were reported in pure form and various methods for estimation of andrographolide were reported (Bandyopadhyay et al., 1986; Chauhan et al., 1999). Four diterpenes, andrographolide, neoandrographolide, deoxyandrographolide and andrographiside were isolated from the I11nI11-butanol fraction of the alcoholic extract of the plant. The methanol soluble portion of the benzene extract of the plant yielded carvacrol and eugenol along with myristic acid, hentriacontane and tritriacontane (Ojha, 1983). Tissue culture studies to enhance the andrographolide contents were carried out. Eight cytotypes of I11A. paniculataI11 were analyzed for andrographolide content spectrophotometrically and it was found that a cytotypes obtained from Jessore in Bangladesh gave highest yield. The root yielded a new flavone (5-hydroxy-7, 8, 2â, 3â-tetramethoxyflavone) found to be identical with mono- I11OI11-methylwightin along with apigenin-7,4â-di- I11OI11-methyl ether and andrographolide (Govindachari et al., 1969); two new flavonoids, 5-hydroxy-7,8-dimethoxyflavone and 5-hydroxy-3,7,8,2â-tetramethoxyflavone in addition to the known flavonoid, 5-hydroxy-7,8-dimethoxyflavone (7- I11OI11-methylwogonin); a new glycoside, 2â,5- dihydroxy-7,8-dimethoxyflavone-2â- I11OI11- Ã-D-glucoside, and 3 Ã-hydroxy-5-stigmasta 9(11), 22(23)-diene. Synthesis of 5-hydroxy-7,8,2â-trimethoxyflavone; 5,2â-dihydroxy-7,8-dimethoxyflavone and 3,7,8,2â-tetramethoxy-5-hydroxyflavone isolated by foreign workers (Biswas and Chowdhury, 1972). The polyphenols obtained from the mother liquor after removal of andrographolide from the leaves were identified as caffeic, chlorogenic and a mixture of dicaffeol and quinic acids. The different aspects of the plant along with its chemistry have been reviewed by Bhatt and Nanavati (1978), Tomar et al., (1982) and Aminuddin et al., (1997).

author: L.
description: Medium sized trees with drooping branches. Leaves oblong-lanceolate, rounded at base. Flowers in extra-axillary or terminal cymes, 2-3 together. Fruit ovoid, reticulate, areolate, reddish green or yellowish brown. Seeds black, arillate.
pharmacology: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) in a preliminary biological screening revealed antispasmodic activity on isolated guinea pig ileum. The extract was devoid of antiprotozoal, anticancer and diuretic activities and also effects on respiration, preganglionically stimulated nictitating membrane, CVS and CNS in experimental animals. View Reference
chemical_composition: The fruits were found to contain steroids/triterpenoids, alkaloids, saponins, tannins and phenolics, while the seeds contained steroids/triterpenoids, alkaloids, flavonoids and tannins. Flavonoids were found to be absent in fruits and the seeds were devoid of phenolics and saponins. The stem bark was reported to yield three acetogenins identified as reticulacinone along with rolliniastatin-2 and movlizarin (Hisham et al., 1994). The biosynthesis of the alkaloid coclaurine, a precursor of proaporphine, aporphine and bisbenzylisoquinoline alkaloids present in the young shoot was studied in the plant. The root bark was reported to yield liriodenine. A serried of N-fatty acyl tryptamines in which the acyl portion ranged from hexadecanoyl to hexacosanoyl was isolated from the petroleum ether extract of the seeds (Maeda et al., 1993).

author: Benth. ex Hook. f.
description: A stout plant 30-60 cm with a perennial root: stems straggling. Leaves opposite; stipules interpetiolar, 2.5-6.2 by 1-2.8 cm, sessile or petioled, ovate or ovate-lanceolate, acute, sometimes cordate; lateral villous on both sides, base obtuse or acute, sometimesa cordate; lateral nerves numetous, prominent beneath ; petioles 0-1.25 cm long; stipules bristly. Flowers in corymbose usually hairy dense peduncled terminal cymes. Calyx in flower in .25 cm long; teeth equaling the tube, narrowly triangular, acute. Corolla tubular or infundibuliform red-purple; lobes 4, ovate usually shorter than the tube, tube .45-.6 cm long; lobes .2cm long, oblong, obtuse. Stamens 4; filaments short or long; anthers included or exserted, blue. Capsules subglobose, didymous, with the calyx-teeth near the top. Seeds 1-2 plano-convex, .12-.15 cm long, deeply pitted. The plant varies much in hairiness.

pharmacology: The two isomeric pentacyclic triterpenoids viz., 16S224-hydroxy-3-ketoisomultiflorene, 3Ã-hydroxy-16-ketoisomultiflorene and friedelin isolated from the aerial parts on a preliminary screening were found to exhibit diuretic activity in rats. N-Tritriacontane exhibited antiinflammatory activity against carrageenin-induced acute oedema in mice (Rizvi et al., 1980a,b). The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) collected from Uttar Pradesh in a preliminary biological screening exhibited diuretic and antiinflammatory activity study, the samples of the plant (excluding root) collected from Kerala did not show diuretic activity (Aswal et al., 1996). The 50 per cent ethanolic extracts of the plant (excluding root) collected from Uttar Pradesh was devoid of antiprotozoal and antiviral activities and effects on respiration, preganglionically stimulated nictitating membrane, CVS, CNS and isolated tissues in experimental animals. Its LD B1150 B11 was found to be>1000 mg/kg i.p. in mice (Aswal et al., 1984). The samples of the plant (excluding root) collected from Kerala were also found inactive when tested for the above activities (Aswal et al., 1996). View Reference

The aerial parts also yielded n-tritriacontane, friedelin, canophyllal and canophyllol (Rizvi et al., 1980a, b).

author: Lam.
description: An erect slender shrub, 2-3 m high, the young parts finely pubescent; bark smooth, yellowish. Leaves distichous, 12.7-23 by 3-5 cm, oblong-lanceolate, acutely acuminate, entire, glabrous above, stellately pubescent and paler beneath, strongly 3-nerved from the base, with reticulate venation between the nerves, base subacute; petiolate. Flowers in axillary irregular few-flowered cymes; bracts small, linear, acute, pubescent; pedicels rather long, densely, pubescent. Perianth 3-partite; segments broadly ovate or suborbicular, .5 cm long, pubescent, concave. Ovary inferior, 4-celled; ovules numerous, 2-seriate; style short; stigmas 3 or more, linear. Capsules 7.5-10 cm long, straight, obtuse, 4-gonous. Seeds acute at both ends, 3-gonous, .25 cm long, deeply pitted.
pharmacology: Pharmacological activities of chakranine, the alkaloidal principle isolated from the root, did not lend support to the reputation which the plant enjoys in Indigenous system of medicine in the treatment of intestinal infections and other clinical disorders. In the dose of 0.5 mg/kg there was a short-lived hypotensive effect associated with slight respiratory arrest. In higher doses, there was a marked respiratory arrest, a sudden and rapid fall in blood pressure resulting in death of the animal. Chakranine (1 per cent) had positive inotropic and marked negative chronotropic effects. It had no antispasmodic effect but it produced a marked tonic contraction of uterus of guinea pig. The alkaloid in dosage 0.5 mg to 5 mg/kg i.v. chakranine orally, increased intestinal peristalsis. Administering 100 mg of LDB1150B11 of the extract was 2.2 mg/kg i.v. in the dose of 100mg/kg p.o. there was no mortality and no toxic manifestations even though the alkaloid was highly water soluble. Chakranine had no ganglion blocking activity. It showed weak antibacterial activity against I11Micrococcus pyogenes var. aureusI11 and I11Streptococcus pyogenes.I11 It was ineffective against I11Diplococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus viridans, Escherichia coli var. communis, Vibrio choleraeI11 and I11Shigella dysenteriae var. shiga.I11 Isoaristolochic acid and chakranine-free extract did not show any antibacterial activity against any of the bacteria. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) in a preliminary biological screening showed antiinflammatory activity against carrageenin-induced hind paw oedema in rat. The extract was devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, antiviral and diuretic activities and effects on isolated guinea pig ileum, rat uterus, respiration, CVS and CNS in experimental mince. The LDB1150B11 of the extract was 68.1 mg/kg i.p. in mice. The root was found to have antifungal activity against I11Helminthosporium sativum.I11 View Reference
chemical_composition: The I11nI11- hexane extract of the root contained Ã-sitosterol. The fatty acids isolated from the root were identified as palmitic, lignoceric, oleic and linoleic acids, and a yellow bitter principle identical to isoaristolochic acid was also obtained (Manjunath and Shankar Rao, 1938). Later, a crystalline alkaloidal principle named chakranine was isolated from the root (Kamat et al., 1958). Presence of steroids and carboxylic acids in the petroleum ether fraction; tannins, sugars, alkaloids and carboxylic acids in the ethanolic and aqueous fractions; and steroids, triterpenoids and carboxylic acids in the chloroform fraction were also reported (Mary et al., 1977).
