pharmacology: There being casual relationship between betel nut chewing and oro-pharyngeal cancer in human beings, the mechanisms of betel nut toxicity on the mucous membrane, cytotoxicity and carcinogenicity have been investigated in different centres. Antifertility action has also been shown. The effect of polyphenolics obtained from fresh unripe areca nuts was studied on rat uterus under various hormonal influences and compared with the effects obtained with alkaloidal fractions. The total aqueous extract and the aqueous residue after ethyl acetate extraction, which gave positive reaction to alkaloids, were spasmogens of the uterine musculature in all phases of oestrous and hormonal influences. The ethyl acetate fraction of the aqueous fraction of the aqueous extract was a stimulant of low degree on all uteri but its spasmogenic activity was comparatively more on uteri treated with progesterone. The absence of uterine contraction after oestrogen and stimulation after progesterone was markedly observed with polymerized fractions of the areca nut. The alcoholic extract of the nuts exerted distinct oxytocic activity on isolated rats uterus at a dose of 100Âµg. The oil from the nuts when administered from days 1-7 post coitum at a dose of 250 mg/kg and 500 mg/kg bw to female albino rats prevented pregnancy in 60 per cent and 80 per cent of rats, respectively, while the oil at a dose of 500 mg/kg bw exerted resorption of implants, since the one rat having implantation sites on day 10 of pregnancy did not deliver at the completion of the term. In a preliminary study, the 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the leaves was found to be devoid of hypoglycaemic action in mice. But subcutaneous administration of the alkaloid fraction of areca nut to diabetic rabbits showed that at the dosage of 0.20 and 0.25 mg/kg bw there was a reduction of about 50 per cent in blood sugar level. The crude betel nut extract and its constituent polyphenols applied locally and given orally promoted healing in incision as well as dead space wounds in male Wistar rats. In addition, they promoted epithelisation in excision wounds. Lectins from the betel nut exhibited haemagglutination pattern with various normal and enzyme treated red cells. The aqueous, alcoholic, alkaline and acid extracts of areca nuts caused constriction of capillaries to varying degrees when tested by rat hind limb perfusion technique. The water extract of areca but potentiated the adrenaline action both in intensity and duration on rat hind limb preparation. The soluble fractions present in the supernatant of the alcohol, alkali, acid and aqueous extracts as also the sediments were spasmogens on the isolated ileum and uterus of the rat. The soluble fractions showed these effects due to the presence of alkaloids and few of the polymerized components, termed phlobaphenes. Arecoline in a dose of 1 mg/kg i.p. induced slight sedation in rats at the end of 5 min in maze learning technique. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the leaves showed effects on respiration and CVS in cat./dog, and antispasmodic activity on isolated guinea pig ileum. The aqueous extract of the nuts inhibited the growth of I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Trichophyton rubrumI11 in vitro, while the alcoholic extract inhibited the growth of I11Escherichia coli, Candida albicans, C. tropicalisI11 and I11Trichophyton interdigitaleI11, Arecoline did not inhibit the growth of Staphylococcus aureus in 2 per cent concentration, while the aqueous and ethyl acetate extracts inhibited the growth even in 1/10,000 dilution. The ethyl acetate fraction, consisting of leucocyanidin, catechin and other unidentified polyphenols and the oxidized and polymerized compounds exhibited varying degree of antibacterial activity. The acetone extract of the fruits revealed antifungal activity by inhibiting the conidial germination of I11Pyricularia oryzaeI11 and I11Colletotrichum falcatum,I11 the casual agents of blast of rice and red rot of sugarcane, respectively. The action of the extract of nuts on human blood leucocytes in vitro revealed that the extract had a depressing effect on normal phagocytic function. The rats showed severe diarrhoea and died within 1-3 wk depending upon the amount of betel nut meal consumed. The foetotoxic potential of betel nuts was studied in Swiss albino mice using total aqueous extracts if ripe betel nuts of unprocessed and processed varieties when administered to pregnant animals at dose levels of 1, 3 and 5 mg/day/mouse (weighing 27Â±1g) through days of 6-15 gestation. The treatments resulted in increased resorptions as well as dead foetuses. Occurrence of leukoplakia and tumours in hamster buccal pouches after chronic topical application of dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO) extract of betel nut alone and in combination with tobacco were studied applying the extract three times a week for 21 wk. Betel nut alone resulted in the development of tumours in 38 per cent and leukoplakia in 90 per cent of animals, while the combined extracts resulted in the development of tumours in 76 per cent of the group. Betel nut aqueous extract, polyphenol fraction and tannic acid increased glutathione content, while, protein-SH and protein âSH and protein âSH +SS contents were decreased in different tissues. Arecoline decreased glutathione, protein-SH and protein -SH+SS contents in various tissues of Swiss mice. The observed decrease in glutathione level on treatment with arecoline might be first stage in the exposure of organism to carcinogenic principle from betel nut. Sun dried Mangalore betel nut extract in water and in DMSO and sun-cured Vadakkan tobacco extract in DMSO, were tested for their carcinogenicity. On subcutaneous administration of betel nut extract, 60 per cent of Swiss mice developed transplantable fibrosarcomas at the site of injection, Skin application of DMSO extracts of tobacco and of betel nut separately did not result in skin lesions in C17 mice; but when a mixed DMSO extract of tobacco and betel nut was used, skin papillomas and epidermoid carcinoma developed in some animals. In a study on carcinogenicity of some folk medicinal herbs, the total aqueous extract of areca nut in 72 subcutaneous injections administered weekly was reported to produce local tumours in 100 per cent of outbred black rats. Carcinogenicity of different preparations of betel nut in mice viz., ripe-unprocessed-sun dried nut, ripe-processed-sun dried nut, unripe-processed-sun dried nut, ripe-unprocessed-sundried water soaked nut and ripe-unprocessed undried water soaked nut, following diet-feeding or oral feeding for 12 months showed that only oral feeding unprocessed betel nuts at high doses displayed a very weak carcinogenicity. Swiss mice were injected (i.p.) with different constituents of betel nut like betel nut aqueous extract, polyphenol fraction and arecoline. All the above studied constituents were observed to increase DNA biosynthesis and RNase activity in different tissues. Aqueous extract of betel nut of North-East India induced DNA-strand breaks and enhanced rate of mouse kidney cells proliferation in vitro. It was also found to be able to enhance the rate of cell division at a dose of 100Âµg/ml while at higher dose of 250Âµg/ml was extremely toxic to the cells. Presence of aflatoxins in foods and feeds available in Tamil Nadu were studied. A total of 147 samples, consisting of scented âsupariâ (67 samples), broken processed areca nut (54 samples) and areca nut sample were found to contain aflatoxins. In a study on tannins in betel nut and its products consumed in India, the betel nuts as well as the other materials consumed in betel quid were reported to contain high levels of condensed tannins, which could cause nutritional problems, especially for people whose diets were only marginally adequate. C11ToxicologyC11 Development of tumour in animals by the extract of arecanut is reported. Chewing of betel quid (excluding tobacco) enhances levels of nitrite in oral cavity, which may promote increased generation of carcinogenic nitrosamines. Arecoline in very large doses depresses the central nervous system and paralyzes the muscles. C11Clinical StudiesC11 In an epidemiological study in North-East India, the demography and aetiology of cancer of hypo pharynx and larynx with special reference to betel nut chewing habit was studied. The relative frequency of cancer based on examination of biopsy tissues was assessed. The local raw betel nut chewing habit was found to be of considerable significance especially among the females in the causaton of hypopharyngeal cancer. A relationship between betel quid chewing and buccal mucosa cancer was studied in patients of South India. Out of the 3529 new cancer patients, 362 were buccal mucosa or gingiva. Detailed history of the patients, clinical examination and histopathology showed there was evidence for direct contact of the betel quid with the development of mucosal cancer. Powder of Areca catechu, Samalia malabarica, Mimusops Elengi, Woodfordia fruticosa and Cichorium intybus were used in the form of vaginal tablets in single blind technique in twenty five patients of vaginal discharge. Significant improvement was observed in 15 days of treatment. AC-4, a composite drug containing Embelia ribes, Laccardia lacca, Areca catechu and Saraca asoca in equal parts, when administered orally (1g/day in two divided doses) to 281 women for 15 days (4th day of menstrual cycle to 18th day) exhibited good contraceptive activity. There was no pregnancy due to drug failure after 10th cycle. No toxic symptoms or severe side effects were noticed. View Reference
chemical_composition: In earlier investigation carried out in Europe, five alkaloids viz., arecoline, arecaidine, guvacoline, guvacine and arecolidine were isolated from the nuts and they were considered to constitute the active principles especially as anthelmintic. A detailed analysis, however, revealed that the young and mature nuts contained (+)-catechin and leucocyanidin. In another study, it was found that polymeric proanthocyanidins dominated and their separation by simple means was difficult and therefore, a combination of methods was used for their separation. There was considerable variation in the stage of polymerization depending on the maturity of the nuts. The tannins of the tender, mature and ripe nuts were analyzed. The percentage of tannins in the three nuts was 44.09, 40.35 and 38.56 per cent, respectively. Besides these, the extracts of the nuts were found to contain (+)-catechin and a dextrorotatory isomer of leucocyanidin (5, 7, 3â, 4â-tetrahydroxyflavan-3, 4-diol). The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the leaves in another study was devoid of tannins in a preliminary chemical study. The chemical analysis of the nuts showed the presence of moisture, tannins, fats and other insolubles (42.4 per cent) (Banerjee et al., 1960). The fatty acid analysis of areca nut fat revealed the chief component acids as lauric (19.5 per cent), myristic (46.2 per cent), and palmitic (1.7 per cent) and the unsaturated acids as oleic (6.2 per cent), lineoleic (5.4 per cent) and hexadecenoic (7.2 per cent) acids, Minor proportions of stearic, decenoic and of unsaturated monoethylenic CB1112B11 and CB1114B11 acids were also present. The chief component glycerides were 56 per cent of fully saturated (trimyristin, dimyristin and lauromyristopalmitin); 30 per cent of mono-unsaturated-disaturated (mainly hexadecenolauromyristin with some oleo-(linoleo) mysristopalmitins and dimyristins) and 14 per cent of diunsaturated-monosaturated (oleolinoleoglycerides, mostly oleolinoleopalmitin). The fully saturated components were found to contain 19.4 per cent of stearic acids. The occurrence of Ã-sitosterol in the nut was reported. Ripe and semi-ripe areca nuts obtained from Kerala were found to have a large number of amino acids both in free and combined state. The distinguishing features of the amino acid make up were absence or insignificant quantity of tryptophan and methionine, presence of high percentage of proline in both free and combined forms and relative increase of free tyrosine and phenylalanine and of combined arginine in the semi-ripe and ripe nuts. Various aspects of areca nut have been reviewed by Arjungi (1976).

pharmacology: The experimental studies on A. mexicana were primarily devoted to the mechanism of argemone toxicity in view of epidemics of dropsy due to adulteration of edible oils with argemone oil. The antifertility and antimicrobial actions of argemone lose importance due to its potential toxicity. The effects of two alkaloids berberine and sanguinarine was studied in vitro on human pregnancy plasma diamine oxidase (histaminase). At a concentration of 5x 10P11-6P11 mole both the alkaloids inhibited more than 50 per cent activity of the enzyme. The three isoquinoline alkaloids characterized from the seeds viz., dihydropalmatine hydroxide (I), berberine (II) and protopine (III) when administered to male dogs at a dose level of 30 mg/kg for 70d induced inhibition of spermatogenesis at the stage XII of late spermatids. The aqueous extract of the leaves at the doses of 30, 60 and 120 mg/kg i.p. possessed significant antiinflammatory activity against carrageenin-induced rat paw oedema. The crude latex of the plant showed low grade anticoagulant activity and normal fibrinolysis in rabbit plasma. The total alkaloidal fraction obtained from the root and the stem produced a fall in blood pressure of anesthetized dogs at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg and more. Protopine fraction produced a rise in blood pressure in smaller concentrations and fall in higher doses. Berberine fraction produced only a fall in blood pressure. The respiration was stimulated by total alkaloidal fraction when given intravenously. The total alkaloids also stimulated the smooth muscles and antagonized the action of acetylcholine, histamine and 5-hydroxytryptamine. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant in preliminary biological screening revealed effect on respiration in dog/cat and antiviral activity against Ranikhet disease virus. Both the alcoholic and aqueous extracts of the fruits showed antibacterial activity against Escherichia coli. The extract in another study was active against I11Bacillus pumilus (+), Pseudomonas mangiferae indicae (-), Salmonella paratyphi (-), Staphylococcus albus (+)I11 and I11Xanthomonas campestris (-).I11 The oil obtained from the plant showed in vitro antibacterial activity by various methods against I11Micrococcus pyogenes var. aureus, Mic pyogenes var. albus, Mic pyogenes var. citreus, Bacillus subtilis, Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Salmonella typhosa, Salm paratyphi I11A and B, I11Escherichia coli, Proteus vulgarisI11and I11Pseudomonas pyocyanea.I11 The crude extract of the root showed antifungal activity against I11Helminthosporium sativumI11 (94.5 per cent), I11Colletotrichum falcatumI11 (81.5 per cent) and I11Fusarium oxysporumI11 (78.0 per cent). The aqueous extract of the leaves showed moderate antifungal activity in treated bananas infested with I11Botryodiplodia theobramae, Fusarium oxysporum, Helminthosporium speciferum, Curvularia lunata, Aspergillus flavus and Trichothecium roseumI11 (causing banana root- rot). In ringworm fungi, the extract of the leaves showed moderate activity against I11Trichophyton mentagrophytes and Microsporum gypseumI11 while the poor activity against I11Epidermophyton floccosum.I11 The extract of the healthy twigs/ whole plant was found to have antifungal activity against I11Penicillium chrysogenum, P. notatum, Aspergillus niger, Mucor sp. and Curvularia tuberculata.I11 The extract of the bark was found to have some antiviral activity against potato virus X. The juice obtained from the seeds inhibited the infectivity of top necrosis virus of pea. The crude extract of the leaves showed 59.22 per cent inhibition of groundnut mosaic virus I11in vitro.I11 The extract of the shoots inhibited the larvae of I11Meloidogyne javanicaI11 infesting the leaves of ladyâs finger. The oil obtained from the seeds showed nematicidal activity against the larvae of I11Meloidogyne incognitaI11 when applied to soil or to the leaves of inoculated ladyâs finger plants. Exposure to 40 per cent and 80 per cent sublethal concentrations (24h LC B1150 B11) of the molluscicidal components protopine and sanguinarine from the plant revealed a significant decrease in the levels of protein, free amino acid, DNA and RNA in the nervous tissue of I11Lymnae acuminata.I11 Argemone oil is more toxic than certain brand oils viz., olive oil and liquid paraffin, but if the oil is heated to a stage at which it fumes well (at 240ÂºC for 15 min), its toxicity was not much more than that of the brand oils or liquid paraffin. Pure argemone oil administered orally, injected or painted on the ratâs skin produced capillary reaction only on the skin; the oil or the products of its breakdown were excreted chiefly if not exclusively through the skin. Controlled studies on the toxicity of argemone oil carried out in monkeys, suggested that 0.05 ml of the oil/kg bw was associated with some toxic manifestations, while 0.025 ml/kg bw did not produce any toxic symptoms over a period of 60d. The effect of argemone oil feeding on blood biochemistry and tissue changes in albino rats of both sexes was studied. Histopathological changes in liver showed increased fibrosis, hyperplasia of bile ducts and congestion in a few portal tracts. Lings of argemone oil fed animals indicated congestion and thickening of interalveolar septa. Alveolar spaces were disorganized and irregular. Kidneys showed vascular and glomerular congestion and patchy tubular lesions. Parenteral administration of argemone oil (5ml/kg bw) daily for 3d produced a significant increase in both non-enzymatic and NADPH-supported enzymatic lipid peroxidation in whole homogenate, mitochondria and microsomes in rats. The total alkaloids of argemone on i.p. or s.c administration in rats for 3 to 6 wk produced ascites, diarrhoea, loss of hair and loss of weight in 66 per cent of rats. The alkaloids stimulated the growth of vessels which formed a dense plexus very prone to haemorrhage. A number of reviews featuring the epidemiology, toxicology, clinical features, treatment, chemistry, pharmacognosy of I11A. mexicanaI11 have appeared from time to time. The aetiology, pathophysiology, mechanism, diagnosis, prognosis and prevention of epidemic dropsy due to argemone oil has been dealt in some of the reviews: Chakravarthi (1953); Thatte and Dahanukar (1999); Sharma et al., (1999); Bhatt and Krishnamachari (1978). Experimental production of syndrome of epidemic dropsy in human beings (Bhatia and Malaviya, 1951) was made in order to study the exact mechanism of epidemic dropsy. C11Clinical Studies C11 Clinical studies including case reports have been carried out on a various aspects of epidemic dropsy. While only the references are being given no details are being covered. These are the cutaneous manifestations; optic disc vasculitis; ocular manifestations; cardiovascular manifestations (Sanghvi, 1960); hepatomegaly (hepatic alterations); hypermelanosis of the skin; pigmentation, hair loss and non-tender hepatomegaly; sedimentation rate of blood cells. There have been a number of records of epidemic dropsies in different parts of the country as a result of consumption of edible oils adulterated with argemone oil, which is either mixed accidentally or purposefully. Ingestion of this contaminated oil can often lead to fatal epidemic dropsy. The liver, heart, kidney and lungs are the major target organs of the toxins (the alkaloids sanguinarine and dihydrosanguinarine) and damage is mostly caused by free radical (singlet oxygen) and hydroxyl radical to the cell membranes. A large number of epidemics have occurred all over India. Some of these were the epidemic dropsy in Surada, a village in Ganjam district; West Bengal; Bombay; Chandrapur (Maharashtra ); Sirpur Kaghaznagar township of Andhra Pradesh; North Delhi; Palam area of Delhi; Rajasthan; Barbanki district of Uttar Pradesh; Trans Yamuna areas of Delhi and Uttar Pradesh. View Reference
chemical_composition: The plant yielded three known alkaloids (Â±) cheilanthifoline, protopine and norsanguinarine. This was the first report of the isolation of (Â± )-cheilanthifoline from the species (Tripathi et al., 1999). From the latex of the plant berberine (0.74 per cent) and two bases were isolated. One of the bases was identified as protopine. In addition, presence of I11LI11-glutamine, hydroxyproline, threonine, Ã-alanine and methionine was also indicated (Santra and Saoji, 1971). The stem revealed the presence of protopine and berberine. Besides the alkaloids, other constituents found were tannins, resins and an unidentified toxic principle in the oil (Bose et al., 1963). The petroleum ether extract of the flowers was found to contain isorhamnetin (4â, 5, 7- trihydroxy-3â-methoxyflavonol) and two of its glycosides, isorhamnetin-3-glucoside and isorhamnetin-3,7-diglucoside. Seasonal variations of flavonol glycosides in the flowers. In addition. The flowers contained 3-methoxyquercetin and vanilic acid. The chloroform extract of the flowers was found to contain cryptopine and Ã-sitosterol. The ethanolic extract of the leaves when fractionated with petroleum ether and ethyl acetate revealed the presence of Ã-amyrin in the petroleum ether fraction and isorhamnetin-3-glucoside in the ethyl acetate fraction. The aqueous layer revealed the presence of cysteine and phenylalanine. Two new aliphatic compounds were isolated from the leaves which were identified as 6, 11-triacontanediol (mexicanol) and 10-hydroxyheptadec- I11cisI11-4-enoic (mexicanic acid). The earliest report on the chemical investigation on the plant was the study of Argemone oil from which a colourless crystalline free base, representing a part of the complex molecule of the toxic substance present in the oil was isolated. Chemical composition of argemone oil and reported two physiologically active alkaloids. The major alkaloid was identified as dihydrosanguinarine (87 per cent of the total alkaloids) and the other alkaloid was identified a sanguinarine (5 per cent of the total alkaloids). (Misra et al., 1961a) isolated these alkaloids in an yield of 2 per cent from the oil. The seed oil, in addition, was found to contain 1 per cent hydroxy, 2 per cent (mostly I11cisI11, but possibly some I11transI11) epoxy and keto fatty acids besides myristic (0.5 per cent), palmitic (14.9 per cent), oleic (29.2 per cent) and linoleic (55.4 per cent) acids. Three other fatty acids were isolated from the seed oil, two of which were characterized as 11-oxotriacontanoic acid and 11- hydroxytriacontanoic acid and the third fatty acid namely argemonic acid was an unusual long chain fatty acid identified as (+)-6-hydroxy-6-methyl-9-oxo-octacosanoic acid. The seed oil samples from Jamaica and India on reverse phase chromatography revealed the presence of myristic (0,1), palmitic (9,12), stearic (5,5), arachidic (0,1),oleic (33,23) and linoleic 1-2 per cent, if present. Two new phenolic compounds 5,7,2â6â-tetrahydroxyflavone (argemexitin) and 5, 7-dihydroxychromone 7-neohesperidoside were isolated from the seeds (Bhardwaj et al., 1982).

author: Daly.
description: A very large climber; stems stout, white-tomentose. Leaves 7.5-30 by 3.25-25 cm (sometimes even larger), ovate, acute, glabrous above, persistently white-tomentose beneath, base cordate; petioles 5-15 cm long, white-tomentose. Flowers in subcapitate cymes; peduncles 7.5-15 cm long, stout, white-tomentose; bracts large, ovate-lanceolate with along acumen, thin, veined, pubescent outside, glabrous inside, deciduous, the outer sometimes 5 cm long; pedicels very short; often almost 0, white-tomentose. Calyx white-tomentose outside; sepals 5, nearly 1.6 cm long, oblong-elliptic, obtuse. Corolla 5-6.25 cm long, tubular-infundibuliform, the bands silky-pubescent outside; tube somewhat inflated, white-pubescent outside, rose-purple and glabrous inside. Stamens 5, included; anthers oblong, straight. Disk annular. Ovary glabrous, 4-celled; ovules 4; style filiform; stigma 2, globose. Fruit a dry hard berry 2 cm in diam., globose, apiculate. Seeds 4 or fewer, embedded in mealy pulp.

locations.place: Shenbagathoppu â top (Grizzled Squirrel Wildlife Sanctuary)

locations.vegetation: Tropical semi evergreen to evergreen forest

pharmacology: The alcoholic extract of the root exhibited statistically antiinflammatory activity against granuloma formation technique in albino rats which was comparable to acetylsalicylic acid. The extract did not show much activity against formalin-induced arthritis in rats. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the seeds in a preliminary biological screening showed effect on CVS in dog/cat. The extract also exhibited antispasmodic activity on the isolated guinea pig ileum. The alcoholic extract of the leaves revealed antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 but was inactive against I11Escherichia coliI11. The aqueous extract was inactive against both the bacteria. The seed oil was found to possess in vitro antibacterial activity against I11Klebsiella sp., Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosaI11 and I11Bacillus anthracisI11 (Mishra and Chaturvedi, 1978; Batra and Mehta, 1985), I11Salmonella typhi, Salm paratyphi, Shigella boydii, Sh flexneri, Streptococcus ?-haemolyticusI11 and I11Bacillus subtilis.I11 The seed oil also showed antifungal activity against I11Aspergillus flavus, Colletotrichum capsici, Cryptococcus neoformans, Alternaria solani.I11 Hexadecanyl p-hydroxycinnamate and scopoletin isolated from the root were tested for antifungal activity against I11Fusarium fusiformis, F. semitectumI11 and I11Alternaria alternata.I11 At a concentration of 1000 ppm both the compounds produced 100 per cent inhibition against I11Alternaria alternataI11. The compounds also revealed phytotoxicity in terms of root growth inhibition of germinating wheat seeds. The extract of the plant and fruits had interferon-like antiviral activity against vaccinia virus in CAM cultures, but was devoid of any activity against Ranikhet disease virus. The effect of the aqueous and a alcoholic extracts of the leaves on the spontaneous movements of both the adult worm and a nerve/muscle preparation of I11Setaria cervi, I11 a filarial worm of cattle, and on the survival of microfilariae in vitro was studied. The aqueous extract in a dose of 150Âµg/ml caused a decrease in tone and amplitude of spontaneous movements of the worm. A similar response was produced by the alcoholic extract but at a much lower concentration of 75Âµg/ml. The aqueous extract produced complete paralysis of the nerve/muscle preparation in a dose 25Âµg/ml whereas with alcoholic extract only 50Âµg/ml was required. View Reference
chemical_composition: The seeds yielded a fatty oil which was found to contain the glycerides of palmitic, stearic, linolenic, linoleic and oleic acids (Kelkar et al., 1947). In another study, the seed oil revealed the presence of myristoleic, myristic, palmitic, linolenic, oleic, stearic, nonadecanoic, eicosenoic, heneicosanoic and behenic acids identified as their corresponding methyl ester through GLC. Presence of branched fatty acids 12-methylmyristic acid and 15-methylstearic acid was also reported (Batra and Mehta, 1985). The fruits were reported to contain I11nI11-triacontanol, Ã-sitosterol, I11pI11-hydroxycinnamoyl octadecanolate and caffeic acid (Purshothaman et al., 1982). The petroleum ether extracts of the leaves yielded 1-triacontanol, epifriedelinol acetate, epifriedelinol and Ã-sitosterol (Sahu and Chakravarthi, 1971). The leaves were found rich in quercetin. Extraction of the leaves with 90 per cent methanol led to the isolation of flavonoids, quercetin and kaempferol together with the latterâs glycoside kaempferol 3- I11OI11-L-rhamnopyranoside (Khan et al., 1992). Two new flavone glycosides characterized as 7,8,3â,4â,5â-pentahydroxyflavone 5- I11OI11- S224-L-rhamnopyranoside and 7,8,3â,4â,5â-penthahydroxyflavone 5- I11OI11-Ã-D-glucopyranoside were also reported from leaves. The hexane extract of the root yielded tetradecanyl palmitate, 5,8-oxidotetracosan-10-one I11pI11-hydroxycinnamate and hexadecanyl I11pI11-hydroxycinnamate along with scopoletin (Srivastava and Shukla, 1998). The ethanolic extract of the seeds revealed a mixture of three alkaloids, out of which only one was characterized as ergometrine. The other constituents isolated were caffeic acid and ethyl caffeate (Agarwal and Rastogi, 1974). Another study also revealed the presence of ergoline alkaloids in the seeds. The ergolines were indicated to be of clavinet type (Nair et al., 1987). Some aspects of chemical and pharmacological studies on the plant have been reviewed by Srivastava and associates (1998).

author: Nimmo.
description: Perennial tuberous herbs. Leaf solitary, peltate, broadly ovate or orbicular or suborbicular. Flowers unisexual in spadix shorter than spathes. Male flowers embedded in spadix. Female flowers few, crowded at the base of spadix; ovary 1-celled, secund. Berries angled.

The activity was stable up to 70ÂºC (Shet and Madaiah, 1988). View Reference

author: Retz.
description: Perennial herbs. Culms terete, tufted, from a woody base. Leaves convolute, linear-lanceolate, base rounded or shallowly cordate; apex acuminate. Inflorescence a contracted panicle; rachis slender; smooth; branches filiform or capillary. Spikelets erect. Lower involucral glume awned, 1-nerved; upper involucral glume longer than the lower, with a hyaline margin, 1-nerved. Floral glumes 3-nerved. Stamens 3. Ovary superior, styles free, Stigma penicillate.Grain narrow, cylindric.

author: L.
description: Woody twining, glabrous, perennial herbs. Leaves simple and alternate, variable in size, reaching 10 cm long; linear-oblong to obovate-oblong, glabrous, with some what undulate margins, base cuneate, rounded or subcordate. Infloroscence a few-flowered axillary raceme. Perianth greenish-white, with globose inflated base, then narrowed into a cylindric tube with oblique mouth and linear -oblong, obtuse brownish lip; perianth hairy within. Stamens 6, adnate above the ovary. Ovary inferior, more or less 6-celled, ovules many on parietal placenta; style columnar, divided above into 6 lobes. Fruit a capsule; 3 to 5 cm long, oblong, opening from below upwards, 6-valved. Seeds flat, winged, fragrant.
pharmacology: Different extracts and fractions of I11A. indicaI11 root showed uterofoetal death and its subsequent resorption (interceptive effect) in mice. Chloroform soluble acidic fraction of ethanolic extract showed interceptive activity in mice and hamster, which could be reversed by exogenous administration of progesterone and prolactin. A sesquiterpene isolated from the root exerted interceptive activity and antiimplantation activity in adult mice and antioestrogenic activity in immature female mice. Ethanolic and petroleum ether extracts inhibited estrogen production, and eventually produced sterility in female rats. Aristolic acid was found to be antioestrogenic and has antiimplantation effect in mice. It interfered with steroidal conditioning of the uterus and rendered it unsuitable for ovum implantation. A methyl ester of aristolic acid showed abortifacient activity. p-Coumaric acid isolated from the plant showed interceptive activity. It induced alteration in estrus cycle, ovarian and uterine weight and had no marked effect on the estrogen-primed immature female mice. It also caused loss of libido, decrease in weight of testis and accessory sex organs, decrease in fructose content of coagulating gland and reduction in acid phosphatase activity in prostrate, which could be reversed by administration of prolactin and testosterone propionate. p- Coumaric acid showed high margin of safety (>1000mg/kg) and did not show teratogenic effect. The ethanolic extract of root showed antimicrobial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Escherichia coli.I11 Aqueous and ethanolic extracts of root showed cytotoxic activity against KB cell lines (EDB1150B11 3 to 5Âµg/ml) and against adenocarcinoma 755 as well as against lymphocytic luekaemia PB11388B11 in vivo. Aristolochic acid showed mutagenic activity in Ameâs test while aristolic and aristolactam acid were not mutagenic. Aristolochic acid acted as a competitive inhibitor of phospholipase AB112B11 enzyme in snake venom. It also inhibited the oedema-inducing activity of phospholipase AB112B11 obtained from human synovial fluid. The methyl ester of aristolic acid produced damage to liver and kidney. The treated animal also exhibited cannibalism. The crude petroleum ether, chloroform and alcoholic extracts of the root administered orally at the single dose of 100 mg/kg bw given at the post implantation period showed 100 per cent interceptive activity in mature female mice. The aqueous, alcoholic and petroleum ether extracts of the root at 1:20 concentration affected the oestrous cycle adversely ending at the dioestrous stage in female Wistar rats. The water soluble acidic part of the alcoholic extract of the root showed 100 per cent interceptive activity at a single dose of 50 mg/kg orally in mice and hamsters. No such activity was observed in the case of rats in which there was only delayed parturition. Aristolic acid isolated from the root given in the dose of 60 mg/kg bw prevented oestrogen-induced weight increase and epithelial growth of mouse uterus. A single oral dose of aristolic acid at the dose levels of 120 and 90 mg/kg on day 1 or day 6 of pregnancy in mouse resulted in a rise of acid phosphates and fall of alkaline phosphatase and protein in uterus in both groups. The methyl ester of aristolic acid isolated from the root was found to exert 100 per cent abortifacient activity at a single oral dose of 60 mg/kg bw when administered on sixth or seventh day of pregnancy in mice; 20 and 25 per cent abortifacient activities were observed at the same dose on day 10 and 12 post coitum, respectively in the animals. The water soluble part of the chloroform fraction of the root when fed orally at a dose of 75 mg/kg caused degenerative changes of varying degrees in the seminiferous germinal cell components with prominent nuclear degeneration in all cell types. There was a significant reduction in the fluid content in the accessory sex organs of the experimental mice indicating an impaired endocrine function of the testis. In adult male rats, oral administration of p-coumaric acid in doses of 50 mg/kg/day for 56d produced complete loss of libido, significant decrease in the weight of the testis and accessory sex organs, decrease in the fructose content of the coagulating gland and a reduction in the acid phosphatase activity in the prostrate. The water soluble portion of the alcoholic extract of the plant at a dose of 100 mg/100g i.p. administered in albino rats for 16d was found to exhibit antiinflammatory action. Aristolic acid was not found mutagenic to bacterial system. On the other hand aristolochic acid, analogue of aristolic acid, was mutagenic. The juice of the root was found to have relaxant effect on the rhythmic contractions of uteri of rats and human beings. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant in a preliminary biological screening revealed diuretic activity in rat. The ethanolic extract of the root showed antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Escherichia coliI11 while the aqueous extract found to be devoid of any activity against both the organisms. The aqueous and ethanolic extracts of the seeds in vitro studies were devoid of antimicrobial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococuss aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes, Strept viridans. Diplococcus pneumoniae, Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Escherichia coli, Salmonella typhi, Salm paratyphiI11 A and B, I11Shigella flexneri, Sh sonnei, Candida albicans, C. tropicalis, Microsporum canis, M. gypseum, M. nanum, Trichophyton mentagrophytes, T. rubrum, Piedraria hortae, Trichosporon cutaneum, Madurella mycetomy, Cryptococcus neoformans, Histoplasma capsulatumI11 and I11Phialophora jeanselmei.I11 The extract of the root showed antifungal activity against I11Helminthosporium sativum.I11 Feeding male houseflies with 0.075 per cent aristolochic acid obtained from the plant induced sterility. The hexane extract of the root showed insecticidal activity against the adults of I11Culex p. fatigans.I11 View Reference
chemical_composition: The oil of the root was found to contain glycerides of palmitic, stearic, lignoceric, cerotic, oleic and linoleic acids; sitosterol, ceryl alcohol, isoaristolochic acid, reducing sugars and an alkaloid, aristolochine. The oil also contained ishwarene, ishwarone and ishwarol (Krishna Rao et al., 1935). Presence of (+) camphor and ledol was also reported in the oil. From the air dried plant, isolation of methyl ester of 12-nonacosenoic acid was reported for the first time. The phenanthrene alkaloids aristolochic acid, aristolochine, and other polysubstituted phenanthrene derivatives are the significant constituents of the plant. The alkaloid, aristolochine and the sesquiterpene ishwarone (Krishnarao et al.,, 1935) were later identified as I11lI11-curine and as novel tetracyclic sesquiterpene ketone based on remophilane skeleton, respectively. The absolute stereochemistry of ishwarone was established by chemical correlation (+)-nootkane, as also based on spectral and chemical evidence l; The structure of ishwarol was assigned in correlation with the structure of ishwarone. Further, three new sesquiterpene hydrocarbons, ishwarane, aristolochene and 5ÃH, 7 Ã,10? -selina-4(14),11-diene were isolated from the oil. Besides aristolochic acid, aristolochic acid-D and aristolactam- Ã-D-glucoside are reported, five more phenanthrene derivatives hitherto unknown in nature were isolated from the root. These were compound A, an ester; compound B designated as aristolic acid; compound C designated as aristolamide; compound D and compound E designated as methyl aristolochate. In addition, stigmast-4-en-3-one, not reported from any Aristolochia species so far; sitosterol; two uncharacterized isomeric sesquiterpene alcohols and I11pI11-coumaric acid were also reported (Pakrashi et al., 1977). Two isomeric sesquiterpene alcohols (12S)-7,12-secoishwaran-12-ol and (+)-ledol; a phenanthrene derivative aristololactam N- Ã-D-glucoside and the steroids 3 Ã-hydroxystigmast05-en-7-one cepharadione A, aristololactam AII and Ã-sitosterol- Ã-D-glucoside; aristololide, a phenanthroid lactone, 5?-stigmastane-3-6-dione,(-)-cubebin and (-)-hinokinin were isolated from the root. The structure of 8-methyl-juglone, aristolindiquinone isolated earlier from the plant was established on the basis of its synthesis from I11OI11-ally- I11pI11-cresol. The 13C NMR spectra of compounds related to aristolochic acid and aristolactam were studied in detail to determine the chemical shifts and coupling constants of polysubstituted phenanthrenes (Achari et al., 1984).

author: Sivarajan & Pradeep
description: Twining herbs with angular branches. Leaves alternate, simple, 7-16 X 2.5-5 cm, oblong-lanceolate, long-acuminate, truncate to subcordate at base, 5-ribbed. Inflorescence few-flowered monochasial racemes. Flowers 3-merous, zygomorphic. Perianth tubular; tube 0.2-0.25 cm long, with bulbous base 0.5-0.6 cm across; limb brown, oblique, 2-2.5 cm long, 0.6-1 cm wide. Stylar column 6-lobed. Fruit a capsule; 1.5-2X1-1.5 cm, ovoid, drooping, 6-ridged, splitting at upper part and hanging like a basket.

author: Cham.
description: An extensively climbing perennial shrub with stout glabrous stem; Leaves 10-21 cm long, ovate or ovate oblong, acute or acuminate, base cordate with narrow sinus; petioles twining. Inflorescence an axillary many flowered raceme. Flowers hermaphrodite, numerous, but most of them abortive, usually only 1 fertile. Perianth base globose, greenish-yellow, tube curved, mouth oblique. Stamens 6, adnate to the top of the ovary, anthers dehiscing dorsally. Ovary inferior. Fruit a capsule 2.5-3.5 cm long, oblong-ellipsoid, the pedicel splitting into 6 filaments in fruit. Seeds flat, winged, fragrant when bruised.

author: Benth.
description: A large, erect herb 60-90 cm high sparingly branched with acutely triangular stems often tinged with purple. Leaves simple, opposite, 3.7-15 by 1-4.5 cm, lanceolate or acuminate, entire or serrate. Inflorescence a terminal raceme. Flowers large, hermaphrodite, irregular; pedicels .6-1.5 cm long; bracts beneath the pedicels .6-.8 cm long, lanceolate, acute. Calyx 5-partite; .8-1 cm long, segments herbaceous divided to the base; sepals ovate, acute, nearly glabrous, much imbricate. Corolla 2-lipped dull violet-purple; 2-2.1 cm long, reticulately veined; upper lip broad, emarginated; lower lip spreading, 3-fid. Stamens 4, perfect, didynamous; filaments of the lower stamens long, arching, dilated and furnished with a discoid appendage at the base. Ovary 2-celled; ovules many in each cell; stigma 2-lamellate. Fruit a capsule; globose .6-1 cm in diam., glabrous. Seeds .5 mm long, oblong rounded or truncate at the ends, covered with white tubercles, yellowish..

Leaves simple, opposite, 3.7-15 by 1-4.5 cm, lanceolate or acuminate, entire or serrate. Inflorescence a terminal raceme. Flowers large, hermaphrodite, irregular; pedicels .6-1.5 cm long; bracts beneath the pedicels .6-.8 cm long, lanceolate, acute. Calyx 5-partite; .8-1 cm long, segments herbaceous divided to the base; sepals ovate, acute, nearly glabrous, much imbricate. Corolla 2-lipped dull violet-purple; 2-2.1 cm long, reticulately veined; upper lip broad, emarginated; lower lip spreading, 3-fid. Stamens 4, perfect, didynamous; filaments of the lower stamens long, arching, dilated and furnished with a discoid appendage at the base. Ovary 2-celled; ovules many in each cell; stigma 2-lamellate. Fruit a capsule; globose .6-1 cm in diam., glabrous. Seeds .5 mm long, oblong rounded or truncate at the ends, covered with white tubercles, yellowish..

author: (Clarke) Pampan.
description: Perennial pubescent or villous, aromatic shrubs. Leaves alternate. Lower leaves petioled, ovate, deeply pinnatisect, white -tomentose beneath. Upper leaves smaller, 3-fid or entire, lanceolate. Infloroscence a head, solitary or 2-3 together in spicate panicled racemes; outer flowers female, inner bisexual. Corolla of female flowers slender, tubular; corolla of bisexual flower regular, tubular. Stamens 5, inserted on the corolla. Outer involucral bracts smaller than the inner. Ovary 1-celled, ovule solitary, erect; style slender; stigma 2-fid. Fruit an achene; oblong -ellipsoid.
pharmacology: The ethanolic extract of root at doses of 640 and 320 mg/kg doses s.c. prolonged the survival time of I11Plasmodium bergheiI11 infection in mice for a period of 60d in in vivo studies. The aqueous extract of the fruits caused immediate rise of both systolic and diastolic blood pressure of anaesthetized dogs. The respiratory rate was increased but amplitude was diminished. The drug showed direct stimulant action on frog myocardium. A direct spasmogenic action on guinea pig and rabbit gut was shown by the extract. It also showed anthelmintic activity against tapeworms. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant in a preliminary biological screening was found to be devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, antiprotozoal, anthelmintic, antiviral, hypoglycaemic, diuretic and anticancer activities and effects on isolated guinea pig ileum, respiration, nictitating membrane, CVS and CNS in experimental animals, The antibacterial and antifungal activities of the freshly extracted essential oil (1:1000 dilution) from the air dried leaves was tested against seven bacteria and three fungi viz., I11Staphylococcus aureus, Staph aureusI11 (H57), I11Salmonella typhi, Escherichia coli, Proteus vulgaris, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Candida albicans, C. utilisI11 and I11Aspergillus nigerI11 by the serial dilution method. The extract was found to be active against I11Staphylococcus aureus, Staph aureusI11 (H57), I11Klebsiella pneumoniae, Pseudomonas aeruginosaI11 and I11Aspergillus niger.I11 The oil obtained from the leaves in the doses of 250, 500 and 1000 ppm showed different degree of fungitoxicity against various human pathogenic fungi viz., Absidia ramosa, I11Aspergillus fumigatusI11 (100 per cent), I11Blastomyces dermatidis, Microsporum canis, M. gallinae, M. ferrugineum, M. gypseumI11 (100 per cent), I11Epidermophyton floccosumI11 (100 per cent), I11Phialophora compactumI11 (100 per cent), I11P.jeansemei, P. melinii, P. pedrosoi, Trichophyton mentagrophytes, T. rubrum, T. soudanenseI11 and I11T. violaceumI11 (100 per cent). The 80 per cent ethanolic extract of the leaves revealed antibacterial activity against a number of bacteria using the agar dilution method. The extract was active against I11Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Bacillus subtilisI11 and I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 at concentrations of 25, 26, 6.25 and 6.25 mg/ml, respectively. The hexane and acetone extracts of the plant showed marked insecticidal activity against the larvae and adults of I11Culex p. fatigansI11 and I11Musca domestica.I11 The insecticidal principle was identified as capelin (1-phenyl-2, 4-hexadiyn-1-one). View Reference
chemical_composition: The plant which occurs in several parts of India was reported to yield an essential oil (0.34 per cent). The oil contained I11pI11-cymene, (-)-linalool, Ã-thujone, an azulenen and Ã-thujyl alcohol (free and combined). The oil also contained an unidentified hydrocarbon. The oil resembled the commercially important American I11A. absinthiumI11 oil possessing aromatic and medicinal properties (Rao and Sood, 1964). In another study, the essential oil was reported to contain 1, 8-cineole, (+)-limonene, terpinolene, fenchone, (-)-thujone, thujyl alcohol, linalool, citral A and B, geraniol and aromadendrene. The study of oil from three different altitudes and climates viz., Nainital (ht 2010 m), Ratighat (ht (1320 m) and Garampani (ht 900 m) in Kumaun region revealed that lower altitude, rainfall and higher temperature favoured the formation of oxygenated compounds, while the higher altitude, rainfall and lower temperature favoured the formation of hydrocarbons but inhibited the formation of the essential oil from the plant (Sinha and Baslas, 1968). The physico-chemical constants of the oil from different localities were also reported. The oils extracted from the plants from Nepal and Bhutan were found to contain camphor (major component), (+)-limonene, S224-and Ã-pinene, Delta-carene, linalool, 1,8-cineol, thujone and citral. The chemical composition of the oil was compared with rosemary oil produced in United States. In view of the similarity in composition and aroma, the oil appeared to have a potential as substitute to rosemary oil used in perfumery. The plant collected from Almora, Pithorgarh and Jogeshwar of Kumaun hills yielded 0.3 â 0.45 per cent of essential oil. The essential oil from the aerial parts of the plant from Garhwal in Himalayas was reported to contain camphor Ã-eudesmol, 1, 8-cineol, borneol, Artemisia, camphene, Ã-pinene as the main constituents besides many other minor constituents (Uniyal et al., 1985). A new pentacyclic triterpene alcohol, fernenol was isolated from petroleum ether extract of the plant (Kundu et al, 1968). In addition, (-) thujone, stigmasterol, Ã-sitosterol, S224-amyrin and its acetate and three hydrocarbons designated as A, B and C were also obtained (Kundu et al., 1969). In a preliminary study, the leaves were reported to contain alkaloids, saponins and flavonoids while tannins were found to be absent The I11nI11âbutanol extractive of the dried leaves yielded an inositol whose structure was established as L-2-O âmethyl- I11chiroI11-inositol (L-quebrachitol) (Agarwal and Singh, 1994).

author: Buch.-Ham. ex Roxb.
description: Inodorous obliquely ascending, branched shrubs. Leaves 2.5-5 by 1.25- 2 cm, sessile; the lower usually simple, cuneate, with a variously toothed or lobed apex and with some linear stipuliform segments at the base, deep green on both sides, glabrous or slightly pubescent, not hoary-tomentose; the uppermost floral leaves minute, entrire. Infloroscence a head; very numerous in panicled racemes; outer flowers (ray florets) female, fertile; inner flowers (disc florets), bisexual, sterile. Involucral bracts glabrous, ovate, acute. Calyx tube adherent to the ovary. Corolla epigynous, gamopetalous, tubular. Stamens 5, inserted on the corolla. Ovary 1-celled; ovule solitary, erect. Fruit an achene; minute, ellipsoid, smooth, brown.
pharmacology: The ethanolic and petroleum ether extracts of the aerial parts showed in vivo antimalarial activity against drug sensitive I11Plasmodium bergheiI11 infections in mice at doses of 640 and 320 mg/kg s.c. and prolonged the survival time of mice up to a period of 60d. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (collected from Rajasthan) in a preliminary biological screening revealed antiviral activity against vaccinia virus. The extract of the plant (collected from Kashmir) revealed diuretic activity in rat. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root ) in a preliminary biological screening revealed antispasmodic activity in isolated guinea pig ileum. The volatile oil of the plant exhibited antibacterial activity against I11Aerobacter aerogenes, Bacillus anthracis, Bac cereus, Bac mycoides, Bac subtilis, Bac pumilus, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Micrococcus flavus, Pseudomonas mangiferae indicae, Proteus vulgaris, Salmonella typhi, Serratia marcescens, Staphylococcus albus, Staph epidermidis, Staph aureus, Shigella dysenteriaeI11 and I11Streptococcus faecalis.I11 The oil showed inhibitory activity against gram positive organisms viz., I11Staphylococcus aureus, Staph citreusI11 and I11Bacillus subtilisI11 while it had no activity against I11Staphylococcus albus.I11 The extract of the above ground parts exhibited moderate feeding deterrent activity against I11Diacrisia obliqua.I11 View Reference

author: Lam.
description: A large evergreen tree, with milky juice; glabrous except the youngest shoots. Leaves simple, alternate, 10-20 cm long, elliptic or obovate, acuminate, entire, or those of the young plants sometimes lobed; dark-green and shining above, rather rough beneath. Main nerves 7-8 pairs, stipule large, soon caducous. Flowers monoecious, densely crowded on oblong or globose, unisexual solitary usually axillary receptacles. Male flowers: Perianth 2-4 lobed. Lobes obtuse; stamen 1, erect. Pistillode 0. Female flowers: Perianth tubular, confluent below with the receptacle. Ovary straight, ovule pendulous. Fruit a much enlarged fleshy hanging on short stalks from the trunk, clothed with the accrescent or pyramidal apices. Seed pendulous; cotyledons unequal.

author: L.
description: Erects undershrubs. Leaves linear-lanceolate to lanceolate. Flowers in extra-axillary umbellate inflorescence. Corolla rotate, reflexed. Corona saffron yellow, staminal, Follicles erect. Seeds broadly ovate, coma silky white.
pharmacology: The most notable biological effect in the herb was the cardiotonic activity and the active principle was asclepin, a glycoside. Asclepin showed a powerful positive inotropic action on hypodynamic cardiac muscle preparation. Asclepin was found to have higher cumulative toxicity, asclepin was found more potent than digoxin both than digoxin. The alcoholic extract of the root (10, 25 and 50 mg/kg i.v.) produced an increase in blood pressure and heart rate in non-vagotomised dogs. In higher doses (100-200 mg/kg i.v.), the animals developed ventricular extrasystoles, ventricular tachycardia and ultimately died of ventricular fibrillation. The study suggested that pressor and chronotropic response of the extract could be due to direct effect on chromaffin cells causing release of catecholamines from adrenals. The 50 per cent alcoholic extract of the plant in a dose of 100 mg/kg p.o. from 1-7d post coitum revealed 40 per cent antiimplantation activity in rats. The higher dose of 50 mg/kg was found to be 100 per cent lethal. The rats were found to be tolerant to the toxic effects of the extra as there was no mortality even with a dose of 100 mg/kg for seven days. The alcoholic and aqueous extracts of the leaves were devoid of in vitro antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Escherichia coli.I11 The aqueous and alcoholic extracts of the fruits were devoid of any activity against I11Escherichia coliI11 whereas the alcoholic extract of the fruits possessed some activity against only I11Staphylococcus aureus.I11 View Reference
chemical_composition: The ethanolic extract of the plant was shown to contain twenty two Kedde-positive substances. Of these uzarigenin, calactin, calotropin, caroglaucigenin, calotropagenin and uzrain were isolated and characterized along with a new genin (Singh and Rastogi, 1969). The genin was later characterized as 3â- I11OI11 âacetylcalotropin and named as asclepin (Singh and Rastogi, 1972). The ethanolic extract also yielded four glycosides. Two of the four glycosides were reported to be glucorhamnosides whereas the other two were found to be glucosides. Ã-Sitosterol, its glucoside and oleanolic acid were also isolated from the extract (Singh and Rastogi, 1969). The stem contained hesperidin (hesperitin-7- I11OI11 ârhamnoglucoside) besides-Ã-sitosterol and nonacosan-6-one (Sulochana et al., 1989). The shoot revealed the presence of saponins and absence of alkaloids, flavonoids and tannins (Kumar et al., 1990). The root was reported to contain flavonoids, glycosides, saponins, sterols and terpenoids while alkaloids were found to be absent (Agrawal et al., 1989).

author: Willd.
description: A scandant, spinous, much- branched undershrub; rootstock tuberous; tubers elongate more or less fusiform. Cladodes long, slender, spinous tipped. Flowers white, fragrant in simple racemes; rachis triangular with several cladodes along it. Flowers hermaphrodite, small. Perianth segments -6, linear oblong, obtuse. Stamens 6, adnate to the base of the perianth segment. Ovary 3-celled, style very short, stigmas3, spreading. Fruit a globose berry, red when ripe.
pharmacology: Nematicidal, anticancer, antidysenterica, antifungal, gastric-sedative, antibacterial, antiabortifacient (shatavarin I), antioxytoxic (shatavarin IV), antiviral, diuretic, galactogogue, antiamoebic, spasmodic to uterus, hypoglycaemic, phagocytic, hypotensive, anticoagulant, enzymatic. The plant has undergone extensive pharmacological investigations. The studies demonstrated that plant has significant beneficial effects in dyspepsia, acid-pepsin disease and deficient lactation. Anticancer and antistress effects need further studies. The cytoprotective effect of the powders of dry fruits of I11Terminalia chebulaI11 and root of I11A. racemosusI11 was studied on the experimentally induced acute gastric ulcerations. A mixture of the two drugs in a dose of 1.5g/kg each orally twice a day for 15d was effective in preventing formation of duodenal ulcer and diminishing the ulcer index in gastric lesions. In in vitro studies, the powder of the plant did not possess any antacid activity, Probably the beneficial effects of the plant in duodenal ulcer patient was due to direct healing effect or by enhancing the mucosal barrier by prolonging the life span of mucosal cells by cytoprotection. The effects of intramuscular administration [0.1ml (250mg/kg)] of the crude alcoholic extract of the root were studied in post partum, estrogen-primed non-primed rats. The extract increased the weight of mammary glands in post partum and estrogen-primed rats and the uterine weight in estrogen-primed group. The fresh root (1/2 kg/day) had a galactogogue action when given to buffaloes on 21st d after calving continued up to 50th d. The milk yield was found to be significantly increased after the use of the drug. Oral administration of the powdered root (100mg/kg/day for 10d) mixed with concentrate in normal lactating goats resulted in a substantial increase in the milk yield (7.33 per cent and 5.65 per cent increase during the drug and post drug period, respectively. The alcoholic extract of the root exhibited antioxytocic activity. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) revealed anticancer activity against human epidermoid carcinoma of nasopharynx in tissue culture. The powdered root extract revealed inhibitory action on DMBA-induced mammary tumourigenesis in rats of Holtzman strain. The mammary tumour incidence showed a sharp decline when virgin female rats, normal or primed with 17Ã-estradiol treatment were put on diets containing 0.25 per cent, 0.5 per cent, 1 per cent or 2 per cent root extract powder for 10d prior to their exposure to DMBA. The effect of the pretreatment of the decoction of the root (100mg/kg/day for 15d orally) was evaluated against I11Escherichia coliI11 induced peritonitis in mice. The results indicated 50 per cent mortality at 16h as compared to 100 per cent in the control animals, thus suggesting an immunomodulating property. The methanolic extract of the root at doses of 200 and 400 mg/kg showed maximum inhibition of oedema of 18.6 per cent at 5h with serotonin-induced rat paw oedema, respectively. The antiinflammatory activity of the extract was comparable to that of phenylbutazone. The organic (250 mg dried ethanolic extract per kg bw) and the inorganic parts (90 mg pure ash/kg bw) of the root revealed hypoglycaemic activity in a single dose effect on the oral glucose tolerance test (GTT) in fasting albino rats. The aqueous extracts of both fresh and dried root were found to have amylase and lipase activities, the activity being higher in the former. The aqueous solution of the crude alcoholic extract of the root in a dose of 10-20 mg caused initial increase in force and rate of contraction in isolated frogâs heart a higher dose (40 mg) caused cardiac arrest. The decision of the root in a dose of 100 mg/kg bw for varying period of 4wk to 8 months showed growth promoting effects in rats. The decoction treated animals also showed a better weight gain (81.19 per cent) as compared to the control animals (67.9 per cent). It however, had no effect on the progeny of treated animals. The growth promoting effect was indicative of its anabolic effect and ascribed to its adaptogenic substances. The alcoholic extract of the root at a dose of 50 mg/kg (p.o.) revealed antiallergic activity as evidenced by inhibition of passive cutaneous anaphylaxis in mouse (57 per cent) and rat (53 per cent). The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) in a preliminary biological screening revealed antispasmodic activity on isolated guinea pig ileum and effect on guinea pig heart. The alcoholic extract of the root was found to possess in vitro antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Escherichia coliI11. The hexane, aqueous and alcoholic extracts of the root at concentration of 200 mg/ml were devoid of any in vitro antibacterial activity against I11Bacillus subtilis, Escherichia coli, Proteus vulgaris, Salmonella typhimurium, Pseudomonas aeruginosaI11 and I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 using the agar well diffusion test. The juice of the root showed fungitoxicity against three plant fungi viz., I11Helminthosporium sativumI11 (60.7 per cent), I11Colletotrichum falcatumI11 (58.2 per cent) and I11Fusarium oxysporumI11 (60.7 per cent). The root bark had marked antibacterial, antitubercular and antifungal actions against eight bacteria viz., I11Micrococcus pyogenes var. aureus, Bacillus subtilis, Diplococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, Escherichia coli, Salmonella typhosa, Vibrio commaI11 and I11Shigella dysenteriaeI11; against two mycobacteria I11Mycobacterium phleiI11 and I11MycobacteriumI11 607; and against four fungi viz., I11Microsporum gypseum, Trichophyton mentagrophytes, Candida albicansI11 and I11Helminthosporium sativum.I11 The methanol fraction of the leaves using the disc diffusion test a concentration of 4000 and 5000 ppm was found to inhibit I11Proteus vulgarisI11 while it was devoid of any activity against I11Escherichia coli, Klebsiella aerogenesI11 and I11Pseudomonas aerogenosaI11. The aqueous extract of the root was lethal or inhibitory, in in vitro studies to hatching of eggs of I11Meloidogyne javanicaI11 and I11M. arenaria.I11 C11Clinical StudiesC11 In a preliminary clinical trial, 23 patients having duodenal ulcers were given freshly expressed juice of the root in a dose of 25 ml with 10 ml honey 2-3 times/day for 45d. There was a complete relief in 14 patients, partial in 7 patients while 2 patients dropped out. There were no side effects. The clinical efficacy of the plants was evaluated in 32 patients with duodenal ulcers. The root powder (12.0/day in four divided doses) was given for an average duration of six weeks. The powder relieved symptoms in most of the patients within a week of therapy. 75 per cent of the patients had radiologic and endoscopic evidence of ulcer healing. In a clinical trial on twenty radiologically confirmed cases of duodenal ulcers (parinamasula) (15 cases having hyperchlorhydria and hyperacidity and 5 cases having normal gastric acidity) were given tuberous root powder 20g/day in three divided doses with milk for a month. The results indicated that there was a significant reduction in symptoms and total acids and free good response in 30 per cent cases of duodenal ulcer. The pharmacognosy, chemistry, pharmacology and therapeutics of the plant were reviewed. View Reference
chemical_composition: The flowers contain quercetin, hyperoside and rutin (Subaramanian and Nair, 1968a), while these were devoid of vitamin C and carotene. The fruits (green in colour) showed the presence of glycosides of quercetin, rutin and hyperoside, quercetin was found to be present as glycoside only. The fully ripe fruits (pink red in colour) contained anthocyanins viz., cyaniding-3-galactoside and cyaniding-3-glucorhamnoside (Subramnian and Nair, 1968a). The petroleum ether extract of the fruits was found to contain sitosterol, stigmasterol and sarsasapogenin, while the methanolic extract showed the presence of sitosterol Ã-D-glucoside, stigmasterol Ã-D-glucoside, two spirostanoilc and two furostanolic saponins. Although the saponins were not fully characterized but on acid hydrolysis, showed the presence of sarsasapogenin, D- glucose and L-rhamnose (Sharma et al., 1981). The leaves were found to contain rutin, a flavonoid glycoside as well as diosgenin (Subramanian and Nair, 1968a, b). The sapogenin present in the root was identified as sarsapogenin. The ethanolic extract of the woody portion of the tuberous root was found to contain kaempferol besides sarsasapogenin (Ahmad et al., 1991). The ethanolic extract of the root was shown to contain several steroidal glycosides named as shatavarins. Shatavarin-I, the major glycosidal component was characterized as (25S,22R)-3-Ã-D-glucopyranosyl-(1-->4)-[S224 -L-rhamnopyranosyl â(1-->2)-Ã-D-glucopyranoside-26- I11OI11 âÃ-D-glucopyranosyl -5Ã-furostane-3Ã, 22,26-triol. The presence of sitosterol, 4, 6-dihydroxy- I11OI11 â(2â-hydroxyisobutyl) benzaldehyde and undecanyl cetanoate was also reported (Paliwal et al., 1991). The ethanolic extract of the root was devoid of flavonoids. It however, had saponins which on acid hydrolysis yielded steroidal sapogenin. No asparagine could be isolated (Subramanian and Nair, 1968a). The alkaloids and tannins were found to be absent. The root contained proteins, saponins, carbohydrates, crude fibre, inorganic matter and mucilage. The mucilage was found to contain glucose and galacturonic acid in the ratio of 3:2. In addition, uronic acid constituted 39.2 per cent of the mucilage besides hemicelluloses and insoluble polysaccharides. The ethanolic extract of the root yielded D- glucose, D-mannose and a new disaccharide which was assigned the structure of 3- I11OI11 âÃ-D-glucopyranosyl-D-mannopyranose. The analysis of the hemicellulose of the tubers gave two fractiona AB112B11 and BB112B11. Both the fractions constituted from the same sugar and uronic acid, namely glucose and galacturonic acid but in different proportions. In hemicellulose AB112B11 the molecular ratio of these compounds was 10:1 while in BB112B11 it was 5:2. Under the controlled conditions of hydrolysis both the fractions gave rise to glucose and a gluco-galacturonic acid. Studies in the polyfructosans and transfructosidation reaction in tubers were carried out.

Basic Description of Plant : A scandant, spinous, much- branched undershrub; rootstock tuberous; tubers elongate more or less fusiform. Cladodes long, slender, spinous tipped. Flowers white, fragrant in simple racemes; rachis triangular with several cladodes along it. Flowers hermaphrodite, small. Perianth segments -6, linear oblong, obtuse.

author: And.
description: An erect or procumbent herb, sometimes climbing among bushes. Stems 30-90 cm long, much-branched. Leaves opposite, 2.5-5.6 by 2-3.75 cm, entire; ovate, acute, darkgreen above, paler beneath; main nerves 5-6 pairs; petioles 1.25-2.5 cm long. Inflorescence a terminal and axillary spike-like raceme. Pedicels of the lower flowers reaching .3 cm long, those of the upper shorter or almost 0; bracts and bracteoles below the pedicels .25-.3 cm long, ovate-lanceolate, acute, ciliate, shorter than calyx. Flowers hermaphrodite. Calyx nearly .6 cm long, deeply divided, lobes 5. Corolla tube inflated above, pale-blue with a yellowish tube and usually a purple blotch on the lowest lobe; ca 3.5 cm long; pubescent outside. Stamens 4, all perfect, didynamous; anthers oblong, minutely spurred or submuticous at the base. Ovary superior, 2-celled; ovules 2 in each cell; style linear, hairy along lower part; stigma 2-fid or subcapitate. Fruit a capsule; clavate, pointed, usually constricted about the middle of the enlarged upper part, 4-seeded.
pharmacology: The effects of aqueous extract of the plant and luteolin 7-I11OI11 âneohesperidoside isolated from the flowers were studied against hypotonicity-induced haemolysis in vitro and were found to exhibit a biphasic activity. In in vivo studies, the glycoside produced a dose âdependent inhibition against carrageenin-induced rat oedema. The antiinflammatory activity was significant and compared well with phenylbutazone (Sethuraman and Vigneswari, 1998). The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant in a preliminary biological screening showed effect on CVS in dog/cat. The extract was devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, antiviral, anticancer and diuretic activities and effects on isolated guinea pig ileum, preganglionically stimulated nictitating membrane and CNS in experimental animals. The LDB1150B11 of the extract was >1000 mg/kg i.p. in mice. View Reference
chemical_composition: The leaves were also found to contain luteolin and luteolin -7-glucoside. The flowers revealed the presence of luteolin and its glycosidic form luteolin 7- I11OI11 âneohesperidoside (Sethuraman and Vigneswari, 1998).

author: Wight & Arn.
description: A shrub or small trees; spines strong and sharp, sometimes absent. Leaves 1-foliolate; leaflet 5-10 by2.5-3.75 cm elliptic, rounded at the apex, emarginae, entire or crenulate, glabrous, reticulately veined, base acute; petioles .6 cm long. Flowers in axillary racemose cymes; pedicles short; bracts minute, subulate. Calyx usually 4, sometimes 3-5 lobed; lobes rounded or subacute, ciliolate. Petals white, .3 cm broadly elliptic obovate, very concave in bud, not adnate to the staminal-tube, glandular. Stamens 8; filaments usually united into a tube throughout nearly their entire length, sometimes united at the base only when they are linear and flattened; anthers large, cordate, attached at the back near the base on the triangular teeth of the staminal-tube or the triangular apex of the filaments. Disk copular. Ovary ovoid, oblong or obovoid; style short, stout, somewhat clavate. Berry globular, 2 cm in diam.
pharmacology: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) from Maharashtra in a preliminary biological screening showed antiviral activity against Ranikhet disease virus. It was, however, devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, antiprotozoal, hypoglycaemic, diuretic and anticancer activities and effects on isolated guinea pig ileum, respiration, CVS and CNS in experimental animals. In another study, the extract of the plant from Karnataka showed hypoglycaemic activity in mice but was devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, antiviral and diuretic activities and effects on respiration, preganglionically stimulated nictitating membrane, CVS, CNS and isolated tissues. The hexane extract of the plant in concentration of 100-1000Âµg/ml was found to be devoid of any in vitro antibacterial activity against various bacterial strains viz., I11Staphylococcus aureus, Proteus mirabilisI11 and I11Pseudomonas aeruginosa.I11 The extract of aerial parts was reported to show antiviral activity against Ranikhet disease virus. The extract was found inactive against vaccinia virus. View Reference
chemical_composition: The aerial parts were reported to yield three new pyranocoumarins identified as racemosin isolated from hexane extract and characterized as 5,10-dimethoxy-8,8-dimethyl-2-oxo-2H, 8-H benzo [1,2-b;5,4-bâ]dipyran (Joshi et al., 1978); atalantoflavone [8,8-dimethyl-5-hydroxy-2-(4â-hydroxyphenyl)-4H,8h-benzo-(1,2-b;3,4-bâ) dipyran-4-one] isolated from the chloroform extract (Banerji et al., 1988a). Aerial parts were also reported to contain friedelin and biogenetically related coumarin derivatives namely xanthyletin, xanthotoxin, (Joshi et al., 1978) luvangetin, umbelliferone, rutarin and rutaretin (Banerji et al., 1988a). Tannins were found to be absent in the 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) (Atal et al., 1978). The fruits were reported to contain a coumarin racemol, the structure of which was described as (-)-6,7. dihydro-7-(1-hydroxy-1-methyl)-9-hydroxyfuro[2,3-g] coumarin (Purushothaman et al., 1986).

author: (L.) Benth.
description: An herbaceous twiner; stem and branches slender, striate, clothed with pale-yellow or grey pubescence. Leaves 3-foliolate; petioles 1.25-2.5 cm long, clothed with yellowish pubescence; stipules .15 cm long, triangular, acute. Leaflets 2-4.5 by 1.5-2.5 cm, densely grey-pubescent and reticulately veined (but not very closely) beneath; petiolules very short; stipels 0. Flowers pedicelled, 2-6 on short densely pubescent axillary peduncles; pedicels .6 cm long, densely hairy. Calyx .6 cm long, fulvous-pubescent; teeth linear, acute, the lowest twice as long as the tube. Corolla .15 cm long, yellow. Stamens diadelphous; anthers uniforms. Ovary sessile; ovulues 3 or more; style filiform, incurved, glabrous; stigma capitates. Pods 1.5-2 by .6 cm straight, apiculate, clothed with long soft brownish hair, with deep obliquely-transverse lines between the seeds. Seeds 4-6.
pharmacology: In a preliminary biological screening, the 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) was found to be devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, antiprotozoal, anthelmintic, antiviral, hypoglycaemic, diuretic and anticancer activities and effects on isolated guinea pig ileum, respiration, CVS and CNS in experimental animals. The LDB1150B11 of the extract was found to be >1000 mg/kg i.p. in mice (Dhar et al., 1973). The 50 per cent acetone extract of the seeds showed negligible antifungal activity against the plant fungi I11Epidermophyton floccosum, Microsporum gypseumI11 while it was completely inactive against I11Paecilmyces variotiI11 and I11Trichophyton mentagrophytesI11 (Rathore and Misra, 1987). The volatile oil from the leaves showed 30 per cent fungitoxicity against I11Fusarium oxysporum.I11 View Reference
chemical_composition: In a preliminary study, the 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant was found to contain tannins (Atal et al., 1978). The ethanolic extract of the shoot contained saponins while alkaloids, flavonoids and tannins were found to be absent. The ethanolic extract of the leaves on fractionation yielded hentriacontane, Ã-sitosterol glucoside and four fatty esters of hexacosanol (palmitate, stearate, arachidate and oleate) from the petroleum ether fraction (Sharma and Gupta, 1985). In a later study, the ethanolic extract of the leaves yielded a highly oxygenated flavone glucoside named as atyloside and identified as 3,4â5â,6,7,8-hexahydroxyflavone-8- Ã-glucopyranoside (Gupta et al., 1990). The ethanolic extract of the root yielded a novel epoxyflavanone (2S)-5,7-dihydroxy-2â,4â-dimethoxy-8-(2,3-epoxy-3-methylbutyl) flavanone. The quantitative estimation of crude protein, pentosan and water soluble gum contents of the seed was reported by Kapoor and associates (1992).
