author: A. Juss.
description: A large tree 12-15 m high, with a straight trunk. Leaves alternate, simply pinnate, 20-38 cm long, crowded near the ends of the branches; leaflest 9-12, subopposite, 2.5-7.5 by 1.25-3.75 cm obliquely lanceolate, sometimes falcate, acuminate, serrate, glabrous on both surfaces, base inequilateral, acute; petiolules very short. Flowers white, fragrant, in branched glabrous panicles shorter than the leaves; bracts minute lanceolate, caducous. Calyx 5-partite, puberulous outside, ciliolate. Petals 5, much exceeding the calyx, free, imbricate. Staminal-tube glabrous, a little shorter than petals, obconic, the laciniae truncate and toothed at the apex; anthers 10, opposite the laciniae and a little shorter than them, apiculate. Disk 0. Ovary glabrous, 3-celled, the cells opposite to the petals; ovules 2 in each cell, collateral; stigma 3-toothed, included in the tube. Drupes the shape of an olive, 1.25-2 cm long, glabrous, 1-seeded.

locations.vegetation: Tropical Dry Deciduous type of Vegetation

pharmacology: Neem has also been in use for a variety of conditions (relevant to man, cattle and agriculture) in India for thousands of years and is continued to be used. In view of its prevalent uses, it has been very extensively investigated for its biological activities in experimental models as well as clinical settings. Neem oil (0.55 cc) and its two bitter principles nimbidin (5.0 mg) and nimbidol (5.0 mg) did not exhibit any estrogenic activity in ovariectomised rats. Neem oil possessed mild antiovulatory activity (25.0 per cent, 37.5 per cent and 40.0 per cent, in doses of 2, 4 and 6 ml/kg bw orally, respectively) in rabbits, when given for 3d prior to inducing ovulation. Single or multiple post coital intravaginal application of neem oil (75 and 25Âµl) on 2-4 and 4-6 d of pregnancy during pre-, peri- and post-implantation periods could completely prevent implantation in rats. In another study, neem oil was found to have antiimplantation/abortifacient effect in rats and rabbits when applied intravaginally on day 2 to day 7 pf expected pregnancy. Neem oil (1 ml) extracted from the seeds, when administered deep into vagina in Rhesus monkeys using a tuberculin syringe showed that the oil on vagina application acted both as pre-coital as well as post-coital contraceptive agent. Subcutaneous administration of neem oil (0.05 to 0.30 ml/rat/day for 5 or 7d after coitus showed significant antifertility activity. Subcutaneous administration of ethanolic extract of the seeds (0.1ml/day/rat) for 6, 12 and 18 d caused significant decrease in the glycogen content of liver and kidneys and increase in adrenals. Protein contents were also increased in adrenals and decreased in kidneys. All biochemical parameters remained unchanged in spleen. Histological features of these organs were also changed. The kidneys showed severe damage which included disorganization of cortical and tubular cells and there was no differentiation of cortical and tubular regions. The ethanolic extract of the seeds when tested for its toxicity in reproductive organs of adult cyclic rats at a dose of 0.1 ml/rat, s.c. for three different durations of 6, 12 and 18d as compared to control rats receiving olive oil as vehicle, caused degenerative changes in the ovarian follicles and thickening of the cells of granulosa. A polyherbal preparation âpraneenâ containing the purified extract of neem, quinine, hydrochloride and saponins extracted from a pericarp of I11Sapindus mukerossiI11 used in either in liquid form or as cream, on intravaginal application was found to be effective in preventing pregnancy in rabbits and also in post coital tests in Bonnet monkeys and baboons. Acute and sub-acute toxicity studies revealed the safety of the preparation and lack of side effects in both rodents and monkeys. The shelf life of the cream at room temperature was estimated to be 18 months by accelerated stability studies. The product had spermicidal activity. In an in vitro study the spermicidal activity of sodium nimbidinate using sperm suspension prepared from the epididymis of rats and human semen revealed that 2.5 mg per cent of sodium nimbidinate killed all the rat sperms in 30 min. Freshly prepared water extract as well as decoction of crushed green leaves (1 ml) orally fed to mice daily for one month showed a reversible antifertility activity without inhibition of spermatogenesis. Mating with the extract-treated mice reduced the number of pregnancies as well as the litter size. However, after one and a half month of the drug-free interval, the male mice showed a normal reproductive function as indicated by the number of pregnancies. Indigenously available neem oil in its natural form tested for its spermicidal activity ( in vitro and in vivo) showed that the undiluted oil possessed strong spermicidal action (within 30 sec) against Rhesus monkey and human spermatozoa in vitro. Neem oil in doses of 2,4 and 6 ml/kg bw fed orally for one month showed remarkable loss of reproductive functions in rats and rabbits without interfering with spermatogenesis. The ethanolic extract of the leaves in oral dose of 100 mg/kg daily for 21d in male rats though did not interfere with spermatogenesis but antiimplantational and abortifacient effects were observed in females mated by these males. An alternate approach to vasectomy for long term male contraception involving a single intravas application of neem oil (50Âµl) was studied in male rats and results compared with control animals receiving peanut oil. Animals put on continuous mating 4 wk after the treatment with females of proven fertility revealed ability throughout the 8 months of observation period. Nimbidin, isolated from oil, had a potent hypoglycaemic activity in fasting and glucose-fed rabbits. The aqueous extract of the leaves administered i.v. at a dose of 0.15 ml/kg had appreciable effect on blood glucose levels in dogs. The oil in 2.5 ml and nimbidin in 200 mg/kg bw doses exhibited significant hypoglycaemic activity by reducing the blood sugar level by 24 and 26 per cent, respectively at the 5th of h of feeding. The tender leaf decoction failed to show any significant effect at all the 5th h of feeding. The tender leaf decoction failed to show any significant effect at all the three dose levels studied. Neem oil was investigated for possible hypoglycaemic activity on normal fasting rabbits; hyperglycaemic rabbits following oral glucose meal; hyperglycaemic rats following i.p. injection of adrenaline and alloxan-induced diabetic rabbits. The results indicated that the after oral administration of 2 ml/kg bw of neem oil. The fall of blood sugar persisted for 8 h and level of blood sugar returned to normal after 24h. On chronic administration for 21d (once a day) the blood sugar fell by 24.13 per cent. Sodium nimbidinate obtained from the seed oil was found to be a potent diuretic agent in dogs. The ethanolic extracts of the leaves and seeds showed in vitro antimalarial activity against chloroquine-sensitive and resistant strains of Plasmodium falciparum. Neem seed extracts as well as its various purified fractions extracted with solvents of different polarity PNE, ENM (rich in relatively polar components) and ENS (non-polar components) showed in vitro antiplasmodial activity against Plasmodium falciparum. The aqueous suspension (100 mg/kg) of the leaves influenced several biochemical, immunological and visceral parameters in normal and stressed rats. It lowered the blood glucose, triglyceride and SGOT levels in normal rats, and attenuated stress-induced elevations of cholesterol and urea levels. Modulation of humoral and cell-mediated immune response by leaves extract was seen in ovalbumin-immunized mice when fed for 3 wk orally. Nimbidiol in a dose of 50 mg/kg in yeast-induced pyrexia in rats, caused immediate reduction in temperature. Nimbidol was also found to be more potent than nimbidin at a dose of 25 mg/100g bw given orally twice a day for 4d in suppressing the infection of I11Plasmodium gallinaceumI11 in chicks. Two different fractions of leaves, DM (dried material) and FPM (filter paper material) suspended in propylene glycol showed reduction in the spontaneous activity, respiratory rate, piloerection, diuresis and hypothermia after oral administration in mice. The cardio-depressant effect of neem leaf extract on isolated frog and rabbitâs heart was not blocked by atropine or mefgramine. Hydroalcoholic neem leaf extract caused a dose âdependent hypotensive effect in frog heart. The triterpenoid 24-methylenecycloartanol showed antiproteolytic activity in vitro as demonstrated by inhibition of trypsin-induced hydrolysis of bovine serum, albumin and casein. Neem oil, nimbidin and nimbidol exhibited a non specific spasmolytic activity on the contractions induced by histamine and acetylcholine on guinea pig ileum. Aqueous liquid extract of fruits in kaolin and pectin in the form of suspension revealed antidiarrhoeal activity against castor oil-induced diarrhoea in rats. The oil obtained from the various parts of neem tree i.e. leaves, bark and seeds, possessed wide antibacterial spectrum against gram positive and gram negative organisms viz., I11Staphylococcus aureus, Pasteurella pestis, Bacillus typhosum, Bac paratyphosumI11 A and B, I11Bac FriedlanderI11 and I11Vibrio cholerae.I11 The essential oil obtained from the leaves particularly possessed marked antibacterial activity against streptomycin-resistant strain of I11Mycobacterium tuberculosisI11 (human, avian and bovine types) as compared to the oils of obtained from the bark and seeds. Two hundred clinical isolates of bacteria, subjected to in vitro antibacterial effects of neem oil ( procured from Khadi and Village Industries Commission, Pune), showed 92 per cent susceptibility, the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) varying between 1/4 to 1/64 dilution. The oil has significant antibacterial properties against pathogenic gram negative bacilli such as I11Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Escherichia coli, Proteus sp.I11 and I11Klebsiella aerogenesI11 and against gram positive cocci such as I11Staphylococcus pyogenes.I11 The essential oil of the seeds showed in vitro inhibition against pathogenic bacteria I11Bacillus anthracis, Bac mycoides, Bac pumilus, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas mangiferae indicae, Sarcina lutea, Salmonella typhi, Staphylococcus aureus, Staph albusI11 and I11Xanthomonas campestris.I11 In in vitro studies the extract of the flowers showed antibacterial activity against some plant and human pathogenic bacteria. The extract showed varing range of inhibition against I11Xanthomonas campestris I11 (-), I11Pseudomonas mangiferae indicaeI11 (-), I11Bacillus subtilisI11 (-),I11Bac pumilusI11 (+), I11Staphylococcus albusI11 (+) and I11Vibrio choleraeI11 (+). Neem oil and its various constituents on screening for antifungal activity against a number of fungi using different techniques showed promising results. The essential oil of the seeds possessed in vitro antifungal activity against the dermatophytic fungi I11Microsporum gypseumI11 and I11Trichophyton rubrumI11 while it was less active against I11Malbranchea pulchella, Gymnoascus reesaiiI11 and I11Aspergillus fumigatus.I11 The oil had fungicidal activity against keratinophillic fungi I11Microsporum gypseum, Chrysosporium tropicum, Trichophyton rubrum, Aspergillus fumigatus, Penicillium liliacinum, Fusarium nivale, Malbranchea pulchellaI11 and I11Gymnoascus reesaii.I11 The leaf extract was also found active against the dermatophytic fungi I11Paecilomyces lilacinus, Microsporum gypseumI11 and I11Pseudogymnoascus roseus.I11 The leaf extract tested for its in vitro effect on the mycelial growth of 2 strains (HB111B11 and HB112B11) of Scytalidium anamorph of Hendersonula toruloidea causing skin and nail disease in man, showed only 3.17 per cent inhibition against the HB112B11 strain, while no activity against the HB111B11 strain, while no activity against the H1 strain. The extract of the leaves showed strong toxicity against the ringworm fungi I11Epidermophyton floccosumI11 (60.47 per cent) and I11Trichophyton mentagrophytesI11 (53.44 per cent), while poor activity against I11Microsporum gypseum.I11 Neem cake amended soil significantly reduced the incidence of black scurf on potatoes, reduced the wilt incidence in pigeon pea, Thanjavur wilt of coconut; muskmelon wilt caused by I11Fusarium solani.I11 The extract of the leaves inhibited the growth of the spores and sclerotial production of the fungal pathogens of rice viz., I11Corticium sasakiiI11 and I11Pyricularia oryzaeI11 while it had no activity against I11Drechslera oryzae.I11 Neem, as a green manure, prolonged the sclerotial viability over control of I11Corticium sasakiiI11. The ethanolic extract of the leaves (1000 ppm) completely inhibited the conidial and mycelial growth of I11Rhizoctonia solaniI11 and I11Fusarium moniliformeI11 in addition to I11Pyricularia oryzae.I11 The aqueous extract of the leaves was effective against the fungal pathogens I11Botryodiplodia theobromae, Fusarium oxysporum, Helminthosporium speciferum, Curvuluria lunata, Aspergillus flavusI11 and I11Trichothecium roseumI11 causing banana rot and I11Pestalotiopsis mangiferaeI11 causing leaf spot of I11Mangifera indica.I11 The extract also inhibited the mycelial growth of weeds fungi I11Myceliophthora leuta, Papulaspora lyssina. Chaetomium globosumI11 and I11Trichoderma virideI11 in vitro causing considerable loss to mushrooms. The aqueous extracts of leaf, trunk bark, fruit pulp as well as the oil of the seeds revealed fungicidal effect on soil borne pathogens I11Fusarium oxysporumI11f. sp. ciceri, I11Rhizoctonia solani, Sclerotium rolfsiiI11 and I11Sclerotina sclerotorumI11 causing wilt and rot of gram (I11Cicer arietinumI11) grown on liquid medium. The seedling extract inhibited the spore germination of I11Botrytis cinereI11a and I11Colletotrichum gloeoesporioides.I11 The 10 per cent water extract of the tender leaves inhibited the plaque formation of vaccinia virus in tissue culture by two logs and pock formation on chorioallantoic membrane by four logs. The crude extract of the leaves was found to be potent in reducing the infectivity of potato virus X, bean common mosaic virus infecting various legumes and pulses, urd bean leaf crinkle virus and spinach mosaic virus. The leaf and the bark extracts inhibited the cowpea mosaic comovirus. Neem tree has emerged as a single most important source of insecticides. All parts of the tree are biologically active. The tree has shown diverse biological effects against insects. Today numerous studies are available describing the insecticidal, repellent, feeding and oviposition deterrent, antihormonal, growth regulatory and sterilant effects of the tree. These biological activities have been demonstrated for the oil expelled from seeds and leaves; leaf, fruit and seed extracts; neem cake and various other isolates. These materials have been tested against household pests of medical and hygienic importance. The bitter fixed oil, amorphous bitter principles and crystalline substances attribute to the insecticidal activity of the tree. Neem oil applications revealed good acaricidal activity in sarcoptic mange in sheep. Pure neem oil obtained from the seed kernels and neem ointment (neem oil in paraffin base 50:50) evaluated in experimentally created incised and gap wounds in bovine calves showed an initial mild irritant effect followed by an anodyne and astringent effect on wounds. The wounds neither suppurated nor miasmated and healed by granulation. C11Clinical studiesC11 Polyherbal preparation âpraneemâ, containing purified extracts of neem, quinine hydrochloride and saponins extracted from the pericarp of Sapindus mukerossi was used as a cream or pessary in Phase I clinical trials at the Safdarjung Hospital, New Delhi in patients with abnormal discharge due to genital infections. The subjects applied 5 ml of the cream every night for 7- 14d. The cream was highly effective in patients with Chlamydia trachomatis. Patients with vaginitis due to Candida albicans were also benefited clinically in the trial. In addition, it showed antimicrobial action on Chlamydia trachomatis, Candida albicans and Gardenerella vaginalis amongst the vaginal pathogens in in vitro studies. The formulation was also claimed to be effective in the treatment of human papillomas virus-16 infection in female genital tract. In a limited preliminary clinical trial, oral administration of 5 g of aqueous leaf paste or equivalent amount of dried leaf in a capsule enabled diabetic patients to reduce their dosage of insulin up to 30-50 per cent without significant effect on the blood glucose levels. Of the 9 patients of congestive cardiac failure with anasarca, examined for the diuretic effect on sodium nimbidinate (250 mg administered daily for 2-13d with an average of about 5 injections per patient) eight showed a definite diuretic response as compared to the four controls who were on bed rest, low sodium diet and adequate digitalization without any diuretic. The clinical efficacy of neem leaves in the form of a lotion, was studied in common skin disorders in 19 randomly selected cases of the age group of 25-35 years. The lotion was applied twice daily. In acute eczema cases (3), new skin formation took place within 5-10d of treatment. In cases with acute on chronic eczema (3), the response was slow and one case had a relapse after 30-40d of treatment. View Reference
chemical_composition: Nimbin and nimbinin could not be obtained from certain fresh samples of solvent extracted neem oil and the yield of these products from commercial samples varied appreciably. This indicated the possibility of these substances being secondary products formed during storage of the seed or the expressed oil. Studies on structure elucidation of nimbin were carried out by different groups of workers. Nimbin was found to be triterpenoid derivable from apoeuphol with one of the rings (ring C) broken. The other constituents isolated from the seed oil were nimbinin; vepinine, gedunin and desacetylgedunin; the protomeliacin meliantriol; salannolide; 4-epinimbin, nimbin, desacetylnimbin and salannin; 17-epinimbocinol, nimbocinol. The detailed chemical, analytical and spectral studies on nimbin group of constituents in the tree have been carried out.. Seed/ Fruits The seed kernel extracts has resulted in the isolation of several azadirachtins and their analogues. While a lot of work has been done outside India by foreign workers, we report here the work done by Indian workers on azadirachtins (A, B, D, H, I and K). The extract on preparative high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) without conventional chromatography yielded the known azadirachtins viz., azadirachtin A, azadirachtin B and azadirachtin D; azadirachtin H and 11Ã-H epimer; azadirachtin I and azadirachtin K. Besides these, azadirachtin related compounds viz., 13, 14-desepoxyazadirachtin A, 1-epiazadirachtin H; 3S224-acetoxy-1S224-hydroxyazadirachtol and 11S224-hydroxy-12-norazadirachtin were also identified from the seeds. The seeds in addition yielded the limonoids identified as 11-hydroxyvilasinin and 23-desmethyllmocin-B. Azadirachtin A was obtained in crystalline state and its crystal and molecular structure was determined using X-ray diffraction techniques. A study on the stereochemistry of azadirachtins H and I suggested that the structures of the two should be revised. 11S224-H and 11Ã-H epimers of azadirachtin H were reviewed. Preparative HPLC procedure has been devised for isolation of azadirachtins and other triterpenoids from seed kernels. Using this optimized method, the azadirachtin content of the seed kernels of neem fruits collected from nine agro-climatic zones of Rajasthan and eight agro-climatic zones of Gujarat were determined. The azadirachtin content varied from 0.194 per cent to 0.670 per cent in the former by weight of the seed kernel. A simple analytical method using optimum HPLC conditions and various solvents as extracting medium was established for the estimation of neem bitters (azadirachtin and nimbidin) in the neem seed kernels. The maximum amount of nimbidin was found in the neem bitters precipitated out when water was used as extracting medium whereas, the percentage of azadirachtin was maximum when extracted with 90 per cent ethanol in water (Akhila and Srivastava, 1998). The feasibility of using a triple solvent systems comprising, acetonitrile, methanol and water in the quantification of azadirachtin in the neem based pesticides has been studied. Radioactive azadirachtin, nimbin and salannin were also produced using P1114P11C-mevalonate and acetate as precursors under in vivo and in vitro conditions in the seed kernels. The tetranortriterpenoids identified in the seeds/kernel were desacetylnimbin; nimbidinin and nimbidic acid; nimbolide, ohcinolide B, 6-deacetylnimbin, azadiradione, nimbin, salannin; nimbanal and 3-acetyl derivative of salannol. It has been reported that photooxidation of nimbin results in its conversion to nimbinolide and isonimbinolide. The seed oil contained azadirone, azadiradione and epoxyazadiradione besides gedunin. The tetranortriterpenoids isolated from the ethanolic extract of the fresh green leaves were identified as meldenin diol, vilasinin, nimonol and isomeldenin; while the fallen yellow leaves gave meldenin and isomeldenin. Quercetin was obtained as an aglycone from the glycosides of the leaves (green/yellow). The structure of nimonol was assigned to nimocinol, the tetranortriterpenoid isolated from the fruits. Later, the structure of nimonol was reassigned on detailed studies. While 6-acetylnimonol was found to be identical with 6-acetoxyazadirone, dihydronimonol was identified as isomeldenin. The biosynthetic relationship of the two limonoids nimocinol and nimocinolide present in the winter leaves was studied under in vivo conditions. The hexane extract of the fresh leaves contained S224-linolenic acid. Optimised procedures for the isolation of limonoids nimbolide and 28-deoxonimbolide, the major antifeedant compounds against the pests of black pepper (Longitarsus nigripennis) and cashew (Heliopeltis antonii), respectively, were developed. About 100 compounds, mostly triterpenoids of protolimonoids (protomeliacins), limonoids (OR meliacins OR tetranortriterpenoids), tetranortriterpenoid-S226-hydroxy butenolides, pentanortriterpenoids, a hexanortriterpenoid apart from a few nontriterpenoid constituents have been reported from various parts as detailed below. Azadirachtin, azadirachtol, azadirachnol, deacetyl-azadiractinol (= 3-tigloylazadirachtol), azadiradione, an isomer of epoxyazadiradione, 17 epi and 17-B-hyroxyazadiradione, gedunin, 7-hydroxygedunin, melianone, nimbiol, nimboeinol (7-acetoxy-7-hydroxy azadiradione), nimocin, 7-deacetoxy-nimolicinol, nimolinone, nimbochalcin and nimbocetin, 21, 23:24, 25-diepoxytirucall-7-en-21-ol salannin (fruits). Kernels yields about 40.0 -48.9%of the oil and contain high amount of tocopherol, arachidic, linoleic, margosic, myristic, oleic, palmitic and stearic acids, azadirone azadiradione, epoxyazadiradione 6-O-acetylnimbandiol, desacetylnimbin, nimocinol, isonimolicinolide and nimolinolic acid have been isolated from various parts of tree. Flowers The petroleum ether extract of dry flowers gave a waxy solid substance and an oil having bitter taste comprising of saturated acids. The ethanolic extract was reported to have bitter toxic substances (Subramanian and Rangaswamy, 1947). Mitra et al. (1947) examined the ethanolic extract of the dry blossoms of neem and isolated a crystalline compound, nimbosterol; a glycoside nimbosterin; a flavon nimbicetin; a hydrocarbon nonacosane; a highly pungent essential oil; a sesquiterpene and a fatty acid fraction containing palmitic, oleic and smaller amounts of stearic, linoleic, behenic and arachidic acids. Nimbicetin was later identified as tetrahydroxyflavone identical with kaempferol (Mitra, 1951). The flowers in addition yielded three flavonoids viz., myricetin, quercetin and kaempferol (Pankajamani and Seshadri, 1952). On examination of the ethanolic extract of the blossoms from Delhi area, Mitra and Siddiqui (1948) could not obtain any bitter principle but obtained the earlier isolated compounds nimbicetin, nimbosterol and nonacosane. A myricetin glycoside, designated as melictrin was isolated from the ethanol extract of the flowers along with quercetin-3-galactoside and kaempferol-3-glucoside. Melicitrin was characterized as myrectin-3â-L-arabinoside and formed the first report of isolation of a myricetin pentoside (Subramanian and Nair, 1972). Further a new tetranortriterpenoid neeflone was isolated from the flowers whose structure was established as 15-acetoxy-7-deactoxydihhdoazadirone (Nanduri and Banstola, 1995). An essential oil (0.25 per cent) obtained from the flowers was found to contain thio-amyl alcohol (7.6 per cent), benzyl alcohol (9.67 per cent), benzyl acetate (8.2 per cent), an unidentified alcohol (3.9 per cent), sesquiterpenes viz., azadirachtene, margosene, and a hydrocarbon (Nigam, 1963). A new isoprenylated flavanone nimbaflavone characterized as 8, 3â-diisoprenyl-5, 7-dihyroxy-4âmethoxyflavanone and a new meliacin 2â, 3â-dehydrosalannol related to salannin were isolated from the leaves in addition to the known meliacins nimbolide, 3-desacetylsalannin and Ã-sitosterol and its Ã-D-glucoside. This was the first report on occurrence of an isoprenyl flavanone in the Meliaceae family which strengthens the taxonomic closeness of Meliaceae with Rutacea (Garg and Bhakuni, 1984b, 1985). Further, the limonoids, azadirachtin A was isolated from the leaves (Podder and Mahato, 1985). Neem oil There have been a number of investigations of neem oil which have been of a conflicting nature both with respect to the active principles as well as the component fatty acids of the fixed glycerides. The so called margosic acid claimed by Chatterjee (1919) and Chatterjee and Sen (1920) was subsequently shown by a number of workers to be a mixture of common fatty acids viz., oleic, stearic, palmitic, linoleic, arachidic and lignoceric acids (Roy and Dutt, 1929; Child and Ramanathan, 1936; Hildich and Murti, 1939; Child and Nathanael, 1944). The oil also had some unsaturated resinous acid along with bitter resinous impurities (Roy and Dutt, 1929).

Author : A. Juss.
Family : Meliaceae
Basic Description of Plant : A large tree 12-15 m high, with a straight trunk. Leaves alternate, simply pinnate, 20-38 cm long, crowded near the ends of the branches; leaflest 9-12, subopposite, 2.5-7.5 by 1.25-3.75 cm obliquely lanceolate, sometimes falcate, acuminate, serrate, glabrous on both surfaces, base inequilateral, acute; petiolules

author: Muell.-Arg.
description: A large or middle-sized tree; young parts minutely pubescent. Leaves 7.5-20 by 3-7.5 cm, elliptic, shortly acuminate, glabrous, base usually acute; petioles 2-3.75 cm long; stipules ovate, decidous. MALE FLOWERS very small, reddish, in puberulous racemose panicles 18-25 cm long, generally much crowded on the trunk; pedicels scarcely .12 cm long, crowded in little clusters of 3-together with or without a short peduncle, and with an ovate concave bract at the base. Sepals 4-6, scarcely .21 cm long. Stamens 5-10. Pistillode discoid, entire or 2-5 lobed. FEMALE FLOWERS about twice as large as the male, in simple puberulous racemes 20 cm long; pedicels .2-.3 cm long, irregularly arranged along the rhachis, and with a minute bract at the base of each. Sepals 4-6, much larger than in the male, usually acute. Ovary ovoid, truncate, hairy, 3-celled; stigma sessile, 3-lobed. Fruit subglobose, 2.5 cm or more in diam., rough with 3 prominent ridges running from the apex to the base, bright crimson when ripe, hanging in great profusion from the trunk, which appears as a crimson mass.
chemical_composition: Stigmasterol was reported from the bark of the plant (Desai et al., 1977).

author: L. Wettst.
description: Herbs, 10-25 cm long, rooting at nodes. Leaves sessile, obovate-oblong, 0.5-2.0 X 0.2-7.0 cm. Flower bluish-white; one sepal ovate, longer than remaining 4 sepals; corolla lobes with glistening dots when fresh. Capsules ovoid, long. Seeds oblong, minute.
pharmacology: I11Bacopa monnieriI11 (âbrahmiâ) is popularly used remedy in psychoneurological disorders in Ayurveda. It has been used in epilepsy, insanity, as a nervine tonic, memory enhancer, for intellectual enhancement etc. Therefore, it has been investigated in detail with special reference to psychoneuropharmacology, and the possible biochemical mechanism of action was elucidated. Some clinical trials were conducted. Some Neuropharmacological actions of hersaponin isolated from the plant were investigated. It had primarily a sedative action in mice. It did not protect rats against electroshock and mice against metrazol seizures. Alcoholic extract of âbrahmiâ in a dose of 25 mg/kg produced slight reduction in the spontaneous motility in mice while 50 to 100 mg/kg i.p. in dose exerted sedative effects in albino rats and rabbits. The behavioural effects of the plant suggested that it had tranquilizing properties but was much weaker than chlorpromazine. It could not block the conditioned avoidance response (CAR) in rats significantly even at higher doses but markedly potentiated chlorpromazine effect on CAR. When given in combination with reserpine, the effect was found to be approximately the sum of their independent effects. Further studies revealed that it decreased motivation for food in hungry rats but did not affect the visual discriminative capacity in rats. It exhibited signs of neurological deficit at 20 mg/kg. The plant extract reduced the spontaneous motor activity (SMA) in non stimulated in rats like other tranquilizers but was less effective than chlorpromazine in antagonising the SMA of amphetamine stimulated rats. It produced graded hypothermia in mice. Effect of the plant extract was studied on conditioned learning of rats, employing T maze. It was observed that oral administration of aqueous decoction of âbrahmiâ exerted a significant improvement in conditioned learning of these animals. Bacosine isolated from aerial parts (dose 25 mg/kg i.p.) exhibited moderate analgesic effects. Brahmi extract in a dose of 100 mg/ml showed barbiturate hypnosis potentiating effect with improved learning behaviour in albino rats. Effects of total extract, alkaloidal fraction and hersaponin isolated from plant on the respiratory activity in vitro of rat brain was studied. The total extract and alkaloidal fraction inhibited the respiration of rat brain tissue to a varying degree. The effect of ethanolic extract of the plant on the cerebral amino acid, S226-aminobutyric acid (GABA), glutamate and glutamine of albino rats was studied at different time intervals with a dose of 100 mg/kg bw. The extract increased GABA level profoundly 15 min after administration, suggesting a correlation between the sedative property of âbrahmiâ and the increased GABA level of cerebral tissues. âBrahmiâ was studied experimentally for its antianxiety effects in rats. The total extract of âbrahmiâ in a dose of 50 mg/100 g bw (50 mg dry extract) orally and its water soluble and insoluble fractions (equivalent to the dose of its total extract) did not show any significant effect on the activity of normal rats. The water insoluble portion showed a significant barbiturate hypnosis potentiation effect. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant was reported to exhibit anticancer activity against Walker carcinosarcoma 256 in rat which was confirmed in the fractionated extract. The crude alcoholic extract of the plant was reported to have cardiotonic and vasoconstrictor actions in frogs and sedative and neuromuscular blocking actions both in frogs and rats. A glycoside saponin isolated was found to have cardiotonic action in normal and hypodynamic frogâs heart, sedative action in rats and guinea pigs, spasmodic action on smooth muscle of rabbit, guinea pigâs ileum and ratâs uterus. The total alkaloidal fraction of the plant stimulated autonomic ganglia followed by blockade, produced spasm of the skeletal muscle acting through neuromuscular junctional apparatus, stimulated respiration followed by depression, showed phenomenon of tachyphylaxis and produced rigidity and convulsions in mice. The alcoholic extract of the plant (50mg/kg i.p.) showed tranquilizing effect in rats and dogs. The aqueous and ethanolic extracts of stem and leaves did not show antibacterial activity against gram positive and gram negative bacteria. The aqueous and ethanolic extracts of stem and leaves did not show anthelmintic activity when tested against earthworms in I11in vitroI11 studies. C11Clinical StudiesC11 A clinical study was undertaken with crude aqueous and defatted alcoholic extracts of the plant in 24 patients with varied mental disorders. The study revealed improvement in learning process and correction in the abnormal behaviour of epileptic patients treated with defatted alcoholic extract (2-4 mg/kg bw) and crude aqueous extract of âbrahmiâ 2 ozs daily for 5 months. 35 cases of anxiety neurosis were treated with âbrahmiâ. One month of treatment of âbrahmiâ in the dose of 30 ml per day in two divided doses (representing 12 g of the dry crude drug) provided significant relief in symptoms besides a quantitative reduction in the level of anxiety. Efficacy of plant was studied in revitalizing intellectual functions in forty school going children from rural area in Varanasi. One group was given âbrahmiâ syrup one teaspoon full (350 mg), thrice daily for three months and the other group was given syrup âSimplexâ used as placebo in the same dose. There was no renovation and improvement of the perceptual motor functions during the development phase in the group receiving âbrahmiâ. View Reference
chemical_composition: Two saponins designated as bacoside A and bacoside B, betulic acid, D- mannitol, stigmastanol, Ã-sitosterol and stigmasterol were isolated from the plant. Bacoside A on acid hydrolysis gave three mononsaccharides, two of which were identified as glucose and arabinose. Bacoside B also gave glucose and arabinose on hydrolysis. Presence of stigmasterol was also confirmed by. Bacosides A and B were identified in terms of their carbohydrate and aglycone moieties. Bacoside A on acid hydrolysis gave rise to four crystalline bacogenins AB111B11, A B112B11, AB113B11, AB114B11. On the basis of correlation studies with structure of bacogenin A1, the structure of bacoside A was proposed as 3-(S224-L-arabinopyranosyl-I11OI11 âÃ-D-glucopyranosid-10,20-dihydroxy-16-keto-dammarene-(24). Bacoside B on hydrolysis gave glucose, arabinose and the same bacogenins as above and hence bacoside B was assigned the same gross structure as proposed for bacoside A. The two bacosides were optical isomers in which bacoside B was found to be dextrorotatory and bacoside A laevorotatory. The haemolytic action of bacoside B was twice that of bacoside A, due to the differences in the configuration of the carbohydrate chain. Three new triterpene saponins bacoside AB111B11, bacoside AB112B11 and bacoside AB113B11 were isolated in minor quantities from the mixture of saponins obtained from the plant. These were assigned structures as 3-I11OI11 â[S224-L-arabinofuranosyl (1-->3)-S224-arabinopyranosyl] jujubogenin, 3Ã-[I11OI11 -S224 âL-arabinofuranosyl (1-->6)-I11OI11 â[-S224-arabinopyranosyl (1-->5)]-I11OI11 â(S224-D-glucofuranosyl)oxy] pseudojujubogenin and 3-Ã-[I11OI11 âÃ-D-glucopyranosyl (1-->3)-I11OI11 â[S224-L-arabinofuranosyl (1-->2)]-I11OI11 â(Ã-D-glucopyranosyl)oxy] jujubogenin, respectively. The I11cisI11-isomer of ebelin lactone was also obtained as one of the artifacts of the aglycone and its structure was revised (Jain and Kulshrestha, 1993). Preliminary chemical studies on the plant showed absence of alkaloids, steroids and amino acids (Shukla, 1983). In another study, the plant showed presence of steroids/terpenoids, alkaloids, flavonoids, tannins and saponins and absence of phenolics. In yet another preliminary Phytochemical study, presence of alkaloids, flavonoids, saponins, sterols and absence of glycosides and terpenoids were reported in the plant. The aerial parts yielded a new triterpene named as bacosine which was characterized as lup-20(29)-ene-3S224-ol-27-oic acid (Vohra et al., 1997). A new sterol, 13,14-seco-stigma 9(11), 14(15) diene-3Ã-ol, designated as bacosterol was also reported from the aerial parts. Isolation of alkaloids, brahmine and herpestine was reported from the leaves. A mixture of three alkaloids, BB111B11, BB112B11 and BB113B11 was previously obtained from the leaves but these could only be isolated as salts. The fresh samples of leaves did not contain appreciable quantities of the bases, BB112B11 and BB113B11 .A previously underscribed sterol was obtained along with the alkaloids. Four new dammarane type triterpene saponins, bacopasaponins A, B, C and D were isolated from leaves and identified as 3-I11OI11 âS224-L-arabinopyranosyl-20-I11OI11 âS224-L-arabinopyranosyl-jujubogenin, 3-I11OI11 â[S224-L-arabinofuranosyl (1-->2) S224-L-arabinopyranosyl] pseudojujubogenin, 3-I11OI11 â[Ã-D-glucopyranosyl (1-->3) {S224-L-arabinofuranosyl (1-->2) S224-L-arabinopyranosyl] pseudojujubogenin and 3-I11OI11 â[S224-L-arabinofuranosyl (1-->2) Ã-D-glucopyranosyl] pseudojujubogenin respectively (Garai et al., 1996a, 1996b).The leaves were reported to yield further two or more dammarane-type jujubogenin bisdesmosides, bacopasaponins E and F which were characterized as 3-I11OI11 â[Ã-D-glucopyranosyl (1-->3) {S224-L-arabinofuranosyl (1-->2)}S224- L-arabinopyranosyl] 20-I11OI11 âS224-L-arabinopyranosyl jujubogenin and 3-I11OI11 â[Ã-D-glucopyranosyl (1-->3) {S224-L-arabinofuranosyl (1-->2) Ã-D-glucopyranosyl]-20-I11OI11 â(S224-L-arabinopyranosyl jujubogenin, respectively (Mahato et al., 2000).

author: (Arn.) Hansen.
description: Glabrous fleshy herbs. Rhizome tuberous with rounded lobes or branches, finely warted all over with large scattered stellate pustules, pale brown. Flowering stems numerous, crowded, male and female from the rhizome, 7.5-15 cm long, obtuse imbricate glabrous yellow or orange scales. MALE FLOWERS crowdes in ovoid-oblong heads 5-6.2 cm long, dull-red, drying dark much browm; pedicels rather stout, at first erect, then dropping; bracts 4 or 5, linear, subacute, reflexed. .4 cm long. FEMALE FLOWERS nearly globose velvety heads 3 cm in diam., purplish, drying dark-brown, densely covered with the minute flowers and with small clavate bodies. Perianth 0. Ovary stalked, hyaline; style long.
chemical_composition: In a preliminary study, inflorescence axis, leaf scale and rhizome showed presence of steroids, triterpenes, tannins, phenols, saponins and sugars and absence of starch, alkaloids and glycosides (Shantha et al., 1992). The rhizome yielded Ã-amyrin stearate, olean-12-ene-3, 11-dione, Ã-amyrin, taraxasterol and palmitic acid (Narayanan et al., 1976). Taraxastenone along with Ã-amyrin palmitate and taraxasterol were also reported from the rhizome (Yadagiri et al., 1984).

author: (Willd.) Muell.-Arg.
description: A leafy stout usually monoecious undershrub 1-2 m high with herbaceous branches from the root, glabrous except the young shoots and sometimes the leaves beneath. Leaves sinuate-toothed, the upper small, lanceolate, penninerved, the lower large, reaching 15-30 cm long and often as broad, ovate, often palmately 3-5 lobed, base rounded or cuneate, 2-glandular; petioles 5-15 cm long; stipules of 2 glands. Flowers in numerous axillary racemes or contracted panicles, all male or with a few females below. MALE FLOWERS: Calyx globose, .25 cm long, 4-5 partite, glabrous, or slightly pubescent; segments suborbicular, concave, imbricate, membranous finely mottled. Petals 0. Disk of 6 glands. Stamens about 20, slender, free; anthers terminal, the cells adnate throughout to the broad connective, dehiscing at first introrsely, the slits ultimately lateral. Pistillode 0. FEMALE FLOWERS: Sepals ovate-lanceolate, pubescent, not accrescent in fruit. Petals 0. Disk .25 cm in diam., thin, entire. Ovary 3-celled; ovule solitary in each cell; style rather long. 2-fid; stigmas smooth. Capsules .8-1.25 cm long, obovoid, usually hairy, of three 2-valved crustaceous cocci. Seeds .8 by .5 cm, ellipsoid, quite smooth, mottled.
pharmacology: Antileukaemic, antiasthmatic, anticancer, hypotensive, purgative, cathartic. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant, in a preliminary screening showed effects on respiration and CVS in dogs/cats. It did not show any antibacterial, antifungal, antiprotozoal, antiviral, hypoglycaemic, anticancer and diuretic activities and effects on CNS in experimental animals. C11ToxicologyC11 In large doses the seeds are acronarcotic poison. View Reference
chemical_composition: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant was devoid of tannins. The leaves showed presence of steroids/terpenoids, flavonoids and absence of alkaloids and saponins. A new non vicinal dihydroxy monounsaturated acid was isolated from the seed oil as a minor component and characterized as 11, 13- dihydroxytetracos-trans-9-enoic acid (axillarenic acid). In a preliminary screening, presence of glycosides and terpenoids and absence of alkaloids, flavonoids, saponins and sterols was reported in the seeds. The plant afforded 5 new phorbol esters belonging to diterpenes hydrocarbon, tigliane skeleton viz., montanin, baliospermin, 12-deoxyphorbol-13-palmitate, 12-deoxy-5Ã -hydroxyphorbol-13-myristate and 12-deoxy-16-hydroxyphorbol-13-palmitate (in roots); axillarenic acid (in seeds). The root showed presence of flavonoids, glycosides, sterols and absence of alkaloids, saponins and terpenoids (Tewari et al., 1984).

author: (Retz.) Willd.
description: Thorny; stems many, tufted on a stout rootstock, 25-30 m high by 15-17.5 cm in diam., usually graceful and curving; nodes prominent (the lowest rooting), the lower emitting horizontal, almost naked shoots armed at the nodes with 2-3 stout recurved spines sometimes 2.5 cm or more long; internodes up to 45 cm long; walls 2.5-5 cm thick; stem-sheaths coriaceous, variable in shape, up to 30-38 by 23-30 cm, striate, with rounded tip and plaited margins, when young orange-yellow streaked with green-yellow and thickly ciliate with golden hairs, blade upto 10 cm long, triangular, acuminate, glabrous outside, densely hirsute inside, the margins decurrent, thickly ciliate; ligule narrow, entire or fringed with pale hairs. Leaves upto 17.5-20 by 2.5 cm, linear or linear lanceolate, tip stiff, glabrous or puberlous beneath, one or more margins scabrous, base rounded, ciliate, midrib narrow, nerves 4-6 with 7-9 intermediate and a few transverse pellucid glands; leaf-sheath ending in a thick callus and shortly bristly auricle; ligule short. Infloroscence an enormous panicle often occupying the whole stem; branchlets bearing loose clusters of pale, suberect, lanceolate, acute, glabrous spikelets 1.25-2.5 by .5 cm. Involucral glumes 2 or 0, ovate lanceolate, acute or mucronate, .5-.8 cm long, many-nerved, empty; floral glumes 3-7, the uppermost 1-3 male or neuter; palea subacute with 2 ciliate keels. Lodicules 3, ovate or subovate, hyaline, ciliate, 1-3 nerved. Anthers yellow, obtuse. Style short. Grain .5-.8 cm long, oblong, beaked by the style base, moved on one side.

locations.place: Shenbagathoppu â top (Grizzled Squirrel Wildlife Sanctuary)

pharmacology: In a preliminary study, the aqueous extract of the leaves in a dose of 2.5 ml/100g in rats showed moderate diuretic activity. The juice from the fresh leaves in a dose of 1 to 10 mg/ml was found to have a mild stimulant action on isolated tissues of rat and human uterus. A compound isolated from the ethanol extract of leaves was tested for its hypoglycaemic action in normal and alloxanized rabbits. Dried bamboo buds (tender shoot) and their alcoholic and rectified spirit extracts exhibited oestrogenic activity in ovariectomised rats. An ethanolic extract of tender shoot caused a reduction in fertility of male rats. The aqueous extract of buds exhibited 44 per cent abortifacient activity in rats when a dose of 175mg/kg was administered orally. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the root, on oral administration (150 mg/kg bw) did not show antifertility activity in female albino rats. The 50 per cent ethanolic and acetone extracts of root at 100 mg/kg did not prevent pregnancy in rats. The aqueous extract (200 mg/kg bw) produced marked sedative and hypothermic effect after 30 min of i.p. administration in mice, rats and guinea pigs. The cold and hot water extract of leaves exhibited antifungal activity against I11Pythium aphanidermatum in vitroI11 studies, the hot water extract being more active. The petroleum ether extract of leaves, seeds, stem and root exhibited larvicidal and juvenile hormone activity against I11Culex quinquefasciatus, Aedes aegyptiI11 and I11Anopheles stephensi.I11 View Reference
chemical_composition: Antitumour activity of bambool leaf extracts against benzopyrene and 4-nitroquinoline-1-oxide-induced tumours in rats, after administration of extract (0.71 mg/ml) or its lignin 0.1% in drinking water libitum for 150 days, was found to be insignificant. Damage to tumour DNA by extract was observed in vitro indicating its direct action on tumour cells.

description: An erect shrub; branches slender, terete, zigzag, downy. Leaves broader than long, 2.8-5 by 3.7-6.2 cm, divided a little less than Â½ way down into 2 rounded lobes, glabrous above, pubescent beneath, base truncate or rarely subcordate; main nerves 1 (rarely 9) from the base; petioles 1.2-2 cm long, pubescent, thickened at both ends. Flowers usually in pairs (rarely 1 or 3), on short axillary or leaf-opposed peduncles; bracts linear, .6-1.2 cm long; pedicels .5 cm long. Calyx campanulate, limb 1.2 cm long, broadly ovate, spathaceous. Petals 3.7-5 cm long, much imbricated, obovate-spathulate, yellow, the upper with a purple blotch on the densely tomentose; Ovary stalked; ovules many; style 1.2-1.5 cm long; stigma peltate. Pods stalked, 10-12.5 by 1.2-1.5 cm, flat pointed, slightly puberulous when fully ripe, veined. Seeds 8-12, oblong, rounded at the apex, .75 by .45 cm.
pharmacology: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root), when screened for various biological activities, viz., antibacterial, antifungal, antiprotozoal, antiviral, antifertility and diuretic activities and effects on respiration, preganglionically stimulated nictitating membrane, CVS, CNS in experimental animals and on isolated guinea pig ileum and rat uterus, did not show any activity. View Reference
chemical_composition: The flowers were reported to yield rutin, quercetin (Row and Vishwanadham, 1954), isoquercitrin and quercetin-3-glucoside (Subramanian and Nair, 1963). The seeds were reported to be rich source of minerals like Ca, Mg, Fe and Zn. Albumins and glutelins were the predominant seed protein fractions. The total free phenols, tannins, L-dopa (3, 4-dihydroxyphenylalanine) were analyzed and haemagglutinating activity was assayed (Mohan and Janardhanan, 1995).

locations.vegetation: Tropical Dry Deciduous type of Vegetation

pharmacology: The saline extract of seed exhibited haemagglutinating activity against erythrocytes of man, monkey, rabbit, rat, goat, sheep, cow, buffalo, horse, mule and fowl. The decoction of bark and leaves was found to inhibit the activity of pectic enzymes viz., protopectinase and polygalacturonase of I11Alternaria tenuis.I11 In an experimental study, effects of I11Bauhinia variegataI11 (âkachnarâ) and I11Eichornia crassipesI11 (jalkumbhiâ) were studied on rats with goiter induced by neomercazole in a dose of 15 mg/day up to 20d. Both the drugs (200mg/day) were effective in bringing the goitrogenic thyroid to normal level. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the stem bark in a preliminary screening showed gross behavioural effects, hypothermia and antagonism to amphetamine hyperactivity in mice. The fresh leaf juice was devoid of bacterostatic activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Escherichia coli.I11 The methanolic extract of leaves exhibited antibacterial activity against I11Proteus vulgaris, Bacillus anthracis, Escherichia coli, Streptococuss agalactiaeI11 and antifungal activity against I11Aspergillus fumigatusI11 and I11A. niger.I11 The extracts of the buds, flowers, leaves and stem extracts were tested against I11Salmonella paratyphi, Staphylococcus albus, Vibrio cholerae, Xanthomonas campestris, Xanth malvacearum.I11 In general, the stem bark was most active against most of the organisms. The leaf extract exhibited toxicity against ringworm causing fungi I11Epidermophyton floccosum, Trichophyton mentagrophytesI11 and I11Microsporum gypseum.I11 The aqueous extract of the bark showed nematicidal activity against second stage juveniles of I11Meloidogyne incognita.I11 The extract of the stem showed juvenilizing activity against I11Dysdercus cingulatusI11 nymphs. View Reference
chemical_composition: The stem yielded a flavone glycoside characterized as 5, 7-dihyroxyflavone-4- I11OI11 âS224-L-rhamnopyranosyl-Ã-D-glucopyranoside (Gupta et al., 1979). The isolation of Ã-sitosterol, lupeol and a 5, 7-dimethoxyflavone 4â, I11OI11 âS224-L-rhamnopyranosyl âÃ-D-glucopyranoside was also reported (Gupta et al., 1980). A flavonolglycoside, characterized as kaempferol -3-glucoside, was also isolated (Gupta and Chauhan, 1984). Stem bark showed presence of hentriacontane, octacosanol, stigmasterol (Prakash and Khosa, 1978) and of sterol, glycosides, reducing sugars and nitrogenous substances, in a preliminary Phytochemical screening (Prakash et al., 1978). In a preliminary study, the bark showed presence of saponins and tannins and absence of alkaloids. In another study, the leaves and bark showed presence of alkaloids, glycosides, steroids while saponins were present only in bark and tannins were absent in both the parts. The seed oil consisted of the glycerides of the fatty acids viz., myristic, palmitic, stearic, oleic, linoleic and lignoceric together with sitosterol (Puntambekar and Krishna, 1940). Linoleic, stearic, oleic, palmitic, caprylic, capric, lauric and myristic acids were reported by other workers. Crude protein, crude fibre, carbohydrates were reported in seeds.

author: L.
description: Erect, annual herbs, stem 4-gonous, grooved. Leaves opposite, very variable, sometimes 3-foliolate, but usually consisting of 2 subopposite pairs of leaflets and a deeply 3-lobed terminal leaflet which is larger than the lateral ones, the lowest pair of leaflets sometimes again pinnatyely divided; ultimate leaflets subsessile, ovate, acute, serate, glabrous; common petioles somewhat dilated and sheating at the base. Heads solitary on long peduncles, reaching 1.25 cm in diam, elongating in fruit. Outer invol-bracts herbaceous, oblong, subacute, shorter than the inner, ciliate and with scarious margins. Ray-florets ligulate, white or yellow, ligules narrow, strap-shaped; corolla tubular, 10-12 mm long; lobes of corolla ovate, acute. Anther-cells entire at the base, or sagittate with blunt auricles. Style arms of bisexual flowers hairy above; tips short, acute or subulate. Pappus of 2-4 rigid retrosely hispid slightly spreading awns. Achenes .8-1.6 cm long, linear, quadrangular, slightly tapering towards the apex, glabrous.
pharmacology: The leaf, stem, branch and root did not show cholinesterase activity. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant, collected from Dehradun, when screened for antibacterial, antifungal, antiprotozoal, hypoglycaemic and anticancer activities and effects on respiration, CVS, CNS in experimental animals and on isolated guinea pig ileum, did not show any activity. The ether extract of leaves and stem did not exhibit juvenile hormone like activity. View Reference

author: (L.) DC.
description: Annual herbs, stem erect, from 2.5-25 cm long, stout or slender, glabrous or hairy. Leaves sensitive, crowded into a rosette on the top of the stem 3.75-7.5 cm long; petiole short; rhachis slender, glabrous or hairy; leaflets opposite, 1 cm long, 6-15 pairs (the terminal pair the largest, the pairs becoming smaller downwards), oblong, obliquely rounded and apiculate at the apex, subsessile, glabrous, paler beneath. Flowers dimorphic, .8 cm across, yellow; peduncles many of various lengths upto 10 cm long, slender, pubescent or glabrous; pedicels many; bracts lanceolate, small, crowded beneath the pedicels. Sepals 5, lanceolate, acute with parallel nerves. Corolla much exceeding the sepals; lobes 5, rounded, spreading. Stamens 10, distinct; filaments free, the 5 inner longer. Ovary 5-celled; styles 5, nearly glabrous. Capsules ellipsoid, apiculate, slightly exceeding the sepals; cells few-seeded. Seeds ovoid, transversely striate.
chemical_composition: Isoorientin, orientin, isovitexin, isoorientin 7-O-glucoside, isoorientin 2''-O-rhamnoside, and isovitexin 2''-O-rhamnoside were isolated from the MeOH ext. of the leaves. From the roots (-)-epicatechin and epicatechin-(4bÂ®8)-epicatechin (proanthocyanidin B2) were isolated. C-glycosylflavones were found in leaves. Amentoflavone (13',118-biapigenin) was isolated from the roots Benzene derivs., such as 1,4-dimethoxy benzene (24.9%), 1,2-dimethoxy benzene (10.6%) and 2-methoxy-4-Me phenol (3.5%), the monoterpenes (Z)-linalool oxide (8.1%), (E)-linalool oxide (5.2%) and linalyl acetate (3.4%), as well as 1-octen-3-ol (9.5%) and isophorone (3.1%) were found to be the main constituents of essential oil. Amentoflavone was isolated from I11Biophytum sensitivumI11 using High-Performance Thin-Layer Chromatography (HPTLC) method. Two biflavones, cupressuflavone and amentoflavone, three flavonoids, luteolin 7-Me ether , isoorientin and 3'-methoxyluteolin 7-O-glucoside, as well as two acids, 4-caffeoylquinic acid and 5-caffeoylquinic acid were isolated from the aerial parts of I11Biophytum sensitivumI11.

author: Benth.
description: A large shrub or small tree reaching 10 m high and 7.5 cm in diam.; bark smooth. Leaves very variable 6.2-15 by 2.5-6.2 cm; oblong-lanceolate or ovate, obtuse acute or acuminate, entire glabrous, penninerved, base usually acute; main nerves 6-8 slender; petioles .6-1.2 cm long. Flowers in terminal racemes the males at the top, the females few at the base of the raceme. MALE FLOWERS: -Pedicels .4 cm long, filiform-sepals usually 4, membranous, suborbicular, concave, imbricate, .4 cm in diam. Petals much smaller than the sepals, hyaline, .8-.12 mm long, broadly obovate. Glands of the disk scale-like, as long as the petals, oblong slightly 3-lobed. Stamens 10-30; filaments .15-.12 long, flattened; anthers somewhat horseshoe-shaped, the cells on the margin of connective. FEMALE FLOWERS: Pedicels stout, thickened upwards. Sepals ovate-lanceolate, acute, very deciduous. Petals 0. Style 3 deeply 2-fid. Capsules ellipsoid or subglobose, .8-1.2 cm long, glabrous deeply 3-1obed, of three 2-valved cocci. Seeds reaching 1 by .6 cm, ellipsoid, smooth and shining, brown mottled with white.
pharmacology: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant, (excluding root) when screened for various biological activities showed effects on isolated rat uterus. The extract did not show antibacterial, antifungal, antiprotozoal, antiviral and diuretic activities and effects on respiration, CVS, CNS in experimental animals. View Reference
chemical_composition: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant, (excluding root) when screened for various biological activities showed effects on isolated rat uterus. The extract did not show antibacterial, antifungal, antiprotozoal, antiviral and diuretic activities and effects on respiration, CVS, CNS in experimental animals. LDB1150B11 of the extract was reported to be 825 mg/kg i.p. in mice (Abraham et al., 1986).

author: DC.
description: Prostate or decumbent herbs branched from the base; branches slender, leafy, 7.5-25 cm long, simple or dichotomously forked, pubescent or glabrous, the young ones often sericeo-canescent. Leaves alternate, membranous; spinous toothed, those near the base of the stem reaching sometimes 10-12.5 by 3.7-6.2 cm, obovate-oblong or elliptic-oblong, petioled, upper stem-leaves much smaller, 1.2-3.7 by .6-2.1 cm, subsessile, obovate or elliptic, pubescent on both sides, the young ones often sericeo-villous. Anther-bases sagitate; tails usually slender. Heads heterogamous, solitary or cymose, on slender peduncles; flower yellow. Outer flowers many-seriate, female, fertile; disk-flowers bisexal, few, fertile (rarely sterile). Involucre ovoid or campanulate; bracts many-seriate imbricate, narrow, acute, herbaceous or soft, the outer gradually smaller. Receptacle flat, naked. Corolla lobes of male flower glabrous; of female flowers filiform, minutely 2-3 toothed, those of the bisexual flowers regular, tubular, slender, with a slightly enlarged 5-toothed limb. Style-arms of the bisexual flowers flattened or almost filiform, somewhat acute, papillose on the back, rarely connate so as to form one undivided style. Pappus slender, 1-seriate, usually caduceus. Achenes slightly hairy.
pharmacology: In preliminary screening, the 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant, exhibited gross behavioural effects and antagonism of amphetamine hyperactivity test in mice and diuretic activity in rats. It did not show anthelmintic, hypoglycaemic and anticancer activities and effects on respiration, preganglionically stimulated nictitating membrane, CVS, and isolated guinea pig ileum. View Reference
chemical_composition: In preliminary screening, the 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant, exhibited gross behavioural effects and antagonism of amphetamine hyperactivity test in mice and diuretic activity in rats. It did not show anthelmintic, hypoglycaemic and anticancer activities and effects on respiration, preganglionically stimulated nictitating membrane, CVS, and isolated guinea pig ileum. LDB1150B11 of the extract was found to be 600 mg/kg i.p. in mice (Dhar et al., 1974).

author: Wedd.
description: An erect shrub or small tree; bark thin, grayish-brown; stems and branches terete, pubescent. Leaves membranous, alternate, subequal or alternately large and small, the larger 10-20 by 4.5-8.7 cm, elliptic-lanceolate, acuminate or caudate, crenulate or serrulate from above the rounded subacute or sometimes cordate base, glabrous and sometimes rugose above, pubescent beneath, strongly 3-nerved from the base with 2-4 lateral pairs of nerves above, reticulately veined between the nerves; petioles 2-7.5 cm long; stipules small, deciduous flowers monoecious, minute, greenish-white, in small, axillary sessile clusters .4-.6 cm in diam., the males and females in different axils. MALE FLOWERS: Perianth 4-partite, pubescent. Stamens 4. Pistillode small globose. FEMALE FLOWERS: Perianth tubular, 4-toothed, pubescent. Achenes minute, ovoid, closely invested by the perianth.
pharmacology: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) did not show any activity when screened for antibacterial, antifungal, antiprotozoal, hypoglycaemic, anticancer and diuretic activities and effects on respiration, nictitating membrane, CVS and CNS in experimental animals and on isolated guinea pig ileum. View Reference
chemical_composition: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) showed presence of tannins (Atal et al., 1978).

author: L.
description: Prostrate herb; stems glandular-hairy, base woody, root large, fusiform. Leaves at each node in unequal pairs, ovate oblong; the larger 2.5-3.7 cm, the smaller 1.2-2 cm long, both nearly as broad as long, broadly ovate or sub-orbicular, rounded at the apex, green and glabrous above, usually white with minute scales beneath, the margins entire, often coloured pink, somewhat undulate, base rounded or subcordate; petioles nearly as long as the blade, slender. Flower very small, pink, 4-10 together in axillary and terminal umbels; perianth .3 cm long; ovarial part of tube .12 mm long, contracted above the ovary, lobes glandular hairy with vertical streaks outside. Stamens 2 or 3 slightly exserted. Ovary oblique, stipitate; ovule erect; stigma peltate.Fruit .3 cm long, clavate, rounded, braodly and bluntly 5-ribbed, very glandular.
pharmacology: Diuretic, antiinflammatory, antiviral, anticonvulsant, cardiotonic, antihypertensive, hepatoprotective, antibacterial, significant antifibrinolytic. âPunarnavaâ (I11B. diffusaI11) has attracted lot of attention due to its prevalent uses in Ayurvedic system of medicine. It is widely used in jaundice, hepatitis, oedema, oligurea, anaemia inflammations, eye diseases, etc. Pharmacologists and clinicians have investigated âpunarnavaâ for all these activities. In some cases, the findings support the existing clinical uses. Different extracts and three isolated from extracts were subjected to in vivo and in vitro testing for antihepatotoxic activity. The petroleum ether, chloroform and methanol extracts and the total alkaloids (isolated from the methanolic extract) of the root were reported to slightly lower the increased SGOPT, SGPT, SALP in rats treated with CCI4. The chloroform and the methanol extracts exhibiting relatively better enzyme lowering effects were subjected to further fractionation yielding one of the isolates identified as rotenoid (6, 11-dihydroxy-9-10-dimethyl-4-methoxyrotenoid. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of root (100 mg/100 g bw) protected the albino rats from hepatotoxic action against country made liquor (CML) - induced hepatotoxicity. An alcoholic extract of the plant given orally exhibited hepatoprotective against experimentally induced CCIB114B11 â hepatotoxicity in rats and mice. Administration of aqueous form of drug (2 ml/kg) had more hepatoprotective activity than the powder form. This was probably due to the better absorption of the liquid form through the intestinal tract. The effect of extracts of red and white varieties of the plant was studied on diuresis and renal enzymes. Both the varieties exhibited diuretic activity in toads. Red variety showed comparatively less activity. The diuretic activity of water soluble fraction of root and leaves was reported in male albino rats and dogs. The activity was attributed to the presence of potassium content in it. The aqueous and acetone extracts of the root, showed significant antiinflammatory activity against carrageenan-induced oedema and formaldehyde-induced arthritis in albino rats. The water insoluble alcoholic extract of different parts of the plant viz., root, stem, leaves and flowers and plant was studied for antiinflammatory activity against carrageenan-induced oedema in rats and for diuretic activity. The root and leaves were found to be most active and the activity was found maximum during rainy season. The alkaloidal fraction isolated from the root was investigated for its effect on plasma cortisol, adrenal, cortisol and humoral response in stressed rats. It exhibited restorative activity against stress-induced changes in plasma and adrenal cortisol levels. It also significantly augmented the antibody production in stressed rats as compared to control. The 50 per cent aqueous ethanolic extract of root, when administered orally in experimental monkeys was found to stop intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD)-induced bleeding at 50mg/kg bw. Presence of cholinestrase activity was shown in leaves while the activity was not detected in stem/branch. The punarnavine isolated from the plant produced distinct and persistent rise of blood pressure and marked diuresis in cats when injected intravenously. The total alcoholic extract, its water soluble and water insoluble fractions and fat soluble fraction from petroleum ether extract showed a cardiotonic effect, an increase in blood pressure in dog and relaxant effect on smooth muscle of rabbit. In a general pharmacological screening, the 50 per cent alcoholic extract of the root exhibited significant antiinflammatory activity in both in carrageenan oedema and cotton pellet implantation models and diuretic activity in albino rats. It also showed spasmogenic action on isolated guinea pig ileum. Aqueous extracts of powdered stem and root were found to be ineffective as anticoagulants against both plasma and whole blood. The plant was found to promote longevity, growth and nitrogen retention in the rats on the stock diet. The alcoholic extract of root showed antimicrobial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 whereas aqueous extract was active against I11Escherichia coliI11 and inactive against I11Staphylococcus aureus.I11 The phosphate buffer and ether extracts of shoot showed antibiotic activity against I11Staphylococcus aureus.I11 The seed exhibited antibacterial activity against I11Bacillus subtilis, Pseudomonas cichoriiI11and I11Salmonella typhimuriumI11 but was inactive against I11Escherichia coli.I11 The aqueous extract of root exhibited antifungal activity against I11Microsporum nanum.I11 The aqueous extract of root exhibited 21-50 per cent inhibition of spore germination against I11Curvularia lunata, Cylindrocarpon lichenicola, Fusarium solaniI11 and I11Myrothecium leucotrichum.I11 The fresh leaf extract inhibited germs tube elongation of I11Drechslera oryzae.I11 The aqueous extract of leaves/stem/ flowers/seed/plant exhibited antifungal activity against 3 keratinophilic fungi; moderate activity against I11Microsporum gypseumI11 (39.01 per cent), was less effective against I11Chrysosporium tropicumI11 (25.63 per cent) and showed minimum antimycotic activity against I11Trichophyton terrestre.I11 The aqueous extract of leaf showed nematicidal activity against second stage juveniles of I11Meloidogyne incognitaI11 (kofoid and white) chitwood. The aqueous extract of root was reported to contain an agent with characteristics of protein and which showed broad spectrum potent antiviral activity against tubular (tobacco mosaic virus â TMV and sunhemp rosette virus-SRV), spherical (gomphrena mosaic virus-GMV and tobacco ring spot virus-TRSV) and potato virus X in different plant host virus combinations. C11ToxicologyC11 Vomiting may be associated with large doses of the drug on account of its emetic properties. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 In a double blind clinical trial conducted on 43 normal adults, powdered whole plant in form of tablets, moderately decreased the mean level of blood urea and serum acid phosphatase. The results of a double blind trial to study the effect of âpunarnavaâ (plant) on haemoglobin, blood urea, serum cholesterol, blood sugar, vital capacity and body weight in 43 normal healthy adult volunteers in the age group 45-50 years over a period of 42 months were reported. It did not show any appreciable effect on the blood constituents in the initial examinations. Subsequent examinations have shown that it decreased blood urea and serum acid phosphatase with an increase in serum cholesterol and marginal increase in blood sugar. Weight remained almost stationery. In a trial involving 19 patients suffering from generalized anasarca, or jaundice of varying etiology, plant root extract was given orally and urine output, pulse rate and dropsy were recorded in subsequent weeks. There was increased urinary output with reduction in specific gravity of urine. In a controlled clinical trial on a total of 15 cases (including 3 cases in control group) of nephrotic syndrome, a decoction or total crude powder (10g daily in divided doses) exhibited beneficial effects comparable to corticosteroids. Out of a total of 12 cases on the decoction, 4 cases showed relief, 7 cases were improved and 1 case showed deterioration. A clinical study was carried out to evaluate the diuretic and immunological actions of âpunarnavaâ with special reference to nephrotic syndrome in 40 patients. The drug was administered to patients in the dose of 500 mg thrice a day for one month. The results showed increase in serum protein level and reduced urinary protein excretion in patients of nephrotic syndrome. In a double blind trial in children (8-12 years), it was reported that administration of milk fortified with I11Withania somniferaI11 and âpunarnavaâ daily for two months increased significantly Hb per cent and mean corpuscular haemoglobin concentration. chemical_composition: Isolated an acid designated as boerhavic acid. In a preliminary screening, plant revealed presence of sterols (Singh and Udupa, 1972b), Ã-sitosterol, alkaloids. Presence of steroids, sugars and alkaloids was also reported. Flavonoids, glycosides, saponins and terpenoids were found to be absent. The plant was found to contain 39.0 mg/100 g free vitamin C carotene was absent. A steroid, androst-5-ene- analogue and flavone, 6, 5â-dimethoxy-5, 7, 3â-trihydroxyflavone were isolated from the aerial parts. Hentriacontane, Ã-sitosterol and ursolic acid along with glucose, fructose and sucrose were isolated from the root. The root was also reported to yield Ã-ecdysone along with triacontanol and Ã-sitosterol. A rotenoids, characterized as 6, 11-dihydroxy-9, 10-dimethyl-4-methoxyrotenoid, was isolated from the root. A new unsaturated acid, characterized as triacont-24-en-l-oic acid was also reported from the root in addition to Ã-sitosterol. Two quinolizidine alkaloids identified as punarnavine-I and punarnavine-II were isolated from root, stem and leaves. The distribution of these alkaloids was maximum in stem and minimum in root. A relation was established between the growth process of the plant and biosynthesis of these two alkaloids. The alkaloidal content was initially low during commencement of pre-reproductive phase, gradually increased in different plants parts, becoming maximum during termination phase of reproductive stage (Nandi and Chatterjee, 1974). A new C-methylflavone characterized as 5, 7-dihydroxy-3â,4â-dimethoxy-6,8-dimethylflavone was reported from root and designated as borhavone. The root was also reported to yield a new dihydroisofuranoxanthone, methyl-3, 10-dihydro-11-hydroxy-1-methoxy-4, 6-dimethyl-10-oxo-1H-furo [3, 4-b] xanthene-3-carboxylate, designated as borhavine. Four new compounds, boerhavisterol, boerhadiffusene, diffusarotenoid and boerhavilanostenyl benzoate and a known rotenoid, boeravinone A were isolated from the root and their structures elucidated as : 9, 10-seco-stigmast-5, 8 (9) âdien-3-Ã-ol; 1-(2â, 6â, 6â-trimethylcyohex-1â-enyl)-11-(3â-3â-dimethylcyclohexyl)-4, 8-dimethyl-undiec-1-ene; 4, 9-dihydroxy-10-methyl-6a-dehydrortenoid-6-pentanoate; 27-I11OI11 â(4â-benzoyl-Ã-D-glucopyranosyl)-9Ã-lanost-5-en-3-one and 6-methoxy-9, 11-dihyroxy-10-methyl-6a, 12a- dehydrorotenoid, respectively.

author: (Roxb.) Rolfe.
description: A shrub with spreading branches; bark smooth, grey; branchlets slender, angular, glabrous. Leaves numerous, distichous, 1.2-2.8 cm, membranous, broadly elliptic, obtuse, glabrous, glaucous beneath; main nerves 3-5 pairs; petioles .4 cm. Flowers appearing with the young leaves, axillary on filiform pedicels, the males in the lower, in fascicles of 1-3. MALE FLOWERS: Calyx turbinate or hemispheric with a truncate limb, the margin often thickened and lobulate opposite the minute inflexed and rounded the lobes. Petals 0. Disk 0. Stamens 3; filaments connate in a column; anthers slender, adnate to the whole length of the column, the cells linear, parallel distinct. Pistillode 0. FEMALE FLOWERS greenish. Pedicels shorter than in the male. Calyx deeply divided into 6 rounded apiculate segments. Ovary truncate; styles 3, stout. Fruit orange-red, fleshy but dehiscent, seated on the greatly enlarged colored calyx. Seeds 3-quetrous with an orange-yellow aril; testa perforate at the hilum.

author: Gehrm.
description: Large scandens shrubs. Leaves sub-coriaceous, often with shallowly crenate margins. Flowers monoecious, in small dense axillary clusters or long spikes subtended by stipular hairy bracts. Drupes ellipsoid -oblong seated on slightly enlarged calyx, black and juicy.
pharmacology: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) collected from Uttar Pradesh showed hypotensive activity (confirmed in the fractionated test) and effects on respiration in dogs/cats, and gross behavioural effect in mice. It was found to be devoid of antibacterial, antifungal, antiprotozoal, hypoglycaemic, anticancer and diuretic activities and effect on isolated tissues. In another study, the 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) collected from Karnataka showed effects on CVS in dogs/cats and diuretic activity in rats. The plant was devoid of other activities viz., anthelmintic, hypoglycaemic and anticancer and effects on isolated guinea pig ileum and CNS. The aqueous and alcoholic extracts of the plant exhibited antifungal activity against I11Aspergillus niger,I11 while these extracts did not show antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11and I11Escherichia coli.I11 The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) was devoid of insecticidal activity against I11Musca domesticaI11and I11Tribolium castaneum.I11 View Reference

author: Blume. Bijdr.
description: A large climbing shrub, sometimes with aerial roots; bark dark-grey; stems 5-20 cm in diam.; branches sometimes with long deflexed spines; young branches long, slender, usually fulvous-tomentose. Leaves alternate, 2.5-10 by 1.2-5 cm, subcoriaceous, elliptic-oblong or obovate, obtuse or subacute, often with shallowly crenate margins, glabrous above, pale and pubescent beneath; main nerves 6-12 pairs, slightly arching, the transverse veins at right angles, parallel; petioles .4-1 cm long. Flowers monoecious, greenish-yellow, in small dense axillary clusters or long spikes, often subtended by stipular hairy obliquely lanceolate acute bracts .3 cm long. Calyx .5 cm long, hairy outside; segments triangular-ovate, acute, connate at the base. Petals .15 cm long, broadly obovate or suborbicular, shortly cuneate at base, crenulate at apex. Staminal column .3 cm long to top of anthers. Styles with long slender arms. Drupe 1 cm long or more, ellipsoid-oblong, seated on th slightly enlarged calyx, black and juicy when ripe.
chemical_composition: The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the plant (excluding root) showed presence of tannins. The bark yielded friedelin and Ã-sitosterol, while the root afforded a terpenoids identified as taraxerone. The root, stem bark, leaf and fruit showed absence of saponins, alkaloids and flavonoids.
