author: (Lam.) Taub.
description: Decidous trees with ash coloured, fissured bark. Leaves 3-foliolate; leaflets, obovate, ovate-rhomboid. Flowers large in dense rigid racemes; densely brown velvety. Corolla salmon or orange coloured, clothed outside with silvery hairs. Pods stalked, 1-seeded, reticulately veined, silvery tomentose.
pharmacology: Anthelmintic, antiimplantation, antiovulatory, abortifacient, antileprotic, antigout, antiestrogenic, spasmogenic, antifungal, antispasmodic, hypotensive, astringent, alterative, aphrodisiac, antiasthmatic, bactericidal. I11Butea MonospermaI11 (âpalasâ) is a popular drug in Ayurveda, and is prescribed in various conditions which includes worm infestations, eye diseases, antifertility activity, menstrual irregularity, etc. Antifertility activity and its mechanism have been studied in several centres. Studies have also been conducted in males. Its inflammatory activity with special reference to eye disease has been studied. The hot alcoholic extract of the seed was found effective in preventing pregnancy in all eight rats when administered at a dose of 300mg/kg bw on day 1-4 of pregnancy. At higher doses it was toxic. The same extract was shown to have antiovulatory effect when tested on rabbits. The dried alcoholic extract of seeds was reported to have distinct antifertility activity in mice and rats when given orally during the first five days of pregnancy. The antifertility activity occurred in the seed powder and its alcoholic extract but not in the aqueous or chloroform extract. The activity was of low efficacy. The extract did not have oestrogenic, antioestrogenic or androgenic actions. It partially inhibited ovulation. Various fractions of the ethanolic extract of the seeds and flowers were tested for antiimplantation activity in albino rats, at different doses. The ethanolic extract of seeds, and outer seed coat at the dose of 200 mg/kg bw in female rats exhibited 75 and 62.5 per cent antifertility activity, respectively. An aqueous extract of flowers provided protection against experimentally-induced liver injury by CClB114B11 in albino rats as evidenced by biochemical and histopathological studies. In pentobarbitone sleeping time studies, the extract showed improvement of the metabolic functions in these liver injured animals. The ocular antiinflammatory activity of the âarkasâ from the root and leaves and âarkasâ formulated as gels was studied in rabbits. The âarkasâ of the plant showed better results than the flurbiprofen, while with respect to gels, intraocular pressure monitored at different time intervals revealed no statistically significant difference between gel formulations. The water extracts of the seeds and its various fractions (FrB111B11, FrB112B11, Fr B113B11) were used for pharmacological studies. The results showed fall of blood pressure together with bronchi constriction in dogs and contraction of guinea pig ileum by water extract. FrB113B11 considerably potentiated the action of ACh on blood pressure, frog rectus and guinea pig ileum. FrB112B11 showed hypotensive action similar to that of FrB113B11 considerably potentiated the action of Ach on blood pressure. Palasonin and its piperazine salt were tested for their effect on isolated frogâs and rabbits heart, rabbitâs smooth muscles, blood pressure and respiration in dogs. Palasonin exhibited perceptible lessening of the amplitude in frogâs and rabbitâs heart. It caused slight increase in the tone of smooth muscle. It did not produce any immediate perceptible effect on blood pressure and respiration. It also exhibited partial neuromuscular blocking effect at the concentrations studied in experiments using frogâs sciatic nerve. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of leaves, when screened for biological activities, showed spasmodic action on isolated guinea pig ileum. The alcoholic extract of the fresh bark and seeds showed antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureusI11 and I11Escherichia coli.I11 The chloroform, methanolic and aqueous extracts leaves, and a steroidal compound isolated from the leaves were screened for antimicrobial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus pumilusI11 and I11Escherichia coli.I11 The methanolic extract and the steroidal compound exhibited strong activity against I11Bacillus pumilus.I11 The activity of the methanolic extract was attributed to the steroidal compound present in it. The leaf extract when screened for antifungal activity, the per cent inhibition of mycelial growth was 35.47 per cent for I11Epidermophyton floccosum,I11 40.64 per cent for I11Trichophyton mentagrophytesI11and 33.35 per cent for I11Microsporum gypseum.I11 The seeds were found to contain alkaloids, two of which were water soluble. The total alkaloids were found to be toxic to earthworms. A compound principle, isolated from the ethanolic extract of the seeds showed anthelmintic activity against roundworms. Palasonin, obtained from the seeds, and its piperazine salt were studied for in vitro anthelmintic activity against I11Ascaris lumbricoidesI11 (human) and in vivo studies against I11Toxicara canisI11in dogs. The fruit and bark were found to possess a very mild degree of insecticidal activity against houseflies, Musca domestica nebulo and Aedes aegypti. C11ToxicologyC11 Seeds contain 3 alkaloids which were toxic to earthworms. Palas exhibited low mortality in mice on acute toxicity tests. Chronic toxicity trials performed for months on rats, dogs and rabbits showed nephrotoxicity. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 Clinical trials revealed that seeds are effective in roundworm and threadworm infestations. However the clinical use of the seed as an anthelmintic drug in human is found to produce nephrotoxicity, hence not considerable safe. The seed powder was found to be effective against I11Ascaris lumbricoidesI11 in a clinical trial. A study of âpalashâ seeds used as decoction either orally or as retention enema was carried out in 15 cases of worm infestation (6 cases of roundworm, 8 cases of thread worm, and 1 case of tapeworm infestation. Five out of 6 patients of round worm, 7 out of 8 patients of thread worm showed good results whereas in the case of tapeworm no response was observed. Side effects like nausea, vomiting, dizziness, general weakness and pain in abdomen were regularly observed with oral administration, when used as retention enema, the drug caused bowel irritation. View Reference
chemical_composition: A glycoside of butin (3â, 4â, 7-trihydroxyflavanone) was obtained from the flowers in 2.6 per cent yield and named butrin. Butein (0.003 per cent) was obtained in traces as a by product. The glycoside on acid hydrolysis gave two molecules of glucose and one molecule of butin. A bioside structure was proposed for butrin, with the sugar group occupying only one hydroxy group of butin. Later studies established that butrin was a 3â, 7-diglycoside of butin and the first example of a glycoside, amongst the anthoxanthins, to contain the sugar residues in two different positions. It was also the first instance of a compound to carry a sugar group in the side phenyl nucleus among both anthoxanthins and anthocyanins. Butrin was obtained in good yield by a simple method from the dry flowers. On acid hydrolysis, it gave a mixture of butin and butein. Two colourless, crystalline compounds were also isolated, one of which was a phytosterol and other an unidentified heteroside. Free butein and butin were also isolated from the flowers. Presence of a new chalcone glycoside isobutrin, was detected by circular chromatography along with butrin from the flowers. It was identified to be a chalcone isomer of butrin and constitution established as 4, 3â-diglycoside of butein. Isobutrin was found to be the major component of the water soluble flavonoid pigments form the flowers with an intense yellow colour. Studies showed that the flower extract could be used as a colourant in the yellow range in place of synthetic food colours. Another new glycoside palasitrin was isolated from the flowers, which yielded two molecules of glucose (at 6 and 3â position) and 2-(3, 4-dihyroxybenzylidene)-6-hydroxycoumaran-3-one on hydrolysis . A reinvestigation of the flowers revealed the presence of seven flavonoid glucosides, two of them being butrin and isobutrin isolated earlier from the plant. Three of the glucoside were identified as coreopsin, isocoreopsin and sulphurein. The remaining two new ones were named monospermoside and isomonospermoside and characterized as butein-3-Ã-D-glucoside and 3â, 4â, 7- trihydroxyflavone-3â-glucoside, respectively. Another report also showed presence of seven flavones and flavonoid constituents including butrin and isobutrin along with four amino acids (histidine, aspartic acid, alanine and Ã-alanine). ?-Sitosterol was reported from the flowers. The flower petals afforded free amino acids viz., histidine, aspartic acid, alanine, phenylalanine along with free sugars glucose and fructose. The oil from seeds showed presence of unsaturated acids (oleic and linoleic), saturated acids (palmitic and lignoceric) sitosterol and acid fractions of molecular weight 354 and 383. Further studied the seed oil for fatty acid composition. Studies showed presence of 46-47 per cent saturated acids with palmitic acid as the major component (20-23 per cent), along with smaller amounts of stearic, arachidic, behenic, lignoceric, caprylic, capric, myristic and lauric acids. The unsaturated acids consisted of oleic (26-31 per cent) and linoleic (19-28 per cent) acids. The seeds were reported to be a promising source for vegetable oil, yielding 17.5 per cent oil on air dry basis and its use in soap making was suggested. Composition of saturated and unsaturated fatty acids was also reported by other workers. S224-Amyrin, Ã-sitosterol, Ã-sitosterol-Ã-D-glucoside and sucrose were reported from the seeds. The fresh seeds were also found to contain proteolytic and lipotylic enzymes.

author: L.
description: Perennial, armed, usually scandent tufted palms. Leaves alternate, pinnatisect; leaflets acuminate; nerves parallel; rhachis often produced as an armed flagellum; sheath armed, produced into a ligule or ochrea with or without a lateral armed flagellum. Flowers small, polygamo-dioecious, in spikelets, solitary or binate (a female, a male, or both) in the axils of the bracteoles of axillary usually much-elongate and much branched spadices. Spathe tubular or open, persistent, sheathing the peduncle and branches of the spadix, and passing into bracts and the bracteoles. MALE FLOWERS: Calyx copular, 3-toothed. Petals 3, acute, coriaceous, valvate. Stamens 6; filaments short; anthers dorsifixed. FEMALE FLOWERS slightly accrescent; fruiting pedicelliform or exlobes valvate. Staminodes connate into a cup. Ovary incompletely 3-celled, clothed with retrorse scales; ovules basilar, erect; style carp thin, clothed with apprised, deflexed, closely imbricate scales. Seed subglobose or oblong, smooth or pitted; albumen uniform or ruminate; embryo vertical or basal.

author: L.
description: A very handsome, small or middle-sized evergreen tree, with a crooked trunk; bark grey, smooth. Leaves coriaceous, shining, 10-17.5 by 7.5-10 cm, broadly elliptic, rounded at the apex, often emarginated, with subrepand waved margins and very close lateral nerves, giving a striate appearance to the blade, base acute; petioles 1-1.5 cm long, stout, flat. Flowers 2-2.5 cm in diam., pure white, fragrant, in lax few-flowered racemes 10-15 cm long. Sepals 4, ovate-orbicular, concave, reflexed, ciliolate, the two outer much the smaller. Petals 4, oblong, obtuse, spreading. Stamens numerous; filaments united into 4-6 bundles. Ovary 1-celled; ovule 1, erect; style long, twisted, stigma large; mushroom-shaped. Fruit globose, 2.5-1.2 cm in diam., smooth, yellowish; pulp scanty.

author: (L.) R. Br.
description: Large erect shrubs or small trees. Brk yellowish-white, furrowed; branches stout, terete, more or less covered (especeally the younger ones) with fine appressed cottony pubescence. Leaves opposite, decussate, 10-20 by 3.7-5 cm, broadly obovate or elliptic-oblong.sub-sessile, clothed beneath and more or less above with fine cottony tomentum. Iflorescence a rymbose cyme. Flowers of medium size, 1.2-5 cm in diam., pedicels much longer than the flowers, covered with cottony wool; buds ovoid. Calyx of 5 distinct sepals, glandular inside, braodly ovate, by .4 cm. Corolla 2 cm. long or more; lobes 1.2-1.5 cm long, deltoid-ovate, subacute, rebvolute and twisted in age; corona of 5 fleshy laterally compressed lobes, adnate to and standing out as wide buttresses from the staminal-column with an upcurved and involute spur at the base and bifid at, or with 2 obtuse auricles a little below, the apex. Anthers short and broad, with short broad membranous appendages inflexed over the depressed pentagonal summit of the style-apex; pollen-masses solitary in each anther-cell, pendulous, attached to the pollen-carriers by short slender caudicles. Folicles short, thick not echinate. Seeds comose.

author: Gmel.
description: A climbing shrub, sometimes spiny; young branches yellowish-green, pubescent. Leaves alternate, 3.7-9.5 by 1.5-4 cm thinly coriaceous, oblong-lanceolate or ovate, glabrous on both surfaces, base narrowed or rounded, often slightly inequilateral; main nerves 3-5 pairs, curved, ascending; petioles .14-.3 cm long. Flowers hermaphrodite, monochlaymydeous, .25 cm long, in pubescent axillary spikes 1.2-2.5 cm long, one or two spikes from an axil; bracts minute, linear-lanceolate, one at the base of each flower. Perianth pubescent externally, urceolate, 4-5 toothed, the apices of the teeth recurved. Stamens as many as the lobes of the perianth and opposite to them; filaments glabrous, free, or attached between the thick fleshy lobes of the disk; anthers small, oblong, adnate, 2-celled, dehiscing longitudinally. Ovary superior, ovoid-conical, glabrous; ovule solitary, pendulous from a short placenta; style cylindric; stigma capitates, 4-lobed. Fruit drupaceous, about 1,25 cm long, ovoid or ellipsoid, orange-red, surmounted by the remains of the style, glabrous.

author: Wight.
description: A large climbing shrub; stems reaching 15 cm in diam.; young branches purple, glabrous, shining. Leaves simple, alternate, 7.5-10 by 3-5 cm, elliptic-oblong, obtuse or acute, with a short callous tip, glabrous on both surfaces, shining above, paler beneath petioles 1.2-2 cm long; stipular thorns, short, stout, hooked. Flowers white, 10-12.5 cm in diam., in terminal corymbs; pedicles 3.7-6.2 cm long, stout, flattened, glabrous. Sepals 4; the outer 2.5 cm in diam., orbicular, much imbricate; the inner broadly oblong, finely tomentose outside. Petals 4, spreading, pubescent on the upper surface. Stamens very numerous, 5-6.2 cm long, inserted on the tortus at the base of a 5-7.5 cm long gynophores. Ovary stalked, ovoid, glabrous. author: L.
description: Annual and perennial climber; branches slender, striate, pubescent or glabrous. Leaves alternate, deltoid, 2-ternate; petioles2-3.7 cm long; ultimate segments of the leaves lanceolate, glabrous or sparsely pubescent, inciso-serrate, very acute at the apex and narrowed at the base. Flowers irregular, polygamo-dioecious, white, .3-.4 cm long, in few flowered umbellate cymes; peduncles slender, stiff, axillary, 3.7-10 cm long, provided beneath the cyme with 2 opposite usually circinate tendrils; pedicels very slender, .3-1.2 cm long. Sepals 4, much imbricate; outer sepals rounded, obovate, usually with a few scattered hairs on the back just below the apical margin; inner sepals larger than the outer, rounded, membranous. Petals 4, arranged in pairs, the two upper furnished with a large scale below the base of each, the 2 lower smaller, distant, each furnished with a small crested scale. Disk unilateral, undulate, of 2 glands opposite the lower petals. Stamens 8, excentric; filaments unequal, free of connate at the base. Ovary sessile or subsessile, 3-celled; ovule solitary, ascending; style very short, 3-fid. Capsules shortly stalked, subglobose or more commonly depressed-pyriform, trigonous, truncate at top, winged at the angles, bladdery, veined. Seeds globose, .4-.6 cm in diam., smooth, balck, with a small white heart-shaped aril.
chemical_composition: Seeds are cyanogenic and contain glycosides. Essential oil is also extracted from seeds.

author: Roxb.
description: A glabrous middle-sized or sometimes a large tree attaining 18 m with rounded head; bark thick, rough, dark-grey. Leaves alternate, 15-30 by 7.5-17.5 cm usually sessile, broadly ovate or oblong-ovate, rounded or shortly acuminate, crenate-denticulate, glabrous, tapering at the base; main nerves 10-12 pairs; petioles 0-2 cm long, margines. Flowers yellowish-white, ill-smelling, sessile, 6.2-8.7 cm across, in thick swollen hard terminal spikes each with a central elliptice bract and 2 linear lateral ones. Calyx about 2.5 cm long; tube campanulate; segments 4, rather shorter than the tube, oblong, obtuse, stiff, erect. Petals 4, elliptic-oblong, 3.7-5 cm long, obtuse or subacute. Stamens very numerous, epigynous, in several rows, slightly connate at the base; filaments very long, red, the intermediate perfect; anthers versatile, dehiscing longitudinally. Fruit 6.2-7.5 cm in diam., globular, green, glabrous, somewhat like an apple in appearance. Seeds numerous, nesting in fleshy pulp.

author: L.
description: A large evergreen shrub with a short stem, glabrous except the inflorescence; bark light-grey, scaly; branchlets usually alternate, with twin stout sharp horizontal spines 2.5-1.2 cm long at their base. Leaves 3.7-7.5 by 2.5-5 cm, coriaceous, elliptic or obovate, obtuse, often shortly mucronate, glabrous and shining, petiolate. Flowers white scarcely odorous, in pubescent terminal corymbose cymes. Calyx pubescent, cleft rather more than Â½ way down; lobes .25-.3 cm long, lanceolate, very acute, ciliate. Corolla hypocrateriform, tube about 1.2 cm long, swollen and pubescent near the top; lobes 1 cm long, oblong-lanceolate, acute, often pubescent and ciliolate. Stamens included within the corolla-tube; filaments very short; anthers linear-oblong. Ovary glabrous, 2-celled; ovules 4 in each cell; stigma slightly penicillate at the apex. Fruits 1.2-2.5 cm long,ellipsoidal, purplish-black when ripe, smooth, 4-more seeded.

author: L.
description: Tall unarmed palms with annulate, naked or sheathed trunks; trunk 12-20 m high by 30-45 cm in diam., cylindric, annulate, not or scarcely soboliferous, smooth, grey, shining, covered with long shallow cracks with corky edges. Leaves bipinnate, 5.5-6 by 3-4.5 m; primary divisions 1.5-2 m long, arched and drooping; leaflets 10-20 cm long, fasciculate or alternate, cuneiform, obliquely truncate, irregularly serrate-toothed on the truncate margin, the upper margin produced beyond the leaflets into a tail, flabellately veined, quite glabrous, bright green, shining, the margins at the base recurved; petiole very stout, about 7.5 cm thick at the base; sheath smooth, with fibrous netted margins. Spadix 3-3.5 m long; branches simple forming a dense tassel. Spathes ca .5 m long, closely embracing the peduncle of the spadix. MALE FLOWERS: symmetric; buds narrowly cylindric. 1.2 cm long. Sepals 3, cordate, ciliate. Petals 3, coriaceous, concave, reddish. Stamens about 40; filaments short, white; anthers acuminate, as long as the petals. Pistillode 0. FEMALE FLOWERS: Subglobose, smaller than the male. Sepals 3, rather broader than in the male. Petals 3, rounded, valvate. Staminodes usually 3. Ovary obovoid, 3-gonous, 3-celled; ovule solitary, erect; stigma sessile, 3-lobed. Fruit 1.6-2 cm in diam., reddish; pericarp acrid, stinging. Seeds 1 or 2.
phenology: Flowers: during most of the year.

author: L.
description: A tall much branched shrub; bark smooth, reddish-brown; branchlets finely pubescent. Leaves 7.5-10 cm long; rhachis densely fulvous-pubescent with an erect linear gland between each pair of the leaflets; stipules foliaceous, reflexed, very large, rotund-reniform, produced at the base on the side next the petiole into a long subulate point, persistent. Leaflets 8-12 pairs, 2-2.5 by 1-1.25 cm slightly overlapping, oblong ovate, obtuse or emarginate, mucronate, glabrous or finely downy dull green above, paler beneath, base usually rounded; petiolules 1.25 mm long. Flowers large, reaching 5 cm across, in terminal and axillary corymbose racemes; pedicels 2-2.5 cm long; bracts ovate, acuminate, caducous. Calyx glabrous; segments 5, leathery, concave, the 2 outer much smaller than the other 3. Petals 5, with long claws, crisped on the margin, bright yellow, veined with orange. Stamens 10, of which the 3 upper are reduced to staminodes, the remaining 7 perfect, of which the 3 lower are larger than the 4 lateral ones. Pods 7.5-12.5 by 1.25-1.5 cm, flat, thin, papery, oblong, obtuse, mucronate, pale brown, deeply depressed between the seeds, having a crumpled appearance, transversely veined, pubescent. Seeds 10-20.

author: L.
description: An annual foetid herb, up to 1 m high. Leaves 7.5-10 cm long; rachis grooved, more or less pubescent, with a conical gland between each of the 2 lowest pairs of leaflets; stipules 1.25-2 cm long, linear-subulate, caducous. Leaflets 3 pairs, opposite, 2.5-4.5 by 1.25-2.5cm (the lowest pair the smallest), obovate-oblong, glaucous, membranous, glabrous or more less pubescent, base somewhat oblique, usually rounded; main nerves 8-10 pairs; petiolules .25 cm long, pubescent. Flowers usually in subsessile pairs in the axils of the leaves, the upper crowded; common peduncle in fruit not exceeding .4 cm long; pedicels in fruit rarely exceeding .8 cm long. Calyx glabrous; segments 5, divided to the base, .5 cm long, ovate, acute, spreading. Petals 5, pale yellow, subequal, .8 by .25 cm, oblong, obtuse, spreading, the upper petal (standard) 2-lobed, the others entire. Stamens 10, the 3 upper reduced to minute staminodes, the remaining 7 perfect, subequal. Ovary superior, ovules many. Pods 12.5-20 by .4-.5 cm, subtetragonous, much curved when young, obliquely 25-30, rhombo-hedral, with the long axis in the direction of the pod.

author: Willd.
description: A climbing unarmed shrub; young branches usually covered with pale lenticular warts. Leaves alternate, 6.25-10 by 3-5.5 cm, broadly elliptic ovate, or obovate, shortly acuminate, crenate-serrate in the upper part, usually entire near the base, glabrous, base rounded or acute; petioles .6-1.25 cm long. Flowers yellowish- or greenish-white, unisexual, in terminal pyramidal panicles 5-15 cm long; pedicels pubescent; bracts small, lanceolate. Calyx pubescent outside; lobes 5, semiorbicular, ciliate. Petals .3 cm long, oblong, rounded at the apex, inserted below the disk, spreading at the apex. MALE FLOWERS: Stamens 5, inserted on the margin of the disk; filaments short; anthers oblong, about .2 cm long. Rudimentary ovary small, subconical, slightly 3-toothed at the apex. FEMALE FLOWERS: Stamens inserted on the edge of the disk which is larger than the disk in the male flowers; anthers small, without pollen, ovate, acute or subtriangular. Ovary globose, seated on the disk (not immersed). 2-4 lobed, 2-4 celled; ovules 2 from the base of the cell, collateral, erect; narrowed into a short stout style; stigma large, 3-4 lobed. Capsules 1-1.25 cm in diam., subglobose, bright yellow, transversely wrinkled, 3-valved, the valves spreading after dehiscence remaining united at the base exposing the seeds. Seeds 1-6, often solitary, ovoid, cinnamon-brown, striate, completely enveloped in a scarlet fleshy aril.
pharmacology: Many pharmacological studies deal with its effects on the central nervous system, and the tranquilizing property of the alkaloidal fractions or the oil. The seed oil sedated rats in a dose of 1 g/kg body weight on intramuscular administration. On intraperitoneal exposure, this effect was less marked. In cats 50-100 mg/kg peritoneal exposure, this effect was less marked. In cats 50-100 mg/kg oil proved hypotensive with a fall in cardiac output, brady cardia and marked increase in pulse pressure. The extract showed marked CNS depressing activity (230 Â± 5 mg/kg body weight, ip ) without loss of the righting reflex even in larger doses than above. Studies have been done on the tranquilising fraction of the oil. C11CLINICAL USAGEC11 The effect of this plant on the memory process has also been evaluated. Clinical observations on the use of the oil in psychiatric practice were promising. In ayurveda, it is used for its tranquilising action, which has been substantiated by contemporary clinical trials. View Reference

author: (L.) Urban.
description: A slender herbaceous creeping plant; stems long, prostrate, coming off from the leaf-axils of a vertical rootstock, filiform, often reddish, and with long internodes, rooting at the nodes. Leaves 1.25-3.75 cm in diam., several from the rootstock which often have much elongated petioles, and 1-3 from each node of the stems, orbicular-reniform, rather broader than long, more or less cupped, entire or shallowly crenate, glabrous on both sides, and with numerous slender nerves from a deeply cordate base; petioles very variable in length, 7.5-15 cm long or more, channeled, glabrous or nearly so; stipules short, adnate to the petioles, forming a sheathing base. Flowers in fascicled umberls, each umbel consisting of 3-4 pink, sessile (rarely pedicelled) flowers; peduncles pubescent or glabrous, short, pink; bracts ovate, acute, concave, 2 beneath each umbel. Calyx-teeth 0. Petals minute, pink, ovate, acute. Fruit .4 cm long, longer than broad, ovoid, hard, with thickened pericarp, reticulate-rugose, often crowned by the persistent petals, the primary and secondary ridges distrinct.
pharmacology: Antiprotozoal, spasmolytic, alterative, astringent, antiinflammatory, antifertility, sedative, CNS depressant, antitubercular, antileprotic, hepatoprotective, antispasmodic, antiamoebic, hypotensive. C11ToxicologyC11 Subcutaneous injection of asiaticoside in doses of 0.04 to 0.05 gm / kg in rat and rabbit was found toxic. The oral dose of 1 gm / kg was well tolerated. Contact dermatitis has been observed due to Madecassol ( an extract of C. asiatica). Triterpene glycosides have been identified as having oncogenic activity and asiaticoside has been implicated as a possible carcinogen on repeated application. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 The result of double blind trial of Mandookaparni on mentally retarded children showed a very significant increase in both general ability and behavioural pattern when the drug was administered even for a short period of 12 weeks. It produced a significant improvement and behavioural change. View Reference

author: (L.) Kuntze.
description: Annual, robust, erect, leafy; stems up to 1 m high, branched, pubescent. Leaves 5-7.5 by 2.5-3 cm, lanceolate or elliptic-lanceolate, acute, coarsely serrate, more or less pubescent on both sides, base tapering into the petioles. Heads 1.25-2 cm in diam., subcorymbose, many- flowered, with a linear bract near the top of the peduncles. Outer involucral-bracts linear, hairy, herbaceous, shorter than those of the inner rows; inermediate bracts with herbaceous hairy tips, linear, acute or subobtuse, ofte constricted at the base of the herbaceous part, equalling or shorter (rarely longer) than the innermost; inner-most bracts usually the longest, linear, subacute, often tipped with purple. Corollas all equal, regular tubular, slender; lobes 5, narrow. Anther-bases obtuse. Style-arms subulate, hairy. Pappus reddish, the exterior row very short, subpaleaceous, peristent, the inner somewhat flattened, deciduous, much shorter than the glabrous corolla. Achenes 1-2.5 mm long, obolong-cylindric, 10 ribbed, pubescent.

author: Thuill.
description: Annual herbs, 15-30 cm high, the whole plant clothed with glandular and simple hairs. Leaves sessile or nearly so, .8-2.5 by .6-1cm, mucronate; the lower leaves obovate-spathulate; the upper elliptic-ovate, obtuse or acute, becoming gradually smaller upwards. Flowers white, less than .6 cm across, in corymbose cymes; bracts ovate, herbaceous. Calyx less than .6 cm long; sepals 5 (rarely 4), hairy, lanceolate, very acute, their margins narrowly membranous. Petals 5, about equal in length to the sepals or a little longer, bifid to about one third of the way down. Stamens 10, rarely 5 or fewer. Ovary 1-celled; ovules many; styles 5, opposite the sepals (rarely 4 or 3). Fruit a capsules; more than twice as long as the sepals, curved upwars. Seeds yellowish-brown, minute, roundish-obovoid, tuberculate.

description: Perennial glabrous twining herbs. Root of many small tuberous knobs with fleshy fibres; stem slender. Leaves opposite, membranous, 3-10 by 1.25-5 cm, the lower leaves suborbicular, the middle-stem leaves ovate, the upper oblong, all usually apiculate, glabrous, base rounded, acute or sub-cordate; petioles .6-1.25 cm long. Peduncles 1-3 together, 1.25-7.5 cm long, arising from between the petioles or subaxillary; pedicels fascicled or subpaniculate, slender, glabrous; bracts subulate. Calyx 5-partite, divided to the base; sepals .4-.5 cm long, narrowly lanceolate, acute, with scarous margins, more or less recurved. Corolla tubular, usually enongate, 2.5-3.75 cm long; tube inflated at the base and enlarged at the mouth; limb suddenly contracted from a broad triangular base into linear lobes, at first connate throughout their entire length, apperaing in bud like a narrow beak, afterwards free, about Â½ as long as the tube; outer corona cupular, truncate, with 5 small pockets alternating with the inner corona-lobes, ciliate; inner corona-lobes .25 cm long, linear, slightly clavate at the apex. Staminal-column airising a little above the base of the corolla, very short, included in its inflated basal part; anthers oblong or subquadrate without appendages. Pollen-masses with a pellucid apical margin, erect, attached to the pollen-carriers by very short caudicles. Follicles 9-12.5 by .3 cm, slender, straight or very slighly curved, tapering to a fine point, glabrous. Seeds .6 cm long, linear-oblong; comose; coma 2.5-3.75 cm long.

author: (Roxb.) Baker.
description: Herbs. Root-fibres cylindric, with ellipsoid tubers hanging from them. Leaves radical, clustered, 6-12, membranous, sessile, 15-30 by 1.25-2.5 cm, shorter than the scape, usually falcate, recurved, acuminate, the margins undulate. Scape terete, naked, 3.75-30 cm long. Flowers white, in simple or shortly branched racemes 5 by 2.5-3.75 cm when expanded; bracts lanceolate, acuminate, the lower 1.25-2 cm long; pedicels ascending, .6-1.25 cm long, jointed below the middle. Perianth-segments less than 1.25 long by .4 cm broad, oblong-lanceolate, subacute, 7-9 nerved. Stamens 6, hypogynous, .8 cm long, free or the filiform, often widened above the middle; anthers .4-.5 cm long, dehiscing introrsely, the filament inserted in a small pit on the back of the connective. Stigma minute. Ovary 3-quetrous, 3-celled; capsules obovoid, 1by .6 cm, shining, transversely veined, emarginated, the cells 4-6 seeded. Seeds irregularly orbicular, .3 cm in diam., black.

locations.vegetation: Tropical semi evergreen to evergreen forest

chemical_composition: The roots contain a bibenzyl xyloside, steroidal sapogenins, sarsasapogenins, tigogenin, neogitogenin and tokorogenin. It also contains pentacosyl docosandoate and stigmasterol.

author: L.
description: A climbing shrub; branches striate, pubescent or subglabrous. Leaves peltate, 3.75-5 cm in diam., orbicular or reniform, often slightly broder than long, cordate or truncate at the base, mucronate, pubescent on the surfaces when young, at length glabrous, underside pale or sub-glaucous, margins ciliate: petiole 3.75-5 cm long, pubescent, inserted .3-.6 cm within the basal margin. Flowers minute, yellowish. MALE FLOWERS pedicelled in nearly axillary cymes; peduncles filiform, .6 cm long, pubescent; bracts small, subulate. Sepals 4, hairy outside, obovate-oblong, concave. Petals combined into a cyathiform corolla hairy without, glabrous within, half the length of the sepals. Anthers 2-4, sessile, connate, encircling the top of the peltate staminal column, bursting transversely; filaments longer than the corolla. FEMALE FLOWERS in elongate, solitary or twin, axillary racemes; pedicels very short, pubescent or villous; bracts foliaceous, more or less stalked or nearly sessile, orbicular or renifrom, mucronate, usually softly villous (sometimes glabrous) ciliate, persistent. Sepal 1, ovate-oblong, villous on the outside. Staminodes 0. Ovary style short. 3-fid or 3 toothed. Drupe globose, compressed, hairy, red; endocarp transversely ridged. Seed horseshoe-shaped.
chemical_composition: Hayatin, mp. 298Âº dec., furnished hydrochloride, picrate, chloroplatinate, methiodide and methochloride; hayatinin furnished HCI and picrate; hayatin, L- curine and d-isochondrodendrine from roots and vines; structure of hayatinin, mp. 231Âº, elucidated; root bark showed presence of eleven quaternary alkaloids, three of which were termed menismine, cissamine and pareirine in addition to known 1-bebeerine, hayatinin, hayatin and d-isochondrodendrine, five more tertiary alkaloids present in root bark; a new alkaloid (+ + )-4"-O-methylcurine isolated; structure of hayatin established as dl-bebeerine; hayatidin, mp. 179Âº, identified as dl-4"-O-methylbebeerine; hayatinin shown to be racemic mixture; cissamine chloride, mp. 215Âº, was identical with cyclanoline chloride.

author: L.
description: Climbers; stems leafless when old, very long, fleshy, glabrous, much contracted at the nodes, quandrangular, the angles of the young branches winged; tendrils long, slender, simple. Leaves 2.5-5 cm long, broadly ovate or reniform, sometimes 3-7 lobed, denticulate, glabrous, cordate, rounded, truncate or cuneate at the base; petioles .6-1.25 cm long; stipules small, broadly ovate, obtuse. Flowers in shortly peduncled cymes with spreading umbellate branches. Calyx cup-shaped, truncate or very obscurely lobed. Petals 4, ovate oblong, acute, .3 cm long, hooded at the apex. Disk erect, 4-lobed. Style short, stout. Berry obovoid or globose, scarcely .6 cm long, apiculate, red when ripe. 1- (very rarely 2-) seeded.
pharmacology: Hypotensive, stomachic, powerful alterative, analgesic, antifungal, cardiotonic, antiamoebic, antiasthmatic, fracture healing. The alcoholic extract of I11C. quandrangularisI11 improved the rate of fracture healing and calcification process in experimental animals. The rate of bone fracture healing was markedly hastened in animals with alcoholic free aqueous extract of the plant without affecting plasma biochemical parameters. The parental administration of total extract of the plant neutralized the antianabolic effect of cortisone in healing of fractures in rabbits. The water soluble fraction of 80% alcoholic percolate of the plant demonstrated cholinergic action in isolated ileum of rabbit and albino rat, rat uterus, dog tracheal muscle and ileum in situ and cardiotonic action in atropinised frog heart. An unidentified water soluble constituent presumably a glucoside obtained from the plant elicited dose dependent negative chronotropic effect in isolated at trial tissue of guinea pigs. The glucoside also produced dose dependent fall in blood pressure in anaesthetized cats. Diuretic activity was observed with 50 per cent ethanolic extract in mice. It is showed moderate genotoxic effect in Swiss mice. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 In a clinical trial, I11Cissus quadrangularisI11 was used as a supplement to treat jawbone fracture, the immobilization period was reduced significantly. A herbal preparation in form of lotion and mouth spray, possessing Ashtisamhar as constituent, was found effective in a variety of inflammatory lesions of the oral cavity including gingivitis and periodontitis. author: Lam.
description: Quite glabrous; stem stout, cylindric or tetragonous. Leaves variable usually 3-foliolate (with very shortly stalked or sessile leaflets), sometimes 3-partite or 3-lobed or simple (often all 3 kinds of leaves on one and the same plant); leaflets or segments unequal, the middle one lanceolate, the lateral ones very obliquely ovate or oblong, all acuminate or acute, bristle-serrate, glabrous on both sides; petioles 2.5-5 cm long; stipules ovate-orbicular. Flowers 4-merous, in subumbellate divaricate cymes which are usually shorter than the petioles, numerous near the end of the branch; pedicels short. Calyx saucer-shaped, subtruncate. Petals 4, free. Style long. Berry 1 cm long, obovoid 1- seeded, black. Seed .3-.45 cm in diam., girt with a ring round the middle, smooth, yellowish-white.

author: Schrad.
description: Monoecious, trailing herbs; root perennial; stems diffuse or creeping, slender, angled, branched, hirsute or scabrid. Tendrils simple or 2-fid, slender, hairy. Leaves very variable, 3.75-6.25 by 2.5-5 cm in the wild form (larger in the cultivated one), usually deltoid in outline, pale-green above, ashy beneath, scabrid on both surfaces, 5-7 lobed or very commonly 3-lobed, the middle lobe the largest, each lobe deeply pinnatifid or sinuate-lobulate, the segments obtuse; petioles 1.25-2.5 cm (longer in the cultivated form) densely hirsute. Flowers rather large, yellow, monocious, all solitary. MALE FLOWERS: Peduncles .6-1.25 cm long, villous. Calyx hairy, campanulate, .5 cm long; teeth 5, lanceolate, .2 cm long. Corolla .6 cm long, late, .5 cm long; teeth lanceolate, .2 cm long. Corollar 5-partite, .6 cm long, pale yellow; segments obovate, apiculate. Stamens 3; filaments short, free; anthers scarcely cohering, one 1-celled, the others 2-celled, the cells linear, flexouse, the connective not produced. Pollen smooth. Rudimentary ovary glanduliform. FEMALE FLOWERS: Calyx and corolla as in the male. Rudimentary stamens 3, setose or ligulate. Ovary ellipsoid, densely hairy. Fruit globular, slightly depressed, 5-7.5 cm in diam, variegated green and white, glabrous when ripe, filled with a dry spongy very bitter pulp; epicarp thin. Seeds .4-.6 cm long, pale brown.
pharmacology: The aqueous extract of the rind of I11C. colocynthisI11 fruit showed significant hypoglycaemic effect in normal rabbits. Aqueous extract of saponin components obtained from the rind showed antihyperglycaemic effect in alloxan induced diabetic rabbits. Different extracts of seeds showed significant insulinotropic effect in isolated rat islets and rat pancreas accounting for the anitdiabetic activity of fruits. 50 per cent ethanolic extract of fruit showed an antiandrogenic effect thereby inducing reversible infertility in male albino rats. Decreased body weight gains, inefficiency of feed utilization, enterohepatonephropathy and diarrhoea have been shown in rats fed diet containing 10 per cent of fruits. The fruit extract inhibited lipid peroxidation and production of reactive oxygen species in rat liver. Coloside A (S224-elaterin-2-D-glucopyranoside) isolated from the pulp exhibited uterine depressant property in vitro in rats. It produced a negative chronotropic and negative ionotropic effect on isolated rabbit and frog heart and exhibited antihistaminic and anticholinergic action in isolated rabbit intestine and guinea pig ileum. Major therapeutic claims as Antidabetic. The drug used traditionally in prescribed doses may be considered safe. View Reference

Stamens many, .6-.3 cm long; filaments ligulate, glabrous; connective not produced. Carpels many; ovule 1, pendulous. Achenes ovoid, compressed, silky-villous, with long feathery tails.

author: L.
description: Annual, erect herb, up to 1m high; stems grooved, densely clothed with glandular and simple hairs. Leaves 3-5 foliolate; petioles of the lower leaves 2.5-5 cm long, gradually becoming shorter upwards; the floral leaves (bracts) often sub-sessile. Leaflets elliptic-oblong or obovate, acute or obtuse, the terminal the largest and reaching 4.5 by 2.5 cm (when 5-foliolate the basal pair much reduced); petiolules short, hairy. Flowers yellow, axillary, growing out into a lax raceme. Sepals 4, spreading. Petals 4, subequal, oblong-obovate, about 1.25 cm long veined. Stamens exceeding 20. Ovary sessile or with a very short gynophore; ovules many, on 2 parietal placentas; style short or 0. Capsules 5-6.25 by .4 cm, erect, hairy, obliquely striate, compressed, tapering towards both ends, terminated by a style .3 cm long. Seeds brown-black when ripe, finely transversely striate, subglobose.

author: (L.) Moon
description: A shrub 1-3 m high, scarcely woody, not much branched; stems bluntly quadrangular; young parts usually glabrous. Leaves opposite, often some ternate (passing into bracts above), sometimes reaching as much as 27 cm long but usually 7.5-15 by 5.6-6.25 cm, oblong or elliptic, acute, coarsely and sharply serrate, glabrous, base acute; petioles very stout, .6 cm long. Flowers numerous, showy, in lax pubescent dichotomous cymes, with a pair of acute bracts at each branching and a flower in the fork, each in the axil of a large leafy bract and collectively forming a long lax terminal usually pyramidal erect panicle 15-25 cm long; pedicels often twisted so as to make the large lower corolla-tube appear uppermost; bracts 1.25-3.75 cm long, from obovate to lanceolate, pubescent, subpersistent, often colored. Calyx .5 cm long, puberulous, cup-shaped, truncate, not enlarged in fruit; lobes very small, tringular, acute, ciliolate. Corolla glabrous outside, pale-blue, the large lower lobe (often appearing upper in flower) dark bluish-purple; tube 1 cm long, cylindric, hairy within at the insertion of the stamens, oblique at the mouth; the 2 upper and 2 lateral lobes elliptic, obtuse, flat, spreading, 1 cm long, the lower lobe lip-like, more than 1.25 cm long, concave, deflexed. Stamens 4, didynamous, much-exserted; filaments much curved, densely hairy at the base. Ovary and style glabrous; ovule solitary in each cell. Drupe .6 cm long, somewhat succulent, braodly obovoid, normaly 4 lobed with 1 pyrene in each lobe.

author: L.
description: A perennial twining herb; stems terete, more or less pubescent. Leaves imparipinnate; petioles 2-2.5 cm long; stipules .4 cm long, linear, acute. Leaflets 5-7, subcoriaceous, 2.5-5 by 2-3 cm elliptic-oblong, obtuse, glabrous or with a few short appressed hairs, base obtuse of acute; stipels filiform. Flowers axillary, solitary; pedicels .8-1.25 cm long, roundish, obtuse. Calyx Calyx tubular; 1.25-2 cm long; the 2 upper teeth subconnate. teeth lanceolate, shorter than the tube. Corolla much exserted; 3.75-5 cm long; standard bright-blue or sometimes white, with an orange centre; large, erect, emarginate, narrowed and not appendiculate at the base; wings falcate-oblong, spreading, adhering to the middle of the keel; keel shorter than the wings, incurved, acute. Stamens monadelphous or diadelphous; anthers uniform. Ovary stalked; ovules many; style elongate, incurved, more or less flattened, bearded along the inner side. Pods 5-10 by .8-1.25, flattened, nearly yellowish-brown, smooth.
pharmacology: Insecticidal, cholinergic, antioxytocic, antihistaminic, analgesic, diuretic, purgative, laxative, abortifacient. View Reference
chemical_composition: Roots contain taraxerol and taraxerone while seeds contain cinnamic acid and an anthoxanthin glucoside. Palmitic, stearic, oleic, linoleic and linolenic acids have been reported from seed oil. Leaves contain glycosides of kaempferol and stigmast-4-ene-3, 6-dione. Flowers furnished a blue anthocyanins which contain delphinidin-3, 5-diglucosdide, six acylated anthocyanins based on delphinidin along with flavonols. lactone, aparajitin, clitorin from leaves were also reported.

author: (L.) Voigt.
description: Perennial, scandent or prostrate, much branched herbs; root thick; stems grooved, slender, glabrous. Tendrils slender, striate, simple. Leaves 5-10 cm long and broad, bright-green above, paler beneath, studded and sometimes rough with papillae, palmately 5-nerved from a cordate base, often with circular glands between the nerves, obtusely 5-angled or sometimes deeply 5-lobed, the lobes broad, obtuse or acute, apiculate, more or less sinuate-toothed; petioles 2-3.75 cm, long. Flowers rather large, dioecious. MALE FLOWERS: Peduncles 1-flowered, 2-3.75 cm long, subfiliform. Calyx tube glabrous, broadly campanulate, .4-.5 cm long; limb 5-lobed, teeth .25 cm long, linear. Corolla 2.5 cm long, campanulate, shortly 5-fid, veined, pubescent inside, glabrous outside; segments .45-.75 cm long, triangular, acute. Stamens 3; filaments connate into a column; anthers connate into a subglobose capitulum. Rudimentary ovary 0. FEMALE FLOWERS: Peduncles 1.25-2.5 cm long; flower solitary. Calyx and corolla as in the male. Staminodes 3, subulate, .3 cm long. Ovary fusiform, glabrous, slightly ribbed; 3-placentiferous; ovules many, horizontal; style slender; stigmas 3, bifid. Fruit fusiform-ellipsoid, slightly beaked, 2.5-5 by 1.25-2.5 cm, marked when immature with white streaks, bright scarlet whn fully ripple. Seeds somewhat obovoid, rounded at the apex, slightly papillose, much compressed, yellowish-grey.
pharmacology: Water soluble alkaloidal principle in leaves, juice and decoction of leaves and stem as well as the decoction of the fruits, pectin isolated from the fruit demonstrated hypoglycaemic activity in guinea pig, rabbits and rats, respectively. Ethanolic extract of leaves exhibited hypoglycaemic activity in experimentally induced diabetes in rats. Inhibition of the key gluconeogenic enzymes, like glucose-6-phosphatase and fructose-1,6-biphospahtase and enhancement of G6PDH enzyme have been suggested as hypoglycaemic mechanism. Hypoglycaemic effects were more marked in glucose tolerance test in alloxan diabetic dogs. The ethanolic extract of the leaves reduced the accumulation and cross linking of aortic collagen in diabetic rats. A clinical trial with leaf preparation showed marked improvement in the glucose tolerance in maturity onset diabetes. Powder of stem and dried leaf decoction had significant hypoglycaemic and hypolipidaemic effects in diabetic patients. Antioxidant effects of ethanolic extract of leaves in plasma, liver and kidney as well as hypolipidaemic effects of pectin from fruit have also been documented in rats. Hepatoprotective effects of leaves have been demonstrated in both rats and humans. Major therapeutic claims in Diabetes and worm infestation. The drug used traditionally in prescribed doses may be considered safe. View Reference

author: L.
description: An unarmed monoecious palm. Trunk 12-24 m high, annulate, thickened at the base, with a mass of rootlets. Leaves 2-5 m long; leaflets equidistant, 1 m long, linear-lanceolate coriaceous; petioles 1-2 m long, stout. Spadix 1-2 m long, stout, androgynous, at length drooping, simply panicled; branches bearing scattered female flowers (often between 2 males) towards their bases and numerous males above. Lower spathes up to 1 m long, oblong, hard splitting lengthwise. MALE FLOWERS unsymmetric. Sepals small, valvate. Petals .6 cm long, acute, valvate. Stamens 6; filaments subulate; anthers linear erect. Pistillode minute or 0. FEMALE FLOWERS larger than the male, 2.5 cm long, ovoid, supported by broad bracteoles. Perianth accrescent. Sepals 2.5 cm diam., round, concave, imbricate. Petals shorter than the sepals, convolute, with imbricate tips. Fruit 20-30 cm long, 3-gonously obovoid or subglobose, green or yellowish; pericarp thick, fibrous; endocarp bony, with 3 basal pores indicating the 3 cells of the ovary; albumen lining the endocarp, the cavity large, filled with a sweet milky fluid known as Cocoa-nut milk.
chemical_composition: Albumin, globulin and prolamine fractions of coconut separated, hydrolysed and amino acids analysed. author: L.
description: Herbs, stem .5-1 m long, slender, dichotomously branched from the base upwards; branches diffuse, glabrous or pubescent, creeping and rooting below. Leaves 2.5-7.5 cm by 1.25-3.75 cm, ovate or oblong, obtuse, sessile or shortly petiolate, pubescent or villous on both surfaces, base unequal-sided, rounded, cuneate or cordate; nerves 7-11 pairs; sheaths short or long, pubescent or villous, the margins ciliate or sometimes bearded with rufous hairs. Spathes 1-3 together, funnel-shaped or turbinate, auricled on one side, pubescent or hirsute; peduncles very short or 0. Upper branch of cyme 2-3 flowered; the lower 1-2 flowered, not uncommonly depauperate or obsolete. Sepals small, oblong, pubescent. Petals blue; larger petals orbicular or transversely oblong. Anthers oblong. Stamens 3 perfect, with 2-3 imperfect; anthers oblong, one usually longer than the others. Ovary 3-celled, 2 cells 2-ovulate, 1 cell 1-ovulate. Capsules .6 cm long, pyriform, membranous, 5-seeded. Seeds oblong, closely pitted.

author: L.
description: Herbs. Extensively cultivated throughout India, largely in the Deccan.
pharmacology: Antimicrobial, spasmolytic. Ethanolic (50%) extract of the seed shows fungitoxic effect against I11Helminthosporium oryzae.I11 C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 Herbal preparation Dhanyapanchaka kashaya, prepared from I11Coriandrum sativum, Valeriana wallichii, Aegle marmelos, Cyperus rotundusI11 and I11Zingiber officinaleI11 has been found to be effective in dyspeptic symptoms and on free HCl of hypoacidity group. Gasozyme syrup (indigenous herbal drug containing I11Carica papaya, Carum copticum, Coriandrum sativum, Peucedanum graveolens, Atropa belladonna, Aegle marmelos, Piper longumI11 and I11Embelia ribesI11 seeds) was administered orally (2 teaspoonfull twice a day after meal for 3 months) to 40 patients of gastritis. Eight cases (20%) were completely relieved of symptoms, 16 cases showed marked improvement and 10 showed satisfactory improvements. The classical herbal compound Shalaparnyadi churna, consisting of I11Desmodium gangeticum, Sida cordifolia, Aegle marmelos, Coriandrum sativumI11and I11Zingiber officinaleI11, was assessed for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). A group of 15 patients of IBS was treated with above churna in the doses of 3 gm thrice a day for one month and the results were compared with a control group consisting of 5 patients who were observed for placebo response. The result showed positive response in all cases. View Reference

author: (Koen.) Smith
description: An erect herb 1-3 m high; rootstock tuberous, inspired; stem subwoody at the base. Leaves 15-30 by 5.5-7.5 cm, subsessile, spirally arranged, oblong or oblanceolate-oblong, acute or acuminate, often cuspidate, glabrous above, silky-pubescent beneatu, base rounded; sheaths coriaceous; ligule 0. Flowers white, numerous, in very dense spikes 5-12.5 by 3.75-7.5 cm; bracts 2-3 cm long, ovate, acuminate, often pungently mucronate, bright-red; bracteole solitary below the calyx, 1.5 cm long. Calyx 3 cm long; 3-lobed; lobes .6 cm long, deltoid-ovate, cuspidate. Corolla-tube as long as the calyx; lobes ovate-oblong, apiculate, the lateral lobes 4.5 by 1.25 cm, the dorsal 4 by 2 cm. Lip suborbicular, white with a yellow centre, 5 cm and more in diam., concave, plicate, crisped, the margins sometimes meeting in the middle; disk pubescent and with a yellow centre, a tuft of hairs at its base of the filament; connective petaloid, 1.25 cm broad, pubescent, produced into a glabrous appendage as long as the linear anther-cells. Stamen 1 perfect; filament forming with the connective an oblong petaloid process with contiguous linear anther-cells situated in its middle; lateral staminodes minute or obsolete. Ovary 3-celled; ovules many, superposed; placentas axile; style 3.75 cm long, filiform; stigma with a semi-linear marginally ciliate foveola. Capsules globosely 3-gonous, 2 cm in diam., red. Seeds black, with a white aril.

author: Roxb.
description: A middle-sized tree; young shoots, branchlets, inflorescence, calyx, and ovary clothed with minute orbicular silvery scales. Leaves 12.5-25 by 5.6-11.25 cm, crowded towards the ends of the branchlets, oblong-lanceolate, subacute, glabrous when fully grown, more or less crenate or serrate, penninerved, base usually acute with no apparent glands above the petioles; main nerves numerous, slender; petioles 2-3.75 cm long. Flowers pale yellowish-green, solitary or fascicled in the axils of minute bracts on long erect often fascicled racemes, the males in the upper part of the raceme, the females in the lower part. MALE FLOWERS: Pedicels variable in length, reaching .4 cm long, slender. Calyx more than .6 cm across flattened out, divided about Â¾ the way down; segments 5, more than .25 cm long, ovate, obtuse. Petals 5, elliptic-lanceolate, .3 cm, long, obtuse, woolly. Stamens 12, inflexed in bud; filaments .3 cm long, the lower half hairy. Pistillode 0. FEMALE FLOWERS: Pedicels short, stout. Sepals more acute than in the male with densely ciliate margins. Petals .2 cm long, obovate, with densely woolly margins. Styles 3, nearly .4 cm long. Capsules less than 1.25 cm in diam., subglobose, a little depressed, slightly 3-lobed, clothed with small orbicular scales. Seeds .8 by .6 cm, ellipsoid rounded and quite smooth on the back.

author: Roemer & Schultes
description: A large twining shrub; branches terete, pale, glabrous. Leaves opposite, 7.5-12.5 by 3.75-6.25 cm, elliptic-oblong or sometimes oblong-lanceolate, rounded, retuse, or sometimes acute, apiculate, green above, whitish beneath, glabrous, base usually acute; main nerves numerous, slender, nearly at right angles to the midrib, uniting in an intramarginal nerve; petioles .6-1.25 cm long. Flowers greenish-yellow, in short axillary paniculate cymes; pedicels glabrous; bracts ovate, acute, with scarious margins. Calyx glabrous 5-partite; segments .15 cm long, ovate, subacute. Corolla-tube .2 cm long, linear or linear-lanceolate, subacute; lobes 5, overlapping to the right in bud; corona-scales clavete. Stamens inserted towards the base of the corolla-tube; filaments free, distinct; anthers with a connective produced into a fleshy apicules more or less connivnent into a cone and united with style. Follicles 5-10 cm long, straight, rigid, divaricate, gradually tapering to a blunt point from about the middle, where they are 1.25-2 cm in diam. Seeds .6-.8 cm long, obate-oblong, black; coma rather more than 2.5 cm long.

author: Gaertn.
description: Herbs with a stout, tuberous rootstock. Rootstock short or elongate with copious fleshy root-fibres. Leaves sessile or petiolate, 15-45 by 1.25-2.5 cm, linear or linear-lanceolate, membranous, plicate, glabrous or sparsely softly hairy, the tips sometimes rooting and reaching the ground, base sheathing. Scape very short, clavate, flattened, with the pedicels, bracts, and ovary hidden among the leaf-sheaths. Flowers bright-yellow, distichous, the lowest in the raceme 2-sexual, the upper male; bracts lanceolate, membranous. Perianth 6- partite, segments 1.25-2.5 cm long, elliptic-oblong, acute, hairy on the back, the stipes (the long slender beak of th ovary) very slender, 1.25-2.5 cm long, which alone with the perianth appears above ground. Stamens 6, small, adnate to the base of the perianth-lobes; filaments very short; anthers linear. Ovary inferior, 3-celled, with a short or long beak; ovules 6-8 in each cell; stigma 3-cleft. Capsules 1.25 cm long, hypogaeous, 1-4 seeded, with a slender beak; septa spongy. Seeds oblong; testa deeply grooved in wavy lines, black, shining.
chemical_composition: A glycoside 5, 7-dimethoxy myricetin 3-0l-xylo-pyranosy 4-0 b-d glycopyranoside is present in the rhizomes. Free sugars, mucilage, hemicellulose; and other polysaccharides are present. Ã-sitoserol and crystalline needles of saprogenic have been detected. The chloroform extract indicated the presence of alkaloids. Curculigoside, a phenolice glycoside, has been characterized.

author: Roxb.
description: Stems very long, rather stout, closely twining, branched, glabrous, pale greenish-yellow, sometimes dotted with red. Flowers solitary or in umbellate clusters of 2-4 or in short racemes; pedicels short, glabrous, usually curved (rarely 0); bracts .15 cm long, ovate-oblong, obtuse, fleshy. Calyx divided almost to the bse, 5-lobed; lobes .3 cm long, slightly unequal, broadly ovate, obtuse, glabrous, fleshy. Corolla wihte; tube .6-.8 by .4 cm, almost cylindric, 5 or 4 lobed; lobes .25-.3 cm long, deltoid, acute, reflexed; scales almost at the base of the corolla-tube, large, oblong, subequadrate or somwhat obovate, fimbriate and incurved at the apex. Stamens 5-4, in the throat of the corolla-tube; filaments scarcely any; anthers about Â½ exserted beyond the top of the corolla-tube. Ovary ovoid, perfectlyo or imperfectly 2-celled; ovules 2 in each cell; stylees simple, very short and thick; stigmas 2, distinct, large, thick and fleshy. Capsules .6-.8 cm in diam., depressed-globose, glabrous, circumscissile near the base. Seeds 2-4, large, black, and glabrous.
pharmacology: Ethanolic extract of the whole plant of I11C. reflexaI11 caused bradycardia and decrease in arterial blood pressure in guinea pig atrea and inhibited both histamine and acetylcholine induced contractions of guinea pig ileum. Extracts of stem showed variable effects on smooth muscles of rat, rabbit, guinea pig, frog and dog. The extract also showed acetylcholine like action on isolated ileum of guinea pig and rabbit, frog rectus muscle and dog blood pressure and small intestine. The alcoholic extract of plant showed antifertility effect in female rats. The water extract and its constituents aromadendrin and taxifolin exhibited anti-HIV activity. Flavonoid glycosides apigenin 7-O-glucoside, kaempferol 3- I11OI11-S224-rhamnoside and myricetin 3-I11OI11-S224-rhamnoside and myricetin 3- I11OI11-S224-rhamnoside isolated from stem were found to have antioxidant property in vitro. Major therapeutic claims as Purgative. The drug used traditionally in prescribed doses may be considered safe. View Reference

author: L.
description: Annual herbs; root fibrous, dark purple; stems tufted, 15-20 cm high, weak, obtusely trigonous. Leaves shorter or longer than the stem, .25-.3 cm broad, linear, acute. Umbel compound or decompound, when mature yellow finally blackening; rays many, the primary rays 2.5-5 cm long, the secondary 1.25-2.5 cm long. Bearing heads of stellate, spreading minute spikelets; bracts 2-3, the longest reaching 15 cm long; bracteoles 0. Spikelets .3-.6 by .15 cm, linear lanceolate. Glumes 1 mm long, oblong, rounded (not mucronate) at the tip, with a green obscurely 3-nerved back, the sides with hyaline margins. Stamen 1 (rarely 2); anthers linear, muticous. Nut small, globosely obovoid, trigonous, rounded, shortly and stoutly stipitate, at first pale-yellow, becoming white when quite ripe.

author: L.
description: Perennial, glabrous, stoloniferous herbs; stolons elongate, slender, 10-20 cm long, bearing hard ovoid tunicate black fragrant tubers .8-2.5 cm in diam.; root-fibres clothed with flexous hairs; stems subsolitary, 10-75 cm long, triquetrous at the top, sometimes tuberous at the base. Leaves shorter or longer than the stem, narrowly linear, .4-.8 cm broad, finely acuminate, flat, 1-nerved. Umbel simple or compound; rays 2-8, the longest reaching 7.5 cm long, bearing short spikes of 3-10 slender spreading reddish-brown spiklets [ the inflorescence sometimes contracted into a head, occasionally of only one spikelet]; bracts 3, variable in length, the longest reaching 15 cm long, but sometimes abbreviated and much shorter than the head. Spikelets variable in length, 1.5-3.75 by .25 cm, linear, subacute, reddish-brown, 10-50 flowered, oblong, obtuse or slightly apiculate; back reddish-brown, 3-7-nerved; sides; margins, and tip hyaline. Stamens 3; anthers .25 cm long. Nut .15 cm long, broadly obovoid, trigonous, greyish-black; style .15 long; stigmas 3, elongate, reaching .4 cm long, much exserted.
pharmacology: Tranquillizing, antiinflammatory, antipyretic, diuretic, estrogenic, anti-emetic, anthelmintic, smooth muscle relaxant, inhibitory activity against {3H} flunitrazepam binding to benzodiazepine receptor, antimicrobial and juvenile hormone mimicking activity. Petroleum ether extracts of the tubers showed antiinflammatory activity against carrageenan-induced edema in albino rats. The alcoholic extract showed hypotensive, antiemetic, smooth muscle relaxant and antipyretic activity. The extract also showed antimalarial activity. C11ToxicologyC11 The LDB1150B11 of petroleum ether extract of the root was 50 mg /kg and EDB1150B11 was 1.6 mg /kg intraperitoneally. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 A clinical study was made on 66 patients of peptic ulcer and 39 patients of chronic gastritis. 65 patients were treated with Shugan Jianpi decoction (a Chinese herbal preparation containing I11Cyperus rotundusI11as one of the ingredients) and 40 patients with gastropine as control group. The Chinese preparation was found more effective as compared to gastropine. It was also better in improving the function of vegetative nervous system and small intestine absorption. In a clinical trial 138 cases of intestinal metaplasia and 105 cases of a typical hyperplasia of gastric mucosa of chronic gastritis were treated with a Chinese herbal preparation, Xia Wei Yan powder, containing I11Cyperus rotundus,I11 as one of the constituents. The powder was administered orally 5-7 gm t.i.d. The results demonstrated marked therapeutic effects after 2-4 months of administration with no side effects. In a clinical trial oral administration of root powder of I11Cyperus rotundus,I11 1 gm twice daily, in 64 patients of obesity produced significant reduction in their weight. Blood pressure hypertensive obese patients were also reduced significantly, whereas there was no change in the blood pressure of normotensive patients. A clinical trial was conducted on 20 patients of oligomenorrhea to evaluate the effect of an Ayurvedic proprietary medicine, containing I11Cyperus rotundusI11 as one of the constituents. The patients were administered the drug in doses of 2tsf b.d. for a period of three months and then followed up at regular interval of one month. Four patients were reported to have conceived during the study period, indicating the usefulness of medicine in infertility and scanty menstruation. Two compound herbal preparations, consisting I11C. rotundusI11 as one of the constituents, were found effective in the treatment of diarrhoea, dysentery and giardiasis. A study was made to evaluate the effect of aqueous solution (2%) of the methanolic extract of root of I11C. rotundusI11 in conjunctivitis. The drug decreased the redness, pain and ocular discharge and most of the patients were cured within five days. Another clinical trial was taken on 40 patients of chronic hepatitis who were treated with a traditional Chinese decoction, containing I11Cyperus rotundusI11 as one of the Ingredients. It showed marked improvement in function of vegetative nervous system, blood viscosity and blood circulation. View Reference

author: Benth.
description: An erect undershrub .5-1.5 m high; stems slender, woody, obtusely angled, clothed when young with short white subappressed hairs, at length glabrescent. Leaves 3-foliolate; petioles 2.5-6.25 cm long, chanelled above, pubescent with apprssed hairs; stipulate 1 cm long, linear-lanceolate, very acute, striate. Leaflets membranous, ovate-elliptic or sometimes broadly lanceolate, acute or subobtuse, green and glabrous above. Appresedly hairy, reticulately veined and paler beneath, base rounded or acute (the terminal 7.5-15 by 3.75-7 cm, the lateral 4.5-10 by 2.5-3.75); main nerves 7-12 pairs, slender, prominent beneath; petiolules .2 cm long; stipels .6 cm long, linear-subulate. Flowers in terminal and axillary racemes 15-25 cm long, usually arranged in distant few-flowered fascicles (rarely solitary) along a slender hairy rhachis; pedicels filiform, pubescent, ultimately .4-.6 cm long, finally spreading bracts and bracteoles linear-acute, hairy. Calyx .25-.3 cm long, campanulate, strigose; teeth lanceolate, slightly longer than the tube, Corolla .6 cm long; standard white; wings and keel blue. Pods 2.5-4.5 cm long; scarcely constricted between the seeds, clothed with minute hooked hairs; joints 6-10, flat .4 cm long, by .15-.25 cm broad.

description: Shrubs. Young branches triquetrous, densely silky, old branches terete, glabrescent. Leaves 3-foliolate, middle one large, 6-10 x 3-4 cm, elliptic, acuminate, silky on both sides when young, glabrescent above on ageing, slightly hairy on nerves below and on margins; petioles silky hairy. Stipules subulate, 0.8-1 cm long, striated, broader at base. Peduncles 0.1-0.2 cm long, pedicels 0.2-0.25 cm. Peduncle, pedicel and calyx densely silky hairy. Bracts subulate, 0.3-0.4 cm long. Calyx tube campanulate, 0.2-0.25 cm long, lobes triangular ovate, 0.2 cm long, densely villous. Corolla cream, 0.6 cm long. Stamens monadelphous. Ovary 0.3-0.35 cm long, silky without; style curved; stigma capitate. Pods 1.5-2 cm long, 0.3 cm wide, 4-6-jointed, silky hairy.
chemical_composition: Phenethylamine, salsolidine, hordenine, tyramine, candicine and choline from stem and roots, whereas leaves contained only phenethylamine and tyramine.

author: L.
description: A middle sized tree; trunk straight but not high; branches spreading, forming a round, shady head. Leaves fascicled at the ends of the branches, the nerves close, running into the serratures, not forking at the margins, upper surface and the nerves beneath more or less pubescent; petioles 2.5-5 cm long, channeled, sheathing. Flowers often exceeding 15 cm in diam., white, fragrant, appearing with the leaves, usually solitary towards the end of each branchlet; pedicels about 7.5 cm long, calvate, round, smooth. Sepals 5, spreading, orbicular, concave, thick and fleshy. Petals 5, oblong. Stamens many, the inner larger, and hard outside, fleshy within; anthers linear, the inner erect or re-curved, introrse, the outer recurved, extrorse. Carpels 5-20, cohering in the axis, many-ovuled, indehiscent, when ripe united into a globose fruit enveloped in the sepals. Seeds many, imbedded in glutinous pulp, compressed, with hairy margins.
chemical_composition: Betulic acid and betulin from trunk bark.

author: (Muell.-Arg.) Hook. f.
description: A small evergreen tree. Leaves simple, alternate, 7.5-17.5 by 3.75-7.5 cm, elliptic-lanceolate, obtuse or obtusely acuminate (rarely subacute), glabrous, reticulately veined, dark-green above, paler beneath, base usually acute; petioles .6-1.25 cm long; stipules small, triangular. Flowers dioecious (rarely monoecious), the males usually solitary on the old wood, shortly pedicellate, the females solitary or 2-3 together on long pedicels, with usually a small bract on the pedicel. MALE FLOWERS: Calyx .5 cm long, cup-shaped, open in bud, with 5 (rarely 4) shallow distant rounded lobes about .15 cm long. Petals 5 (rarely 4), 2 by .3 cm, oblong, obtuse. Staminal-column 2 cm high, on a hairy receptacle; stamens 10-14, often 11 in 2 rows of 5 each and the free portion about .25 cm long, those of the second series connate into a column, the free portion very short scarcely 1 mm long. The uppermost solitary stamen with a filament .15 cm long. FEMALE FLOWERS: Calyx divided almost to the base; sepals in fruit reaching 2 by 1.25 cm or more, variable in size and shape, often unequal, oblong or oblong-lanceolate, obtuse, parallel-nerved and reticulately veined. Disk annular, hairy. Ovary ovoid, densely hairy; styles .8 cm long, connate at the very base, each deeply divided into 2 branches, the branches again 2-fid at the apex. Capsules 1.25 cm in diam., globose, hairy, 3-lobed. Seeds, ellipsoid, yellowish mottled with brown.

author: L.
description: Herbs with slender twining stems. Tubers large, globose or elongate; stem terete, unarmed, glabrous, bulbiferous in the leaf-axils, the bulbis warted. Leaves opposite and alternate, variable in size, 7.5-35 cm long and broad, membranous, dark-green, broadly ovate, acuminate, cuspidate or caudate, base cordate with a broad, deep, or shallow sinus; nerves 7-9 (rarely 11). MALE FLOWERS variable in size, green or purplish, in short slender (almost capillary) spikes 2.5-10 cm long, close together or scattered on the branches of crowded axillary slender pendulous glabrous spikes or panicles reaching 30 cm long; bracts ovate, acuminate. Perianth sessile by a broad base; segments subvalvate, fleshy, the outer .25 cm long, lanceolate, the inner smaller and narrower. Stamens 6; filaments short; anthers minute, didymous; pistillode 3-lobed. FEMALE FLOWERS sessile, .5 cm long, in axillary solitary or fascicled pendulous spikes 10-25 cm long. Perianth as in the male. Staminodes 6. Bracts below the ovary minute, ovate, acuminate. Style short, conical; stigmas 3, very short, recurved. Capsules 1.5-2.5 by .8-1.25 cm, quadrately oblong, rather broader upwards, with a truncate or subcordate base. Seeds winged at the lower end only, the wing twice as long as the nucleus.

author: L.
description: Herb with slender twining stems. Root-tubers oblong, very long (even 1.5-2 m); stem slender, twining, glabrous, prickly towards the base, often bulbiferous in the leaf-axils. Leaves alternate, 3-5 (rarely 7)-foliolate, glabrous or sparsely pubescent beneath; common petiole 2.5-6.25 cm long; leaflets variable in size and shape, 5-12.5 by 2.5-5 cm, elliptic-lanceolate, ovate or obovate, acuminate, cuspidate or subcaudate, base usually acute; lateral leaflets oblique at the base; petiolules very short. Flowers unisexual, usually dioecious. MALE FLOWERS perianth campanulate, pale-greenish, fragrant, in very slender shortly pedunculate racemes 2.5-3.75 cm long, which are solitary or in fascicles along the hairy branches of a panicle 15-30 cm long; bracts .25 cm long and as broad as long, membranous, often mottled with brown, ovate, subacute, sparsely pubescent, subequal; pedicels very short. Stamens 3 perfect; anthers subsessile; staminodes 3, minute. Pistillode 3-lobed. FEMALE FLOWERS in axillary pendulous pubescent spikes 5-15 cm long. Perianth-segments 6, free, small. Ovary inferior, 3-quetrous, 3-celled; ovules 2 in each cell, superposed. Capsules quadrately oblong, 2-2.5 cm long usually retuse at both ends, nearly glabrous or more or less pubescent, often apiculate. Seeds 1.25-2 cm long (including the wing at the base); wing longer and broader than the oblique nucleus, thinly membranous.
chemical_composition: Diosbulbin B, isolated from I11Dioscorea pentaphyllaI11.

author: Roxb.
description: A large or mederate-sized tree with an erectr trunk and leafy head; bark thin, grey; branchlets glabrous. Leaves alternate, subcoriaceous, 5-15 by 2-6.25 cm, glabrous, elliptic-oblong or oblong-lanceolate, obtuse or shortly and bluntly acuminate, bright-green and shining above, somewhat paler beneath, reticulately veined; petioles .4-.8 cm long. MALE FLOWERS: 3-12 together, subsessile, in shortly peduncled cymes; peduncles .6 cm long; buds linear, tapering; bracts small, caducous. Calyx gamosepalous, .25-.4 cm long, infundibuliform, glabrous or slightly hairy; lobes 4, very short, rounded, ciliate. Corolla pale greenish-yellow, tubular, 1 cm long before expansion; lobes 4, ovate equalling or slightly shorter than the tube. Stamens 16 or more, very unequal, often connate in twos, threes, or sometimes fours; filaments more or less pubescent; anthers linear-lanceolate, acuminate. Ovary rudimentary or 0. FEMALE FLOWERS: solitary, larger than in the male, deeply divided, with an elevated 4-lobed marginal ring at its mouth; lobes 4, ovate, acute. Staminodes 8, with double anthers. Ovary glabrous, 8-celled; style 1; stigmas 4. Fruit 2 cm in diam., subglobose; fruiting calyx a hemispheric woody cup which receives the fruit, the 4 ovate acute thickened calyx-lobes spreading outwards. Seeds 3-8, dull-back, 2.5 cm; albumen not ruminate.
chemical_composition: A new pigment âdiospyrin, mp.258Âº -lupeol, betulin and betulinic acid from stem bark.

author: L. f.
description: A shrub, rarely a small tree, with erect twiggy branches often anglesl young parts scurfy-puberulous. Leaves alternate, exstipulate, subsessile, simple mor or less viscid with a yellowish resinous exudation, 3.75-10 cm by .6-3.75 cm (breadth very variable), oblanceolate, subacute or shortly apiculate, glabrous, shining, tapering much towards the base. Flowers greenish-yellow, small, in short few-flowered axillary spreading cymes pedicels slender, nodding. Sepals oblong, .25-.3 cm long, about equaling the stamens. Stamens inserted on the outer side of the disk; filaments short; anthers oblong-linear, very large. Ovary pilose; style long; ovules 2 in each cell. author: Roxb.
description: A slightly branched glabrous straggling shrub, the stems scarcely more than .6 cm thick, sometimes rooting at the base. Leaves (including the petioles) 20-30 by 4.5-6.25 cm, somewhat crowded, elliptic-lanceolate, acute or acuminate, thinly coriaceous, narrowed into the petiole; petioles 2.5-5 cm long, with a widened subamplexicaul base. Perianth coralline, tubular, campnulate or funnel-shaped, 6-cleft; lobes narrow, 1.8-2 cm long, divided to about the middle; lobes linear, obtuse, .2 cm broad. Anthers versatile, .25 cm long. Style filiform, 1.5 cm long; stigma capitate. Fruit a red globose berry nearly as large as a cherry, smooth, glossy, 1-seeded.

author: (L.) Roemer ex Schultes
description: Herbs, annual, prostrate or ascending, glabrous to glandular-papillate; branches arising from base, rooting at nodes, slender, elongate. Leaves deltoid-ovate to subreniform, obtuse to cordate at base, acute or obtuse and mucronate at apex, 5-25x3-20 mm, glabrous, 3-7-nerved; petioles 2-5 mm long; stipules lacerate into 1-2 mm long filaments. Cymes terminal; pedicels 1-8 mm long, finely glandular-pubescent; bracts lanceolate, 2-5 mm long. Sepals 5, narrowly obovate to elliptic-ovate, 2-4.5 mm long, keeled, 3-nerved, inflexed, glandular-papillose on nerves. Petals 3-5, 2-fid nearly up to middle or more, white; lobes oblong, obtuse at apex, 1.5-3 mm long, 1-nerved. Stamens 2-3, 1.6-2.2 mm long; anthers suborbicular. Ovary globose; styles 2- or 3-fid. Capsules 2-3-valved, 1.5-2.5 mm long; seeds 1 or few, cochleate, 1-2 mm in diam., finely tuberculate.
chemical_composition: Cordatanine isolated and its structure determined; palmitic, succinic and p-hydroxycinnamic acids and S224-spinasterol detected in Chinese plant.

author: DC.
description: A twining slender herb; stems terete, more or less fulvous-hairy. Leaves pinnately 3-foliolate; petioles 1.8-3.75 cm long, fulvous-hairy; stipules .4 cm long, linear lanceolate, hairy. Leaflets stipellate, membranous, 3.75-6.25 by 2.5-3.75 cm (the terminal leaflets not much larger than the lateral ones), the margins of the young leaves ciliate, base shortly cuneate. Flowers in axillary 6-20 flowered racemes 5-10 cm long; rhachis slender, hairy; pedicels .15 cm long; bracts subulate, hairy, .25 cm long. Calyx .8 cm long, clothed when young with silky hairs, soon glabrescent, the mouth obliquely truncate, the base saccate. Corolla 1.25-1.5 cm long, pale yellow exserted, standard obovate, erect, the margins slightly inflexed, the claw auricled; wings and keel adherent, with small blades and long claws. Stamens diadelphous; anthers uniform. Ovary sybstipulate; ovules many; style flattened above the middle, beardless; stigma capitate. Pods 3.75 cm long; linear, straight, torulose, velvety. Seeds 3-4, ellipsoid, .15 cm long, black, shining.

author: (Forssk.) Alston
description: A low shrub branches erect, terete, thickened above the nodes, glabrous. Leaves 8.25-17.5 by 3-6.25 cm, lanceolate or elliptic-lanceolate, acuminate, glabrous, shining and dark green above, paler beneath,.base acute; main nerves about 6 pairs, slender, prominent beneath petioles .6-1.25 cm long. Flowers in terminal dense or lax nearly sessile spikes 5-20 cm long; bracts foliaceous, reaching 2 by 1 cm, elliptic-lanceolate, acute, sometimes aristate, entire, tapering towards the base, pubescent and ciliate, reticulately veined; bracteoles .3 cm long, lanceolate, acute, hairy. Calyx .6 cm long, hairy, divided to within .2 cm of the base; segments linear-lanceolate, very acute. Corolla bluish green, hairy outside, reaching 4.5 cm long; upper lip rather more than 1 cm long; narrowly linear from a triangular base, notched at the apex; lower lip 1.25 cm long, divided almost to the base into 3 lobes, the lateral lobes oblong, subacute, the middle lobes broader, oblong, obtuse. Filaments of the stamens hairy at the base anthers .25 cm long. Ovary pubescent at the very tip, style filiform, glabrous in the upper, pubescent in the lower part stigma of 2 short divaricate lobes. Capsules nearly 2.5 cm long by 1 cm wide above the seeds, acutely pointed, pubescent all over; stalk about 1 cm long. Seeds .8 cm in diam., broadly ovoid, much compressed, white, covered with small acute tubercles, the basal notch very deep.
