author: Hassk.
description: Annual, erect or prostrate, branched, often rooting at the nodes; stem and branches strigose with appressed white hairs. Leaves opposite, sessile, 2.5-7.5 cm long, variable in breadth, usually oblong-lanceolate, subentire, acute or subacute, sparsely strigose with appressed hairs on both sides, base tapering. Heads .6-.8 cm in diam., solitary or 2 together on unequal axillary peduncles. Involucral-bracts about 8, ovate obtuse or acute, herbaceous, strigose with appressed white hairs. Ray flowers ligulate, the ligule small, spreading, scarcely as long as the bracts, not toothed, white. Disk-flowers tubular, the corollas often 4-toothed. Pappus 0, except ocasionally very minute teeth on the top of the achene. Achenes cuneate, compressed and with a narrow wing, covered with warty excrescences.

locations.vegetation: Tropical semi evergreen to evergreen forest

pharmacology: I11E. albaI11 protected guinea pigs against the mortality induced by CCLB114B11-liver damage. In the control group 77.7% animals died where as in I11E. albaI11 treated group only 22.3% died within 24 hours. Serum transaminases were also significantly lower in the treated group. Histopathology of liver also showed a reduction in parenchymal damage. There were similar findings in rabbits too.Only with fairly large doses in vitro the extract of I11E. albaI11 showed negative inotropic and chronotropic effects. The alcoholic extract of the plant has shown antiviral activity against Ranikhet disease virus. Tranquilising action has been shown. C11Clinical UsageC11 For healthy black and long hair the plant is commonly used in hair oil all over India. The fresh juice of leaves is used for increasing appetite, improving digestion and as a mild bowel regulator. It is commonly used in viral hepatitis to promote bile flow and protect the parenchyma. It is popularly used to enhance memory and learning. The plant has a reputation as an anti aging agent in Ayurveda. It is also used as a general tonic for debility P115P11. Externally it is used for inglammation, Minor cuts and burns and the fresh leaf-juice is considered very effective in stopping bleeding. Leaf juice mixed with honey is also used for children with upper respiratory infection. It is used in eye and ear infections. View Reference
chemical_composition: Reducing sugars and sterols have been detected. From leaves and stems, wedelolatone has been isolated in crystalline form. Stigma sterol and L-terthienyl methanol have been identified. Ã-amyrin and 7-desmethyl wedelolactorne-7-glucoside have also been isolated. Wedelic acid, apigenin, luteolin and the glucosides of the latter two have been isolated.

author: L.
description: Erect perennial herbs, 15-38 cm high; rootstock short, giving off many stout fibrous roots; stem usually dichotomously branched, strigose, with appressed white hairs. Leaves mostly radical, 12.5-20 by 3.75-5.6 cm, forming a spreading rosette on the ground, obovate-oblong, rounded or subacute, coarsely serrate-denate, more or less hairy on both surfaces, base tapering into an obscure petiole; main nerves numerous, prominent beneath, with reticulate veins between; cauline leaves smaller than the radical, sessile or nearly so. Heads numerous, sessile, closely packed, forming a large flat-topped terminal inflorescence nearly 2.5 cm across and surrounded at the base by 3 large stiff broadly-ovate cordate con-duplicate conspicuously-nerved leafy bracts. Invol-bracts in 2 series enclosing 4 flowers; bracts of the outer row half as long as those of the inner, 1 nerved; bracts of the inner row usually 3-(rarely 5-) nerved, scarous, linear, cuspidate. Corolla violet exserted; tube long, slender; limb deeply cleft on one side, causing the 5 linear lobes to present a palmate apperance. Anthers sagittate at the base, with obtuse auricles.Style much exserted, the arms recurved. Pappus white, 1-seriate, consisting of 5 (rarely4) rigid bristles dilated at the base. Achenes .5 cm long, truncate, finely 10-ribbed, slightly pubescent. The embryo sometimes germinates in the head.
chemical_composition: Epifriedelinol, lupeol, stigmasterol and a mixture of triacontan-1-ol and dotriacontana-1-ol isolated (Phytochemistry 1969, 8, 933).

author: (L. f.) Lindau.
description: A scapigerous herb. Leaves alternate, crowded, sub-radical; obovate, crenate, obtuse, up to 20 cm long, 6.25 cm broad, the bases surrounded by woolly hairs. Flowers small, in close rigid, simple or branched, spikes, the scapes closely covered by spirally imbricate bracts, the upper ones larger and flower-bearing; bracteoles small. Calyx 4-partite, the segments unequal. Corolla-tube linear; limb 2-lipped; lobes 5, the lower longest, imbricate in bud. Stamens 2 perfect; anthers elliptic, the cells parallel, sometimes with a minute spur. Disk small. Ovary oblong, 2-celled; ovular 6-10, superposed, in each cell; style slender; stigma shortly 2-lobed. Fruit an oblong acute capsule. Seeds small, reticulate, not on retinacula; cotyledons small, round.

author: Burm. f.
description: A large scandent shrub; branches long, slender, flexible, terete, with long internodes, the bark studded with lenticels. Leaves coriaceous, 5-7.5 by 2-3.75 cm, elliptic or elliptic-lanceolate, shortly and obtusely acuminate, entire, glabrous on both sides, shining above, paler and somewhat silvery beneath, the whole surface covered with scattered minute reddish sunken glands, base rounded or acute; main nerves numerous, slender; petioles .6-1.5 cm long, more or less margined, glabrous. Flowers 5-merous, numerous, small, in lax panicled racemes which are terminal and from the upper axils; branches of the panicle often 7.5-10 cm long with more or less glandular-pubescent rhachis, pedicels .15-.2 cm long, glandular-pubescent; bracts minute, setaceous, deciduous. Calyx about .12 cm long; sepals connate about 1/3 of the way up, the teeth 5, broadly triangular-ovate, ciliate. Petals 5, greenish-yellow, free, elliptic, subobtuse, pubescent on both sides. Stamens 5, shorter than the petals, erect; filaments inserted a little below the middle of the petals. Ovary ovoid or globose; ovules few, inserted on a subglobose placenta; style short; stigma capitate. Fruit globose, .3-.4 cm in diam., smooth succulent, black when ripe, like a pepper-corn when dried, tipped with the persistent style.
pharmacology: Nematicidal, estrogenic, hypoglycaemic, anthelmintic, antibiotic, antitubercular, antiimplantation, antiovulatory, antifertility, antiinflammatory, hypotensive, antipyretic, diuretic, hepatoprotective, antileishmanial, resorptive, antispermatogenic, antiandrogenic, anticancer, immunostimulant. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 Clinical studies were conducted with alcoholic and aqueous extracts of I11E. ribesI11 fruits on 40 children infected by ascarides. Alcoholic extract was found effective in 80 per cent cases, while aqueous extract cured 55 percent cases, rendering stools free from ova. No toxic effects were observed during and after treatment. Fruits of I11Embelia ribes,I11 when administered in doses of 200 mg/kg to patients of worm infestation, produced good results. Marked improvement was observed in cases of tape worm, giardia and N. nana. A single dose upto a maximum of 8 gm was sufficient. Worms were expelled within 6 to 24 hours of taking the drug. The drug is well tolerated and safe for use. School children (5 -12 years) suffering from various helminth diseases were treated with Ayurvedic preparation, Kuberakshadi yoga, in a dose of 200 mg per kg body wt. in two divided dose. The drug was found effective against I11Enterobium vermicularisI11 and I11Ascaris lumbricoides.I11 Kuberakshadiyoga contained I11Caesalpinia bonducella, Embelia ribes, Ptychotis sp., Myristica fragrans, Caryophyllum aromaticumI11 and I11Cuminum cyminum.I11 In a clinical study, powder containing I11Embelia ribes, Mallotus philippinensisI11and I11Butea monospermaI11 was found effective in hymenolepiasis in children. Pippalyadi yoga, a composite drug containing I11Piper longum, Embelia ribesI11and borax in equal amount, was investigated in 254 women covering 4694 cycles for contraceptive property. Oral administration of drug in a dose of 1 gm / day gave very good results. Drug failure was observed only in 4 women. Pregnancy due to drug omission was found in 26 women, Minor side effects were observed in 17 cases. Fertility appeared normal after discontinuation of the drug. Clinical trial were conducted with Vidangadi yoga (a herbal preparation containing I11Embelia ribesI11 seeds, I11Hibiscus rosa-sinensisI11 flowers and I11Ferula asafoetidaI11 oleo-gum resin) for its antifertility activity. The drug was found to be very effective and showed no toxic effects. AC-4, a composite drug containing I11Embelia ribes, Laccardia lacca, Areca catechuI11 and I11Saraca asocaI11 in equal parts, when administered orally (1 gm./day in two divided doses) to 281 women for 15 days (4th day of menstrual cycle to 18th day) exhibited good contraceptive activity. There was no pregnancy due to drug failure after 10th cycle. No toxic symptoms or severe side effects were noticed. Powders of Vidanga and Tankana in a dose of 2 gm twice a day, after meals, were administered in 150 fertile women for 6 months. 58 percent of women were benefited who followed the medication for six months continuously and no pregnancy was recorded for two years of follow up. However, it was noted that cycle-wise result was 80 per cent successful. It was concluded that Tankana, Vidanga and Pippali Churna, administered for 5 days, can be used for 6 months to prevent pregnancy for 24 months. Solid extract prepared from the decoction of I11Holarrhena antidysentericaI11 ( bark and seeds), I11Berberis aristataI11 (wood), I11Embelia ribesI11 (fruit), I11Cyperus rotundusI11 (tuber), I11Aegle marmelosI11 (fruit pulp) and I11Butea monospermaI11 (seeds), in a clinical trial on 25 patients of diarrhoea and dysentery, showed complete cure rate of 80 per cent with an average 3.3 days treatment, without any toxic effect. Gasozyme syrup (indigenous herbal drug, containing I11Carica papaya, Carum copticum, Coriandrum sativum, Peucedanum graveolens, Atropa belladonna, Aegle marmelos, Piper longumI11 and I11Embelia ribesI11seeds) was administered orally (2 teaspoonfull twice a day after meals for 3 months) to 40 patients of gastritis. Eight cases (20%) were completely relieved of symptoms, 16 cases showed marked improvement and 10 showed satisfactory improvements. View Reference

author: Gaertn.
description: A deciduous small or middle-sized tree with crooked trunk and spreading branches; bark greenish-grey, peeling off in conchoidal flakes; branchlets glabrous or finely pubescent, 10-20 cm long, often deciduous. Leaves subsessile, 1-1.25 by .25-.3 cm, closely set along the branchlets, distichous, light-green, glabrous, narrowly linear, obtuse imbricate when young having the appearance of pinnate leaves stipules ovate, finely acute. Flowers greenish-yellow, in axillary fascicles on the leaf-bearing branchlets, often on the naked portion below the leaves, with fimbriate bracts at the base. MALE FLOWERS numerous, on short slender pedicels. Sepals 6, oblong, obtuse, .12 cm long. Disk 0. Anthers 3 on a short central column. FEMALE FLOWERS few, subsessile. Sepals as in the male. Disk a lacerate cup. Ovary 3-celled; styles connate at the base, irregularly twice 2-fid with acute lobes. Fruit 1.251.5 cm in diam., fleshy, globose, with 6 obscure vertical furrows, pale yellow, of three 2-seeded crustaceous cocci. Seeds 6, 3-gonous.
chemical_composition: Trigalloylglucose, terchebin, corilagin, ellagic acid from fruits; preparation of phyllembic acid salts and structure studies. author: DC.
description: Glabrescent herb; branchlets ascending. Leaves alternate often with cluster of basal leaves, lower ones pinnatifid; upper ones entire, linear lanceolate, chartaceous, base decurrent, apex acute. Capitulum stalked, axillary, solitary, heterogamous, radiate; receptacle flat or convex, pitted; involucre broadly campanulate. Phyllaris (sub) biseriate, lanceolate, herbaceous, margin scarious, finely dentate, acumenate. Pappus filiform, minutely setose, refluxed in fruit. Disk florets: Corolla tubular-companulate; lobes 5, linear-lanceolate, minutely papillose without acute. Stamens 5, included; anthers linear. Ovary oblong, pubescent; stigma obtuse, hispid. Ray-florets: Corolla shortly tubular below; ray linear-oblong. Stigma obtuse. Achenes hardly enlarged, minutely pubescent.

author: Grath.
description: A small tree. Leaves upto 20 cm in diam., orbicular, accurately 5-7 lobed, irregularly toothed, glabrous, cordate at the base. 5-9 nerved; petioles 5-11.25 cm long. Flowers yellow, 3.75-6.25 cm across, in lax, terminal panicles; buds oblong, fulvous-pubescent, 5-pointed, 2 or 3 are velvety-tomentose on both surfaces and very caduceus. Sepals 5, upto 3.75 cm long, narrow-linear, acute, deflexed, covered outside with fulvous, stellate pubescence, the inner surface glabrous. Petals 5, a little shorter than the sepals, with a very long narrow claw; limb pilose with stiff hairs; style long, filiform, glabrous. Stamens many. Ovary 3-5 celled; ovules 2 in each cell; style filiform. Fruit 1-4 celled, triquetrous, 3.75-5 cm long, acuminate, angles winged, faces cordate at the base, covered with straight or slightly curved prickles from broad bases. Seeds 1 in each cell, .6 cm long, oblong.

author: (Wall.) Cooke
description: A shrub or small tree 2.5-4.5 m high; bark grey, rough. Leaves 7.5-20 by 3-7.5 cm, coriaceous, oblong or oblong-lanceolate, shortly acuminate, glabrous, base acute; main nerves 12-16 pairs; petioles .8-2 cm long, dilated at the base. Flowers in pedunculate many flowered cymes; buds clavate, rounded at the apex. Calyx .5 cm long, coriaceous, glabrous; lobes .2 cm long, broadly oblong, obtuse, with membranous margins. Corolla-tube .3-2.5 cm long, inflated near the top; limb 2.5 cm across, with obtuse crisped lobes over-lapping to the right. Stamens erect, inserted in the inflated part of the corolla, included; filaments short; anthers linear, acute, 2-lobed at the base, polliniferous and dehiscing throughout their entire length. Carpels of the ovary 2, sometimes slightly coherent; ovules numerous in each carpel, many-seriate; style usually long, filiform; stigma at the level of the anthers, clavate or oblong-ellipsoid with a slender papillose bifid apiculus. Follicles 2.5-3 by 1-1.25 cm, yellow when ripe, subsessile, curved, somewhat boat-shaped, usually with a short beak which is often recureved, and 2 sharp side-ribs. Seeds .8 cm long, surrounded by a red pulp.
chemical_composition: Methanol extract of leaves showed significant activity against B16 melanoma in mice Coronaridine, voacangine, ibogamine, 19-oxocoronaridine and pseudoindoxyl of voacangine isolated from roots.

author: L.
description: A tree reaching 20 m in height; bark thin, smooth, grey, armed with small conical dark colored prickles. Leaves pinnately 3-foilolate, 15-30 cm long, deciduous; petioles 10-15 cm long, unarmed, readily disarticulating; stipules lanceolate, 1 cm long, very caducous. Leaflets 10-15 by 8.5-12.5 cm (the terminal lealflet the largest), membranous, broadly rhomboid-ovate, acute or acuminate, more or less stellately pubescent when young, glabrous when mature, base truncate or rhomboidal; petiolules .8-1.25 cm long; stipels thick, roundish, gland-like, persistent. Flowers appearing before the leaves, in dense racemes, 10-22.5 cm long, arranged in clusters of 1-3 on a puberulous or teometose rhachis; peduncles stout, woody, reaching 15 cm long; pedicels .6 cm long, bracts small, triangular, tomentose, decidous; bracteoles .4 cm long, subulate, tomentose. Calyx (before the expansion of the flower) tubular, 5-toothed at the tip, 2.5-3 cm long, clothed with deciduous tomentum, mouth very oblique, the upper segment subulate, the 2 lateral similar but smaller, the lowest one longer and doubled over the others so as to form a blunt point to the bud, the calyx soon splitting down the back to the base and appearing like a spathe. Corolla bright red, 5-6.25 cm long, standard 2.5-3.75 cm, much exserted. Pods 12.5-30 cm long, stalked, subcylindric, distinctly torulose, glabrescent. Seeds 4-8, subreniform, 2 by 1 cm brown.
pharmacology: Isoflavones viz., indicanine D. wighteone, alpinumisoflavone, erysenegalensein E and 8-prenyl-erythrinin C isolated from stem bark of I11E. variegataI11 showed cytocidal activity against KB cells. Flavonoids isolated from methanol extract of stem bark viz. abyssinone V, 4â-hydroxy-6, 3â, 5â-triprenylisoflavonone and erycrystagallin showed phospholipase A2 inhibitory activity. Erycrystagallin showed antibacterial activity against oral cariogenic bacteria while erythrinin B in the methanolic extract of bark showed inhibitory effect on Na+/H+ exchange system. Total alkaloids isolated from the stem bark showed smooth and skeletal muscle relaxant, antispasmodic, CNS and cardiac depressant actions. They also showed anticonvulsant but no analgesic, antipyretic, antiinflammatory, laxative and diuretic effects. Major therapeutic claims as Antiinflammatory and Aanalgesic. The drug used traditionally prescribed doses may be considered safe. View Reference

description: Trees, bark flakes off into long stripes. Leaves lanceolate. Flowers large 1-3 together on a short peduncle. Calyx tube hard, bluish white. Lid of calyx and corolla conical.
chemical_composition: Dried leaves contain 1-3% (v/w) essential oil (fresh leaves contain 0.4-1.6%), the major constituent of which is 1, 8-cineole (54-95%). In addition, there are moderate amounts of other monoterpenes, including S224-pinene (2.6%). p-cymene (2.7%), aromadendrene, cuminaldehyde, globulol and pinocarveol. Gas chromatography and gas chromatography-mass spectroscopy of the oil indicated the presence of more than 70 components, 48 of which were identified. The concentration of S224-terpeneol was estimated to be 28% (17). The leaves are rich in tannins and ellagitannins, and also contain 2-4% triterpenes (ursolic acid derivatives), a series of phloroglucinol- sesquiterpene-coupled derivatives (macro carpals B, C, D, E, H, I and J) and flavonoids (rutin, quercetin, quercitrin, and hyperoside) (5, 7, 10, 12, 17-19).

author: (L.) L.
description: A perennial herb with a small woody branched roostock; stems numerous, often more than 30 cm long, prostrate, spreading, slender, wiry, usually clothed with long spreading hairs, but sometimes quite glabrous. Leaves numerous, .6-2 by .4-.8 cm, elliptic-oblong, obtuse, strongly apiculate usually acute at the base, densely clothed with appressed silky hairs; petioles vey short, sometimes almost 0. Flowers light-blue, solitary or sometimes 2 from a pair of lanceolate bracts on the peduncle; peduncles vey long, filiform, axillary; pedicels filiform. Calyx densely silky; sepals .4 cm log, lanceolate, very acute. Corolla .5 cm long. Stamens 5. Ovary 2-celled; ovules 4; styles2, distinct from the base, each cleft into 2 linear or subclavate stigmas.Capsules .3-.4 cm in diam., globose, thin, 4-valvd. Seeds usually 4, glabrous.
pharmacology: Fraction âdâ base was shown to decrease the rate and force of contraction in frog heart, in low doses (0.02 mg) while high doses (0.1 mg) causes cardiac arrest. Experiments on rabbit intestinal muscle showed that, in doses of 1:500,000 to 1:2,50,000 it decreased the amplitude of contraction and increased the tone of intestinal muscle. Evolvine, an alkaloid, has sympathomimetic activity. C11Clinical UsageC11 The whole herb is used medicinally in the form of decoction with cumin and milk in fever, nervous debility, loss of memory, also in syphilis, and scrofula. Decoction of the drug, with I11Ocimum sanctumI11 is administered in fevers accompanied by indigestion or diarrhea. Shankapushpi is used as a brain tonic. The root is used by the sandals, for intermittent childhood fever. The leaves are made into cigarettes and smoked in chronic bronchitis and asthma. The plant is useful in internal haemorrhages. The oil promotes the growth of hair. Decoction was given in cases of malarial fever. I11Evolvulus alsinoidesI11 has got antidysenteric and antiseptic properties. It is used as a Rasayan. View Reference
chemical_composition: Betaine and a water-soluble base are identified. Extract shows positive results for sterols other than phenols, tannins, carbohydrates, proteins and aminoacids. Evoline, an alkaloid can also be identified from the whole plant.

description: A shrub or small tree without aerial roots; young parts scabrous; bark white, smooth. Leaves crowded about the extremities of the branchlets 3.75-12.5 by 2-7 cm, alternate, petiolate, oblong-lanceolate to ovate or obovate or elliptic, entire (very rarely irregularly 3-lobed), blunt or acuminate, serrate, toothed or crenate in the upper part, scabrid and hispid on both surfaces, base usually rounded, 3-nerved; lateral main nerves 3-5 pairs, very prominent and hispid on the lower surface as are the reticulations; petioles 1-3 cm long; stipules minute. Receptacles solitary, pedunculate, globose, 1.25-2 cm in diam., slightly depressed at the apex, when ripe yellow or purple with yellowish dots, scabrous-hispid, with rather a prominent umbilicus; basal bracts 0; peduncles .4-.6 cm long. MALE FLOWERS numerous in the upper part of the receptacles. Sepals 4-5, linear-lanceolate, scabrid. Stamen 1. GALL FLOWERS: Sepals as in the male. Ovary ovoid-lanceolate; style thick, terminal; stigma dilated. FERTILE FLOWERS: Sepals 6-7, linear lanceolate, smooth. Achenes oblong, obovoid, minutely tuberculate. Style lateral, filiform; stigma obovoid.
chemical_composition: GLC of surface hydrocarbons from fresh leaves showed predominant occurrence of lower even-numbered alkanes [C14, (12.9), C16 (16.5), C18 (11.3) and C20 (2.5%)] which was an unusual alkane distribution pattern for a dicotyledonous plant.

author: L.
description: A very large tree reaching 33 m high, sending down many aerial roots from the branches and thus extending the growth of the tree indefinitely; young parts softly pubescent. Leaves coriaceous, 10-20 by 5-12.5 cm, ovate or orbicular-ovate to elliptic, obtuse, entire, glabrescent above, glabrous or minutely pubescent beneath, base rounded or subcordate, 3-7 nerved with about 5-7 pairs of lateral nerves above the basal ones and distinct reticulat venation between; peduncles 1.25-5 cm long, stout; stipules .6-2.5 cm long, coriaceous. Receptacles about .6 cm in diam., sessile in pairs, axillary, globose, puberulous, red when ripe, with broad rounded nearly glabrous coriaceous basal bracts. MALE FLOWERS rather numerous near the mouth of the receptacles. Sepals lanceolate. Stamen 1. GALL FLOWERS: Perianth as in the male. Style short. FERTILE FLOWERS: Perianth shorter than in the male. Style elongate.
pharmacology: Hypoglycaemic, hypotensive, antifertility, antidiabetic, antioxidant, hypocholesterolemic. C11ToxicologyC11 LDB1150B11 of plant in mice was 9.47 g/kg by i.p. route. In chronic toxicity test, extract produced hepatic damage initially but changes were reversible even on continued administration. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 A clinical trial was taken over 15 patients of burn with a polyherbal ointment, of which I11Ficus benghalensisI11 root bark was one of the ingredients. It proved to be highly efficacious in controlling I11Candida albicansI11 infections and helped in quicker epithelialisation. The burns were completely healed in 8 to 26 days of treatment. A composite herbal drug, of which I11Ficus benghalensisI11 was one of constituents, was administered to 15 patients of leucorrhoea for 2 weeks in doses of 100 mg b.d. Complete relief was observed in 62% cases, 18% cases responded moderately and the rest 10% failed to attend follow up studies. A preliminary clinical trial was taken on 64 patients of leucorrhoea of varied etiology and patients of different age groups (11 years to 50 years). I11Ficus benghalensisI11stem bark powder was administered in doses of 3 gm. 5 times a day with cowâs milk for 30 days. 62 patients were relieved from white discharge, out of which 7 cases had complete relief, while 26 cases had marked relief. Moderate relief was achieved in 21 patients and 8 patients showed mild response in associated symptoms viz., backache, general debility, itching and constipation. The drug proved efficacious in leucorrhoea. View Reference

author: L. f.
description: A shrub or small tree, all parts more or less hispid-pubescent. Leaves usually opposite, petiolate, membranous, 10-30 by 5-15 cm, ovate, oblong, or subovate, apiculate or shortly and abruptly acuminate, the lower surface hispid-pubescent, the upper hispid-scabrid, base rounded, subcordate or subcuneate, 3-5 nerved; lateral main nerves 3-5 pairs with fine reticulations between; petioles 1.25-3.75 cm long (in young shoots 7.5-9 cm long), densely hispid; stipules 2 to each leaf, ovate-lanceolate, pubescent outside, about 1.25 cm long. Receptacles 1.25-2.5 cm across, turbinate, obovoid or subpyriform, yellowish when ripe, slightly umbonate, hispid and sometimes with bracts scattered along the sides, on peduncles .5-1.5 cm long in pairs from the axils of the leaves, or in fascicles from shortened tuberculate branches from the old wood, or in pairs or fascicles on elongate stipular bracteate sometimes leafy branches issuing from the larger branches and stem and often reaching to or even penetrating the soil; basal bracts 3. MALE FLOWERS rather numerous, near the apex of the receptacle containing the galls. Sepals 3, concave, hyaline. Stamen 1; anther broad; filament short. GALL FLOWERS pedicellate. Perianth 0. Ovary smooth, globose; style short, subterminal; stigma dilated. FERTILE FLOWERS: Perianth 0. Achenes ovoid; style lateral; stigma cylindric, tubular.

author: L.
description: Ficus religiosa is an evergreen or deciduous tree, 20 m tall and 1.5-2 m dbh, irregularly-shaped, with wide-spreading branches and without aerial roots from the branches. The trunk is regularly shaped, often with low buttresses. Bark is grey with brownish specks, smooth, exfoliating in irregular rounded flakes. Leaves alternate, spirally arranged and broadly ovate, glossy, coriaceous (leathery), dark green leaves, 10-18 by 7.5-10 cm, with unusual tail-like tips, pink when young, stipulate, base-cordate. Petioles is slender and 7.5- 10 cm long. Galls on leaves. Flowers axillary sessile, unisexual. Figs in pairs, rounded, flat-topped green, to 1.5 cm across, axillary, sessile, smooth, ripening to purple with red dots, basal bracts 3 and broad.
pharmacology: Antibacterial activity Aqueous and ethanolic extracts of F. religiosa leaves showed antibacterial effect against Staphylococcus aureus, Salmonella paratyphi, Shigella dysenteriae, S. typhimurium, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Bacillus subtillis, S. aureus, Escherichia coli, S. typhi.[16â18] In another study, chloroform extract of fruits showed antimicrobial effect against Azobacter chroococcum, Bacillus cereus, B. megaterium, Streptococcus faecalis, Streptomycin lactis, and Klebsiella pneumonia.[17] The ethanolic extract of leaves showed antifungal effect against Candida albicans.[18] Aqueous, methanol, and chloroform extracts from the leaves of F. religiosa were completely screened for antibacterial and antifungal activities. The chloroform extract of F. religiosa possessed a broad spectrum of antibacterial activity with a zone of inhibition of 10â21mm. The methanolic extracts possessed moderate antibacterial activity against a few bacterial strains. There was less antibacterial activity or none at all using aqueous extracts. The extracts of F. religiosa were found to be active against Aspergillus niger and Penicillium notatum. The extracts from the leaves exhibited considerable and variable inhibitory effects against most of the microorganisms tested.[18,19] Anthelmintic activity F. religiosa bark methanolic extract was 100% lethal for Haemonchus contortus worms.[20] The stem and bark extracts of F. religiosa proved lethal to Ascaridia galli in vitro. The latex of some species of Ficus (Moraceae), i.e., Ficus inspida, F. carica was also reported to have anthelmintic activity against Syphacia obvelata, Aspiculuris tetraptera, and Vampirolepis nana.[21] The pharmacological studies on F. glabrata latex with live Ascaris demonstrated a lethal effect at concentrations reduced to 0.05% latex in physiological saline solution. It has been accepted that anthelmintic activity is due to a proteolytic fraction called ficin. It is evident from above that methanolic extracts of F. religiosa possibly exerted anthelmintic effect because of ficin.[22] Immunomodulatory activity The immunomodulatory effect of alcoholic extract of the bark of F. religiosa (moraceae) was investigated in mice. The study was carried out by various hematological and serological tests. Administration of extract remarkably ameliorated both cellular and humoral antibody response. It is concluded that the extract possessed promising immunostimulant properties.[23] Antioxidant activity The literature showed that the antioxidative properties of the extract of F. religiosa fruit and bark were done using different solvents. They were evaluated on the basis of oil stability index together with their radical scavenging ability against 1, 1-diphenyl-2-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH).[24] The oxidative stress and oxidative damage to tissues are common end points of chronic diseases such as diabetes, atherosclerosis, and rheumatoid arthritis. Oxidative stress in diabetes coexists with a reduction in the antioxidant status, which can further increase the deleterious effects of free radicals. The aqueous extract of F. religiosa reduces oxidative stress in experimentally induced type 2 diabetes rats. Type 2 diabetic rats gained relatively less weight during the course of development as compared to normal rats. Decrease in uptake of glucose, free fatty acids from circulation, and accelerated Î²-oxidation in adipose tissue lead to weight loss in diabetes. The aqueous extract of F. religiosa improved the body weight of diabetic rats.[25] Aqueous extract of F. religiosa modulated the superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity in the diabetic rats dose dependently and also decreased catalase (CAT) activity. It could be possible due to less availability of NADPH or gradual decrease in erythrocyte CAT concentration by excessive generation of O2++ inactivates the enzyme. Since the activity of an enzyme depends upon its substrate, depletion of glutathione (GSH) may be the reason for decreased glutathione peroxidase (GSH-Px) activity. Aqueous extract of F. religiosa bark had upregulated the CAT and GSH-Px activities. Drug at higher dose (200 mg/kg) was better effective in modulating the enzyme.[26] The methanolic extract of F. religiosa leaf inhibits the production of nitric oxide and proinflammatory cytokines in lipopolysaccharide (LPS) stimulated microglia via the mitogen activation protein kinase (MAPK) pathway by using cell viability assay, nitric oxide assay, and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). The extract exerts strong anti-inflammatory properties in microglial activation. It is likely that extract has a neuroprotective effect against inflammation by inflammatory mediators such as nitric oxide and cytokines.[27] Recently, the methanolic extract of F. religiosa has been reported to have neurotrophic effects and acetylcholinesterase inhibitory activity.[28] Wound-healing activity The effect of hydroalcoholic extract of F. religiosa leaves on experimentally induced wounds in rats using different wound models results in dose-dependent wound-healing activity in excision wound, incision wound, and burn wound. A formulation of leaves extract was prepared in emulsifying ointment at a concentration of 5% and 10% and applied to the wounds. In excision wound and burn wound models, the extract showed significant decrease in the period of epithelization and in wound contraction (50%). A significant increase in the breaking strength was observed in an incision wound model when compared to the control. The result suggests that leaf extract of F. religiosa (both 5% and 10%) applied topically possess dose-dependent wound-healing activity.[29] Anticonvulsant activity Methanolic extract of figs of F. religiosa had anticonvulsant activity against maximum electroshock (MES) and picrotoxin-induced convulsions, with no neurotoxic effect, in a dose-dependent manner. F. religiosa extract showed a significant protection in MES and picrotoxin-induced convulsion models in a dose-dependent manner. There was a significant decrease in the duration of tonic hind limb extension at all the three doses of extract (25, 50, and 100mg/kg) in MES model with maximum protection observed at 100mg/kg dose, as compared to control group. The anticonvulsant activity of the extract at 100mg/kg was found to be comparable to phenytoin-treated group; similarly, treatment with extract caused a dose-dependent delay of the latency to clonic convulsions in picrotoxin-induced convulsion model. However significant increase in the latency to clonic convulsions was observed only at 50 and 100mg/kg dose of extract as compared to control group. F. religiosa extract increased the threshold of MES and picrotoxin-induced convulsions with no neurotoxic effects, in a dose-dependent manner. Inhibition of antiepileptic effect of extract by cyproheptadine pretreatment showed that the extract might be mediating its effect via modulating serotonin-dependent GABAergic and/or glutamatergic neurotransmission.[30] Hypolipidemic activity Dietary fiber content of food namely peepalbanti (F. religiosa), cellulose, and lignin were predominating constituents in peepalbanti, fed at 10% dietary level to rats, induced a greater resistance to hyperlipidemia than cellulose. Teent had the most pronounced hypocholesterolemic effect that appeared to operate through increased fecal excretion of cholesterol as well as bile acids. Dietary hemicellulose showed a significant negative correlation with serum and liver cholesterol and a significant positive correlation with fecal bile acids. The dietary fiber influenced total lipids, cholesterol, triglycerides, and phospholipids of the liver to varying extents.[31] Hypoglycemic activity Î²-Sitosterol-D-glycoside was isolated from the root bark of F. religiosa, which has a peroral hypoglycemic activity.[32] Oral administration of F. religiosa bark extract at the doses of 25, 50, and 100mg/kg was studied in normal, glucose-loaded, and STZ (streptozotocin) diabetic rats. The three doses of bark extract produced significant reduction in blood glucose levels in all the models. The effect was more pronounced in 50 and 10mg/kg than 25mg/kg. F. religiosa also showed significant increase in serum insulin, body weight, and glycogen content in liver and skeletal muscle of STZ-induced diabetic rats, while there was significant reduction in the levels of serum triglyceride and total cholesterol. F. religiosa also showed significant antilipid peroxidative effect in the pancreas of STZ-induced diabetic rats. The results indicate that aqueous extract of F. religiosa bark possesses significant antidiabetic activity.[33] View Reference
chemical_composition: The stem bark of F. religiosa are reported of phenols, tannins, steroids, alkaloids and flavonoids, Î²-sitosteryl-D-glucoside, vitamin K, n-octacosanol, methyl oleanolate, lanosterol, stigmasterol, lupen-3-one.[10]. The root bark reported to have Î²-sitosteryl-D-glucoside. The fruits contain 4.9% protein having the essential amino acids, isoleucine, and phenylalanine.[11] The seeds contain phytosterolin, Î²-sitosterol, and its glycoside, albuminoids, carbohydrate, fatty matter, coloring matter, caoutchoue 0.7â5.1%.[12]. The fruits contain flavonols, namely kaempeferol, quercetin, and myricetin [13]. Leaves and fruits contain carbohydrate, protein, lipid, calcium, sodium, potassium, and phosphorus.[14] The aqueous extract of dried bark of F. religiosa has been reported to contain phytosterols, flavonoids, tannins, furanocoumarin derivatives namely bergapten and begaptol.

author: L. f.
description: A moderate-size shady tree, all parts glabrous; aerial roots usually few, sometimes absent. Leaves alternate, coriaceous, 5-10 cm long and nearly as broad, elliptic, ovate or obovate, rounded or shortly and bluntly acuminate at the apex, polished and shining, base narrowed into the petiole, 3-nerved, with 5-6 pairs of main lateral nerves above the basal ones, not more prominent than the secondary nerves, reticulately veined between; petioles .6-1.25 cm long; stipules lanceolate, 1 cm long. Receptacles small, about .8 cm in diam., sessile in pairs, axillary or from the scars of fallen leaves, depressed-globose, smooth, yellow or reddish when ripe; basal bracts 3, broadly ovate, blunt, spreading, persistent. MALE FLOWERS numerous, scattered, sessile or shortly pedicellate. Sepals 3, subspathulate. Stamen 1; filament as long as the cordate apiculate anther. GALL FLOWERS sessile or pedicellate. Sepals 3, oblong or broadly spathulate. Style short. FERTILE FLOWERS usually sessile. Sepals 3, much shorter than in the gall flowers. Style short; stigma cylindric or clavate. Achenes ovoid or obovoid.
chemical_composition: Lupenyl acetatem friedelin, epifriedelinol, glutinol, taraxerol, oleanolic acid and two pentacyclic triterpenoids isolated from leaves.

author: (Gaertn.) Desr.
description: A moderate-sized evergreen tree with yellow juice. Branches drooping, bark rough, dark-brown; young shoots glabrous. Leaves simple, opposite, 5-12.5 by 2-5 cm, elliptic lanceolate, acute or slightly acuminate, glabrous, nerves oblique; petioles 1.25-1.5 cm long, stout. MALE FLOWERS in the axills of fallen leaves, 3 or 4 together; pedicels thickened upwards variable in length. Sepals thick and fleshy, membranous. Petals more than twice as long as the sepals, obovate-oblong, concave, with narrowly membranous margins. Stamens numerous on a short, thick androphore, monadelphous, forming a globular head. FEMALE or HERMAPHRODITE FLOWERS larger than the male, in terminal and axillary fascicles of 1-3. Sepals and petals as in the male. Staminodes 10-20, unequal, in a ring round the ovary, free or connate at the base. Ovary globular, grooved; stigma 5-12-rayed, tubercled. Fruit 6.25-7.5 cm in diam., yellow or reddish, more or less globular, with 7-13 (usually 8) deep, vertical furrows, mamillate; pericarp very thick, fleshy. Seeds as many as the grooves of the fruit, 2 cm long, ovoid, compressed, surrounded by a white or red aril; testa pale-brown, veined.
chemical_composition: Two isoprenylated benzophenone derivatives âcamboginol and cambogin âisolated from latex and structure of cambogin proposed; structure of cambogin, an enantiomer of isoxanthochymol, confirmed by X-ray studies; structure of camboginol revised and confirmed.

author: (Dupetit-Thouars) Choisy
description: A small evergreen tree with yellow juice. Leaves simple, 3.75-9 cm by 2.5-3.75 cm, red when young, oblong-lanceolate, glabrous with entire, repand margins; petioles .6-1 cm long. Flowers polygamous, axillary or terminal, solitary or in spreading fascicles; pedicels gradually thickened upwards, .4-.8 cm long or 0; bracts scale-like, deciduous. Sepals .15 cm long, 4, decussate, thick and fleshy; outer smaller, oblong-ovate; inner larger obovate-orbicular. Petals 4, thick, a little longer than the sepals. MALE FLOWERS 3-8 in axillary and terminal fascicles, the pedicels of the terminal fascicles carried on a short peduncle. Stamens very numerous, on a short column; anthers 2-celled, dehiscing longitudinally; filaments very short. FEMALE FLOWERS sessile or very shortly pedicelled, solitary bundles, arranged crosswise, each bundle containing 2-7 staminodes in or more rows; filaments short, very thick. Ovary 4-8 celled; stigma sessile, with as many lobes as the cells. Fruit globose, not furrowed, 2.5-3 cm in diam., purple throughout. Seeds 5-8, compressed, embedded in pulp.

author: L.
description: A shrub about 2 m high, glabrous or nearly so, unarmaed; buds resinous. Leaves sessile or nearly so, 4.5-7 by 2-2.5 cm, elliptic-oblong or obovate-oblong, obtuse or subacute, glabrous, shining, base obtuse, acute, or sometimes cordate; main nerves 12-18 pairs; stipules connate, truncate or mucronate. Flowers sub-sessile, 1-3 together. Calyx .3 cm long, densely pubescent; teeth triangular, .2-.3 cm long. Corolla at first white, soon changing to yellow; tube pubescent outside, 3 by 1.25-1.5 cm; twisted in bud. Stamens as many as the corolla-lobes, inserted in the throat of the corolla; anthers sessile or subsessile, linear, included. Ovary 1-celled; ovules numerous, 2-seriate, on 2-6 parietal placentas; style thick; stigma large,club-shaped or fusiform, usually 2-fid. Fruit 2.5-3.75 cm long, oblong or ellipsoid, with numerous longitudinal elevated lines and with a stout beak, smooth; pericarp thin ; placentas 4-5. Seeds many, imbedded in the placentas, compressed; testa thin; embryo small, in horny albumen.

author: Roxb.
description: A small creoping herb; stems prostrate, 30 cm long or less, rooting at the nodes, filiform, puberulous. Leaves opposite, 1.25-3 cm in diam., orbicular, deeply cordate, pubescent or glabrous; petioles 1.25-5 cm long, pubescent; stipules broadly ovate, obtuse. Flowers terminal solirary or in peduncled 2-3 flowered umbels; peducles .6-3.75 cm long; pedicles very short; bracts lanceolate-subulate. Calyx .5 cm long; teeth longer than the tube, lanceolate, acuminate, ciliate. Corolla glabrous or slightly pubescent outside; tube dialted upwards, hairy in the throat; lobes ovate-oblong, acute, shorter than the tube, recurved. Stamens inserted on the corolla-tube; filaments filiform; anthers linear. Ovary 2-celled; ovules solitary in each cell, erect from the base, anatropous; style slender, with 2 short or elongate branches. Berry .6-1 cm in diam., globose, crowned with the large calyx-limb, smooth, pulpy, red when ripe; pyrenes small, flat and smooth on the ventral, rough and bluntly keeled on the convex dorsal surface.

author: Wight
description: A small evergreen tree 9-10 m high; young branches, under surface of the leaves, petioles and inflorescence clothed with short velvety pubescence. Leaves alternate, bifarious, thinly coriaceous, 5-11.25 by 2.8-3 cm, elliptic-oblong or elliptic-lanceolate, acute, obtuse or shortly acuminate, base usually acute; main nerves 6-8 pairs, conspicuous petioles .3 cm long; stipules triangular, cuspidate. Flowers in axillary clusters, the males and females together. Perianth simple. Petals 0. MALE FLOWERS: Pedicels often .6 cm long; slender, pubescent. Sepals 6, ovate, subacute, .3 cm long, keeled and pubescent on the back. Stamens connate in a oblong sessile column. Staminal-column .15 cm long. Pistillode 0 or rarely minute and hidden between the anthers. FEMALE FLOWERS: Pedicels 0-.4 cm long, pubescent. Calyx usually of 6 short imbricate sepasl. Ovary 4-7-celled; ovules 2 in each cell; style enlarged at the truncate 4-7 toothed tip longer than the ovary. Fruit a capsule, 1.25 cm in diam., orbicular, depressed 4-7 celled and 4-7 lobed, sessile or pedicellate, often leaving the bright red seeds on the tree.

author: L.
description: A herbaceous tall glabrous branching climber; rootstock of arched, solid, fleshy-white, cylindric tubers 15-30 by 2.5-3.75 cm, pointed at each end, bifurcately branched or V-shaped, producing a new joint at the end of each branch; roots fibrous; stems annual, 3-6 m long, given off from the angles of the young tubers, herbaceous. Leaves alternate, sessile or nearly so, 7.5-15 by 2-4.5 cm, scattered or opposite, or sometimes ternately whorled, ovate-lancelolate, acuminate, tip ending in a tendril-likes spiral, base cordate; nerves parallel. Flowers large, axillary, solitary, or sub-corymbose towards the ends of the branches from the nearness of the leaves, remaining for about 7 days without withering; pedicels 7.5-15 cm long, the tips deflexed. Perianth-segments reaching 6.25 by .8-1.25 cm, linear lanceolate with crisply waved margins, greenish at first, then yellow, passing through orange and scarlet to crimson. Stamens 6, hypogynous, filaments 3.75-4.5 cm long, spreading; anthers linear, nearly 1.25 cm long, dorsifixed, versatile, dehiscing extrorsely. Ovary 3-celled; ovules numerous in each cell; style filiform, reaching 5 cm long; deflexed, with 3 subulate arms, stigmatose within. Fruit a large coriaceous septicidal capsule. Capsules 4.5 by 2 cm, linear-oblong.
pharmacology: Spasmolytic, CNS depressant, antibiotic, oxytocic, uterine stimulant, nematicidal. Colchicine (2, 4 and 5 mg) when infused into udder of goats decreased milk production. In some animal mammary gland blood flow was increased from 8 to 24 hours after infusion which returned to normal after 4 days of infusion. C11ToxicologyC11 The alcoholic and aqueous extracts of the plant were found to be toxic at dose of 25 mg / kg respectively. After ingestion of tubers, gastroenteritis, acute renal failure, cardiotoxicity and haematological abnormalities were the main toxic manifestations. View Reference

author: Wight
description: A shrub. Leaves alternate, entire, coriaceous: petioles rather longer. Flowers small, polygamo-dioecious, more numerous than in Gomohandra. axillaris, rather larger, sessile; panicle leaf-opposed or extra-axillary, rarely axillary. Calyx cup-shaped, minutely 4-5 toothed. Corolla more deeply lobed than in G. axillaries; lobes 4 or 5. Stamens 4 or 5, hypogynous, exserted; hairs on the filaments about the length of the anther, sometimes absent. MALE FLOWERS with rudimentary ovary sunk in the fleshy disk; stigma minute. FEMALE FLOWERS with long cylindric 1-celled ovary and large discoid stigma; ovules 2, collateral, pendulous from the apex, the funicle dilated. Fruit elongate, drupe-like, surmounted by the remains of the stigma; pericarp smooth, thin; endocarp leathery. Seed solitary, pendulous; albumen fleshy, bipartite; embryo minute. Drupes 1.25-1.5 cm long oblong, blunt at both ends, smooth, white. Seeds large.

author: Wall. ex Wight & Arn.
description: A tall evergreen tree. Leaves simple, alternate, 5-10 by 2.5-3.75 cm, elliptic-lanceolate, obtuse, often emarginated, crenulate, acute at the base, glabrous, shining; petioles .6 cm long. Flowers 3.75 cm across, white; pedicels .6 cm long. Sepals 5, orbicular oblong, silky outside. Petals obcordate, pubescent outside, slightly connate at the base. author: Vent.
description: A straggling shrub; young parts stellately hairy. Leaves 7.5-12.25 by 6.25-9 cm, roundish-ovate, acute or acuminate, often more or less lobed, irregularly serrate, scabrous above, stellately hairy beneath, base subcordate, 3-nerved; petioles 1-1.25 cm long, hairy beneath, base subcordate, 3 nerved; petioles 1-1.25 cm long, hairy; stipules .6 cm long, lanceolate, hairy. Flowers in short, umbellate cymes; buds ovoid or oblong, pilose; peduncles axillary 1-3 together, shorter than the petioles, hairy; pedicels usually 3, longer than the peduncles, pilose; bracts lanceolate, acute, hairy. Sepals 5, linear-oblong, acute, 1.25 cm long, hairy outside. Petals about a quarter the length of the sepals, oblong, rounded at the apex, entire; gland a little more than half the length of the petal, margin villous. Torus short, with tufted hairs at the apex, the lower part glabrous. Stamens numerous. Ovary villous; style much longer than the staments, glabrous; stigma laciniate. Drupes 1.25 cm across, fleshy, minutely stellately hairy, obscurely 4-lobed, wrinkled.

author: L.
description: A small tree; young parts stellately pubescent. Leaves 7.5-17.5 by 6.25-12.5 cm ovate or suborbicular, acute or subaccuminate, irregularly and coarsely toothed, subglabrous above, hoary-tomentose beneath, obliquely cordarte or rounded at the base, 5-6 nerved; petioles 1.25 cm. long, thickened at the top; stipules nearly as long as the petioles, linear or lanceolate, acute. Flowers slightly larger than in the preceding species, in umbellate cymes; buds obovate-oblong, ribbed, pubescent; peduncles axillary, 1-4 together, slender, 1.25-3.75 cm long, puberulous; pedicels 2-5, shorter than the peduncles; bracts beneath the pedicels lanceolate. Sepals 5, linear-oblong, acute, 1 cm long, pubescent outside. Petals 5, yellow, oblong or ovate-oblong, subacute, notched, about two thirds the length of the sepals; gland about one third the length of the petal, the margin white-villous. Torus .4 cm long, glabrous below, with a villous ring at top beneath the ovary. Stamens numerous. Ovary villous. Drupe globose, 1-2 lobed, 1-celled, pilose.

author: Wight & Arn.
description: A shrub or small tree. Leaves 5-7.5 by 2-3.75 cm, ovate oblong, acute irregularly serrate, stellately hairy on both surfaces, base rounded or subcordate, more or less oblique, 3-nerved; petioles .25-.3 cm long, hairy; stipules linear-subulate, hairy, longer than petioles. Flowers in short axillary umbels; buds oblong, obtuse, slightly dilated at the base, pilose, ribbed; peduncles 1-3 together, as long as, or longer than the petioles, pilose; pedicles usually 3, about as long as the peduncles, pilose, ribbed; peduncles 1-3 together, as long as, as the peduncles, pilose; bracts beneath the pedicels ovat. Sepals 5, linear, 1.5 by .25 cm, acute, pilose without, glabrous within, with a small pale pubescent patch at the base inside. Petals 5, usually bifid at the apex, rounded and thickened at the base, nearly 1.25 cm long, linear-oblong, hairy near the base outside, and with a few small tufts of stiff, fascicle hairs about 2/3 of the way up; gland oblong, about one third the length of the petal, pilose at top, less densely so on the lateral margins. Anthers with a few simple hairs on the back. Torus short, glabrous, 5-lobed at the apex beneath the ovary, the lobes ciliate. Ovary hairy; style pilose at the base stigma small bifid. Drupes stellately hairy, 1-4 lobed, yellowish brown; rind crustaceous; stones 1-4, muricate, 1-3 celled; mesocarp thick, fibrous.

author: Vahl.
description: A deciduous tree 10-12 m high; bark pale brown; young parts densely pubescent. Leaves 7.5-12.5 by 5-7.5 cm, ovate, acuminate with a tendency to become lobate at the apex, crenate-dentate, upper surface minutely stellately hairy or subglabrous, the nerves pubescent, lower surface hoary-tomentose, cordate and inequilateral at the base, 6-nerved, 3 nerves at the larger and two at the smaller side of the midrib; petioles .6-2 cm, long, pubescent; stipules 2 cm long, leafy, somewhat falcate, auricled, with a rounded lobe on the lower side, veined. Flowers small, umbellate; buds obovoid-oblong or subglobose, tomentose; peduncles 3 or several, axillary, thick, about equaling the petioles; pedicels 3-5, divergent, shorter than the peduncles; bracts beneath the pedicels linear-lanceolate. Sepals 5, distinct, .8 cm long, oblong, subacute, pubescent outside, glabrous within. Petals 5, about half as long as the sepals, oblong or spathulate, entire or notched; gland about one third the length of the petal, densely white-villous on the margin. Torus rather long, ribbed, glabrous, with 5 obscure villous teeth at the apex. Stamens numerous, inserted on a turbinate often glandular torus. Ovary 2-4 celled, villous; style longer than the stamens; stigma somewhat irregularly 5-lobed, Drupes size of a pea, black, globose or 2- (rarely 4-) lobed; stones 1-2 celled.
chemical_composition: The leaves contain 1% tannin.

author: (Retz.) Schult.
description: Twining shrubs. Leaves opposite. Flowers small, in crowded lateral umbellate cymes. Calyx 5-partite. Corolla campanulate or urceolate, divided to the middle or beyond it; lobes with thick, overlapping to the right in bud; corona arising from and adnate to the corolla-tube. Staminal-column arising from the base of the corolla; anthers short, erect, with short membranous appendages; pollen masses erect, solitary in each anther-cell. Style-apex often exserted beyond the anthers. Follicles smooth. Seeds comose.
pharmacology: Leaf of I11G. sylvestreI11 exhibited Antidiabetic activity in experimental animals and in humans. It was reported to suppress the absorption of sugar from small intestine. I11G. sylvestreI11 leaf and Gymnemic acids were reported to suppress the ability to taste sweet. View Reference

author: Laws.
description: A large shrub, sometimes a small tree, usually armed with long straight thorns. Leaves alternate, coriaceous 7.5-11.25 by 4.5-6.25 cm, broadly obovate-cuneate, rounded or very shortly and bluntly acuminate at the apex, crenulate, dark green, glabrous and polished above, pale beneath, reticulately veined, the veins not prominent on the underside; petioles .6-1.5 cm long, stout. Flowers greenish-white, in short-peduncles or subsessile cymes or fascicles from the tubercles of the older branches. Calyx glabrous, 5-fid, divided nearly to the base; lobes broadly ovate or triangular, with membranous ciliolate margins. Petals 4-5, ovate-oblong, obtuse, .3 cm long, the margin entire or faintly denticulate. Stamens 4-5, shorter than the petals; filaments flattened, inserted below the 10-lobed fleshy disk. Stigmas 3, as long as the style, spreading. Capsules 3-lobed, bright red when ripe, the valves turning back in dehiscence shewing their white inner surfaces. Seeds 6, ellipsoid, .6 cm long, with a small basal aril, brownish-orange, smooth, shining.

author: Lam.
description: Annual herbs, verying from 7-40 cm high; stems terete, numerous, slender, erect, ascending or spreading, glabrous or pubescent. Leaves subsessile, 2-4.5 by .15-.4 cm, linear or linear-lanceolate, acute; stipules short, membranous, truncate, with afew short bristle. author: Wight & Arn.
description: Annual; branches numerous, prostrate or ascending, 4-angled, slightly rough on the angles. Leaves subsessile, 2.5-5.5 by .6-1.25 cm, lanceolate or ovate-lanceolate, acute, rigid, light-green, glabrous and shining above, scabrous towards the much recurved margins, whitish and with the midrib often rough beneath, base usually acute; nerves (except the strong midrib) not visible; stipules with numerous long bristles. Flowers solitary or few, axillary, sessile. Calyx glabrous; teeth rigid, triangular. Corolla campanulate; lobes 4, valvate in bud. Stamens 4; ovary 2-celled. Capsules .6 cm long, dehiscent at the top only, ovoid, glabrous, veined, crowned by the erect clayx-teeth which about equal the capsule. Seeds numerous, pale brown, angled.

author: L.
description: A shrub or small tree; young shoots clothed with stellate hairs. Leaves bifarious, 7.5-12.5 by 5-10 cm, oblong obovate or roundish, cordate, suddenly and shortly acuminate, closely dotted on both surfaces with stellate hairs, more or less irregularly crenate-serrate; petioles .6-1 cm long, stipules subulate .6 cm long. Flowers 2.5-3.75 cm long, distinctly bilabiate, in axillary clusters of 2-6 together; pedicels very short, stellately tomentose; bracts small, subulate, hairy. Calyx tubular, 2 cm long, somewhat 2-lipped, stellately pubescent without, curved, laterally compressed, mouth wide; teeth 5, triangular. Petals 5, equal, or somewhat 2-lipped with long claws which sometimes have ear-shaped appendages. Staminal-column fused with gynophore, much exserted, suddenly deflexed; anthers 10, in a ring round the ovary. Ovary conical, on a curved gynophore 3.75 cm long, linear, 5-lobed, 5-celled; ovules many in each cell; styles 5. Fruit a capsule, cells twisted together into the form of a screw, stellately tomentose. Seeds numerous, angular; testa loose, wrinkled.

author: L.
description: A coarse somewhat succulent annual herb, 15-60 cm high, with stout stem and ascending branches more or less densely hirsute with spreading hairs. Leaves alternate or often subopposite, 4.5-10 by 2.5-5 cm, ovate or ovate-oblong, obtuse or subacute, usually with a few scattered hairs above, minutely pilose beneath, the margins much undulate or subserrate, base rounded or sometimes cordate or narrowed, often unequal-sided and then suddenly contracted and decurrent into the petiole; nerves and veins conspicuous on the lower side; petioles 2-3.75 cm long, more or less winged. Flowers pale-violet, numerous, sessile, 2-ranked, in simple or rarely forked usually extra-axillary bristly ebracteate spikes 5-15 cm long. Calyx .25 cm long, bristly with a few long hairs outside; 5-cleft, segements .15 cm long, linear-lanceolate, acute, unequal. Corolla .5 cm long; tube .3 cm long, hairy outside, narrowd upwards; limb infundibuliform; lobes 5, orbicular-oblong. Stamens 5, inserted below the middle of the corolla-tube; filaments very short; anthers ovate, acute. Ovary 4-celled, 4-ovulate; ovule pendulous from the inner angle of the cell near its apex; style terminal, with an annular frill at the base and with a short obtuse apex. Fruit .4 cm long, deply 2-lobed, each lobe compressed, bluntly 4-ribbed, produced above into a short blunt bidentate beak and containing 2 angular beaked hard 1-seeded pyrenes which have each an empty cavity on the inner side.

author: (L.) R. Br.
description: A perennial prostrate or twining shrub; rootstock woody; stems numerous, slender, terete, glabrous or pubescent, striate, thickened at the nodes. Leaves very variable, from elliptic-oblong to linear-lanceolate, 5-10 cm long, but of very variable breadth (from .8-3.75 cm), apiculate, the narrow leaves acute, the broad ones often obtuse at the apex, glabrous, dark-green, often variegated above, pale and sometimes silvery-white and pubescent beneath, with reticulate veins; petioles .3-.4 cm long. Flowers crowded in sub-sessile cymes in the opposite axils; pedicels short clothed with numerous ovate acute imbricating bracts. Calyx .25 long, glabrous outside; 5-lobed; lobes .15 cm long, ovate, acute, with membranous ciliolate margins. Corolla .5-.6 cm long, greenish outside, purple inside; tube very short; lobes 5, valvate, fleshy, .4 cm long, ovate-oblong, acuminate. Corona scales 5, short, thick, on the throat of the corolla and alternate with its lobes. Stamens inserted at the base of the corolla-tube; pollen-masses cohering in pairs in each cell, granular. Style-apex 5-gonous, flat on the top. Follicles 10-15 by .6 cm, cylindric, tapering to a point at the apex, straight or sometimes slightly curved, striate, glabrous. Seeds .6-.8 cm long, ovate-oblong, flattened, black; coma silvery-white, 2.5 cm long.
phenology: Flowers: throughout the greater part of the year.
pharmacology: Bacteriostatic, anticancer, antiviral, antilithic, hypotensive, antifungal, antibacterial, antiinflammatory, spasmodic. The ethanol extract of H. indicus root significantly prevented rifampicin and isoniazid-induced hepatotoxicity in rats.The chloroform and ethanol (95 per cent) extracts were reported to possess good antifungal activity against I11Aspergillus nigerI11 and weak antibacterial activity against I11Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa.I11 An organic acid isolated from root extract possessed viper venom inhibitory activity. The root extract has potent antiinflammatory, antipyretic and antioxidant properties and effectively neutralized inflammation induced by viper venom in male albino mice and reduced cotton pellet induced granuloma in rats. The root bark showed antioxidant activity. The root extract demonstrated inhibitory activity against Mycobacterium leprae in mice. The root extract was reported to be effective chemo protective agent and prevented oxidative stress and tumour in skin. The aqueous ethanolic extract of root collected during flowering season was found to possess significant antiulcer activity. View Reference

author: L.
description: Arborescent; stem without prickles. Leaves alternate, short-petioled, ovate or ovate lanceolate, more or less acuminate, irregularly and coarsely serrate towards the top, entire near the base, glabrous on both sides or with a few minute stellate hairs on the nerves beneath; stipules lanceolate, subulate, glabrous. Pedicels axillary, solitary, very long, as long as, or longer than the leaves, jointed above the middle. Involucral bracts 5-7, about half as long as the calyx, lanceolate, glabrous. Calyx divided almost to the middle; sepals 5, puberulous with very minute stellate hairs, 2 cm long, lanceolate. Corolla 7.5 cm in diameter, tubular below, red; petals 5, thrice as long as the calyx. Staminal tube exserted far beyond the petals. Ovary 5-celled, style 5. Fruit rarely seen.

locations.vegetation: Tropical semi evergreen to evergreen forest

pharmacology: Partial anti tumour, hypoglycaemic, antifertility, antiovulatory, antiimplantation, antiinflammatory, analgesic, juvenoid activity, antiestrogenic, spasmolytic, CNS depressant, hypotensive, antipyretic, antispasmodic, antiviral, antifungal, antibacterial. The benzene extract of I11H. rosa-sinensisI11 showed antifertility effect in rats. The ethanol extract showed an effect on sex ration in favour of male pups at birth. Flowers collected in winter season showed maximum post-coital antifertility activity. Total alcoholic and benzene extracts showed dose dependent antiestrogenic activity in ovariectomised albino rats and significantly decreased ovarian, uterine and pituitary weight. Benzene extract of flowers had antiovulatory, antiimplantation and abortifacient activities. The benzene extract produced dose dependent antifertility activity mediated via interruption in implantation. It inhibited the hyper permeability of endometrium capillaries. The 50% ethanol and benzene extracts administered orally showed partial antagonism with estradiol disproportionate on KP11+P11 content of uterine flushings in ovariectomised rats. Aqueous infusion of flowers reduced the duration of oestrous cycle in albino rabbits. The aqueous extract of the flowers lowered the lactate dehydrogenase content in males of I11Rhinopoma kinneari.I11 Oral administration of benzene extract affected spermatogenesis and endocrine functions of the testis of male albino rats. Ethanol (80 per cent) extract was reported to possess antiviral activity. C11ToxicologyC11 Alcoholic and aqueous extracts of roots were found toxic in mice. LDB1150B11 of the ethanolic extract of leaves was 1533Â± 25 mg/kg i.p. in albino mice. The approximate LD B1150B11 of the ethanolic extract (50%) of whole plant (excluding roots) was 1000 mg /kg i.p. in mice. C11Therapeutic Evaluation C11 An uncontrolled clinical trial using the ethanolic extract of I11H. rosa-sinensisI11 flowers was carried out on 21 women in the reproductive age group by administering 750 mg/day in 3 divided doses from the 7th to 22nd day of menstrual cycle (total of 229 cycles). Fourteen women did not have pregnancy for 4 years, whereas 7 women dropped out of trial. In another uncontrolled clinical study on 20 patients of mild to moderate hypertension, powdered Japa flowers (6 to 9 gm per day in divided doses) were reported to produce significant reduction in the blood pressure, the effect on the diastolic pressure being more marked than on systolic. Leucosol- H, a composite drug containing I11Santalum album, Amaranthus polygamus, A. spinosus, Berberis aristata, Hibiscus rosa-sinensis, Sida cordifolia, Aegle marmelosI11 and I11Ficus bengalensis,I11 was administered (10 ml, twice a day) to 15 patients of leucorrhoea for two weeks. Complete relief from symptoms was observed in 62% cases. A clinical study on 30 patients suffering from hypertension and hypercholesterolemia with a Siddha drug, Anna Pavala Sindhooram, containing Japa as one of the ingredients, indicates that the drug is efficacious in reducing the cholesterol, phospholipids and triglycerides. However, on withdrawal of the drug there was slow increase in lipids. Clinical trials were conducted with Vidangadi yoga (a herbal preparation containing Embelia ribes seeds. I11Hibiscus rosa-sinensisI11 flowers and Ferula foetida oleo-gum resin) for its antifertility activity. The drug was found to be quite effective with no toxic effects. View Reference

description: A tall evergrrn tree; branches densly leafy at the apex. Leaves alternate, 15-30 by 5-10 cm, obovate or oblanceolate, decurrent into the petiole, acute or rounded at the apex, glabrous on both surfaces, paler beneath; main nerves 12-20 pairs, prominent of both surfaces, nearly straight, making a large angle with costa; petioles .6-2.5 cm long, with 2 petiolar spurs or tubercles at the top, which are early deciduous. Flowers minute, crowded in rufous-tomentose panicles which are shorter or longer than the leaves. Calyx tube cup-shaped, teeth 5, very short. Petals 5, densely vilous in front, cohering at the base and with the edge of the disk, persistent, valvate, .25 cm long, oblong, acute. Stamens 5, inserted at the edge of the disk, coherent at the base with petals; filaments subulate, glabrous; anthers small, subglobose. Ovary in the male flowers 0, in the female flowers inferior, 1-celled; ovule pendulous from near the top of the cell. Drupees reaching 2.5 cm long, obliquely ovoid, rounded at the top, quite glabrous, long pedicelled, almost entirely included in the torus.

author: (Roth) Schum.
description: A large glabrous twining shrub. Stems much branched. Leaves opposite, thick ovate-oblong, acuminate, glabrous above and more or less pubescent beneath, base deeply cordate. Petioles 2.5-5 cm long. Inflorescence is sub lateral few flowered pedunculate cyme. Flowers large, fragrant, edible, purpulish crimson inside, froasted white or pale pink outside. Calyx 5-partite, not glandular inside; segments ovate. Corolla thick, subrotate, deeply 5-fid; lobes overlapping to the right. Corona arising from the base of the staminal column consisting of a fleshy truncate ring. Staminal-column arising from the base of the corolla; filaments connate; anther-wings large, decurrent to the base of the column; pollen-masses 1 in each cell, elongate, compressed, pendulous by a long caudicle from an attenuated apex. Style-apex scarcely umbonate. Follicles linear-oblong, cylindric, slightly tapering to a blunt point.

author: L.
description: A rambling scandent shrub; branches yellow-tomentose, with short horizontal branchlets, leafless below and provide near the ends with a pair of ciccinate hooks. Leaves alternate, 3.75-6.25 by 2.5-3.75 cm, elliptic-obovate, obtuse or subacute, entire, reticulately veined, the veins conspicuous on both surfaces, glabrous, base tapering; petioles .15. long, hairy; stipules lanceolate-subulate. Flowers at the extremities of the short branchlets 2.5-3 cm across, terminal and in the upper axils; pedicels short, 1 flowered, clothed with soft yellow hairs. Sepals 5, ovate-lancelolate, acute, .75 cm long, fulvous-pubescent. Petals 5, many times longer than the sepals, thin, ovate-oblong, acute or truncate. Stamens 10, connate at the base into a short tube, with glandular swellings between the petals. Ovary 5-celled; ovules 2 collateral in each cell; styles 5, filiform, stigma capitate. Drupes about .3 cm in diam., globose, surrounded by the persisitent sepals; fleshy, pulp scanty; stone bony, grooved, 10 celled, with usually 2 or 3 seeds.

author: L.
description: Annual or biennial; rootstock woody; stems densely caespitose, 30-50 cm long, trailing prostrate but not rooting, much-branched, terete or somewhat angled, sparsely clothed with white appressed hair. Pods appressed hairy. Seeds 2, globose.

author: Roxb.
description: An erect ramous shrub, 120-180 cm high; branches striate, ghabous or more or less hairy. Leaves imparipinnate, 7.5-15 cm long; petioles 2-2.1 cm long; stipules very minute, subulate, caduceus. Leaflets 13-21, opposite or a few casually alternate, 1.25-2.5 by .75-1.5 cm, elliptic-oblong, rounded, truncate or emarginated, apiculate, thinly clothed with short grey appressed hairs, base acute; main nerves prominent on the under surface; petiolules of the lateral leaflets .2-2.1 cm, those of the terminal ones .6-1 cm long. Flowers the largest of the genus, numerous, in moderately close short-peduncled racemes shorter than the leaves; pedicels short, slender, hairy; bracts large, boat shaped, long-cuspidate, exceeding the buds, silky-hairy, caduceus. Calyx .2-.3 cm long, appressedly hairy outside; teeth short, triangular. Corolla pueple, 1.251 cm long; standard orbicular, as broad as long, glabrous on the back; keel-petals glabous outside. Stamens diadelphous; anthers uniform, apiculate. Pods 2.5-4.5 cm long, straight, turgid, cylindric, glabrous. Seeds 8-12.

author: L.
description: A shrub 120-180 cm high; branches terete or more or less angular, slightly silvery from fine appressed hairs. Leaves 2.5-7.5 cm long; petioles 1.25-2.5 cm long; stipules small, subulate. Leaflets imparipinnate, 9-13, opposite, membrous, green but drying grayish-black, 1.25-2.5 by .6-1.25 cm, oblong or oblaneolate, rounded, apiculate, glabrous above or nearly so, thinly clothed with appressed hairs beneath, base acute; petiolules of lateral leaflets .12-.21 cm, those of the terminal reaching .6 cm long. Flowers numerous in nearly sessile lax spicate racemes 5-10 cm long. Calyx .12-.15 cm long, hairy outside; teeth triangular, acute, as long as the tube. Corolla pink, .4 cm long; standard pubescent at the back. Stamens diadelphous; anthers uniform, epiculate. Ovary sessile or subsessile, ovules many, style glabrous, stigma capitate. Pods 2-3 cm long, liner, straight or slightly curved, apiculate, thickened at the sutures, glabrous, not torulose. Seeds 8-12.
chemical_composition: Water soluble galactomannan (seed); glycoside indican which on acid hydrolysis and aerial oxidation yields indigo, indirubin (plant). Apigenin ,kaempferol, luteolin and quercetin isolated from various parts of plant (roots, stems, leaves and pods) and tissue culture; production of flavonoids in tissue culture was greater than in plant parts.

author: (L.) Roth.
description: A extensive, hairy, herbaceous annual or perennial twiner, found throughout India up to a height of 6,000 ft in the Himlayas; it is frequently grown in gardens for its ornamental flowers, and often runs wild in hedges and waste places. Leaves alternate, ovate-cordate, 3-lobed; flowers large, funnel-shaped, pale or bright blue tinged with pink, turning red or reddish on ageing, in 1-5 flowered umbellate cymes; capsules ovoid, sub-globose, smooth; seeds 4 or 6, black, grey puberulent.
chemical_composition: Seed oil contained palmitic (6.8), stearic (17.5). arachidic (7.0), oleic (48.4), linoleic (15.3) and linoleic (5.0%) acids; PC of acid hydrolysate of seed extract showed presence of galactose, xylose and arabinose; presence of lysergol and chanoclavine in seeds.

author: K. Gawl.
description: Annuals; stems very long and slender, often purplish, twining, glabrous or with a few spreading hairs. Leaves 2.5-6.25 by 2-5 cm, broadly ovate, acuminate, subacute, entire, glabrous or more or less pubescent, thin; petioles 2.5-7.5 cm long, slender, glabrous or pubescent. Flowers rather small, 1 or 2 together; peduncles 2.5-5.5 cm long; bracts minute, linear-lanceolate; pedicels .6-3 cm long. Sepals 1 cm long, subequal, oblong, subacute, shortly apiculate, minutely verrucose, veined. Corolla infundibuliform, 2.1 cm long, yellow, or white yellowish, with a small purple eye; mouth of limb wide, 2.5 cm in diam. with shallow apiculate lobes. Capsules .8 cm long, ovoid, subacute, glabrous. Seeds dark-brown, velvety.
chemical_composition: Methanolic seed ext. of I11Ipomoea obscuraI11 afforded five indole alkaloids, three of them (ipobscurines B-D) being new natural products of a unique structural type characterized as serotonin hydroxycinnamic acid amide-type conjugates with a second phenylpropanoid moiety forming an ether with the 5-OH position of the indole nucleus. Investigation on seed extraction of I11Ipomea quamoclitI11 revealed the presence of several phytochemical components, viz., n-triacontanol, sitosterol, stigmasterol, a-amyrin, taraxerone, taraxerol, erythrodiol, and cucurbitacin-G. Three dihydroxynortropanes, 2a,7b-dihydroxynortropane (I), 2a,3b-dihydroxynortropane (II), and 3a,7b-dihydroxynortropane (III), were isolated from calystegine-producing plants in the families Convolvulaceae and Solanaceae. 2a,7b-Dihydroxynortropane was isolated from six species in the Convolvulaceae whereas only I11Calystegia soldanellaI11 contained it and 2a,3b-dihydroxynortropane.

author: Wight.
description: A large climbing shrub; stem sometimes as thick as a manâs arm. Leaves oppostie, membranous, 7.5-11.25 by 5-6.25, broadly ovate, acuminate, entire, glabrous. Flowers white, fragrant, in lax trichotomous compound many-flowered (sometimes 40-50) terminal cymes; bracts .6-1 cm long, linear-subulate; pedicels .3-.6 cm long, pubescent. Calyx 1.25 cm long, pubescent; teeth 5-7, subulate from a slightly broader base, usually reflexed, .8 cm long, hairy. Corolla glabrous, hypocrateryform; tube 1-2.1 cm long; lobes 6-10, oblong or lanceolate, 2 cm long, very acute; white. Stamens 2, included in the corolla tube; filaments very short; anthers attached at the back near the base, the connective usually mucronate. Overy 2-celled; ovules usually 2 in each cell, attached near the base; style cylindric; stigma at length usually 2-fid. Berry didymous or often by suppression simple; carpels globose, ellipsoid. Seed usually solitary in each carpel, erect; albumen 0; cotyledons plano-convex; radicle inferior.

locations.vegetation: Tropical semi evergreen to evergreen forest

Basic Description of Plant : A large climbing shrub; stem sometimes as thick as a manâs arm. Leaves oppostie, membranous, 7.5-11.25 by 5-6.25, broadly ovate, acuminate, entire, glabrous. Flowers white, fragrant, in lax trichotomous compound many-flowered (sometimes 40-50) terminal cymes; bracts .6-1 cm long, linear-subulate; pedicels .3-.6 cm long, pubescent. Calyx 1.25 cm long, pubescent; teeth 5-7, subulate from a slightly broader base, usually reflexed, .8 cm long, hairy. Corolla glabrous, hypocrateryform; tube 1-2.1 cm long; lobes 6-10, oblong or lanceolate, 2 cm long, very acute; white. Stamens 2, included in the corolla tube; filaments very short; anthers attached at the back near the base, the connective usually mucronate. Overy 2-celled; ovules usually 2 in each cell, attached near the base; style cylindric; stigma at length usually 2-fid. Berry didymous or often by suppression simple; carpels globose, ellipsoid. Seed usually solitary in each carpel, erect; albumen 0; cotyledons plano-convex; radicle inferior.

author: L.
description: A soft-wooded shrub or small tree, a native of Tropical America, commonly grown as a fence near villages. Leaves alternate, angular or 3-5 lobed, 10-15 cm long. Flowers monoecious, in terminal cymes, the central flowers in the cyme or its forks usually female. Perianth usually double. MALE FLOWERS: Calyx 5-lobed or -partite, the segments often colored, imbricate. Petals 5, free or connate Disk entire or of 5 glands. Stamens 10; filaments of 5 interior connate into a central column; anthers erect, ovate or oblong, the cells parallel, contiguous. Pistillode 0. FEMALE FLOWERS: Calyx as in the male. Petals sometimes absent. Ovary 2-4 celled; ovules solitary in each cell; styles connate below, 2-fid above, the lobes entire or again 2-lobed. Fruit a capsule of 2-4 cocci; cocci 2-valved; endocarp crustaceous or hard. Seeds ovoid or oblong; testa crustaceous; albumen fleshy; cotyledons broad, flat.
chemical_composition: Leaves contain apigenin, vitexin and isovitexin, amyrin stigmasterol, sitgmastenes along with two new flaonid glycosides found in leaves and twings. Palmitic, oleic and linoleic acids in seed fat. Ash of seeds contains Ca., Mg., K. and traces of P. Ash of seeds (4.38%) contained Ca, Mg, NA, K and traces of P; presence of oleic, linoleic , myristic, palmitic, stearic, arachidic acids and sitosterol; detection of glucose, arabinose, xylose and rhamnose in seeds by PC.

author: (Poir.) Baillon
description: A large glabrous or pubescent straggling or climbing shrub; branches smooth or lenticellate. Leaves 1.25-3 by .8-1 cm, variable, oblong or elliptic, sometimes almost rotundate, obtuse or acute, thin, glabrous or nearly so, pale beneath, base rounded, acute or subcordate; main nerves few, slender; petioles .15-.3 cm long, slender, stipules .15 cm long, ovate, acute, sometimes bristle-pointed. Flowers axillary, monoecious; the males in fascicles of 2-6, the females solitary; pedicels .15-.6 cm long, slender. Calyx glabrous, reaching .25 cm long; segments oblong, very obtuse, alternating with the glands of the disk. MALE FLOWERS: Stamens 5, the 3 inner connate into a column, the 2 outer free, shorter. FEMALE FLOWERS: Ovary 5-10-celled; ovules 2 in each cell, superposed; styles 3, minute, 2-lobed. Fruit a purple fleshy berry .4 cm in diam., globose, smooth and shining. Seeds 8-16 (usually 10), irregularly 3-genous, finely granulate.
chemical_composition: Leaves contain tannic acid, but no alkaloid.

author: L.
description: Straggling or scandent shrubs with an odor of black currants; branches 4-angled. Leaves simple, opposite or rarely ternate or whorled. Flowers in pedunculate, capitate, ovoid or cylindric spikes; bracts ovate, conspicuous, longer than the calyx; bracteoles 0. Calyx small, membranous, truncate or obscurely toothed. Corolla yellow, turning orange-red; tubes 2-3 times longer than the lobes; lobes 4-5 spreading. Statmes 4, didynamous, inserted about the middle of the tube, included; anthers broadly oblong. Ovary 2-celled; ovule solitary in each cell, erect from the base or attached laterally clse to the base of each cell; style short; stigma oblique, subcapitate. Fruits globose, drupaceous, bluish-black, shining, a more or less fleshy mesocarp; endocarp hard, separating when ripe into two 1-celled 1-seeded pyrenes.
chemical_composition: Alkaloid fraction lowered blood pressure, accelerated deep respiration and caused shivering in dogs; stimulated intestinal movements and inhibited uterine motility in rats. Due to its low toxicity, alkaloid may have application in treatment of asthma, bronchiectasis, arterial hypertension and fever. A new oxosteriod-lancamarone-isolated; a new triterpene-lantanolic acid, mp.306Âº -isolated; Me 3-oxursolate, mp.191Âº and lantic acid, mp.256Âº, isolated; structure of lantic acid elucidated.

author: Roxb.
description: A shrub 1-2.5 m high; branches quadrangular, strigosely hairy, yellowish-brown. Leaves 3.75-6.25 by 2.5-3.75 cm, opposite or in whorls of 3, ovate, acute or subobtuse, crenate-serrate, rugose and finely pubescent above, softly white-pubescent or subvillous beneath, rounded but usually suddenly narrowed at the base; petioles .6-1 cm long. Flowers odorless, sessile, in axillary pedunculate ovoid heads 1.25-2 cm long, lengthening out into short spikes and elongating infruit. Peduncles 2.5-8 cm long, usually in opposite axils, 4-sided, slender, hairy, somewhat thickened upwards; bracts reaching 1 cm long, ovate, acuminate, softly hairy on both sides, smaller upwards. Calyx .15 cm long, truncate, membranous, very hairy. Corolla light-purple with a yellowish tube, hairy outside; tube .6 cm long cylindric, often slightly swollen over the stamens; limb .8 cm across; lobes 4, rounded, spreading. Statmes 4, didynamous. Filaments very short, slender. Ovary glabrous; style short. Durpe .4 cm in diam., purple.
