author: L.
description: A glabrous much-branched shrub; lateral branches 4-gonous, often ending in a spinous point. Leaves opposite, 1.25-3 by .6-1.5 cm, elliptic or broadly lanceolate, acute or obtuse, often mucronulate, base tapering; petioles very short or 0. Flowers numerous, less than 1.25 cm across, fragrant, white or rose-colored, in large terminal pyramidal panicled cymes; pedicels short, slender. Calyx .3-.5 cm long, broadly campanulate; lobes 4, ovate, acute, .25-.3 cm long, Petals 4, as broad as long, suborbicular or subreniform, undulate. Stamens 8, slightly veined outside, supported by the persistent calyx and tipped with style. Ovary subglobose, 2-4 celled; ovules many, placentas axile; style thick, slightly longer than the stamens; stigma capitate. Capsule globose, stalked in the base of the calyx-tube, coriaceous, irregularly breaking up, ultimately 1-celled. Seeds trigono-pyramidal, about .25 cm long, externally subtuberculate.

author: (Willd.) Link.
description: A variable annual herb, 15-45 cm. high; stem erect, usually much diffusely branched from below, stout, hispid or scabrid; branches quadrangular, hispid. Leaves subsessile or shortly petiolate, 2.5-7.5 by .6-1.25 cm, linear-oblong or oblong-lanceolate, obtuse, entire or crenate, more or less hairy, base tapering; petioles .25-.6 cm long. Flowers sessile or nearly so, in terminal and axillary whorls reaching 2.5 cm in diam.; bracts upto rather more than 3.5 cm long, linear, acute, bristle-tipped, ciliate with long slender hairs. Calyx variable, tubular, .8-1.25 cm long, tube curved, contracted above the nutlets, the lower half usually quite glabrous and membranous, the upper half ribbed, hispid or scabrid; mouth small, very oblique, not villous, the upper part produced forward; teeth small, triangular, bristle-tipped, ciliate, the upper tooth the largest. Corolla white, 2 lipped; .3 cm long; tube .5 cm long , enlarged and pubescent above, annulate about the middle upper lip .3 cm long , densely-white-woolly; lower lip about twice as long, the middle lobe, obovate, rounded, the lateral lobes small, subacute. Stamens 4, didynamous, the lower pair the longest; filaments ascending; anthers conniving, the cells divaricate, at length confluent. Disk present. Ovary 4-partite; style subulate at the apex, the upper lobe obsolete. Fruit of 4 ovoid triquetrous obtuse dry nutlets. Nutlets .25 cm long, oblong, subtruncate at the apex; inner face sharply angular, the dorsal face rounded, smooth, brown.

author: Spr.

author: Wight.
description: A large shrub or small tree; bark of the branches copiously studded with white lenticels. Leaves 3-7.5 by 2-5 cm, elliptic or slightly obovate, acute, acuminate or obtuse, often mucronate, glavraous, usually sprinkled beneath with minute black dots, base acute; main nerves 5-8 pairs; petioles .6-1 cm long, channelled above. Flowers white, fragrant, in dense or lax terminal nearly glabrous thyrsoid panicles sometimes reeaching 15 cm long and broad; branches of the panicle subquadrangular; pedicels 0-.25 cm long; bracts beneath the pedicels .15-.25 cm long, linear-lanceolate, acute; buds obovoid. Calyx .25 cm long, glabrous (rugose in dried specimens) limb truncate or shortly 4-toothed. Corolla .6 cm long; lobes as lng as the tube, elliptic-oblong, sub-acute, reflexed. Stamens 2, inserted on the corolla-tube, exserted beyond the extremity of the corolla-lobes. Ovary 2-celled; ovules 2 in each cell, pendulous; style as long as the corolla-tubes; stigma slightly clavate, obtuse. Drupe obovoid, 1 by .5 cm, dark purple and covered with a powdery bloom when ripe.
chemical_composition: The seeds containreducing sugar mannitol and fatty oil. Leaves contain glucoside syringin mannitol, p-hydroxy cinnamic acid and ursolic acid.

author: (Roxb.) Muell. Arg.
description: A small or middle-sized tree; bark dark-grey; branchlets stout; young shoots tomentose. Leaves alternate, 12.5-20 by 8-13 cm, ovate or deltoid-ovate, or orbicular, cuspidate, broadly peltate, entire or minutely toothed, glabrous or nearly so above, more or less pubescent and closely gland-dooted beneath, base rounded; basal nerves numerous and with 6-8 pairs of strong nerves above the basal ones, with reticulate venation between; petioles 7.5-15 cm long; stipules ovate, acuminate, reflexed, caducous. Flowers dioecious, in axillary racemes or panicles; males many, clustered; females one or few to each bract; bracts often large, entire or toothed. Perianth simple. MALE FLOWERS minute, numerous, in interrupted dense sessile heads, enveloped in bracts and bracteoles, arranged in numerous much-branched axillary rusty-tomentose panicles shorter or longer than the leaves; bracts broader than long, toothed, veined; bracteoles concave. Sepals 3, minute, obovate, cuneate. Petals 0; stamens 2-3; pistillode 0. FEMALE FLOWERS: Panicles simpler than in the male, the branches racemose with larger bracts. Calyx-limb obsolete. Petals 0. Ovary densely glandular, 1-celled; stigma sessile, often embracing one side of the ovary, thickly papillose. Capsules .6-.8 cm in diam., globose, hairy and glandular. Seed globose; testa brown, crustaceous, rough.
chemical_composition: Sitosterol from roots. Leaves contain 20% tannin.

author: Nees.
description: A large evergreen tree; young parts glabrous. Leaves alternate, clustered near the ends of branches, coriaceous, 9-17.5 by 3-6.25 cm variable in shape, from oblong and rounded at both ends to elliptic-lanceolate and acute at both ends, glabrous, shining above, glaucous beneath, finely reticulately veined; main nerves 8-12 pairs, not conspicuous; petioles 2-3 cm long. Flowers yellow, hermaphrodite, numerous, in panicles near the ends of the branches, often several panicles together 15-20 cm long, stout, puberlous. Perianth .6 cm long, silky-pubescent inside and outside; tube very short; segments 6, oblong or linear-oblong, subacute. Stamens 9 perfect, those of the 2 outer rows with eglandular filaments and introse 4-celled anthers, those of the third row with filaments which have 2 stipitate glands at the base and extrose 4-celled anthers, those of the fouth row replaced by stiptate cordate staminodes. Filaments hairy. Ovary sessile, narrowed into the style; stigma discoid. Fruit a globose or ovoid berry, seated on the persistent perianth, 1.25-2 cm in diam., smooth, dark-green dotted with white, ultimately becoming black.

author: Cl.
description: A large much-branced shrub; twigs slender, glabrous, usually covered with numerous small lenticels. Leaves 7.5-15 by 3.75-7.5 cm, ovate-oblong or elliptic-lanceolate, acute or acuminate, regularly or irregularly serrate-dentate, thin, glabrous and shining above, glabrous or with a few scattered hairs on the nerves beneath, base usually acute; main nerves 8-10 pairs, conspicuous beneath; petiole 1.25-2.5 cm long, glabrous or slightly hairy. Flowers very small, faintly fragrant, numerous, in compound, panicled, usually glabrous racemes; pedicels filiform, .1-.2 cm long; bract 1 below the pedicel, narrowly ovate, acute, glabrous; bracteoles 2, about .1 cm long, narrowly ovate, acute, not ciliate. Calyx .15 cm long, divided rather more than Â½ way down; lobes rotund-ovate, obtuse, not or sometimes faintly ciliate, glabrous on the back, marked with dark lines; tube enlarged in fruit, enclosing the berry, rugose and obscurely ribbed outside. Corolla white, .25 cm long, marked with colored lines, divided to the middle; lobes rotund ovate, somewhat abruptly and shortly contracted at the very base and with slightly crenulate margins, spreading. Stamens 5, inserted on the corolla-tube; filaments short. Ovary partially adnate to the calyx; ovules numerous on a subglobose placenta; style short; stigma small. Berry globose, creamy-white, about .3 cm in diam., covered almost to the apex by the persistent calyx and tipped with the short style. Seeds numerous, black.

author: (Lam.) Muell.-Arg.
description: A small much-branched tree; branchlets, young leaves, and inflorescence tawny or rusty-pubescent. Leaves alternate, variable, 7.5-15 by 3-7.5 cm, ovate or ovate-lanceolate, acuminate, entire slightly toothed, glabrous above, pubescent and with numerous orbicular red glands beneath, reticulately veined, base rounded or acute strongly 3-nerved at the base and with 4-7 pairs of nerves above the basal ones; petioles 2.5-5 cm long, cylindric, fulvous-pubescent, with small sessile glands one on each side of the summit. Flowers dioecious, small; the males clustered, sessile or very shortly pedicellate, in erect terminal spikes which are usually several together and often longer than the leaves; the females sessile or nearly so, in short spikes. MALE FLOWERS: Sepals 4 (rarely 5), .3 cm long, lanceolate, acute. Stamens numerous. Bracts .15 cm long, broadly ovate, acute. Buds globosely ovoid. FEMALE FLOWERS: Calyx divided nearly to the base; sepals 3 or 4, thicker than in the male, ovate-lanceolate. Ovary with red glands, 3-celled; styles 3, simple papillose. Capsules .8-1.25 cm in diam., 3-lobed, loculicidally 3-valved, covered with a bright-red powder consisting of minute stellate hairs and fine grains of a red resinous substance soluble in alcohol and ether. Seeds .4 cm in diam., subglobose, black.

author: Muell.-Arg.
description: A nearly glabrous shrub with yellow resinous glands on the young branchlets, inflorescence, and the underside of the leaves branches red-brown; branchlets compressed. Leaves opposite, 7.5-15 by 2.5-4.5 cm, lanceolate, obtusely acuminate, entire or sinuate-toothed glabrous, shining, dotted on the underside with numerous yellow resinous glands, penninerved, base narrowly rounded; nerves 5-7 pairs prominent beneath, and reticulat venation between; petiles .6-1 cm long. MALE FLOWERS sessile or shortly pedicellate; buds ovoid. Calyx divided to the base. Sepals usually 4, lanceolate, .25 cm long, clothed with yellow resinous glands. Bracts ovate, acute. Stamens about 20; filaments stout, .15-.2 cm long. Pistillode 0. FEMALE FLOWERS sessile or nearly so; buds oblong. Capsules .8 cm in diam., tridymous, clothed with yellow resinous glands, echinate with short stout sparsely scattered conical spines. Seeds globose, smooth, .4-.5 cm in diam. There is a great dearth of female flowers in herb.

author: L.
description: A large spreading evergreen tree reaching 15 m in height, all parts glabrous except the inflorescence. Leaves alternate, crowded at the ends of the branches, coriaceous, 12.5-25 by 3.75-7.5 cm, oblong, or oblong-lanceolate, acute, acuminate or subobtuse, shining, entire, the margins often undulate, base narrowed; petioles 1.25-6.25 cm long. Flowers monoecious, .5 cm long, with a somewhat disagreeable odor, arranged in large many flowered pubescent panicles longer than the leaves; pedicels short, thick; bracteoles ovate, small. Sepals ovate, concave, 4-5 partite, pubescent outside, shorter than the petals. Petals 4-5, oblong, subacute, reflexed, glabrous, with 3 strong orange-colored ridges on the inner face. Disk fleshy, 5-lobed. Stamen 1; filament subulate; anther purple. Ovary sessile, 1-celled, glabrous; ovules pendulous. Drupes large, fleshy, obliquely pyriform or subovoid, subcompressed, 7.5-20 cm long; stone compressed, fibrous, very hard.
chemical_composition: Leaves contain two flavnoids, two phenolic compounds, glucose, galactose, arabinose, xylose, rhamnose and tannin. Flowers yield 0.04% of an essential oil. Pannicles give ethyl galate. Mangiferin has been isolated from bark. Roots give mangiferin, friedelin and Ã-sitosterol. Fruit contains vitamins A, C and D. Mangiferrin has carditonic and diuretic properties. Seeds kernel has an astringent taste and is free from toxic principles and contains amino acid. Detection of two flavonoids, two phenolic compounds; glucose, galactose, arabinose, xylose, rhamnose and tannins in leaves by PC; friedelin, Ã-sitosterol, mangiferin (6.9%), mp. 278Âº, protocatechuic acid, catechin, gallic, ellagic, m-digallic acids, m-trigallic acid, gallotanin, but in, fisetin, leucocyanidin and quercetin isolated from different parts of plant; isolation and characterisation of new triterpenic acid -mangiferolic acid, mp. 181Âº; isomangiferolic acid, hydroxymangiferolic acid, mangiferonic acid, hydroxymangiferonic acid, mp.190Âº, ambonic acid and ambolic acid isolated; polysaccharides from unripe fruits identified as glucan, a highly branched arabinan and (1-4)linked galactouronan; new triterpenes -oleanolic aldehyde, mp. 168Â°, an aldehyde (I), mp. 166Âº, a diol (II), mp. 154Âº, a dimer and (20S)dammar-24-ene-3Ã,20 diol, mp. 130Âº -along with erythrodiol from resin; acetates of cycloartanol, amyrin and lupeol isolated; homomangiferin isolated and characterised as mangiferin 3-methyl ether.

author: (Dalzell) Sinclair.
description: Small evergreen tree; young parts puberulous. Leaves alternate, lanceolate, rarely elliptic, acuminate, 6.25-11.25 by 2.5-2 cm, glabrous above, more or less pubescent beneath, sometimes pellucido-punctate, base acute or rounded; petioles short, less than .6 cm long. Flowers axillary or terminal, solitary, straw-colored; pedicles .6-2 cm long. Sepals .6-1 cm long, ovate, acute, pubescent, lobes 3. Petals 6 in 2 series; outer 2.5-3.75 cm, long, oblong, acute or subobtuse, covered on both surfaces with fuscous, velvety tomentum, clawed, the claw rugose outside, glabrous within; inner petals narrower and shorter than the outer. Stamens many, cuneate, the apex of the produced connective subglobose or truncate. Torus flat or slightly concave. Ovaries 10-12, strigose; ovules 2-6. Carpels 5-7, ovoid or obovoid, 2 cm long, rounded or pointed, pubescent or tomentose, rarely slightly torulose.

author: L.
description: A tree reaching 12 m. Leaves impairi-bi- (sometimes tri) pinnate, 22.5-45 cm long; pinnae opposite or alternate; ultimate leaflets 3-11, opposite or nearly so, 1.25-5 by .6-2.5 cm, ovate or lanceolate, acuminate, obtusely serrate, sometimes lobed, glabrous on both surfaces, slightly inequilateral at the base; petiolules short, slender. Flowers hermaphrodite, fragrant, lilac, in long-peduncled, axillary panicles which are shorter than the leaves and glabrous or sparsely puberulous; pedicels slender. author: (Clarke) Cogn.
description: A small tree; branches robust, terete. Leaves 7.5-12.5 by 2.5-6.25 cm, oblong or ovate-oblong, acute or subobtuse, coriaceous, glabrous, shining above, amplexicaul or shortly petiolate, cordate or rounded at the base; nerves obscure. author: L.
description: A middling-sized glabrous evergreen tree; trunk straight, erect; bark smooth, ash-coloured; young branches twiggy, slender. Leaves 7.5-12.5 by 2.5-3.75 cm, oblong-lanceolate, acute or acuminate, red when young, afterwards shining above, glaucous benath, rounded or acute at the base and with close, inconspicuous nerves; petioles .6-.8 cm long. Flowers very fragrant, 2.5-7.5 cm diam., axillary or terminal, solitary or in pairs, subsessile; buds subglobose; bracts 0. Sepals 4, orbicular, cupped, puberulous outside, persistent, the inner pair much longer than the outer. Petals 4, pure white, spreading, obovate-cuneate, with crisped and undulate margins often torn. Stamens very numerous, golden-yellow, much shorter than the petals, slightly united at the base into a fleshy ring; anthers poblong. Style twice as long as the stamens; stigma peltate. Fruit 2.5-3 cm long, ovoid with conical point, surrounded by the enlarged sepals; pericarp tough semi-woody, at length 2-valved. Seeds 1-4, angular, smooth, chestnut-brown.

chemical_composition: Chemical studies on mesuol; revised structure proposed; two new pigments -mesuaxanthone A and mesuaxanthone B -and euxanthone isolated from heartwood; first two compounds characterised as 1,5-dihydroxy-3-methoxyxanthone and 1,5,6-trihydroxyxanthone respectively; a new 4-alkylcoumarin - ferruol A -from trunk bark. Xanthones are isolated from the heartwood, coumarins derivatives from the seeds and canophyllal, canophyllol and canophyllic acid from the leaves. Seeds contain essential oil.

author: (D. Don) Benth.
description: An auromatic herb with a very stout rootstock and many tufted ascending wirey, short, dense, leafy, glabrous or slightly pubescent stems. Leaves very small, ovate, nearly sessile, gland-dotted, .2-.6 cm long. Flowers small, in axillary 2-4-flowered cymes. Calyx 10-13-nerved, 5-lobed or 2-lipped. Corolla 2-lipped, the tube straight, annulate within, the upper lip entire or emarginate, the lower spreading, 3-lobed. Stamens 4 didynamous, the lower pair the longer, ascending, incurved; anther-cells distinct, parallel, at length divergent, the connective usually thickened. Disk cup-shaped. Ovary 4-partite; style slender, 2-lobed at apex, the stigmatic lobes equal or the upper short and lower recurved, flattened. Fruit of 4 smooth, dry-ovoid or oblong nutlets, the basal scar small
chemical_composition: The essential oil of I11Micromeria bifloraI11 Benth. was found to contain mostly monoterpene hydrocarbons and oxygenated monoterpenes. The major constituents of the oil were neral (25.3-32.2%) and geranial (26.7-41.3%). Chemical constituents of I11Micromeria bifloraI11 Benth. were identified as b-amyrin (1), oleanolic acid (2), 5-demethylnobiletin (3), thymonin (4), b-sitosterol (5) and daucosterol (6). All the compounds were isolated from the plant for the first time. The major constituents of essential oil of I11Micromeria bifloraI11 ssp. were arabica K. Walth were trans-caryophyllene (43.7%), caryophylleneoxide (18.0%), spathulenol (8.5%), a-humulene (4.6%), ? -myrcene (3.1%) and germacrene-D (3.1%).

author: L.
description: A diffuse herb, .5-1 m high; stems and branches sparingly prickly and clothed with long weak bristles from bulbous bases. Leaves sensitive, digitate; petioles 2.5-5 cm long, bristly; stipules .8 cm long, linear-lanceolate, acute, bristly; pinnae 1-2 pairs, 5-7.5 cm long, sessile or nearly so, their rhachises clothed with ascending bristles. Leaflets 12-20 pairs, .6-.8 by .4 cm, sessile, coriaceous, linear-oblong, acute, glabrous above, clothed with appressed bristles beneath, base obliquely rounded. Flowers polygamous, 4-merous, pink, in globose heads, .6-.8 cm in diam.; peduncles 2-2.5 cm long, prickly, usually in axillary pairs all along the branches; bracteole solitary, linear, acute, ciliolate. Calyx very minute. Corolla pink, .2-.25 cm long, divided about â  the way down; lobes 4, ovate-oblong, obtuse, Stamens 4, much exserted; anthers not gland-crested. Pods 1.25-2 by .3-.4 cm, flat, slightly recurved, consisting of 3-5 one-seeded joints which fall away from the persistent sutures which are clothed with spreading yellowish weak bristles .3 cm long, the faces of the pods glabrous.
pharmacology: In experimental animals a crude extract from the plant showed a mild to moderate diuretic response. The total plant extract was depressant on isolated rabbit duodenum. The percent decrease in either amplitude or frequency of duodenal contractions was found to be only marginally different from that found after a similar dose of atropine sulphone. In a study of the effect of Lajjalu on regeneration of nerve in experimental animals it was seen that the plant enhances regeneration by 30-40%. C11Clinical UsageC11 The medicinal use of the plant I11Mimosa pudicaI11 dates back to Charaka and Sushruta. The plant is commonly used for bleeding disorders like menorrhagia, dysentery with blood and mucus, and piles. The root powder or decoction is used. The juice of freshly crushed leaves is used internally and externally in piles. A Preliminary clinical trial, in 9 women with menorrhagia, exhibited promising results with relief in severity of bleeding. It is also applied externally to fissures, skin wounds and ulcers. Its action on small blood vessels is implicated in its hemostatic property. View Reference
chemical_composition: Plant contains Ã -amyrin, Ã -sitosterol and Friedelin. Mucilage of seeds contains galactose and mannose. An adrenaline- like substance identified in extracts of leave. Mucilage of seeds contained galactose and mannose in the ratio 1:1. A new chemonastic compound â M-LMF 5- isolated and characterized as 4-O-(3,5- dihydroxybenzoic acid)-Ã -D-glucuronide; its structure also confirmed .

author: L.
description: A large glabrous evergreen tree with milky juice. Trees 13-16 m high, with a compact leafy head and short erect trunk; bark smooth, scaly. Leaves 6.25-10 by 3-5 cm, elliptic, shortly acuminate, glabrous, base acute or rounded; often with slender parallel nerves; petioles 1.25-2.5 cm long. Calyx 1 cm long, fulvous-pubescent; segments 8 in two series, the 4 outer ovate-lanceolate, acute, the 4 inner narrower than the outer. Corolla longer than the calyx; tube .15 cm long; lobes .8 cm long, about 24, in 2 series, the inner series of 8 the outer of 16 lobes, linear-oblong, acute. Stamens 8, opposite the inner circle of lobes; filaments short, glabrous; anthers glabrous slightly twisted, acuminate, densely clothed on the back and margins with white hairs. author: Roxb.
description: Dioecious, perennial climber with tuberous roots; stem slender, branched, furrowed, glabrous and shining. Tendrisl simple, elongate, striate, glabrous. Leaves membranous, broadly ovate in outline, variable, 3.75-10 by 3-8, cordate at the base, glabrous, minutely punctuate, entire or more ore less deeply 3-5 lobed, the lobes triangular, ovate or oblong, distantly denticulate; petioles 1.25-4.5 cm long, channeled above, pubescent, eglandular. MALE FLOWERS: Peduncle solitary, 1-flowered, 3.75-12.5 cm long, slender angled, usually pubescent near the top, otherwise glabrous; bract cucullate, inserted a little below the flower and enclosing it, orbicular-reniform, 1.25-2 cm broad, usually pubescent on both sides, strongly nerved, often ciliolate. Calyx-lobes 5, distant, .5-.3 cm long, linear-lanceolate. Petals 1.25-2.5 cm long, yellow, oblong-lanceolate. Stamens 3, filaments short, free; one 1-celled, the others 2-celled. FEMALE FLOWERS: Solitary, peduncles nearly as long as those of the male, usually with a small bract near the base. Calyx and corolla as in the male. Ovary clothed with long soft papillae. Fruit 2.5-6.25 cm long, ellipsoid, shortly beaked, densely echinate with soft spines. Seeds many, 1 cm long, broadly ellipsoid, slightly compressed, slightly and irregularly corrugated, enclosed in a red pulp.

The fruit is rich in ascorbic acid (275.1 mg. / 100 g.). It contains iodine, 0.7 Âµ g. / 100 g. ( Wijs), 114.0 ; unsapon. Matter, 0.9%; and free fatty acids (as oleic), 1.4%. The component fatty acids of the oil are: saturated acids, 27.1 ; oleic, 9.2 ; linoleic, 8.8 ; and conjugated triene (as a-elaeostearic), 54.9%.

author: L.
description: A small glabrous tree; trunk straight; bark smooth, yellowish-white; branchlets obtusely 4-angled. Leaves opposite, 12.5-20 by 7.5-10 cm, broadly elliptic, acute, acuminate or obruse, bright-green, glabrous, shining, one of the pair next the peduncle often supressed, base acute; main nerves 8-10 pairs, prominent; petioles 1.25 cm long; stipules connate, short, broad, obtuse, membranous. Flowers white, in dense ovoid heads over 2.5 cm long; peduncles solitary (rarely 2-3 together), usually leaf-opposed, 2.5-5 cm long. Calyx-limb truncate. Corolla infundibuliform; tube 1 cm long, the mouth hariy; lobes 5, lanceolate, acute. Stamens 5; filaments hairy; anthers about 1.25 cm exserted. Fruit a syncarpium formed by the succulent enlarged calyx enclonsing many cartilaginous or bony 1-seeded pyrenes; white when ripe, smooth and glossy, about the size of a small egg; pyrenes oboid, compressed, concavo-convex, winged on the edge.

author: Lamk.
description: A small or middle-sized tree; bark corky; wood soft; root pungent; young parts tomentose. Leaves usually 3-pinnate, sometimes 50 cm long; rhachis slender, thickened and articulated at the base; pinnae and pinnules opposite, deciduous, their rhachis very slender, articulated and with a gland at the articulations; ultimate leaflets 1.25-2 by .6-1 cm, the lateral elliptic, the terminal obovate and slightly larger than the lateral ones; nerves obscure; petiolules of the lateral leaflets .15-.25 cm, those of the terminal .3-.6 cm long. Floweers white, bisexual. Petals spathulate, veined. Stamens 5 fertile, alternating with 5-7 antherless ones; filaments villous at the base. Ovary oblong, villous; style cylindric. Pods reaching 44 cm long, 9-ribbed. Seeds 3-angles, the angles winged.
pharmacology: Hypotensive, antibacterial, antifungal, antiviral, depressant, hepatoprotective, antiinflammatory, anticancer and antibiotic (pterygospermin), stimulant, antitubercular, antifertility. Seed extract was shown to be effective in the treatment of pyodermia in mice. 4-(S224-L-Rhamnosyloxy) benzyl isothiocyanate showed antimicrobial activity. C11ToxicologyC11 LDB1150B11 of alcoholic extract of whole plant, excluding roots was 8 mg /kg i.p. in albino mice. View Reference
chemical_composition: The plant contains 4-hydroxymellein, vanillin, moringine, moringinine, bayrenol, indole acetic acids, indole acetonitrile, benzylisothiocyanate, pterygospermin, cartotene, known flavonoids, polysaccharide, protein and components, various essential amino acids, minerals and vitamins, fatty acids and spirochin. Pterygospermin was found to be an antibiotic principle. Moringyne, 4-(S224 -L-rhamnosyloxy) benzyl isothiocyanate and several amino acids. 4-(S224 -rhamnosyloxy) benzyl isothiocynate.

author: (L.) DC.
description: An annual twiner; branches slender, more or less hairy at first, at length glabrescent. Leaves 3-foliolate; petioles 6.25-11.25 cm long, appresedly silky; stipules lanceolate, 1.25 long. Leaflets membranous, 7.5-12.5 by 5-7.5 cm, stipellate (the terminal leaflets slightly the smaller, rhomboid obovate with cuneate base, the lateral leaflets with truncate base, very inequilateral, the lower side greately dilated), all subacute, mucronate, pubescent above, densely clothed with silvery-grey hairs beneath. Flowers in elongate 6-30 flowered racemes 15-30 cm long, the flowers solitary or 2-3 together along a slender silky rhachis; pedicels .3-.6 cm. long, hairy; bracts 1.25 cm long, lanceolate, hairy, caducous; bracteoles .8 cm long, hairy, caducous. Calyx 1 cm long, silky and with a few irritant bristles outside; tube campanulate; upper lateral teeth completely connate into a triangular lip equaling the tube, lateral teeth lanceolate as long as the tube, the lower tooth lanceolate and slightly longer. Corolla 2.5-3.75 cm long, purple; keel slightly incurved. Stamens 10, diadelphous; anthers dimorphus. Ovary sessile; ovules many; style filiform; stigma capitate. Pods 5-7.5 by 1.25 cm, turgid, with a longitudinal rib running the length of each valve, not winged on the margins nor transversely plaited on the faces, falcately curved on both ends, somewhat like the letter S, densely clothed with persistent irritant bristles which are at first pale-brown, afterwards steel-gray. Seeds 5-6, small; hilum not half the length of the circumference of the seed.
pharmacology: Anthelmintic, hypotensive, spasmodic, a potent antiparkinsonian, hypocholestrolemic, antifungal, antiinflammatory, aphrodiasiac, nervine tonic. L- Dopa free fraction of seed exhibited potent antiparkinsonian effect in mice in 200 mg / kg i.p. Seed extract have antiparkinsonian effect, Even L-dopa free fraction of seed showed significant antiparkinsonism activity. Seeds also showed hypoglycaemic and hypocholesterolemic activity in rats. Seed produced a striking and sustained increase of sexual activity in sexually normal male rats. Total alkaloids increase spermatozoa population, weight of testis, seminal vesicles and prostrate of rats. Total alkaloids of seed showed weak neuro-muscular blocking effect on frog rectus abdominus. In a clinical study in 15 psychiatric patients demonstrated that speed powder inhibited the prolactin response to chlorpromazine. C11ToxicologyC11 The acetone extract of the roots was toxic to the insects, being 1.93 times as toxic as the extract of I11Jatropha curcasI11 Linn. seeds. The hairs on fresh/dry pods can cause intensive itching on contract. It may also cause blister/dermatitis due to mucanin. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 I11Mucuna PruriensI11 is ingredient of several commercial preparations being used in management of male sexual disorders, as an aphrodisiac. Some uncontrolled clinical studies have found these preparations to be effective in improving libido and performance in man. A study was made to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of HP-200, derived from I11Mucuna pruriensI11, in patients with Parkinsonâs disease. Sixty patients with Parkinsonâs disease (46 male and 14 female) with a mean age of 59+ /-9 years were treated in an open study for 12 weeks. Of these, 26 patients were taking synthetic levodopa / carbidopa formulations before treatment with HP-200, and the remaining 34 were levodopa naive. HP-200, a powder (supplied as 7.5 g sachet), was mixed with water and given orally. The Unified Parkinsonâs Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) was used at baseline and periodically during the 12-week evaluation. Statistically significant reductions in Hoehn and Yahr stage and UPDRS scores were seen from baseline to the end of the 12- week treatment (p<0.0001, t-test). The group mean (+/- SD) dose for optimal control of symptoms was 6+/-3 sachets. Adverse effects were seen in clinical laboratory reports. HP-200, developed from an alternative medicine source, Ayurveda, was found to be an effective treatment for patients with Parkinsonâs disease. View Reference
chemical_composition: From seeds, 3, 4-dihydroxy-phenylalanine (L-DOPA) was reported. Other major constituents isolated are four new alkaloids viz. mucuadine, mucuadinine, mucuadinine and prurienidine along with mucunin, mucunadine, small amount of nicotine, various amino acids, carbohydrates, acids, indole alkylamines and serotonin. Seed oil contains stearic, palmitic, myristic, arachidic, oleic, linoleic acids and sterol. Seeds are good source of L-3, 4-dihyroxyphenylalanine (L-dopa) (1.5 per cent).A number of amino acids 3-4; four alkaloids viz., mucunine, mucunadine, prurienine and prurieninine; lecithin (12.5 per cent) from seed.

Calyx densely hairy; tube narrowly campanulate, .5-.4 cm long, the segments 5, hairy outside, often terminated by a hairy apiculation. Corolla subcampanulate, 5-lobed. Stamens 3, free; filaments short, anthers free, one 1-celled the others 2-celled. Rudimentary ovary glanduliform. FEMALE FLOWERS: Solitary. Calyx and corolla as in the male flowers. Fruit ellipsoid or turbinate, about 3.75 cm long, smooth or with a few bristles. Seeds numerous, narrowly ovoid, compressed, smooth.

author: (Clarke) Bruckn.
description: Herbs; roots often tuberous. Roots fibrous; stem stout, creeping and rooting, then erect, 15-90 cm high. Leaves alternate, elliptic-lanceolate, acuminate, base narrowed into a short petiole, glabrous or scaberulous, 6.25-17.5 cm long, 2-4.5 cm wide; sheaths 1.25-4 cm long, glabrous or puberulous, mouth usually ciliate. Flowers in axillary and terminal panicles; panicles lax, peduncled, much exceeding the uppermost leaves; fruiting pedicels erect. Sepals 3, free, membranous. Petals 3, free, subequal. Fertile stamens 3, staminodes 2-4, rarely 0. Ovary sessile, 2- or 3-celled; ovules 1-2-many in each cell; style slender. Capsule globose, .4 cm diam.; seeds 2-seriate in each cell; hemispheric, rugose.

author: (L.) Spreng.
description: A small tree with dark grey bark. Leaves imparipinnate, up to 30 cm long, petioles terete, pubescent; leaflets 11-25, alternate, 2-5 by .3-2.5 cm, obliquely ovate oe somewhat rhomboid, acuminate, obtuse or acute, tip usually notched, irregularly crenate-denate, glabrous or nearly so above, pubescent beneath, sprinkled with black dots; petiolules very short. Flowers white, in much-branched terminal peduncled corymbose cymes; peduncles and pedicels pubescent. Calyx pubescent; lobes 5, sub-acute, triangular. Petals 5, linear-oblong, .6 cm long, rounded at the apex, gland-dotted. Stamens 10, free, the alternate shorter; filaments dilated at the base. Disk stipitiform. Ovary seated on the disk, 2-celled; ovules solitary (rarely 2) in each cell; stigma capitate. Fruit a berry, ovoid or subglobose, .6-1 cm in diam., apiculate, rough with glands, black, 2-seeded.
pharmacology: The three carbazole alkaloids mahanimbine, murrayanol and mahanine isolated from the acetone extract of the fresh leaves showed antimicrobial, mosquitocidal and topoisomerase inhibition activities. Hypoglycaemic action of the leaves was demonstrated in rats and there was increased concentration of hepatic glycogen and glycogenesis. Antioxidant property of I11M. KoenigiiI11 leaf extracts prepared in methylene chloride and acetone was reported. The evaluation was based upon oil stability index together with radical scavenging ability against 1-1-diphenyl-2-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH). Leaf extracts prepared in ethanol, petroleum ether, chloroform exhibited antibacterial activity. The petroleum ether extract showed cytotoxic activity. Morphological and histological studies revealed decreased number of neoplasms in colon and intestine in rats fed with I11M. KoenigiiI11 leaf. View Reference

author: (Rich). Bosser
description: A large tree with erect trunk and widely spreading horizontal branches; young parts pubescent. Leaves opposite decussate, petiolate, coriaceous, 12.7-20 by 7 cm, elliptic-oblong, shortly acuminate, entire, glabrous and shining above, more or less pubescent beneath, base usually rounded, sometimes ocordate; main nerves 8-12 pairs, parallel, prominent on both sides; petioles 2-3 cm long; stipules inter-petiolar, lanceolate, acute, caduceus. Flowers fragrant, in solitary terminal globular heads 2.5-3.5 cm in diam., on stout peduncles. Calyx .5-.6 cm long; lobes 5, linar, obtuse, hairy at the top outside; calyx-tubes closely pressed together but not fused. Corolla orange, 1-1.25 cm long; tube infundibuliform, slender; segments about .25 cm long, erect, linear-oblong, acute, imbricate, slightly pubescent outside; segments 5. Stamens inserted on the throat of the corolla; filaments short. Disk inconspicuous. Ovary 2-celled below, 4 celled above; ovules very many horizontal, on 2 bifid placentas which ascend from the septum below its middle and send an arm into each of the upper cells; styles and stigmas white. Fruits packed into a fleshy globose mass of manu few-seeded coriaceous pyrenes; yellow when ripe. Seeds muriculate.
pharmacology: Chlorogenic acid (CGA) isolated from the leaves was screened for hepatoprotective activity by in vitro and in vivo assay methods using carbon tetrachloride (CClB114B11) as a model of liver injury. Intraperitoneal administration of CGA to mice at a dose of 100 mg/kg body weight for 8d cause significant reversal in lipid peroxidation, enzymatic leakage, cytochrome P450 inactivation and produced enhancement of cellular antioxidant defence in (CClB114B11) â administered mice. The 50 per cent ethanolic extract of the stem bark in a preliminary biological screening showed hypologycaemic activity in rat, anthelmintic activity against I11Ascaridia galliI11 worms and gross behavioural effect in mice. The alcoholic extract of the defatted bark at a concentration of 100 mg/ml exhibited in vitro anthelmintic action against I11Ascaridia galliI11 worms of the birds. The extract produced 100 per cent death I11Ascaridia galliI11 worms in 64h after incubation while complete cessation of motility of worms was seen in 48h. The aqueous leaf extract of the plant was found to have nematostatic response against Meloidogyne incognita. View Reference

author: (Graham.) Mabberley
description: A small tree; young branches pale and with wrinkled bark. Leaves alternate, crowded towards the ends of the branches, 7.5-15 by 3.75-7.5 cm, ovate-oblong, acuminate, dark green and glabrous above, paler and pubescent on the nerves beneath, reticulately veined, base rounded or acute or more less inequilateral; petioles 1.25-3 cm long, glabrous or faintly pubescent. Flowers in terminal panicles 5-10 cm long; pedicels stout, densely pubescent; polygamous. Calyx small, pubescent externally, lobes 5, linear-oblong, acute, densely sericeo-villous on both surfaces, tip inflexed.Petals 5, hypogynous, valvate, villous within. Stamens 5, hypogynous, a little shorter than the petal and alternate with them; filaments flattend and dilated below, attached to the edges of the petals at the base; anthers elliptic-oblong, not apiculate. Disk shallow, cup-shaped, villous within. Ovary ovoid, 1-celled, densely clothed with silky hairs, free, attenuated into a stout slightly conical style. Ovules 2, pendulous; style short, stigma thickened. Drupes ellipsoid or somewhat obovoid, 1-1.5 cm long, pubescent when young, glabrous and purple when ripe.

author: L.
description: A large shrub or small tree, rough all over with stiff whitish hairs; young branches shrply quadrangular, hairy. Leaves opposite 5-10 by 2.5-6.25 cm, ovate, acute or acuminate, rough and scabrous above with short bulbous hairs, densely pubescent beneath with appressed hairs, entire or with a few large distant teeth, base rounded or slighlty cuneate; main nerves few, conspicuous beneath; petioles .6 cm long, hairy. Flowers delightfully fragrant, sessile in pedunculate bracteate fascicles of 3-5; peduncles 4-angled, slender, hairy, axillary and solitary and in terminal short trichotomous cymes; bracts broadly ovate or suborbicular, .6-1 cm long, apiculate, hairy on both sides. Calyx .6-.75 cm long, narrowly campanulate, hairy outside, glabrous inside, truncate or obscurely toothed or lobed ciliate. Corolla tube orange about equalling the limb; lobes white, unequally obcordate, cuneate. Anthers 2, subsessile near the top of the corolla-tube. Capsule 1 cm long and broad, obcordate or nearly orbicular, compressed, 2-celled, separating into 2 flat 1 seeded carpels, reticulately veined, glabrous.
phenology: Flowers: More or less throughout the year.

locations.vegetation: Tropical semi evergreen to evergreen forest

pharmacology: Antispasmodic, hypotensive, antiamoebic, antinociceptive, CNS depressant , insecticidal, respiratory stimulant, neuromuscular blocking, analgesic, antiinflammatory, antineoplastic, antiallergic, hepatoprotective, antileishmanial, antiviral, antifungal, immunostimulant, hypnotic, tranquillizing, mild antimalarial, antimicrobial, antipyretic, immunomodulatory, antibacterial. C11ToxicologyC11 The LDB1150B11 of the 50% ethanolic extract of whole plant was reported to be > 1000 mg/kg i.p. in albino mice. The LDB1150B11 of the ethanolic extract (90%) of the aerial part was found to be 1000 mg/kg i.p. in rats. Therapeutic Evaluation Therapeutic trial of Unani preparation containing I11Commiphora mukul, Berberis aristata, Nyctanthes arbortristis, Azadirachta indica, Terminalia chebula, Allium ascolonicumI11 and I11Mentha arvensisI11 on patients suffering from haemorrhoids showed complete relief in 82.5 percent cases and partial relief in 37.7 per cent. Oral administration of decoction of fresh leaves of I11N. arbor-tristisI11 (30 ml three times a day) to 24 cases of sciatica, showed complete relief in symptoms in 91.6% cases within 6 days of treatment. No toxic or side effects were observed. Action of Sushama containing equal amount of extracts of I11Ocimum sanctumI11 and I11Nyctanthus arbor tristisI11 kept for one week in alcohol) was studied on 30 cases of eczema. The drug was used in form of ointment topically and also administered internally. Encouraging results were obtained in 90 per cent cases. View Reference

pharmacology: The fixed oils of I11O. basilicumI11 showed significant inhibition of carrageenan, prostaglandin EB112B11, leukotriene and arachidonic paw edema and had significant antiinflammatory activity in albino rats. Antiulcerogenic activity of powder and its aqueous and methanolic extracts against aspirin â induced ulcers in rats has been documented. Feeble antimalarial activity was observed in chicks and ducklings when they were treated with water extract; however, chloroform extract did not show any antimalarial activity. The essential oil has mosquito larvicidal activity. The essential oil acted as insecticidal fumigant and had synergistic preservative effect against acid tolerant food microflora. The volatile oil had antioxidant property. The essential oil was shown to possess antiworm activity. The aqueous extract showed in vitro anti-HIV activity. Dietary sweet basil showed antimicrobial increase in hepatic monooxygenases. Linalool and methyl chavicol from basil showed antimicrobial activity. The juice of leaves when applied topically was shown to be effective in acne vulgaris. View Reference

Flavonoids: salvigenin and nevadensin, sirseleol, sirselineol, eupatorin, apigenin, acacetin, genkwanin, apigenin 7, 4â-dimethyl ether, cirsimartin, ladanein, gardenin B.

author: L.
description: Shrubby, perennial, 1.25-2 m high, much branched, woody below; stem and branches subquadrangular, the young ones pubescent. Leaves 6.25-12.5 by 3.75-5.5 cm, elliptic-lanceolate, acute coarsely crenate serrate, pubescent on sides, gland-dotted, base cuneate; petioles 2.5-6.25 cm long, slender, more or less pubescent. Flowers in simple or branched rather short racemes, in tolerably close whorls; rhachis quadrangular, softly pubescent; bracts sessile, longer than the calyx, acuminate from a broad ovate base, decussate and squarrose in the young inflorescence, ciliate; pedicels shorter than the calyx, softly pubescent. Calyx .3 cm long in flower, becoming twice as long in fruit, pubescent and glandular; upper lip rounded, beined, scarcely mucronate, curved upwards in fruit, longer than the lower; lower lip strongly nerved, the 2 central teeth short, subulate, the laterla teeth shorter and broader, lanceolate. Corolla .4 cm long, pale greenish-yellow, pubescent outside; upper lip .4 cm broad with 4 rounded teeth; lower lip longer than the upper. Stamens exserted; upper filaments with a bearded tooth at the base. Nutlets .15 cm in diam. Subglobose, rugose, brown.
pharmacology: Essential oil of I11O. gratissimumI11 and eugenol isolated from where it were found to be anthelminthic in vitro. The essential oil acted as insecticidal fumigant. Formulations containing 2 per cent essential oil were shown to be antibacterial. Methanolic extract when injected ip was shown to be antidiabetic in rats. The essential oil was found to be antifungal. Fractions isolated from the leaves by lipid extraction contracted guinea pig ileum, rat colon and was found to increase rat mean arterial blood pressure. The ethanolic extract improved the phagocytic activity without affecting humoral and cell mediated immune system. The essential oil exerted concentration-dependent reversible relaxant effect in guinea pig ileal smooth muscle. The aqueous extract of leaves showed analgesic and spasmolytic properties in rodents. The aqueous extract of leaves found to show antidiarrhoeal effect in rat. The decoction of the leaves was shigellocidal. The essential oil possessed antimicrobial activity. View Reference

author: L.
description: Annual, 30-60 cm high, much branched; stems and branches usually purplish, subqudrangular, sometimes woody below, clothed with soft spreading hairs. Leaves 2.5-5 by 1.5-3 cm, elliptic-oblong, obtuse or acute, entire or serrate, pubescent on both sides, minutely gland-dotted, base obtuse or acute; petioles 1.25-2.5 cm long, slender, hairy. Flowers in racemes 15-20 cm long in close whorls; bracts nearly .3 cm long and almost as broad as long, broadly ovate with a long slender acumen, ciliate; pedicels longer than the flowering calyx, slender, pubescent. Calyx .3-.4 cm long, in flower, pubescent, reaching .5 cm long in fruit; upper lip broadly obovate or suborbicular, much reflexed, very shortly apiculate; lower lip longer than the upper, the teeth lanceolate at the base, the 2 lateral with short straight, the 2 central with long slender awns which project beyond the upper lip and are much curved upwards. Corolla .4 cm long, purplish; upper lip pubescent on the back. Stamens exserted; filaments slender, the upper pair with a small bearded appendage at the base. Nutlets broadly ellipsoid, nearly smooth, yellow with small black markings.

locations.vegetation: Tropical semi evergreen to evergreen forest

pharmacology: Antimicrobial activity of the essential oil has been shown against M. tuberculosis and staph aureus I11in vitroI11 and other bacteria and fung. Eugenol and methyleugenol showed a positive activity. Adaptogenic (antistress) activity has been found in mice and rats. The plant increased the physical endurance and prevented stress-induced ulcers. In general pharamcology the azueous extract showed hypotensive activity and inhibited the smooth muscle contraction induced by acetylcholine, carbachol and histamine. It also potentiated the hexobarbitone sleeping time. Protective action against histamine-induced bronchospasm has been shown in animals. C11Clinical UsageC11 A tea prepared with the leaves of Tulsi is commonly used in cough, cold, mild indigestion, diminished appetite and malaise. The solid extract of Tulsi, in a dose of 500 mg x 3 for one week, significantly relieved the breathlessness in 20 patients with tropical eosinophilia. There was however no reduction in the eosinophilcount in peripheral blood. It is commonly used with black pepper in bronchial asthma. An oil exlacted from Tulsi is used as drops in ear infections. Fungal and bacterial infections of skin are treated with Tulsi juice. The seeds are used as a general tonic. View Reference
chemical_composition: The main components are tannins (4.6%) and essential oil (up to 2%). The amounts of the primary constituents of the essential oil vary according to the geographical distribution and variety of the source plant material; eugenol (up to 62%), methyleugenol (up to 86%), and S224 - and Ã-caryophyllene (up to 42%). Also present are methylchavicol, linalool and 1, 8-cineole (4, 16-19).The plant contains acid, carotene, alkaloids, glycosides, saponins and tannins. Leaves yield essential oil, which contains eugenol, eugenol methyl ether, carvacrol, methyl chavicol, cineole and linalool, caryophyllene, ursolic acids, apigenin, lutelin, orientin, apigenin-7-I11OI11-glcuronide. Seed oil shows presence of sitosterol and palmitic, stearic, oleic, linolenic and lnolenic fatty acids. Essential oil contains nerol, terpinene-4-ol, decylaldehyde, S226-selinene, S224- and Ã-pinenes and camphor.

author: (L.) Kurz
description: A small deciduous tree 8-13 m high, branched at top; bark light-brown, soft, with green juice and often with numerous corky lenticels. Leaves opposite, very large, 1-1.5 m long, 2-3 pinnate with opposite pinnae; rhachis very stout, cylindric; leaflets 2-4 pairs, 6.25-12.5 by 3.75-10 cm, ovate or elliptic, acuminate, glabrous, base rounded or sometimes cordate; petiolules of the lateral leaflets .6-1.5 cm long. Flowers numerous, foetid, in large erect racemes 30-60 cm long or even more; pedicels .6-3 cm long. Calyx 2.5 by 2 cm, leathery, oblong-campanulate, glabrous. Corolla reaching 10 cm long, fleshy; lobes about 3 cm long with crisped margins. Stamens 5, slightly exserted beyond the corolla-tube, one of them a little shorter than the other 4; filaments cottony at the base. Ovary 2-celled the cells parallel, oblong. Disk large, cushion-like. Ovary 2 celled, subsessile, contracted below; ovules numerous, many-seriate; style long; stigma of 2 large blades. Capsules very large, 30-90 by 5-9 cm, straight, tapering to both ends, flat, hardly .8 cm thick, acute; valves semi-woody. Seeds very numerous, 6.25 cm long, winged all round except at the base.

author: Benth.
description: Shrubs; stems 2.5-5 cm long, woody at the base, slender, branched, sharply quadrangular, glabrous or nearly so. Leaves 3.75-7.5 by 2-4.5 cm, ovate, acute, coarsely serrate, glabrous, base usually acute; petioles slender, 1.25-3.75 cm long. Flowers in racemes 7.5-20 cm long, in rather distant whorls; bracts ovate, acute, .2 cm long. Calyx in flower .6 cm long, glabrous or slightly pubescent, often tinged with purple; upper lip obovate-oblong often mucronate; the two middle teeth of the lower lip lanceolate, with a long slightly curved awn, exceeding the upper lip. Corolla variable in length, sometimes reaching 1.25 cm long, slightly pubescent outside, pale-purple, inodorous; tube much longer than the calyx; upper lip with three obtuse lobes, the middle lobe the widest, shorter than the obovate-oblong obtuse concave lower lip. Stamens 4, included, declinate, didynamous; filaments free, not appendaged at the base; anther-cells confluent. Ovary 4-partite; stigma small, subclavate, sometimes slightly notched. Fruit of 4 dry ovoid or globose nutlets, nutlets .15 cm long, ellipsoid or sub-globose, minutely tuberculate, brown.

author: DC.
description: Annual herbs, 10-40 cm high; stem simple or more or less branched, 4-gonous, and as well as the branches clothed with long stiff spreading hairs. Leaves 1.25-2.75 by .6-1.5 cm, drying yellow, elliptic, subacute, densely clothed on both sides with rather long hairs, 3-nerved, entire or sometimes very slightly serrulate, base subacute; petioles .2-.3 cm long, bristly. Flower capitate, often with 2 or 4 leaves close under the head; pedicels .25-.3 cm long; bracts ovate, .2 cm long, bristle-ciliate, glabrous on their backs. Calyx .6 cm long, clothed externally with long stellate, intermixed with simple bristly hairs; tube campanulate; teeth 4-5, erect, .2 cm long, broadly triangular, bristle-ciliate and with a tuft of long spreading bristles springing from an enlarged glandular apex; intermediate teeth scarcely 1 mm long, stout, terete with a tuft of bristles from an enlarged glandular apex. Petals 5, obovate, .3-.5 cm long, purple. Stamens twice as many as petals. Ovary ovoid, Â½ inferior with 16-20 bristles at the apex, 4-5 celled; ovules numerous in each cell. Fruit a capsule, ovoid-oblong, included in the calyx-tube and partially adnate to it; 8-ribbed.

author: Willd.
description: Herbaceous, biennial or perennial, 20-50 cm high, branched; root thick, nodose. Stems many, 4-gonous, rather slender, densely clothed with simple appressed long bristly hairs. Leaves drying yellow, 2.5-5.5 by 1.25 cm, elliptic or elliptic-oblong, usually entire, 3- (or sometimes 5-) nerved, hairy on both surfaces, base acute or subobtuse; petioles .45-.6 cm long. Flowers 4-5 merous, subcapitate, often with 2 or 4 leaves under the head; bracts .25 cm long, ovate, acute ciliate on the margins and with a long bristle-point at the apex, glabrous on the back. Calyx .6.8 cm long, densely clothed with stalked stellate long hairs; tube campanulate; teeth .4-.5 cm long, triangular, ciliate and with a tuft of long bristles from the enlarged glandular apex; intermediate teeth .16 cm long, with a tuft of bristles from the enlarged glandular apex. Petals .6-1.25 cm long, purple or sometimes white. Stamens twice as many as petals. Ovary Â½ inferior, 4-5 celled; ovules numerous in each cell. Fruit a capsule, ovoid-oblong, sometimes obscurely many ribbed, included in the calyx tube and partially adnate to it below.

author: Wallich ex Wight
description: A large branched glabrous shrub; young branches sharply triangular. Leaves alternate, subsessile, coriaceous, numerous, glaucous, 2.5-3.75 by 1.25-2.5 cm elliptic-oblong, or oblong-lanceolate, or obovate-oblibg, mucronate, base cuneate. Flowers minute, axillary, yellowish-green, polygamous (male and bisexual), the male flower in long-pedunculate shortly pedicellate 5-10 flowered umbels, the peduncles of the bi-sexual flowers carrying 1-3 flowers and elongating in fruit. Perianth-tube solid in male flowers, in bisexual flowers adnate to the ovary; limb 3-lobed; lobes triangular, valvate, with a tuft of hairs on the face. Stamens opposite the perianth-lobes. Disk-fleshy, 3-lobed. Drupe yellow, .6-.8 cm in diam., subglobose.

author: L.
description: A small procumbent herb; stems rooting, pubescent with appressed hairs. Leaves palmately 3-foliolate; petioles 3.75-9 cm long, very slender, pubescent; stipules small, oblong, adnate to the petiole; leaflets 1.25-2.5 cm long, obcordate, cuneate at the base, subsessile, glabrous or with a few appressed hairs and with ciliate margins. Flowers axillary, subumbellate; peduncles solitary upto 9 cm long, deflexed in fruit, pubescent; bracts beneath the pedicels lanceolate, hairy. Sepals 5, imbricate, .3-.45 cm long, oblong, obtuse, appressedly hairy outside. Petals 5, hypogynous, yellow, oblong, rounded at the apex, emarginated, twice as long as the sepals. Stamens 10. Ovary 5-lobed, 5-celled; styles 5, distinct; stigma papilose. Capsules 2 cm long, linear-oblong, 5-angled, shortly beaked, tomentose, dehiscing loculicidally. Seeds numerous, broadly ovoid, acute, transversely striate, brown.

locations.vegetation: Tropical semi evergreen to evergreen forest

pharmacology: Antiinflammatory, analgesic, antipyretic, relaxant, hypoglycaemic, antibacterial, hypotensive, spasmogenic. author: Roxb.
description: Palm like shrubs up to 6 m high, rarely erect; stem supported by aerial roots. Leaves long, spirally arranged at the ends of the branches, glaucous-green, 1-1.5 m long, ensiform, caudate-acuminate, coriaceous, sheathing at the base; the marginal spines forward, those on the midrib pointing forward or backward. Flowers dioecious. MALE FLOWERS: Spadix with numerous subsessile cylindric spikes enclosed in long, white, fragrant caudate-acuminate spathes. Staminal-column .6-1.25 cm long; anthers longer than the slender filaments, cuspidate, inserted along the whole length of the upper portion. FEMALE FLOWERS: Spadix solitary, 5 cm in diam. Carpels confluent in obpyramidal groups of 6-10 or fewer; stigmas short, reniform, yellow. Fruit an oblong or globose syncarpium, 15-25 cm long and broad, yellow or red; drupes numerous (50-60); each consisting of 5-12 carpels; carpels 5-7.5 cm long. turbinate, irregular, the crown smooth, convex, more or less depressed round the reniform stigmas.

locations.vegetation: Tropical semi evergreen to evergreen forest

author: Wight & Arn.
description: A slender branched shrub 1-4 m high. Leaves opposite, 7.5-17.5 by 2.5-6.25 cm, elliptic-lanceolate, acuminate, black when dry, glabrous, attenuated into the petiole; petioles 1.25-2.5 cm long; stipules intrapetilar, connate, triangular, acute, from a braod base, membranous, pilose within. Flowers white, in large terminal corymbose more or less pubescent peduncled cymes. Calyx pubescent, .3 cm long; teeth .5 cm long, triangular, acute, slightly reflexed at the tip. Corolla-tube 2.5-3 cm long, slender, glabrous; lobes .6-.8 by .2-.25 cm, linear-oblong, subacute. Stamens 4 (very rarely5), inserted in the throat or mouth of the corolla. Ovary2-celled; ovules solitary in each cell, attached to the middle of the septum exserted. Style very slender, exserted for 3.75 cm or even more, grandually tapering; stigma hardly distinguishable from the style, scarcely if at all fusiform. Fruit size of a pea, globose, smooth, purple.

Author : Wight & Arn.
Family : Rubiaceae
Basic Description of Plant : A slender branched shrub 1-4 m high. Leaves opposite, 7.5-17.5 by 2.5-6.25 cm, elliptic-lanceolate, acuminate, black when dry, glabrous, attenuated into the petiole; petioles 1.25-2.5 cm long; stipules intrapetilar, connate, triangular, acute, from a braod base, membranous, pilose within. Flowers white, in large terminal corymbose more or less pubescent peduncled cymes. Calyx pubescent, .3 cm long; teeth .5 cm long, triangular, acute, slightly reflexed at the tip. Corolla-tube 2.5-3 cm long, slender, glabrous; lobes .6-.8 by .2-.25 cm, linear-oblong, subacute. Stamens 4 (very rarely5), inserted in the throat or mouth of the corolla. Ovary2-celled; ovules solitary in each cell, attached to the middle of the septum exserted. Style very slender, exserted for 3.75 cm or even more, grandually tapering; stigma hardly distinguishable from the style, scarcely if at all fusiform. Fruit size of a pea, globose, smooth, purple.

author: L.
description: A stout bushy shrub .5-1.25 m high; bark thin smooth, yellowish; young branches terete, glabrous. Leaves 7.5-15 by 2.5-6.25 cm, membranous, variable in shape an size, elliptic-oblong or elliptic-lanceolate, sometimes obovate-oblong, obtuse, acute or acuminate, glabrous on both sides, base tapering; main nerves 8-10 pairs; petioles .6-1.25 cm long; stipules connate, triangulare, acute, thin, deciduous. Flowers white, odorous, in terminal sessile corymbose pubescent cymes; pedicels .4-.6 cm long, densely pubescent; bracts broad, membranous; buds oblong-clavate. Calyx densely pubescent, .3 cm long tube narrowly campanulate; teeth .12 cm long, triangular, acute, slightly reflexed at the tip. Corolla-tube 1.25 cm long; lobes .6-.75 by .25 cm, linear-oblong, subacute. Stamens 4. Ovary 2-celled; ovules solitary in each cell, attached to the middle of the septum exserted; style white glabrous or nearly so; stigma green, narrowly clavate, puberulous. Fruit .6-1.5 cm in diam., globose, black, smooth.
chemical_composition: The root bark appears to be the most active part. It contains d-mannitol ; presence of a bitter glucoside ( m.p. 120Âº ) related to salicin, as recorded by earlier workers, has not been confirmed. On boiling with water, the roots give off a pleasant odour. The stem is reported to contain an essential oil (0.55%), a resin (1 .9 %), an alkaloid (1.4 %) and pectic substance (7.8 %). The leaves give a positive test for alkaloids

author: L. Her.
description: An erect, leafy, herb with strong aromatic odour. Leaves mostly opposite, decompound, stipulate. Inflorescence mostly umbel-like on axillary peduncles. Flowers irregular. Calyx 5-partite (or sepals said to be connate at base); the uppermost segment produced at base into a slender, nectar-bearing tube or spur adnate to pedicel. Petals 5 (rarely less by abortion), the 2 upper ones usually larger and more prominently coloured, the lower mostly narrow and rarely very small. Stamens 10, 7 or less. Fruits of 5 valves, each 1-seeded and separating from beak; apex mostly coiling more or less hygrometrically. Commonly known as Geraniums, the plant is aromatic and cultivated for its volatile oil.
chemical_composition: Citronellyldiethylamine isolated from oil and its structure determined.

author: (L.) Roxb.
description: A tall graceful palm, 10-16 m high, with a large thick hemispherical crown; trunk clothed usually on the upper portion with the persistent bases of the petioles. Leaves pinnate, greyish-green, 2-4 m long, quite glabrous; leaflets entire, 15-45 by 2-2.5 cm, fasciculate, 2-4 farious, rigid; petioles short, compressed only towards the apex, bearing at the base a few channeled triangular spines reaching 10 cm long. Flowers dioecious, small, yellowish, on usually several branched axillary erect spadices. MALE FLOWERS white scented. Spadix .5-1 m long, erect; branches filiform; peduncle much compressed. Spathes 30-40 cm long, scurfy, separating into 2 boat-shaped valves. Flowers .6-.8 cm long, numerous, angular, oblique. Calyx-cup shaped, with 3 short rounded teeth. Petals 3 or 4 times as long as the calyx, concave, warted on the outside. Filaments very short, free; anthers linear, shorter than the petals. FEMALE FLOWERS: Spadix and spathe as in the male; fruiting peduncles short, about 15 cm long. Flowers distant, roundish. Calyx cup-shaped, obosoletely 3-toothed. Petals 3, very broad, convolutedly imbricate. Staminodes 3 or 4. Fruiting-spadix 1 m long, nodding, much compressed, of a golden orange color. Fruit 2.5-3 cm long, oblong-ellipsoid, orange-yellow, edible. Seeds 1.6 cm long, rounded at the ends, grooved on one face, pale brown.
chemical_composition: Wild date seed (I11Phoenix sylvestrisI11) contains 8.2% oil. The oil is orange-yellow in color and has a low free fatty acid content, I value of 50, sapon. value of 212, and unsaponifiable matter of 1.9%. Fatty acid profile of oil showed lauric [143-07-7] 23.3, myristic [544-63-8] 12.7, palmitic [57-10-3] 11.5, stearic [57-11-4] 3.9, behenic [112-85-6] 1.0, lignoceric [557-59-5] 1.2, oleic [112-80-1] 35.5, and linoleic [60-33-3] 10.9%. The fatty acid compn. of 4 tree-borne oilseeds, namely I11Ailanthus altissima, Xeromphis uliginosa, Phoenix sylvestris,I11 and I11Clerodendron viscosumI11 has been investigated. The major fatty acids are palmitic, oleic and linoleic, ranging 6.68-28.57, 21.62-67.41, and 1.53-51.24%, resp.

author: L.
description: Erect, annual herbs. Leaves distichous. Flowers small in leaf axils, 1-2 together. Perianth segments 5 or 6, green with broad scarious margins, enlarged in fruiting. Stamens 3; filaments entirely connate. Styles bifid at the apex. Fruits globose, trigonous, depressed at apex. Fruits globose, trigonous, depressed at apex. pharmacology: Antifungal, anticancer, antispasmodic, hypoglycaemic, antiviral, hepatoprotective. C11ToxicologyC11 Hypophyllanthin and phyllanthin are toxic to fish and frog. Aqueous extract of fresh leaves and roots is found to be nontoxic in 2g/kg., p.o. in acute toxicity studies. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 In a clinical trial involving 160 children (1-12 years of age) at the Indian Institute of Research in Yoga & Allied Sciences, Tirupati, I11P. fraternusI11 has been claimed to be effective in treatment of infective hepatitis. Out of the 160 children, 101 cases were cured and 59 cases dropped out. In majority of cases, disappearance of jaundice, hepatic tenderness and bile salts and pigments from urine was observed in 2nd week. Improvement of appetite was more quicker and pronounced than other clinical features in majority of cases. No side effects were observed. A clinical trial was conducted on 25 patients of jaundice. The patients were given 1 gm. Bhumyamalki in tablet form thrice daily for 8 days and 500 mg. t.d.s. for the next 8 days. Complete relief was observed in 22 patients (88%) and partial relief in 2 (8%). One of the patients showed no response. The time required for clinical improvement was 2-7 days. In a preliminary study, carriers of hepatitis B virus were treated with a preparation of I11Phyllanthus amarusI11 for 30 days. 22 of 37 (59%) treated patients had lost hepatitis B surface antigen when tested 15-20 days after the end of the treatment compared with only 1 of 23 (4%) placebo- treated controls. Some subjects have been followed for up to 9 months. In no case has the surface antigen returned. Clinical observation revealed few or no toxic effects. The encouraging results of this preliminary study recommend continued evaluation of this plant and the active principles isolated from it. In another clinical trial I11Phyllanthus amarusI11 was administered to 30 asymptomatic carriers of hepatitis B surface antigen (HbsAg) in a dosage of 250 to 500 mg thrice daily for 4 to 8 weeks. None of the 30 subjects cleared HbsAg. I11Phyllanthus amarusI11 was well tolerated, with no clinical side effects or changes in the organ profiles for safety evaluation. It was concluded that I11Phyllanthus amarusI11 is not effective in clearing HbsAg in asymptomatic carriers of the antigen. In another clinical study extracts of three species of I11PhyllanthusI11 were tested on the serologic status of 123 patients with chronic hepatitis B at Henan Institute of Medical Sciences, China. Eleven patients received an extract of I11Phyllanthus amarusI11 provided from India. Forty-two patients received I11Phyllanthus niruriI11, gathered from Hainan Province in China, and 35 patients received an extract of I11Phyllanthus urinaria,I11 which had no herbal therapy. The detectable hepatitis B e-antigen from their serum and more likely to seroconvert hepatitis B e-antibody status from negative to positive than were patients given either of the two preparations. No patient changed status with respect of hepatitis B s-antigen. A study was made to know whether the powders of I11Phyllanthus amarusI11 plants favourably influence the duration of disease in patients with acute virus B hepatitis when compared to placebo. The powders of the plant were given in capsule form (300 mg capsules-3 capsules thrice daily) and an antacid powder in similar capsule was used a placebo. Persons with encephalopathy, preexisting medical conditions or serum bilirubin above 350 iu/l were excluded from the study. Fifty seven patients were randomized to receive either the placebo (28 cases) or the drug (28 cases). The two groups were comparable at the time of entry. Two cases from the placebo and one from the drug group dropped out of the study. The duration of disease (time taken for bilirubin to come to below 2mg%) was taken as the outcome measure. The duration of disease in the two groups was compared by Coxâs proportional hazards analysis after adjusting for the variables that influence the duration of jaundice. Only initial serum bilirubin was an independent predictor of jaundice. The analysis showed that Phyllanthus amarus powders did not significantly reduce the duration of jaundice in persons with virus B hepatitis. View Reference
chemical_composition: Enantiomer of norsecurinine, 4-methoxy securinine, 4-methoxy ânorsecurinine, nirphyllin and phyllnirurin, phyllantheol, phyllanthenol, nirphyllin and phyllnirurin, 3, 7, 11, 15, 19, 23-hexamethyl-2Z-6Z, 10Z, 14E, 18E, 22E-tetracosahexen -1-ol, triacontanol, phthalic acid bis-ester (phyllester) with Ã-sitosterol, dotriacontanoic acid and a rare sterol 24-isopropylcholesterol (aerial parts); lintetralin, niranthin, nirtetralin, phyllanthin, hypophyllanthin, phyltetralin, vitamin C (leaves); phyllochrysine alkaloids (leaves, stem); lupa-20 (29)-ene-3-ol, 3, 5, 7-trihydroxyflavonal,-4â-O-S224 -L-(-)- rhamnopyranoside, 5, 3â, 4â- trihydroxy flavanone -7-O-S224 -L-(-)-, rhamnopyranoside, nirurin, [5, 6, 7,4â-tetrahydroxy 8-(3-methylbut-2-aryl) flavone-5-0-rutinoside], phyllanterpenyl, ester, pentacosanyl ester, heptacosanoic acid, phyllanthusone, phyllanthosterol, phyllanthosecosteryl ester, phyllanthostigmasterol and fraternusterol (root); estradiol (bark, root); ricinoleic, linoleic and linolenic acid (seed oil); corilagin, ellagic acid, gallic acid, geraniin an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor, and the flavonoids- FGB111B11, and FGB112B11 (plant). Plant extract showed in vitro antihepatitis B virus surface antigen-like activity; plant extract showed and silymarin exhibited hepatoprotective effect in rats by preventing CCIB114B11-induced reduction of ascorbic acid excretion in urine. Four new lignans-2,3-desmethoxy seco-isolintetralin, 2,3-desmethoxy seco-isolintetralin diacetate, linnanthin and demethylenedioxyniranthin-isolated and their structures determined; structures of 5â-desmethoxyniranthin and 2-(3,4-dimethoxybenzyl), 4-(3,4-methylendioxy-benzyl) butyrolactone (I) confirmed by synthesis; an ellagitannin-phyllanthusiin D-isolated and its structure established; isolation and structure elucidation of a new cyclic tannin- amarulone; one more tannin-amarin âisolated and its structure established; geraniin, corilagin,1,6-digalloyl-Ã-D-glucoside, rutin and quercetin-3-O-glucoside also isolated.

description: A glabrous shrub usually growing along river-banks; branches grooved. author: L.
description: A pernnial root climbers; branches with swollen nodes. Leaves entire, often un-equal-sided; stipules various. Flowers dioecious, minute, spicate, each in the axil of a bract. Perianth 0. Stamens 2-4; filaments short; anthers 2-celled, the cells distinct. Ovary 1-celled; ovule solitary, erect; stigmas 2-5. Fruit a small ovoid or globose 1-seeded berry.
phenology: Flower: probably a native of Java, widely cultivated
pharmacology: Fungicidal, nematicidal, antibacterial, antifungal, hypotensive, cardiac and respiratory depressant, antimitotic, mild antifertility, anthelmintic, antitubercular, antimicrobial, smooth muscle relaxant, cardiotonic. C11ToxicologyC11 LDB1150B11 of the 50% ethanolic extract of whole plant was found to be>1000mg/ kg i.p. in mice. The juice of leaves was found nontoxic up to a dose of 1000mg/100gm in mice. Leaf extract at high concentrations induces oxidative damage to biological membranes. Chewing of betel quid (betel leaf, betel nut, trace amounts of lime and catechu) lead to substantial rise in the salivary nitrite levels and the possible relevance of these to the of oral cancer. Excessive indulgence in chewing for long periods is liable to produce dental caries, pyorrhea alveolaris, oral sepsis, dyspepsia, palpitation, neurosis and slow cerebration. In moderate doses, the betel oil exhibits a depressant action on the central nervous system of mammals, lethal doses produce deep narcosis leading to death within few hours. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 A clinical trial was conducted on 80 patients of bronchial asthma of varied etiology. Powder of I11Calotropis giganteaI11 (root bark) and I11Piper nigrumI11 (fruit) were mixed with I11Piper betelI11 leaf juice and the paste thus obtained was made into pills, each weighing 200 mg. The drug was administered in doses of two pills, i.e. 400 mg a day with yew decoction (Thaleespathri kasayam) for 45 days. The observations indicated that the drug has high potential in the treatment of bronchial asthma. View Reference

description: Stems prostrate or ascending (not climbing). Leaves cordate, glabrous, the lower with long petioles, the upper sessile and stem-clasping. pharmacology: I11P. longumI11 possesses bioavailability enhancing propertied. Piperine was shown to enhance the bioavailability of antitubercular drugs rifampicin, pyrazinamide, isoniazid and ethambutol and also the antileprotic drug dapsone.The essential oil of fruit showed antibacterial, antifungal and anthelmintic activities. View Reference
chemical_composition: The alkaloids piperine, piperlongumine (piplartine), piperlonguminine and also methyl-3, 4, 5-trimethoxycinnamate . Sesamin, a lignan, dihydrostigmasterol and two low melting unstable compounds, one of which appeared to be isobutylamide of an unsaturated acid, n-isobutyl-deca-trans-2-trans-4-dieneamide, essential oil consisting of n-hexadecane, n-octadecane, n-cicosane, n-hencosane, S224-thujene, terpinolene, zingiberine, p-methoxyacetophenone, dehydrocarveol and two monocyclic sesquiterpenes. The presence of L- tyrosine, L-cysteine hydrochloride, DL-serine and L-aspartic acid as free amino acids also has been reported in the fruits. The seeds contain sylvatine, dieudesmin. In addition to palmitic, hexadecenoic, stearic, linoleic, oleic, linolenic, higher saturated acids, arachidic and behenic acids are also reported1. Two new monocyclic sesquiterpenes, bp. 235Âº (15.5) and bp. 247Âº (11.1%) from essential oil; two new alkaloids-piperlongumine (piplartine), mp. 124Âº and piperlonguminine -from roots and stem bark, characterised as N-(3,4,5-trimethoxycinnamoyl)-piperidin-2-one-5-ene and isobutyiamide of piperic acid respectively; a new sesquiterpenic hydrocarbon containing tetrasubstituted double bond from essential oil; sesamin isolated; isolation of N-isobutyldeca-trans-2-trans-4-dienamide, mp. 69Âº.

author: L.
description: A stout glabrous climber; stems terete, sparingly rooting, much thickened at the nodes. Leaves coriaceous, 10-17.5 by 5-12.5 cm, broadly ovate, acuminate, glabrous, 5-9 nerved, the supra-basal nerves usually alternate, base usually rounded, more or less oblique; petioles 1.25-2.5 cm long. Flowers in slightly interrupted glabrous spikes of variable length (5-15 cm), dioecious or sometimes polygamous; bracts of the female spikes more or less adnate to the rhachis, forming a short hemispheric cup beneath the ovary; bracteoles forming a semilunar ridge above the ovary. Stamens 2. Stigmas 2-4. Fruit globose, .6 cm in diam. or less, at first yellow, afterwards becoming red when fully ripe.
pharmacology: Extracts of the fruit of I11P. nigrumI11 showed slight selective anthelmintic activity against cestodes. The volatile oil from the fruit showed antifungal activity. The naturally occurring alkaloid, piperine displayed CNS depressant activity in mice. Antipyretic effects in rabbits given typhoid vaccine, and analgesic activity in tail clip pressure in mice. Piperine enhances the pesticidal properties of pyrethrin, white the benzene extracts are markedly fungitoxic. when given orally to rats at 100 mg/kg it showed slight febrifugal activity. C11Clinical UsageC11 Used commonly as a culinary seasoning. Prescribed for dyspepsia, flatulence, diarrhea, used as gargle for sore throat, and as febrifuge in intermittent fevers. A poultice made from pepper, salt and vinegar is used to soften corns. Unani system used black pepper as a carminative, aphrodisiac and antispasmodic. It is also used to relieve diarrhea. It is used with ginger and I11P. longumI11 for viral hepatitis. View Reference

author: Benth.
description: Annual erec, slender, 30-60 cm high; stems quadrangular, simple or branched, glabrous or sparsely hairy. Leaves thinly membranous, 5-10 by 3-5 cm, ovate, acute, coarsely serrate, gland-dotted, with short scattered stiff hairs above and on the nerves beneath, base rounded, truncate or cuneate; petioles .6-5 cm long. Flowers in branched cymes forming a large pyramidal panicle; bracts at the forks of the cymes minute; ultimate pedicels filiform pubescent, often .6 cm long. Calyx pubescent, covered with red or orange minute waxy glands in flower small, .12 cm long, much enlarged in fruit, reaching sometimes when the fruit is fully ripe .4 cm long, incurved, striate, obscurely 2-lipped, with 5 subacute teeth. Corolla 2-lipped, .6 cm long, white with purple spots; tube exserted, broad, straight. Stamens 4 exserted, didynamous, declinate; filaments simple, free; anther-cells usually confluent. Ovary 4-partite. Fruit of 4 orbicular ovoid or oblong smooth granulate dry nutlets; nutlets .12 cm long, broadly ellipsoid, smoth, yellowish-brown.

author: L.
description: A perennial herb, subscandent; stems .5-1.5 m long, somewhat woody, spreading, terete, striate, glabrous. Leaves thin, 4-7.5 by 2-3.75 cm, ovate, subacute, entire, glabrous, somewhat glaucous beneath, reticulately veined, shortly and abruptly attenuated into a short petiole; petiole narrow, amplexicaul at the base and often dilated into stipule-like auricles. Flowers in elongate spikes; rhachis glandular, striate; bracteoles ovate, acumiate, shorter than the calyx glandular or not. Calyx 1-1.25 cm long, narrowly tubular, persistent, densely covered with stalked glands; 5-tothed, teeth small, with membranous margins. Corolla white, slender; tube 2-2.5 cm long; lobes .8 cm long, obovate-oblong, acute, apiculate. Stamens 5; filaments as long as the corolla-tube; anthers exserted just beyond the throat. Ovary attenuated at the apex. Capsule oblong, pointed; pericarp thin below, thick and hardened above. Seeds black; flattened.
pharmacology: Antipyretic, appetizer, uterotonic, antibacterial, antifungal, antifertility, anticancer (plumbagin), anticoagulant, antitumour, hepatoprotective, cytotoxic, appetizer and CNS depressant. Plant extract (100 mg/kg) prevents 100 ovulation and implantation in female rats. Plumbagin administered intratumourally and orally at 2 mg /kg decreased tumour growth by 70% and 60% respectively in rats with methylchloranthene-induced tumour. C11ToxicologyC11 The LDB1150B11 of 50% ethanolic of roots in albino mice was 500 mg/kg i.p. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 Topical application of plumbagin has been found to be useful in patients with common wart. View Reference

locations.vegetation: Tropical Dry Deciduous type of Vegetation

pharmacology: Aqueous extract of stem of I11P. pinnataI11 showed sedative effect in rats and mice and antipyretic activity in rats. Pongapinone A, isolated from stem bark was found to inhibit interculin-1 production. Seed oil exhibited strong spermicidal activity against human sperms in vitro. Direct ethanolic and sequential petroleum ether, chloroform, acetone and ethanolic extract of seeds revealed anti-inflammatory, analgesic and antiulcerogenic activities in rats. Petroleum ether and chloroform extracts showed shortening of pentobarbitone induced sleep time in rats. Pongamol and karanjin isolated from seed kernel showed CNS depressant and stimulant activity, respectively in mice. Antibacterial, antifungal and phytotoxicity of pure compounds pongarotene and karanjin, isolated from the methanolic extract of seeds and methanol and ethyl acetate crude extract of seeds were reported. Deoiled karanj cake can be safely incorporated in concentrate mixture of lactating cows upto 10 per cent level and to growing calves upto 50 per cent nitrogen-replacement of groundnut cake without any harmful effect. Major therapeutic claims in Infectious skin disease and leprosy. View Reference
chemical_composition: Ã-Sitosterol isolated from seeds; karanjin, pongamol, new pongaglabrone, mp. 233Âº and pongapin isolated from seeds; pongaglabrone identified as 3',4' -methylenedioxyfurano-[2â,3â ,7 ,8] flavone (Tetrahedron 1963,19,219); a new furoflavone -6- methoxyfurano [2â,3â,7,8] flavone (6-methoxy-4-oxo-Z- phenyl- furo[2,3-h]-1-benzopyran) -isolated from seeds; in addition, kangone isolated from seeds; waxes, kaempferol and S226-sitosterol from flowers; kanugin from roots and demethoxykanugin from stem bark; a new chromenoflavone -pongachromene -isolated from stem bark and structure determined.

author: L.
description: A large shrub or small tree reaching 10 m high; bark yellowish, lenticellate; young parts glabrous or slightly pubescent; trunk and large branches sometimes spinous. Leaves opposite, 5-9 by 3-6.25, broadly elliptic, obtuse, very shortly acuminate, glabrous entire or the upper part dentate, base rounded or subactue; main nerves 4-5 pairs; petioles 1-1.5 cm long. Flowers small, greenish-yellow, with a disagreeable odor, in terminal pubescent paniculate corymbose cymes; bracts minute, lanceolate. Calyx .25 cm long, thick, glabrous, 2 lipped, one lip 2 toothed, the other subentire. Corolla glabrous outside; tube .3 by .2 cm, cylindric, hairy in the throat inside; lobes 4, oblong, rounded, .12 cm long. Stamens 4, didynamous, inserted below the throat of the corolla, slightly exserted; filaments hairy at the base. Ovary and style glabrous; stigma of 2 equal divaricate lobes. Fruit a small drupe, embraced below by the calyx, .4 cm long, pear-shaped; endocarp ridged, bony, 4-celled, 4-seeded.
