author: (L. f.) Druce.
description: An erect branched herb, up to 1 m high; stems quadrangular, pubescent (especially at the nodes), with small often hooked hairs; internodes long. Leaves 2.5-7.5 by 2-5 cm, ovate or elliptic, obtuse, clothed on both sides with fine hooked hairs and also with a few stout hairs above, coarsely crenate-serrate, base subcordate or truncate, but slightly decurrent on the petiole; petioles .6-3 cm long. Flowers distant, in long spicate racemes 15-30 cm long; rhachis quadrangular, more or less pubescent with small often hooked hairs; pedicels .12 cm long; bracts .25 cm long, linear-lanceolate, hairy. Calyx .4 cm long, nearly cylindric in flower, becoming nearly globose in fruit, densely clothed with fine spreading hooked hairs; teeth small, acute. Corolla pure-white; tube .8 cm long, scarcely enlarged above; limb 2-lipped; upper lip 2-lobed; lower lip larger than the upper, deeply 3-lobed. Fruit enclosed in the enlarged calyx .4 cm long, obcordate, readily splitting into 2 glabrous pyrenes which are reticulately pitted, echinate on the back with 2 rows of straight and curved spines, deeply excavate on the faces.

author: (L.) Batsch
description: An annual, branched wooly procumbent herb; branches 12.5-25 cm long, densely woolly. Leavesalternate, petiolate, 1.25-2 cm long, ovate-oblong. Variously lobed, densely tometose on both surfaces; petioles .31.25 cm long, densely woolly. Flowers .6 cm in diam., axillary, solitary; pedicels short. Calyx-tube flat, dilated, at length conic, spiny and forming with the ripe carpels and orbicular disk; lobes 5, triangular; bracteoles 5, subulate. Petals 5, small. Stamens 10, inserted in the contracted mouth of the calyx; filaments subulate. Carpresl 10, whorled, united with one another and with the calyx; ovule solitary from the apex of the carpel; styles subulate, persistent. Fruit a depressed cone with spinous margins; .6-2 cm in diam., orbicular, densely woolly, the lower surface quite flat. The seeds germinate within the carpels and the roots of the young plant carry the old fruit from which they have emerged as a persistent collar round them, the collar remaining even when the plant is fully grown.

author: L.
description: A small tree; bark peeling off in flakes. Leaves simple, entire, opposite, sessile, glnd dottedand with intramaarginal vain. Flowers solitary or 2-3 together in axillary clusters; pedicels short, stout. Petals 4, white, exceeding the calyx. Stamens exserted. Fruits pyriform, fleshy, green with white or rosy purple pulp. Seeds numerous, globose. The well-known Guava Tree, a native of Mexico and possibly other parts of Tropical America, is cultivated throughout and naturalized in India and in most tropical countries. It is valued for its fruit and as the trees in cultivation are mostly by seeds, there is naturally an immense variety in the quality of the fruit. Grafted plants are also available now in plenty.

author: Talb.
description: A small shrub. author: Roxb.
description: A large deciduous tree with a stout crooked stem and widely spreading branches; bark thick, yellowish-grey, the outer layer corky. Leaves alternate, imparipinnate, 15-22 cm long; rhachis glabrous, prolonged 2-2.5 cm beyond the insertion of the upper lateral leaflet. Leaflets 5-7, coriaceous, 6.25-10 by 3.75-5 cm, oblong, obtuse, rounded, truncate or more or less retuse at the apex, glabrous on both surfaces, shining above, base subacute; main nervous numerous, close, prominent; petiolules .6-1 cm long. Flowers in short lateral and terminal fuscopubescent paniculate racemes, usually shorter than the leaves; pedicels short, articulated beneath the flower. Calyx .6 cm long, veined, brown-pubescent; teeth very short, broadly triangular, the upper the largest. Corolla exserted, 1.25 cm long, pale-yellow, with crisped margins standard 1 cm broad, with a long claw. Stamens monadelphous or the staminal-tube often finally slit on both sides making them isadelphous. Ovary short stalked; ovules 2. Pods 2.5-5 cm in diam., nearly circular, glabrous or nearly so, the wing veined. Seed small.
pharmacology: Extractive of heartwood showed statistically significant hypoglycaemic action in fasting rabbits 3 and 5 hours after oral administration. No harmful effects were noticed in doses which showed hypoglycaemic action. Alcoholic extract of stem significantly lowered blood sugar and improved glucose tolerance of rabbits. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 Clinical trials on I11P. marsupiumI11 heartwood (extract, decoction, powder and infusion) showed encouraging hypoglycaemic effects in a number of diabetic patients. Considerable reduction in sugar levels in blood and urine were observed. The efficacy of I11P. marsupiumI11 in form of ointment as antifungal agent was evaluated in a clinical trial on 50 patients suffering from dermatophyte infection i.e. Tinea cruris (22 patients), T. corporis (14 patients) and mixed infections (14 patients). The ointment was locally applied for 7 to 10 days. The ointment made of alcoholic extract of the wood was found more effective than that prepared from aqueous extract. View Reference

pharmacology: Punica granatum and pelletierine are evaluated as anthelmintics. The root bark also shows activity against tapeworms. The extract from I11Punica granatumI11 was found to be hypoglycaemic in mice. Astringent properties of the fruit rind and fruit juice explain the antidiarrhoeal activity. C11Clinical UsageC11 As per the ayurvedic pharmacopoeia, the root has good vermicidal effect. The bark and seeds are useful in bronchitis. The flowers are used in epistaxis. The unripe fruit is a good appetizer and it is useful in nausea and vomiting. The ripe fruit is tonic, astringent to the bowels, and relieves burning sensation of the body. The rind of the fruit is very useful in diarrhea and dysentery. The fresh juice is used in cooling and refrigerant mixtures of some medicines for dyspepsia. The root bark has been used as an anthelmintic. View Reference
chemical_composition: Sitosterol and ursolic acid isolated; two tannins-punicalagin and punicalin-isolated from peels and their structures determined; hydrolysis of punicalagin yielded ellagic acid and punicalin, the latter yielded glucose and a tetralactone; pectin isolated from fruits contained mannose, galactose, rhamnise, arabinose and glucose in ratio of 1:1.3:2.1:4.4:6.2; principal sugar acid was galacturonic acid.

author: (L.) Benth. ex Kurz
description: A small erect shrub, rarely reaching 1 m high; bark pale, rarely lenticellate. Leaves in whorls of 3, thin, 7.5-17.5 by 2.5-6.25 cm, lanceolate, acute or acuminate, glabrous, bright green above, pale beneath, base tapering; main nerves 8-10 pairs slender; petioles .8 cm long, somewhat obscure, owing to the blade running down into the petiole. Flowers white, often tinged with violet, in many-flowered irregular corymbose cymes; peduncles 5-12.5 cm long; pedicels stout, .3-.6 cm long, bright red; bracts beneath the pedicels triangular, acute, .1-.15 cm long. Calyx glabrous bright-red; 5-fid, segments .25 cm long, lanceolate. Corolla hypocrateriform; 1-1.25 cm long or rarely a little longer; tube slender, cylindric, swollen a little above the middle; lobes .3 cm long, elliptic-oblong, rounded at the apex; usually hairy within; lobes 5, overlapping to the left. Disk cup-shaped, membranous, obscurely lobed. Carpels 2, ovules 2 in each carpel, collateral; style filiform; stigma thick, broad and often toothed at the apex. Drupes single, or didymous and connate more or less deeply, about .6 cm in diam., purplish-black when ripe. The inflorescence of this plant with red pedicels and calyx and white corolla is striking.
chemical_composition: More than 50 alkaloid have been reported from this plant. Root yields alkaloids ajmaline, ajmalinine, ajmalicine, yohimbine, alloyohimbine, isoyohimbine, r-yohimbine, cornanthine, raunatine, rauvolfinine, rauwolscine, reserpiline, reserpilin, reserpine, rescinnamine, reserpinine, resepoxidine, sarpagine, serpentine and amorphous bases. Reserpine, reserpiline, 1,2-Dihydrovornilenine reductase, amalicidine (1- carbomethoxy-17S224-hydroxy-16-decarbomethoxy-16, 17 -dihydroajmalicine), ajmalicine, corynanthine (rauhimbine), deserpidine, indobine, indobinine (cyclohexylester of indole propionic acid), rescinnamidine, rescinnamine, rescinnaminol, renoxidine, sarpagine, serperntine, serpentinine, yohamabinine (5Ã-methyl-pseudoyohirnibine), yohimbine, S224-yohimbine (rauwolscine), 3-epi-S224-yohimbine, indolines, ajmalimine (21- trimethoxybenzoyl ajmaline), ajmaline, ajmalinimine, ajmalinine, isoajmaline, rauwolfinine (perakenine), sandwicolidine, sandwicoline (21- monohydro-N-methylsandwicine), tetraphyllicine (serpinine), serposterol (17Ã-methyl-5-androsten-3Ã-ol), Ã-sitosterol and its 7-dehydro derivative, serpoterpene, enantioselective synthesis of (- )ajmalicine, yohambanoid, monoterpenoid indole alkaloid, 10-hydroxy-N(S224)-demethyl-19,20- dehydroraumacline ( root). Structure elucidation of reserpine and deserpidine; essential oil (0.22%) from roots yielded chief terpene constituent -serpoterpine, bp.131Âº; isolation of reserpine, mp. 360Âº, ajmaline, mp.158Âº, serpentine, mp.155Âº, serpentinine, mp.265Âº and ajmalicine (S235-yohimbine), mp. 250Â°, from roots; reserpine, serpajmaline (mixture of serpentine, I serpentinine, ajmaline and 2 unknown compounds, free of reserpine), resajmaline (mixture of serposterol and unsaturated higher alcohols), rescinnamine and ajmalexine (mixture of reserpine and rescinnamine) were isolated from roots; detection of reserpine, reserpinine, yohimbine, ajmaline, serpentine and serpentinine by PC; serpentinine , characterised as 3-hydroxyserpentine; absolute stereochemistry of ajmaline and isoajmaline; raugalline isolated and identified as ajmaline; detection of raunatine I in root extract by PC; stereochemical studies in structure elucidation of yohimbine and reserpine; a review on structure of Rauwolfia alkaloids.

author: Gamble
description: A small bush about .5 m high with pretty pink flowers. Leaves alternate, usually membranous; stipules small, often many and persistent. Disk in male of 4 glands alternate with the ca]yx-lobes, in female of 6 glands combined in a fleshy ring or cup. Stamens 2 or 4, the filaments united in a column around a pistillode; anthers dehiscing horizontally. Ovary 3-celled, 2 ovules in each cell; styles 3, deeply 2-fid. pharmacology: Antiinflammatory, spasmogenic, hepatoprotective, anti-fertility, purgative, immunizing, CNS depressant and spasmolytic. C11ToxicologyC11 Long term use of castor oil can cause colic as well as dehydration with electrolyte imbalance and also a reduction in absorption of nutrients because of strong purgative action. It can cause uterine contraction if taken during pregnancy. Albumin, ricin are the toxic components of castor seeds and are highly poisonous to human beings and animals. Ricin causes an extensive poisonous to human beings and animals. Ricin causes an extensive inflammation of the eyes. Ricinine shows toxicity against codling moth larvae. LDB1150B11 of ricin tryptic peptide with molecular wt. 22000 is 20 and 6Âµg/kg and that of ricin tryptic peptide with molecular wt. 18000 is 18 and 5.5 Âµg/kg after 24 and 48 hrs respectively. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 Three clinical trials were carried out on an Ayurvedic preparation. Hingutriguna Taila, of which I11Ricinus communisI11 is one of the ingredients. The trials were conducted for three diseases viz., sciatica, hemiplegia and hook worm infestation. The studies revealed that Hingutriguna Taila has definite therapeutic value in diseases related to neuromuscular system. Complete relief was achieved in 60% cases of sciatica who completed the full course of treatment. The results in hemiplegia were found promising. The drug was also found quite effective in eradicating hook worm infestation. View Reference

Chlorogenic, oleic, palmitic, ricinoleic, stearic and dihydrostearic acids, hexadecanoic, hydrocyanic and uric acids (oil), squalene and tocopherols (plant). Lysine-2-C14, fed hydroponically to seedlings, was incorporated in ricine solely in S224-position to ring N atom; yield of ricinine about 1% from plant; detection of palmitic (1.2), stearic (0.7), arachidic (0.3), hexadecenoic (0.2), oleic (3.2), linoleic (3.4), linolenic (0.2), ricinoleic (89.4%) and dihydroxystearic acids as Me esters in castor oil by GLC; lupeol and 30-norlupan-3Ã-o1-20-one from coat of castor bean.

author: L.
description: Perennial, herbaceous, climber; roots very long, cylindric, flexuose, with a thin red bark; stems often many yards long, rough, grooved, becoming slightly woody at the base; bark white; branches scandent by means of numerous divaricate or deflexed branchlets and petioles, quadrangular, sometimes prickly on the angles, glabrous, shining. Leaves 3.75-9 by 1.5-3.5 cm, in whorls of 4 (one pair of each whorl often larger and with longer petioles than the other), ovate, acute, the lower leaves larger than the upper, all scabrous above on the nerves beneath, and on the margins with minute white prickles, base rounded or slightly cordate, the base of the upper leaves sometimes acute, all 5 (rarely 7) - nerved from the base; petioles triangular, with many sharp recurved prickles on the edges, often deflexed; stipules 0. Flowers in terminal panicled glabrous cymes; branches trichotomous, spreading; bracts ovate acute, leafy. Calyx 1 cm long. Styles 2; stigmas globose. Fruit .4-.6 cm diam., didymous or globose, smooth, shining, purplish-black when ripe.
pharmacology: The traditional therapeutic use of the plant has been in skin disorders. It is found effective in scabies and in infection with I11Tinea pedis.I11 Its evaluation as an anticancer compound in the laboratory has been extensive, the extract showing weak activity in vitro and in vivo against standard tumour cell lines. The anti-inflammatory potential has been studied on carrageenin-induced oedema in rat hind paw. The plant water extract showed significant anti-inflammatory activity at a dose of 10 and 20 ml/kg body weight, comparable to that of phenylbutazone. Interistingly, no such activity was seen with I11Rubia tinctorum,I11 the Persian variety of manjistha. C11Clinical UsageC11 Used mainly in ointments used for dermatological disorders, also as a decoction. Clinical trials have been conducted in eczema. View Reference
chemical_composition: Colouring matter in roots is a mixture of purpurin and mujistin. Roots also contains small amount of xanthopurpurin and psedopurpurin. Munjistin, alizarin and its glucoside in plant. Anthroguinones, pentacyclic triterpenes, quinines, cyclic hexapeptides and diethyl esters are reported. author: Sm.
description: A tall suberect prickly bush; stems and branches somewhat sparsely armed with hooked scattered prickles, shaggy with long horizontal (often very dense) brown bristly hairs, covering a short grayish pubescence. Leaves alternate, pinnately 3-foliolate; leaf-rhachis (including the petiole) 3-5 cm, shaggy; cmmon petioles 2-2.5 cm long, shaggy stipules subulate. Leaflets broadly elliptic or obovate, acuminate, irregularly serrate-dentate, green on both sides, glabrous or nearly so, prominently reticulately veined beneath, the terminal leaflets 9-12.5 by 7-9 cm with petiolules 1.25-2.5 cm long, the lateral leaflets 3.75-6.25 by 2.5-4.5 cm with petiolules .12 cm long. Flowers in axillary and terminal panicles; pedicels short. Calyx finely pubescent outside, sometimes with a few scattered, bristly hairs; lobes 5, ovate or elliptic, usually mucronate. Petals 5, obovate, longer than the calyx-lobes, white. Stamens 1-seriate. Fruit golden-yellow, globular, succulent, of numerous 1-seeded drupes on a cylindric hairy receptacle; stone rugose.

Leaves opposite, 2-7.5 by 1.25-4.5 cm, ovate or elliptic, acute sparsely hairy, margins entire, base acute; petioles .6-2 cm long. Flowers nearly sessile, axillary, solitary or few together; bracteoles like the leaves but smaller, .8-2 cm long (including the stalk). Calyx .8 cm long, divided about Â¾ the way down; segments linear-subulate, very acute, hairy. Corolla pale blue-violet, 3 cm long. Pubescent outside; tube narrowly cylindric below, infundibuliform above; lobes .6-1 cm long. Obovate-oblong, rounded at ehe apex. Filaments glabrous. Ovary pubescent; stye pubescent. Capsules 2 cm long, slightly pubescent, clavate pointed. Seeds 16-20, orbicular, .3 cm in diam., almost glabrous on the faces with a dense fringe or hygroscopic hairs on the margin.

author: Nees.
description: A small suberect herb 15-30 cm high; stems very slender with almost filiform branches. Leaves 1.25-2.5 by .6-1.25 cm, elliptic-lanceolate, acute or subobtuse, lineolate, glabrous or nearly so, base usually tapering; main nerves 4-6 pairs; petioles 0-.3 cm long. Flowers in narrow pedunculate terminal slender quadrifarous secund spikes 1.25-3.75 cm long; bracts herbaceous, .3 by .12 cm, elliptic-lanceolate, acute, mucronate, minutely pubescent bracteoles, linear-lanceolate. Calyx small, 5-partite; .25 cm long, minutely pubescent, divided almost to the base; segments linear-subulate. Corolla pale-purple, 2-lipped, .8 cm long, slightly pubescent outside; the lower lip longer than the upper, upper lip .25 by .2 cm, bifid; lower lip .3 cm long, obovate shorly 3-lobed. Stamens 2; anthers 2 celled; filaments glabrous; lower cells of the anthers not slightly appendiculate at the base. Ovary 2-celled; ovules 2 in each cell; style filiform; stigma minutely 2-fid. Fruit a capsule; oblong-ellipsoid. Seeds 4, brown

author: (L.) Nees.
description: Herb. Stems usually decumbent, often rooting near the base, then erect, slender, subterete, glaborous or puberulous. Leaves 2.5-5 by 1.25-2 cm, subsessile or shortly periolate, oblong-lanceoloate, acute, lineolate on both sides, glabrous or nearly so, base usually tapering, less commonly rounded and unequal-sided; main nerves about 6 pairs; petioles rarely reaching .4 cm long. Flowers in erect terminal usually pubescent imperfectly 1-sided spikes; bracts (including the scarious margin) .6 by .5 cm, broadly elliptic, pubescent, cuspidate, much imbricate, the margins thinly scarious, ciliate, often .15 cm wide ; bracteoles .5 cm long, linear-lanceolate, acute, with scarious margins, minutely pubescent. Calyx .4 cm long, puberulous, segments lanceolate-subulate. Corolla white, blue, or pink, with darker spots, pubescent outside, nearly 1.25 cm long; upper lip .3 cm long, oblong, emarginated; lower lip .4 cm long, shortly 3-lobbed. Lower anther-cells with a white appendage at the base. Capsules .4-.5 cm long, ovoid-oblong, acute, compressed, with scarious faces and hard edges, pubescent. Seeds .15 cm in diam., suborbicular, rugose with concentric furrows, pale-brown.
chemical_composition: Flowers contain Luteolin7-glucoside and delphinidin, besides luteolin and another flavone- chrysoeriol.

Flowers in erect terminal usually pubescent imperfectly 1-sided spikes; bracts (including the scarious margin) .6 by .5 cm, broadly elliptic, pubescent, cuspidate, much imbricate, the margins thinly scarious, ciliate, often .15 cm wide ; bracteoles .5 cm long, linear-lanceolate, acute, with scarious margins, minutely pubescent. Calyx .4 cm long, puberulous, segments lanceolate-subulate. Corolla white, blue, or pink, with darker spots, pubescent outside, nearly 1.25 cm long; upper lip .3 cm long, oblong, emarginated; lower lip .4 cm long, shortly 3-lobbed. Lower anther-cells with a white appendage at the base. Capsules .4-.5 cm long, ovoid-oblong, acute, compressed, with scarious faces and hard edges, pubescent. Seeds .15 cm in diam., suborbicular, rugose with concentric furrows, pale-brown.

author: L.
description: Strong-smelling glanduloso-punctate herbs, often shrubby below. Leaves alternate. Leaves petioles, decompound; segments cuneate, spathulate-oblong or linear-oblong. Flowers numerous in divaricately spreading corymbs; pedicels longer than the capsule; bracts lanceolate. Sepals triangular, acute. Petals oblong-obovate, pectinate. Abruptly clawed. Disk thick, urceolate, glandular. Stamens inserted round the base of the disk, the alternate shorter; filaments dilated at the base. Ovary sessile, deeply 3-5 lobed, 3-5 celled; ovules pendulous from the axis of the cells; style central, stigmatose at the apex. Capsules obtuse, shortly pedicelled, many-seeded; seeds angled.

description: A large straggling or climbing shrub; branches divaricate; young twigs angular, glabrous. Calyx copular, persistent; lobes 5, rounded, calyx-lobes, oblong or obovate, clawed, rounded at the apex and with membranous margins. Disk convex, fleshy. author: Vahl.
description: A handsome tree. Leaves alternate, exstipulate, abruptly-pinnate; leaflets subopposite, 2-3 pairs, 7.5-17.5 by 2.5-10 cm, lanceolate or elliptic-lanceolate, acute or acuminate, entire, glabrous above, more or less pubescent beneath, base acute; main nerves about 8-12 pairs; petioles .3 cm long, pubescent. Flowers dingy white, in terminal rusty-pubescent panicles, the males numerous, the bisexual flowers few. Sepals 5, rotund-ovate, ciliolate, fulvous-pubescent outside, glabrous within, .4 cm long. Petals 4-5 shortly clawed, narrower than the sepals, lanceolate, villous outside and more or less so within. Disk complete, concave with a fleshy hirsute margin. Stamens 8; filaments villous; anthers oblong, apiculate. Ovary densely hairy. Fruit fleshy, 2-(usually 3-) lobed, clothed with fulvous hairs when young, glabrous and wrinkled when ripe, with 1 seed in each lobe. Seeds blackish, smooth, about the size of a large pea, very hard.
chemical_composition: Ripe fruits contain 10% glucose and dried fruits contain 11.5% saponins. Aqueous extract of fruits contains emarginatoside (CB1147B11 HB1176B11 OB1111B11). On acid hydrolysis this saponin yields hederagenin, d-glucose, l-rhamnose and d-xylose. The oil of the kernel contains palmitic, stearic, arachidic, behenic, oleic and linoleic. Emarginatosides B&C (hederagenin glycosides), hederagenin, oleanolic acid, sapindic acid, trifolioside, sapindoside A characterised as hederagenin-3-S224-L-arabino-pyranosyl-2S224-L-rhamnopyranoside, sapindoside B characterised as hederagenin-3-S224-L-arabinopyranosyl-2S224-L-rhamnopyranosyl-3Ã-D-xylopyranoside, sapindoside C,D,E glucopyranosides of stigmasterol (fruit pericarp); kaempferol, quercetin, Ã-sitosterol (nut); fatty acid diester of -1-cyano-2-hydroxymethyl-prop-1-ene-3-ol (seed oil); arachidic, behenic, linoleci, oleic, palmitic, stearic acid, eicosenoic acid, protein, carbohyderate, starch (kernel); 3-O-rutinosides of isorhamnetin and quercetin (leaves); triterpenoid saponin (peels).

author: (Roxb.) de Willd.
description: An evergreen tree, 6-10 m high; branches glabrous. Leaves abruptly pinnate, 15-25 cm long; rhachis glabrous, corky at the base; petioles very short; stipules intrapetiolar, completely united, 1-1.25 by .6 cm, scarious, ovate-oblong, obtuse, parallel-nerved. Leaflets 4-6 pairs, 10-20 by 3-5.5 cm oblong-lanceolate, obtuse or acute, quite glabrous, base rounded or cuneate, slightly oblique; petiolules .45-.6 cm long, stout, wrinkled; stipels deciduous. Flowers fragrant, numerous, in dense axillary corymbs 7.5-10 cm across; peduncles stout; pedicels .8-1.25 cm long, red, glabrous; bracts ovate, subacute, cilioate, amplexicaul, colored. Calyx petaloid, passing from yellow to orange and finally red; tube 1.25-2 cm long, cylindric, solid at the base; segments 4, oblong or obovate-oblong, .3 cm long. Petals 0. Stamens 7 or 8, much exserted; filaments filiform, thrice as long as the calyx-segments; anthers purple. Ovary pubescent, especially on the sutures; style curved into a ring. Pods black, 10-25 by 4.5-5 cm, linear oblong, tapering to both ends, compressed, glabrous, veined. Seeds 4-8, ellipsoid-oblongm 3.75 cm long, slightly compressed.

locations.vegetation: Tropical semi evergreen to evergreen forest

pharmacology: Spasmogenic, oxytocic, uterotonic, antibacterial, anti-implantation, antitumour, antiprogestational, antioestrogenic, activity against menorrhagia and anticancer. Water soluble portion of alcoholic extract of stem bark of I11S. asocaI11, phenolic glycoside fraction and pure phenolic glycoside PB112B11 isolated from the phenolic glycoside fraction and also the non-phenolic glycoside fraction showed significant stimulant action on isolated uteri of different species including human uterus. The phenolic glycoside PB112B11was inactive on central nervous system, cardiovascular system and smooth muscles other than uterus. PB112B11 is devoid of toxic effects up to 250 mg/kg in rats and dogs. The non-phenolic glycosides may have cholinergic activity and the phenolic glycoside have direct myotropic action. C11ToxicologyC11 Pure phenolic glycoside was nontoxic to animals up to 250 mg /kg. Therapeutic Evaluation A clinical study was conducted on 50 cases of non specific leucorrhea in reproductive phase and beyond. An indigenous herbomineral compound formulation containing I11Saraca indicaI11 as one of the ingredients was administered to all patients in the doses of 2 tablets twice a day. 45 cases were cured in 2-6 weeks of treatment. A herbal compound preparation consisting of aqueous extracts of I11Ficus glomerata, Saraca indicaI11 and I11Woodfordia floribundaI11 was found useful in uterine disorders. Ayush AC-4, a composite drug containing I11Embelia ribes., Laccardia lacca, Areca catechuI11 and I11Saraca indicaI11 in equal parts, when administered orally (1 gm./ day in to divided doses) to 281 women for 15 days, starting from 4th day of menstrual cycle to 18th day, exhibited good contraceptive activity. There was no pregnancy due to drug failure after 10th cycle. No toxic symptoms or severe side effects were noticed. A clinical trial was conducted on 20 patients of oligomenorrhoea, in which a proprietary herbal preparation, consisting I11S. indicaI11 as one of the ingredients, was administered in doses of 2 tsf b.d. for three months and then followed up at regular intervals of one month. Out of 20, 4 patients conceived during study period which indicates that preparation is beneficial in infertility and scanty menstruation. View Reference

author: (Dennst.) Mabb.
description: A small tree armed with sharp conical woody often fascicled spines; bark smooth, greyish-white. Leaves coriaceous, red when young, 7.5-15 by 3-5.5 cm, ovate, elliptic or oblong, obtuse or subacute, glabrous, penninerved, base subacute; main nerves 3-5 pairs; petioles .4 cm long, stout. Flowers polygamous, yellowish-red. MALE FLOWERS in catkin-like spikes, axillary or above the scars of fallen leaves; bracts filiform, deciduous. Perianth-tube solid; segments 5, slightly imbricate in bud, with tufts of hairs behind the stamens. Stamens 5, inserted at the base of the perianth-lobes; filaments 2-fid; anthers 10. FEMALE FLOWERS in compact cylindric racemes. Perianth-tube adnate to the ovary. Stigma large, peltate. Fruit a drupe, brown, pyriform, stalked, 1 .6-5 cm long, crowned by the persistent perianth-segments, smooth.
chemical_composition: Octadec-9-ynoic, 17-octadecen-9-ynoic, decanoic, lauric, palmitic, stearic, arachidic, behenic, hexadecenoic, oleic, eicosenoic, erucic and linoleic acids identified in seed oil (37.7%).

author: (Wight & Arn.) Clos.
description: A small tree; branches with straight, simple spines when young, afterwards unarmed. Leaves simple, alternate, 5-15 by 2.5-6.25 cm, ovate, acute or acuminate, narrowed at the base, glabrous, margins usually with minute, distant glandular teeth; petioles .6-1.25 cm long. Flowers small, hermaphrodite, pale pink, numerous, in axillary panicles shorter than the leaves; pedicels .6-1.25 cm long; bracts deciduous. Sepals 5-6, broad-oblong, obtuse, somewhat fleshy. Petals as many as sepals, smaller than the sepals obovate. Stamens numerous, connective of anthers produced glabrous; filaments filiform. Ovary 1-celled; ovules few style stout, grooved, .6 cm long. Fruit a berry, 1.25-1.5 cm in diam., ovoid or globose, pointed.

author: L.
description: A prostrate herb 1-3 ft,; stems and branches grooved. Sparsely hairy with long soft white hairs. Leaves 1.25-3.75 cm long, nearly as broad as long, orbicular or elliptic in outline, variously lobed and lacinate, hairy above, hairy on the nerves and clothed beneat6h with a white somewhat mealy tomentum; petioles 0-.4 cm long. Flowers solitary, axilary; pedicels .4 cm long. Calyx .8 cm long, deeply divided, hairy outside; segment 5, linear, 1.25 cm long, strongly ciliate. Corolla 2.5-.6 cm long, 2-lipped, tubular-ventricose, minutely pubescent outside, purple, with a yellow palate. Stamens 4, didynamous, included; anthers sagittate, the cells subparallel, distinct. Ovary 2-celled, the cells each soon divided into 2 chambers by the intrusion of a false dissepiment from between the placentas; ovules numerous, 1-seriate in each chamber; style filiform; stigma 2 lobbed. Capsules 1.5 by .8 cm, scabrous-pilose, 2-valved, oblong compressed, rounded and strongly mucronate at the apex. Seeds .4-.5 by .25 cm, obovoid-oblong, foveolate, glabrous.

locations.vegetation: Tropical semi evergreen to evergreen forest

chemical_composition: A flavonoid glucoside-pedaliin (0.3%), mp.254Âº -isolated from leaves and structure determined (Chem. Pharm. Bull. 1960,8,59).

description: Shrubby, much-branched; branches slender, terete, minutely stellately hairy. Fruit .5-.6 cm in diam., carpels 5-9, puberulous, not pubescent, strongly reticulated, toothed on the dorsal margins; awns 2, nearly linear, about â  the length of the carpel. Seeds smooth, black.

author: L.
description: Evergreen perennial unisexual climber forming many long branches and numerous leaves around shrubs and trees. Stems are semi-woody and possess several prickles (up to 9mm long) stem is its zig-zag fashion of growth, where it bends at every leaf (or flower) outgrowth. The flowers are found in clusters of few-flowered umbels along the end of the flowering stem which assumes a zig-zag orientation. Each umbel has about 2-5 small, cream coloured flowers that emit a strong, sweet, almond smell. Fruit juicy berry which initially is green, then turns red and when ripe becomes black Berries are rather soft, have a spherical shape, and measure about 7-9mm across. Each can hold a maximum of 3 seeds, but usually 2 are found. The reddish-brown seeds are shiny, hard, subspherical and about 4mm in size
chemical_composition: Hydrolysis of crude saponin yielded sarsasapogenin, mp.200Âº, its psedogenin, mp.166Âº, a steroid sapogenin of neo series, mp.110Âº and a new sapogenin- asperagenin, mp.264Âº; 31- norcycloartanol, mp.132Âº, and Ã-sitosterol from roots; a new bisdesmosine 22-hydroxyfurostanol saponin-asperoside-from leaves.

author: Lour.
description: Vines climbing. Stem branched, to 8 m, woody; stem and branches smooth or sometimes sparsely prickly. Petiole 2-4 cm, broadly winged for 1/2-2/3 its length; wings 7-12(-25) mm wide, basally deeply clasping node, tapering toward apex; abscission zone distal; tendrils usually developed. Leaf blade usually ovate, 6-17Ã3-12 cm. Inflorescence of 10-30 umbels, 5-17 cm, basally prophyllate; rachis often slightly zigzagged; umbels of both sexes Â± grouped in whorls of 2-4, densely many flowered, base ellipsoid, ca. 4Ã3 mm. Male flowers: outer tepals 5-6x .1 mm, inner ones 5Ã0.3 mm; stamens ca. 5 mm. Female flowers: tepals slightly smaller than male ones; staminodes 3. Berries globose, 4-6 mm in diam.
chemical_composition: Nine compounds from I11Smilax perfoliataI11 were isolated and identified as palmitic acid (I), b-sitosterol (II), d7-5a-cholesten-3b-ol (III), naringenin (IV), succinic acid (V), apigenin (VI), resveratrol(VII) , daucosterol (VIII) and juncusyl ester B (IX). Compounds (I), (III), (IV), (VI), and (IX) were obtained from the genus Smilax for the first time. One new compd. named smilglaside F (I) and five known ones were isolated from the EtOAc portion of the 95% ethanolic extraction of I11Smilax perfoliataI11 Lour. On the basis of chem. and spectral methods, they were identified as 1,6-O-diferuloyl-(3-O-p-coumaroyl)-b-D- fructofuranosyl-(2-1)-2-O-acetyl-a-D-glucopyranoside, rutin , narcissi (3), cassiamin A (4), cassiamin B (5), and 1,2,3-trimethoxy-5-hydroxyphenol-1-O-b-D-glucopyranosid (6). Compounds 1 and 3-6 were obtained from the genus Smilax for the first time.

author: Aiton
description: Annual, diffuse, much-branched herbs; stems up to 1 m long slender, not bristly. Leaves abruptly-pinnate; rachis 1.25-2.5 cm long, bristly and ending in a long bristle; petioles short; stipules scarious, lanceolate, prolonged below the insertion into long cuspidate or lacerate auricles, persistant. Leaflets small, sensitive, 3-10 pairs, .6-1.25 cm long, linear-oblong, obtuse, bristle-pointed, glabrous above and with strong bristles on the midrib and somewhat straight margins beneath, base rounded, somewhat unequal-sided. Flowers 2-lipped in 5-15 cm long, slender, glabrous raceme; pedicels filiform ascending; bracteoles, scarious .4-.5 cm long, ovate, acute, bristle-pointed. Calyx .6-.8 cm long, with a few scattered bristles, rigid; veins close, parallel, simple; lips equal, entire, acute. Corolla yellow, 1 cm long. Stamens in 2 bundles of 5 each; anthers uniform. Ovules many; style filiform; stigma small, terminal. Pods flattened; joints 4-6, orbicular, margined, densely papillose on the faces.

author: L.
description: A much branched undershrub .25-1.5 m high very prickly; prickles large, with a long compressed base, sharp, often slightly recurved; stem stout, often purple; branches covered with minute stellate hairs. Leaves 5-15 by 2.5-7.5 cm, ovate in outline, acute, subentire or with a few large triangular-ovate subacute lobes, sparsely prickly on both sides, clothed above with simple hairs from bulbous bases intermixed with small stellate ones, coverd below with small stellate hairs; base cordate, cunneate or truncate, often unequal-sided; petioles 1.25-2.5 cm long, prickly. Flowers in racemose extra-axillary cymes; peduncles short; pedicels .6-1.25 cm long, stellately hairy and prickly. Calyx .3 cm long, stellately hairy; teeth pale-purple, closthed outside with darker purple stellate hairs; lobes .5 cm lonog, deltoid-ovate, acute. Stamens 5; filaments very short, almost 0; anthers oblong-lanceolate, opening by small pores. Ovary 2-celled, often hairy at the top; style stellately hairy, curved at the apex. Berry .8 cm diam., globose, dark-yellow when ripe, glabrous or sometimes with a few stellate hairs at the apex. Seeds .4 cm in diam., minutely pitted.
pharmacology: Few drops of water extract of the whole plant are administered through nasal route especially on âPushya Nakshatraâ Prostaglandin content of the endometrium from ten women was examined before and after 3 months of the drung administration. A significant increase in prostaglandin E and F was observed. 17-oxysteroids in the urine of women patients also increased on exposure to a nasal spray of the drug. C11Clinical UsageC11 It is described as useful in asthma, dry cough, chronic febrile afflictions and also in dysuria. The fruit is useful in leucoderma, pruritus and bronchitis. Juice of the leaves with fresh juice of ginger is taken to stop nausea and vomiting. View Reference

author: L.
description: A variable annual herb; stem erect, glabrous or more or less pubescent , much divaricately branched. Stamens 5; filaments short, flattened, hairy at the base; anthers .25 cm long, yellow, obtuse, notched at the apex. Ovary globose, glabrous, 2-celed; style cylinder, hairy. pharmacology: Antiinflammatory, hepatoprotective, antiseptic, narcotic, antispasmodic, antibacterial, antimicrobial, CNS depressant, molluscicidal, antiulcer, cardiac depressant, immunomodulatory. Steroidal glycosides (SN-0, SN-2 & SN-3) showed inhibition of tumour cells of human uterus. C11ToxicologyC11 Green unripe fruits contain glycoalkaloids and their consumption in large quantity may cause toxic hazards, even death, to human beings as well as livestock. author: L.
description: A coarse erect annual herb, .5-1 m high; stem glaucescent, striate, branched above. Cauline leaves sessile, oblong or obovate, entire or runcinate-pinnatifid, Â½- amplexicaul, with spreading acute auricles, dentate, glabrous. Heads on long peduncles, combined into subumbellate cymes (or irregular umbellate cymes), campanulate, 1.25-1.5 cm long, many-flowered; flowers yellow; pedicels often glandular. Involucral-bracts 2-3-seriate, glabrous or nearly so; outer bracts shorter than the inner, which reach 1.25 cm long, compressed, narrowly obvoid, longitudinally ribbed, light-brown. Corollas all ligulate, truncate and 5-toothed at the apex. Anther-bases sagittate, the auricles shortly setaceo-acuminate. Style-branches slender. Achenes rugose, 3-ribbed on faces. Pappus hairs white.

author: Willd.
description: A deciduous glabrous tree 10-12 m high; trunk straight; bark smooth, ash-colored; branches nearly horizontal. Leaves compound, alternate, 30-45 cm long, the common petioles slender, terete, smooth, striate; leaflets subopposite, 3-5 pairs and a terminal one, 7.5-17.5 by 3.75-7.5 cm oblong or elliptic-oblong acuminate, quite entire, more or less oblique; main nerves numerous, horizontal, straight, joined by a strong intramarginal one; petiolules .5-.6 cm long. Inflorescence a sparingly branched, glabrous, terminal spreading panicle 25-38 cm long. Flowers small, shortly pedicelled, unisexual or bisexual, pinkish-green. Calyx small; teeth 4-5 fid, minute, triangular. Petals 4-5, spreading, .25-.3 cm long. Disk cup-shaped, broad, crenate. Stamens inserted beneath the disk. Ovary sessile, free, 4-5 celled; ovules 1 in each cell, pendulous. Drupes fleshy, ovoid, yellow, about 3.75 cm long, stone woody, hard, rough with irregular furrows and cavities, fibrous outside. Seeds usually 1, more rarely 2 or 3.

author: Vahl.
description: An erect branching shrub reaching 2 m high, with acutely tetragonal branches, ovate leaves decurrent into the petiole. Spikes terminal, slender, reaching 45 cm long; flowers solitary in th axils of bracts. Calyx elongate, narrowly cylindric, shortly 4-5 toothed, often variously slit in a late stage. Corollatube slender, cylindric; limb obligue, with 5 flat spreading lobes; at first crimson then rose-colored. Perfect stamens 2 (the lowerpair), included in the corolla-tube; staminodes 2. Ovary 2-celled; ovule solitary in each cell, attatched laterally near the base of the cell; style long, filiform. Fruit enclosed in the calyx, separating into two hard 1-seeded pyrenes.

author: Nees.
description: Monocarpic shrubs, 2-6 m high; stems rigid, rough and warted, glabrate. Leaves 10-22 by 3.75-7.5 cm, one of each pair often smaller than the opposite one, elliptic-lanceolate, acute or acuminate, the margins crenate and ciliate, strongly lineolate on the upper surface with cystoliths, dark green above, paler and more or less hairy on the nerves beneath, base tapering wing-like into the petiole; main nerves 10-14 pairs, slender, prominent; petioles variable in length, sometimes reaching 7.5 cm long. Flowers axillary in simple or branched ovoid, pedunculate, subetrangonal spikes with rounded edges, 2.5-9 cm long; peduncles often with one or two pairs of orbicular sessile bracts below the spike; bracts 1.25-2cm long, often as broad as long, broadly elliptic or obovate, rounded at the apex, concave, glabrous, covered with a viscous secretion with a balsamic but not agreeable odor, green with a pink tinge; bracteoles 0. Disk bright orange. Calyx 1.25 cm long in flower, much enlarged in fruit, divided nearly to the base; segments 5, leathery, elliptic lanceolate, .4-.5 cm broad, obtuse, slightly penicillate at the apex softly pubescent, nerved. Corolla 3.75 cm long or more, with a white tube and purple limb, glabrous outside, with yellow hairs in the mouth inside; cylindric base of the tube narrow, shorter than the ventricose portion; lobes 5, rounded, 1.25 cm long, much crumpled in estivation. Stamens 4, didynamous; anthers oblong, 2-celled, muticous. Filaments of the longer stamens bearded. Ovary 2-celled; ovules 2 in each cell; style linear; stigma of one long linear branch, the other branch obsolete. Capsules 2 by .6 cm, obovoid, acute, apiculate, narrow at the base, 2-seeded. Seeds 1.25 by 1 cm, broadly ovate, acute, densely clothed with white appressed hairs.

author: L.
description: A deciduous tree sometimes reaching 35 m in height, often with short sharp strong axillary spines; bark thin, grey, smooth or rough with lenticels. Leaves 7.5-15 by 4.5-7.5 cm, broadly elliptic, acute, obtuse, or shortly acuminate, glabrous and shining, 5- nerved, base usually rounded; perioles .6-1.25 cm long. Flowers numerous, greenish-white, in terminal pedunculate pubescent compound cymes; penduncles and pedicels short, pubescent. Calyx .25 cm long, pubescent outside; segments 5, lanceolate, acute, .15 cm long. Corolla a little less than 1.25 cm long, 5-lobed, glaborous or nearly so outside; tube cylindric, hairy inside below, the throat glaborous; lobes .4 cm long, narrowly oblong, acute. Stamens 5, inserted in the throat of th corolla; filaments short, filiform; anthers ovate, with destinct parallel cells. Ovary and style glabrous. Fruit globose, 1.25-7.5 cm in diam., slighly rough but shining, orange-red whien ripe. Seeds usually many, discoid, abour 2 cm in diam., much compressed, concave on one side and convex on the other, clothed on both sides with very fine appressed grey silky hairs radiating from the centre.
pharmacology: Anti-HIV, hepatoprotective, anticholestatic, antilipid, peroxidative property, antiulcer, insecticidal, CNS stimulant. Strychnine showed remarkable negative chronotropic activity on frog isolated heart and guinea pig atria and activity retained in vivo also (open chest dog). Strychnine (50 mg/kg) when injected s.c. increased levels of acetylcholine in spinal cord and sustained convulsions in frog for 4 hr. Isostrychnine N-oxide and isobrucine N-oxide showed the most potent cytotoxicity to tumour cell lines of K562, Hela & HEP-2. C11ToxicologyC11 Nux-vomica is a powerful poison in large doses, producing titanic convulsions and eventually death and in lesser doses it may result in mental derangements. Toxic doses of strychnine and powdered seeds, respectively, for the different animals have been reported as follows: horse- 0.192-0.288, 19.2-28.8; ox-0.192-0.384, 19.2-33.6; pig-0.0096-0.048, 3.8-5.8; dog-0.0048-0.0192, 0.5-1.0g. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 Efficacy of Rasnadi Guggulu compound (consisting of I11Strychnos nuxvomica, Aconitum ferox, Semecarpus anacardium, Alpinia galanga, Pluchea lanceolataI11 and I11Commiphora mukulI11) on patients of rheumatoid arthritis was evaluated. It was found to be effective in reducing inflammatory oedema and management of rheumatoid arthritis. It also exhibited analgesic activity in experimental albino rats. A compound herbal preparation, containing I11Picrorhiza kurroa, Commiphora mukul,I11 Myrobalans (Triphala), I11Boerhaavia diffusaI11 and I11Strychnos nux-vomica I11 was evaluated in a clinical trial indicated alleviation of the symptoms within 4 days, whereas jaundice was reported to have disappeared in 80 per cent of the patients within 7 days. The drug restored the liver function to normal as assessed by a fall of serum bilirubin as well as SGOT and SGPT levels. No side effect was observed during therapy. 50 persons above the age of 60 (male and female), having geriatric problems, were treated with an Ayurvedic geriatric drug (dose 2 tabs, 3 times a day) for a period of 6 weeks. 32 persons showed benefit with reduction in their complaints. Others failed to show benefits. Drug improved the conditions of patients by improving bowel function, stimulation of appetite and rejuvenation. The drug contained medicinal plants like I11Crocus sativa, Myristica fragrans, Terminalia arjuna, Withania somnifera, Asparagus racemosusI11 and I11Strychnos nux-vomicaI11 etc. View Reference

Isostrychnine and an alkaloid N-methly-sec.-pseudo-Ã-colurbine isolated from seeds along with 4-hydroxystrychnine; improved method for extraction of strychnine and brucine from seeds; p-hydroxybenzoic, vanillic, 2-hydroxy-4-methoxybenzoic, sinapic and syringic acids and kaempferol, quercetin and 3â-O-methylquercetin present in plant (Curr. Sci. 1979,48,383); a new alkaloid-protostrychnine-isolated along with normacusine B and 4-hydroxy-3-methoxystrychnine and its structure elucidated.

author: (Wall.) Alston
description: A large evergreen shrub or small tree, very handsome when in full flower; bark pale-brown; branchlets slender, obsoletely 4-angled or terete, purplish-brown, shining. Leaves opposite, exstipulate, aromatically fragrant when bruised, coriaceous, variable, 3.75-10 by 1.5-3.75 cm, ovate-elliptic to linear-lanceolate, usually caudate-acuminate, smooth and shining on both surfaces, paler and minutely glandular beneath, the margins slightly curved, base acute; amin nerves numerous, inconspicuous, uniting into an inconspicuous intramarginal nerve near the edge; petioles .25-.6 cm long. Flowers white, conspicuous, in axillary and terminal many-flowered paniculate cymes, in clusters of 3-5 at the ends of the ultimate cyme-branches. Calyx funnel-shaped, .5 cm long, tubercled with glands on the outside, sessile or nearly so; lobes 4-5, broadly ovate or rotundate, concave, erect. Petals 4-5, orbicular usually calyptrate but sometimes imperfectly so. Stamens â, filaments filiform; anthers small, versatile, dehiscing longitudinally. Ovary inferior, 2-celled; ovules many in each cell; style filifrom; stigma small. Fruit pisiform, less than .6 cm in diam., pure white, 1-seeded.

author: R. Br.
description: A well known glabrous much-branched shrub with pale bark. Leaves 7.5-15 by 2-3.75 cm, lanceolate or oblong, acuminate; main nerves 7-9 pairs; petioles .5-.8 cm long. Flowers snow-white, fragrant at nightm inodorous during the day. Calyx small; lobes 5, glandular inside, imbricate. Corolla hypocrateriform; corolla-tube 2-2.5 cm long, the mouth naked; lobes overlapping to the left. There is a long- and a short-styled form, the pistil measuring in the first about 1.25 cm and in the second .6 cm long. The long-styled form has the anthers in the middle of the corolla-tube, the other at 1/3 its length from the base. Carpels of the ovary 2, sometimes slightly coherent; ovules numerous in each carpel, many-seriate; style usually long, filiform; stigma at the level of the anthers, clavate or oblong-ellipsoid with a slender papillose bifid apiculus.

author: L.
description: A large tree 12-20 m high; branches spreading, glabrous. Leaves compound, abruptly pinnate, 5-12.5 cm long; rhachis slender, channeled; stipules linear, caduceus. Leaflets subsessile, 10-20 pairs, tolerably closely set on rhachis, .8-3 by .5-.8 cm, oblong, obtuse, glabrous, reticulately veined. Flowers in lax few-flowered racemes at the ends of the branchlets; pedicels .6-1 cm long, slender, articulated below the calyx, glabrous; bracts concave, .6-.8 cm long, enclosing the buds, caducous; bracteoles small. Calyx 1.25 cm long; tube narrowly turbinate, .4 cm long; segments .8 cm long, subequal, oblong, somewhat oblique, obtuse or subacute. Petals 3 (an upper and 2 lateral, other 2 reduced to scales), 1 cm long, subequal obovate-oblong, yellowish with pink stripes. Stamens monadelphous, only 3 developed, the others reduced to more bristles at the top of the sheath; anthers oblong, dehiscing longitudinally, filaments pubescent at the base. Ovary stalked; ovules 8-12 or more; style pubescent, equaling the stamens. Pods 7.5-20 cm long by 2.5 cm broad and about 1 cm thick, slightly curved, subcompressed, scurfy. Seeds 3-12 obovate-oblong, truncate at the ends, 1.5 by .75 cm compressed with a shallow oblong pit on each of the flat faces, smooth, brown, shining.
pharmacology: Antiinflammatory, antifungal, immunomodulatory, antioxidative, insecticidal. author: G. Don.
description: A shrub or small tree with drooping branches and stellately grey-tomentose innovations, otherwise glabrous. Leaves simple, 5-12.5 by 1-3 cm, narrowly oblong, obtuse, entire with undulate margins. Flowers inodorous, in corymbose few-flowered racemes terminating short lateral braches; peicels .6-1.25 cm long. Calyx 1-1.1 cm long, companulate; 5-toothed, lobes .3 cm long, broadly ovate, obtuse, mucronate. Corolla 3.75-6.25 cm long, orange yellow, campanulate, veined; lobes 5, subequal, rounded. Stamens exserted; filaments glabrous. Stigma 2-lamellate; lobes spathulate-oblong, rounded. Ovary with numerous ovules in each cell. author: (Roxb. ex DC.) Wight & Arn.
description: A large tree reaching 25 m high, with a very thick trunk and horizontally spreading branches; barks thick, smooth, greenish-white, flaking off in large flat pieces. Leaves usually subopposite, 10-15 by 4.5-7 cm, oblong or elliptic-oblong, obtuse or subacute, pale dull green above, pale brown beneath, shallowly crenate-serrate in the upper part or sometimes throughout base rounded or cordate, often unequal-sided; main nerves arcuate, 10-15 pairs, veins reticulate, pellucid; petioles .61 cm long, with 1 or usually 2 prominent glands at the top immediately below the leaves. Flowers sessile, in short axillart spikes or in terminal panicles; bracteoles linear-lanceolate, shorter than the flowers, caducous. Calyx glabrous, .4 cm long; mouth broadly campanulate; teeth triangular, .15 cm long. Petals 0. Disk clothed with yellowish or redish hairs. Stamens 10, much exserted, inserted on the calyx-lobes, biseriate, the 5 lower opposite the calyx-teeth, the 5 upper longer and alternat with the calyx-teeth; filaments subulate or filiform, exserted. Ovary inferior, 1-celled, quite glabrous. Drupe 2.5-5 cm long, ovoid or obovoid-oblong, fibroys-woody, glabrous, dark-brown, with 5 hard projecting wings striated with numerous curved veins.

pharmacology: Cardio protective, anti-anginal, spasmogenic, oxytocic, antifertility, cytotoxic, antifungal, antibacterial, hepatoprotective. The stem bark of I11T. arjunaI11 is a potent antihypercholesterolaemic agent. It reduced the total cholesterol, LDL, VLDL, free fatty acids, phospholipids and triglycerides and elevated HDL in hypercholesterolaemic rabbits. Seventy per cent ethanolic extract of the stem bark showed hypotensive and bradycardiac effects in experimental animals. Aqueous and 95 percent ethanolic extracts exhibited myocardial depressant property . Polar fraction of ethanolic extract relaxed norepinephrine contracted rat aorta. Stem bark increased endogenous superoxide dismutase and reduced glutathione, catalase and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances in the heart. It also protected the heart from oxidative stress ischaemic-reperfusion injury in vitro. Clinically stem bark extract demonstrated antianginal activity and ameliorative effect in hypertension and heart failure. Ethanolic extract showed antifertility activity in albino rats and antifungal activity against dermatophytes. Methanolic extract and ellagic acid isolated from the stem bark showed antimutagenic activity. C11ToxicologyC11 LDB1150B11 of the aqueous extract of the bark is 250 mg /kg. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 Several studies have been made to assess the efficacy of I11Terminalia arjunaI11 bark in cardiac disorders. Decoction of bark powder was found more useful in hypertensive heart disease as compared to congestive heart failure. Alcoholic decoction of bark was found to be beneficial in stable cases of ischaemic heart disease. Prolonged use of this drug brought sense of well being in patients and increased euglobulin lysis time and prothrombin time. The drug also showed electrocardiographic improvement. A particular patient, an adult male who developed Strokes- Adams attacks following acute chest pain, became well after three months use of crude powder of I11T. arjuna.I11 In another study 500 mg crude powder of I11T. arjunaI11was administered in 30 stable angina pain. It was also noted to be useful in cases of ischaemic heart diseases associated with rhythm disturbances, particularly premature beats. The drug was found to be beneficial in modifying various known coronary risk factors like obesity, hypertension, hyperglycaemia and circulating catecholamines in these patients. No significant side effects were observed in these patients. Solidified aqueous extract of Arjuna bark when administered in doses of 500 mg b.d. for 3 months along with antianginal drugs proved useful in reducing Tread mill test positivity and increase in exercise tolerance in 25 patients of Angina pectoris. However there was no reduction in composition of antianginal drugs. A clinical trial was taken on 51 patients of coronary heart disease to assess the effect of I11T. arjuna.I11 All the patients were administered with 2 cap of 500 mg each containing Arjuna bark powder in morning break fast and in evening after meal with milk. The patients were advised to walk in fresh air with a gradual increment in distance with permission of yogic exercise, if any already doing. This treatment was continued for four months followed up each month. The studies revealed statistically significant positive results. Reduction in systolic and diastolic blood pressure, pulse rate, serum cholesterol and HDL and LDL cholesterol was noticed. The patients suffering from Vvyana-Bala-Vaishamya vis-Ã -vis hypertension are at risk for cardiovascular diseases. Borderline hypertensives or patients with high systolic blood pressure are equally at risk as per W.H.O expert meet. The modern medicines are associated with so many side effects. Thus a lead was taken to formulate a combination with Ayurvedic drugs which can affect the severity of hypertension. The extracts of Arjuna, Vacha, Brahmi and Jatamansi when combined in equal doses were administered to 22 hypertensive patients with no lipid derangements. A symptomatic improvement with fall in blood â pressure (both systolic and diastolic) was noted. The improvement was slow and steady and was maximum after 3 months of treatment with Arjuna Vacadi Yoga (given compound). Various symptoms viz., Anidra, Dourbalya, Shirahshoola, Kshubdhata, Shrama and Brahma were grade as per their severity and recorded. A shift in symptoms grade score was observed after three months of treatment i.e. patients showed a generalized improvement. Administration of a herbal drug containing I11Terminalia arjuna, Emblica officinalis, Ocimum sanctumI11 and I11Withania somniferaI11resulted in significant reduction in systolic and diastolic blood pressure. There was a significant reduction in body mass index in patients treated with drug when compared to those conventional drugs alone. Similarly, a significant decline in levels of serum cholesterol, triglycerides and elevation in HDL cholesterol was observed at the end of three months in the indigenous drug group patients. About 6.7 per cent patients in this group developed fresh ST-T changes as compared to improvement in left ventricular ejection fraction and reduction in left ventricular mass was also noted in this group. No major clinical or biochemical side effects were noted in patients on adjuvant indigenous therapy. On the basis of available experimental evidences, the drug is considered as cardio protective, and not as cardiotonic as previously assumed. Its antianginal properties along with its potentials of modifying various coronary risk factors opens up larger opportunities for its use in primary and secondary prevention of ischaemic heart disease. author: (Gaertn.) Roxb.
description: A large handsome tree 12-20 m high. Leaves collected about the extremities of the branches, alternate, coriaceous, 10-20 by 7.5-15 cm, broadly elliptic or elliptic-obovate, rounded or rarely subacute or shortly acuminate at the apex, both surfaces puberulous when young, glabrous and reticulate when old, the margins entire, pellucid, base narrowed; main nerves 6-8 pairs, spreading, prominent, the midrib prominent on both sides; petioles 4.5-10 cm long, without glands at the apex. Flowers pale greenish-yellow, with an offensive odour, in axillary slender spikes longer than the petioles but shorter than the leaves, those in the upper part of the spike male, very shortly pedicelled, those in the lower part hermaphrodite, sessile. Calyx pubescent outside, densely villous within, the teeth broadly triangular acute. Petals absent. Stamens 10, inserted on the calyx-lobes, biseriate, the 5 lower opposite the calyx-teeth, the 5 upper longer and alternat with the calyx-teeth; filaments exserted. Ovary inferior, 1-celled; ovules 2-3, pendulous from the apex of the cell; style subulate, often thickened and villous at the base; stigma simple. Drupe 1.25-2.5 cm in diam., suddenly narrowed into a very short stalk, clothed with minute pale tomentum, obscurely angled when dried.

pharmacology: Purgative, blood pressure depressant, antifungal, antihistaminic, activity against viral hepatitis and vitiligo, antiasthmatic, broncho-dilatory, anti-spasmodic antibacterial, CNS stimulant, amoebicidal, antistress and endurance promoting activity. The lignans isolated from I11T. belliricaI11 were shown to possess anti-HIV, antimalarial and antifungal activities. C11ToxicologyC11 The active crude alcoholic extract were assayed for cellular toxicity to fresh sheep erythrocytes and found to have no cellular toxicity. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 A clinical trial to evaluate antitussive and antiasthmatic effect of Bibhitaka was conducted on 93 cases of different age groups ranging from 1 to 79 years. 61 cases were suffering from Kasa (cough) of different types, 12 cases from Shwasa (dyspnoea) and 20 cases from Kasa-Shwasa mixed in nature (cough with dyspnoea). Powder of Bibhitaka whole fruit (rind with nut) was administered orally in doses ranging from 2-6 gm thrice daily with fresh water. 22 cases had complete relief with no pathological abnormality, 27 cases showed significant relief, whereas 35 cases showed only symptomatic improvement and marked as moderately relieved. The observations and results reflected that Bibhitaka possesses bronchodilatory, antispasmodic, antiphlegmatic, expectorant, sedative and antiasthmatic effects. Under a clinical trial twenty five diabetic patients were treated with Siddha medicines viz., Kadal Azhinjil (I11Salacia chinensisI11) Triphala (combination of I11Terminalia chebula, T. BelliricaI11and I11Phyllanthus EmblicaI11 fruits. Out of 25 patients, 4 showed 50%, 11 showed 40-50% and 6 less than 40% reduction in blood sugar after 4 months of treatment. The urine sugar was brought down much earlier than blood sugar. A clinical study was conducted on 50 cases of vitiligo with a compound herbomineral preparation, viz., Ayush-57, containing I11Terminalia belliricaI11 as one of the ingredients. After 12 weeks of treatment 20 cases showed improvement. The results indicate stimulation of pigment metabolism. However, no concrete conclusion was drawn as the treatment required longer period and bigger samples to declare the utility of the drug. In a preliminary clinical trial on patients of bleeding piles, oral administration of multiherbal composite drug containing I11Berberis aristata, Holarrhena antidysenterica, Picrorrhiza kurroa, Mesua ferrea, Terminalia chebula, T. belericaI11 and I11Emblica officinalisI11 to 22 patients showed significant decrease in bleeding and constipation by the fourth week of therapy. description: A moderate-sized, much-branched deciduous tree. Leaves 6.25-15 by 3.75-7.5 cm, not clustered, alternate or subopposite, elliptic-oblong, acute, penninerved, when young with silky hairs, glabrous or nearly so when mature, rounded or cordate at the base; petioles 1.25-2.5 cm long, pubescent, usually with 2 glands near their summit. Flowers all hermaphrodite, in terminal (often panicled) spikes; bracteoles exceeding the flowers, linear, acute, hairy, conspicuous among the buds bu the soon deciduous. Calyx campanulate, .3 cm long, flat at the base, expanding a little towards the mouth, glabrous outside, hairy within; teeth 5, short, sometimes obscure. Petals absent. Stamens 10, inserted on the calyx-lobes, biseriate, the 5 lower opposite the calyx-teeth, the 5 upper longer and alternat with the calyx-teeth; filaments exserted. Ovary inferior, 1-celled; ovules 2-3, pendulous from the apex of the cell; style subulate, often thickened and villous at the base; stigma simple. Drupe pendulous, 1-3.75 cm long, ellipsoid or obovoid from a board base, glabrous, more or less 5-ribbed when dry, yellowish-green; stone oblong, bony, very thick, obscurely angled.

Therapeutic Evaluation Under a clinical trial 25 diabetic patients were treated with Siddha medicines viz., Kadal Azhinjil (I11Salacia chinensisI11) and Triphala (combination of I11Terminalia chebula, T. belliricaI11 and I11Phyllanthus emblicaI11 fruits). Out of 25 patients, 4 showed 50%, 11 showed 40-50% and 6 less than 40% reduction in blood sugar after 4 months of treatment. The urine sugar was brought down much earlier than blood sugar. A clinical study was conducted on 50 cases of vitiligo with a compound herbomineral preparation, viz., Ayush-57, containing I11Terminalia chebulaI11 as one of the ingredients. After 12 weeks of treatment required longer period and bigger samples to declare the utility of the drug. A clinical trial 240 patients of upper gastro intestinal haemorrhage were treated with liquid I11Galla chinensisI11 composite, consisting of I11Galla chinensis, T. chebulaI11 and alum. 237 patients were completely cured and the haemostatic rate after single dose was 98.7%. This solution was found to be more effective in haemorrhage caused by peptic ulcer than that of gastric carcinoma. It had no side effects. In a preliminary clinical trial on patients of bleeding piles oral administration of multiherbal composite drug containing I11Berberis aristata, Holarrhena antidysenterica, Picrorrhiza kurroa, Mesua ferrea, Terminalia chebula, T. belericaI11 and I11Emblica officinalisI11 to 22 patients showed significant decrease in bleeding and constipation by the fourth week of therapy. Author : Retz.
Family : Combretaceae
Basic Description of Plant : A moderate-sized, much-branched deciduous tree. Leaves 6.25-15 by 3.75-7.5 cm, not clustered, alternate or subopposite, elliptic-oblong, acute, penninerved, when young with silky hairs, glabrous or nearly so when mature, rounded or cordate at the base; petioles 1.25-2.5 cm long, pubescent, usually with 2 glands near their summit. Flowers all hermaphrodite, in terminal (often panicled) spikes; bracteoles exceeding the flowers, linear, acute, hairy, conspicuous among the buds bu the soon deciduous. Calyx campanulate, .3 cm long, flat at the base, expanding a little towards the mouth, glabrous outside, hairy within;

author: Roth.
description: A large deciduous tree; young parts rusty-tomentose. Leaves coriaceous, the upper alternate, the lower subopposite, 10-22 by 4.5-9 cm, oblong, acute or acuminate, nearly glabrous or with a few scattered hairs above (when adult), pale-brown, more or less pubescent and finely reticulately veined beneath, usually with 2 glands near the base of the midrib below, base cordate or rounded, often inequilateral; main nerves 10-15 pairs, arcuate, parallel; petioles 1.25-1.5 cm long, pubescent. Flowers sessile, in slender spikes forming compound panicles; bracts at the forks .3-.5 cm long, ovate, recurved; bracteoles .2 cm long, acuminate from a triangular base, recurved. Calyx (free portion) .2 cm long, reddish-brown, globose when in bud, afterwards cup-shaped; teeth broadly triangular, as long as the free portion of the calyx-tube, glabrous or nearly so outside, densely villous within. Petals absent. Stamens 10, inserted on the alyx-lobes, biseriate, the 5 lower opposite the calyx-teeth, the 5 upper longer and alternat with the calyx-teeth. Disk densely clothed with long yellowish-white hairs. Ovary inferior, 1-celled, densely and softly pubescent; ovules 2-3, pendulous from the apex of the cell; style subulate, often thickened and villous at the base; stigma simple. Fruit rusty-tomentose, .6-1.25 cm long, sessile, closely set in dense spreading panicles, 3-winged, 2 of the wings much smaller than the other.

author: (L.) Soland ex Correa.
description: A small tree. Leaves 7.5-15 cm long, broadly ovate, cordate, acuminate, entire, smooth, finely reticulately veined, with 5-7 prominent nerves and often a glandular pore in one or more of the intercostals spaces beneath, sometimes with a few minute peltate scales on one or both surfaces; petioles 5-10 cm long; stipules subulate, deciduous. Inflorescence axillary, pedicels 5-7.5 cm long, shorter or longer than the petioles. Involucral bracts 0 or 5, lanceolate, shorter than the calyx, caducous. Calyx truncate, covered with minute peltate scales; teeth 5, minute, sometimes obscure. Corolla 5-7.5 cm in diam., yellow with purple base. Staminal tube toothed at the apex. Capsules globose, 2.5 cm in diam., covered with minute peltate scales, surrounded at the base by the persistent calyx. Seeds .3 cm long, ovoid, channeled along the back, pubescent.

author: L.
description: A perennial with a woody fibrous root. The stems are numerous, round, hard, branched, and usually from 10 to 20 cm high. The leaves are small, only about .3 cm long and .15 cm broad, narrow and elliptical, greenish-grey in colour, reflexed at the margins, and set in pairs upon very small foot-stalks. The flowers terminate the branches in whorls. The calyx is tubular, striated, closed at the mouth with small hairs and divided into two lips, the uppermost cut into three teeth and the lower into two. The corolla consists of a tube about the length of the calyx, spreading at the top into two lips of a pale purple colour, the upper lip erect or turned back and notched at the end, the under lip longer and divided into three segments. The seeds are roundish and very small.
chemical_composition: Extractive of stems and leaves possessed maximum antibacterial activity against Staphylococcus aureus ans Escherichia coli at flowering time (Ziva 1958, 6, 164; Chem. Abstr. 1960, 54, 2657 f).

author: (Willd.) Hook. f. & Thoms.
description: An extensive glabrous climber; bark corky, grooved. Leaves membranous. 7-nerved, 5-9 cm long, roundish or subdeltoid, cordate with a broad sinus, reticulately veined, glabrous on both surfaces, subglaucous beneath; petioles up to 7.5 cm long. Racemes often much longer than the leaves, axillary, terminal or from the old wood. Flowers yellow, the males fascicled, the females usually solitary; pedicels slender; bracts lanceolate-subulate, the lower sometimes foliaceous. MALE FLOWERS: Sepals; the 3 outer very small, ovate-oblong acute; the 3 inner larger, membranous, suborbicular, concave. Petals; each loosely embracing a stamen, claw cuneate, lamina triquetrous or sub-trilobed, reflexed at the apex. Stamens 6; filaments free, thickened at the apex; anther-cells dehiscing longitudinally by an oblique, almost marginal slit. FEMALE FLOWERS: Petals cuneate-oblong, with entire (not reflexed) margins. Staminodes 6, clavate. Ovaries3; stigmas forked. Drupes 1-3, dorsally convex, ventrally nearly flat, red, size of a large pea; style-scar subterminal.
pharmacology: Hypoglycaemic, antihyperglycaemic, CNS depressant, antibacterial, antimicrobial, antipyretic, antiinflammatory, antiarthritic, antiallergic, hepatoprotective, analgesic. Immunosuppressive, immunostimulant, antileishmanial, antioxidant, antiendotoxic, hypotensive, diuretic. The water and ethanolic extract of stem inhibited the cyclophosphamide induced immunosuppression. Aqueous extract of the stem showed antiinflammatory, analgesic and antipyretic properties in rats. In clinical studies, it also showed immunosuppressive effect in obstructive jaundice patients, antioxidant activity and amelioration of cyclophosphamide-induced toxicity. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 A composite herbal drug containing I11Tinospora cordifolia, Withania somnifera, Myristica fragrans, Eclipta alba, Bergenia ligulata, Asparagus racemousI11and I11Tribulus terrestrisI11 has been found to be efficacious in 30 patients of calculi. It has been reported that the calculi were discharged through urine as calcium carbonate or calcium oxalate crystals within 15-30 days. Other symptoms associated with calculi were also relieved of. A compound preparation composed of I11Cinnamomum tamala, Aegle Marmelos , Gymnema sylvestre, Pterocarpus marsupium, Azadirachta indica, Tinospora cordifoliaI11and I11Trigonella foenum-graecumI11was tried in 20 patients of diabetes. Dose was determined on the basis of conditions of patients as 2 capsules t.d.s to insulin dependent cases, 2 capsules b.d. to moderate cases and 1 capsule t.d.s to mild diabetics for atleast 3 weeks. It was concluded that the drug provides a total beneficial therapy in all types if diabetics and tends to increase insulin secretion from islets of pancreas. A compound proprietary medicine containing I11Mucuna prureinsI11 (seeds), I11Tinospora cordifoliaI11 (stem), I11Withania somniferaI11 (stem), I11Glycyrrhiza glabraI11 (stem), I11Myristica fragransI11 (fruit) and I11Tribulus terrestrisI11 (fruit) was administered orally (2 tablets b.d.) to 56 patients of sexual dysfunction for 4 weeks. An excellent improvement in erection, duration of coitus and ejaculation and post-coital satisfaction has been reported. In another trial 60 cases with specific sexual problems were treated with the same medicine in doses of 2 tablets twice a day and its effects on sexual performance of two third cases showed subjective improvement ranging from 25% to 100%. The remaining one third were refractory to the treatment. Efficacy of a proprietary herbal preparation consisting of I11Eugenia jambolana, Tinospora cordifolia, Pterocarpus marsupium, Ficus glomerata, Momordica charantiaI11and I11Ocimum sanctumI11 was evaluated on 28 cases of persistant post prandial hyperglycaemia. After 12 weeks of treatment a persistant fall in fasting and post prandial blood glucose levels was recorded. A clinical trial was taken on 25 patients of type II diabetes to study the adjuvant effect of a herbo-mineral proprietary preparation in which I11Tinospora cordifoliaI11 was one of the constituents. The drug contained 19 administered in the doses of 1-2 tablets t.d.s in addition to the regular sulphylureas over a period of 6 weeks. The herbo-mineral preparation showed improvement in glycaemic parameters, viz., fasting blood sugar levels, post lunch blood sugar levels and Fructosamine levels. This indicates the proprietary medicine is useful adjuvant in poorly controlled type âII diabetes. In a clinical trial of 20 patients of infective hepatitis were treated with tablets prepared from stem of I11T. cordifolia.I11 Four tablets (500 mg. each) were administered thrice daily with fresh water for 4 weeks. The majority of the cases i.e. 15 cases (75%) were cured and 5 cases (25% ) were improved. 34 cases suffering from amavata (rehumatoid arthritis) were treated with Suddha guggulu and Guduchyadi kwatha for 6 weeks at Regional Research Institute (Ayurveda), Jaipur. The cases were assessed weekly and clinical observations made by the physicians. The results noted after 6 weeks showed that 27 cases had marked relief and 4 cases moderate relief. View Reference

Drupes 1-3 (usually 2), ovoid, smooth, red, on thick stalks; endocarp marked externally with many sharp-pointed tubercles.

author: Gamble
description: A large sarmentose shrub usually armed with sharp curved or straight prickles. Leaves 3-foliolate; leaflets coriaceous, sessile, 3.75-9 by 2-3.75, lanceolate-oblong or obovate, usually with a long blunt acumen, notched at the apex, crenulate or sub- entire, glabrous, many nerved, the midrib often prickly, base acute. Flowers white, .5-.8 cm across, in axillary cymes. Calyx small, glandular; lobes triangular. Petals 5, oblong, thickened at the apex, imbricate. Disk inconspicuous slightly elongate. MALE FLOWERS: Petals shorter than the stamens; buds globose. Ovary (rudimentary) cylindric-oblong, grooved, seated on a lobed disk. FEMALE FLOWERS: Petals longer than in the male; buds oblong. Stigma sessile, 5-7 lobed. Fruit globose, size of a large pea, 3-5 grooved, orange-colored, pitted on the rind, 3-7 celled. Seed solitary in each cell, smooth, reniform, rounded on the back.

author: L.
description: A procumbent herb; stems and branches pilose; young parts silky-villous. Leaves opposite, abruptly pinnate, one of each pair usually smaller than the other, sometimes wanting; stipules lanceolate, hairy; leaflets 3-6 pairs, .6-1.25 cm long, oblong, mucronate, sericeo-villous with appressed hairs beneath and more or less so on the upper surface, base rounded oblique; petiolules very short, pilose. Flowers axillary or leaf-opposed, solitary; pedicels 1.25-2 cm long, slender, hairy. Sepals .6 cm long, lanceolate, acute, hairy. Petals 1 cm long, oblong-obovate; claw short, hairy. Disk annular, 10-lobed. Ovary bristly; style short, stout; stigmatic lobes longer than the diameter of the style. Fruit globose, consisting of (usually) 5 hairy or nearly glabrous, often muriculate, woody cocci, each with 2 pairs of hard sharp spines, one pair longer than the other. Seeds several in each coccus, with transverse partitions between them.

pharmacology: Hypotensive, CNS stimulant, spasmogenic, analgesic, vasodepressant, muscle relaxant, cardiotonic, diuretic, antiurolithiatic, antibacterial, antifungal, antimicrobial, molluscicidal, cytotoxic activity on FL-cells, hepatoprotective, cytoprotective, anticonvulsant. C11ToxicologyC11 The seeds of I11T. terrestrisI11were found to be toxic to the liver of rats. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 14 patients of Vrikkasmari (renal calculi) and 16 patients of Gavini-asmari (ureteric calculi) were treated with a herbinomineral combination containing Bergenia ligulata and I11Tribulus terrestris.I1128.57% patient of renal calculi and 75% patients of ureteric calculi passed their calculi completely and in other patients there was marked or partial expulsion of calculi or dislogdement of calculi or there was change in shapes, sizes and consistencies of calculi. A composite herbal drug containing I11Tinospora cordifolia, Withania somnifera, Myristica fragrans. Eclipta alba, Bergenia ligulata, Asparagus racemousI11and I11Tribulus terrestrisI11has been found to be efficacious in 30 patients calculi. It has been reported that calculi were discharged through urine as calcium carbonate or calcium oxalate crystals within 15-30 days. Other symptoms associated with calculi were relieved of. A compound preparation containing I11Mucuna prureinsI11 (seeds), I11Tinospora cordifoliaI11 (stem), I11Withania somniferaI11 (stem), I11Glycyrrhiza glabraI11 (stem), I11Myristica fragransI11 (fruit) and I11Tribulus terrestris I11 (fruit) was administered orally (2 tablets b.d) to 56 patients of sexual dysfunction fro 4 weeks. An excellent improvement in erection, duration of coitus and ejaculation and post-coital satisfaction has been reported. A compound preparation, containing I11Tribulus terrestrisI11 as one of the ingredients, administered to patients, 2 tablets two times a day for 10 to 21 days, was found effective in urolithiasis and crystalluria without any side effects. A compound preparation, containing Gokshura, Varuna, Amalaki and Punarnava, administered to a patient suffering from Polycythaemia vera, in a dose of 20 ml decoction twice a day for 15 days and continued for three months, brought Hb%, RBC, WBC, PCV, ESR, blood urea, platelet count to normal level. Varunadi kvatha (a composite Ayurvedic drug containing I11Crataeva religiosa, Tribulus terrestris, Zingiber officinale, Bergenia ligulata, Woodfordia FruticosaI11and Jaggery) was given in dose of 20 ml with water before lunch and dinner to 50 patients having urinary complaints. Excellent results were obtained in 64%of the patients and 26% showed moderate relief. In a clinical study, 406 cases of coronary heart disease were treated with saponin of I11Tribulus terrestris.I11 The results showed that the saponin has the action of dilating coronary artery and improving the coronary circulation. It has shown better effects on improving ECG of myocardial ischaemia as compared to control group treated with a Chinese medicine. It has no adverse reaction on blood system and hepatic and renal systems. Neither has it had any side effects. Effect of Dashmula, of which I11Tribulus terrestrisI11 is one of the constituents, on management of sensory and motor disorders pertaining to sympathetic and parasympathetic outflow amongst the patients presenting with primary neurological disorders have been investigated. A significant improvement in the nerve conduction velocity was observed. The pattern of âHâ reflex also improved in all these patients along with clinical response. Out of 50 patients of nutritional neuropathy 40 patients showed improvement in nerve conduction velocity. Similarly lumbago-sciatica syndrome also showed remarkable improvement. View Reference

author: (Burm. f.) R. Br.
description: Annual, erect, 30-60 cm high; stem stout, often purplish, and, stem as well as the braches, clothed with long soft hairs. Leaves 5-10 by 1.25-2.5 cm, lanceolate-oblong, acute or subobtuse, densely clothed above with short stiff hairs from bulbous white bases, finely pubescent and with a few pustular hairs beneath base usually narrowed; petioles .4-1.25 cm long, often obscure or almost 0. Flowers light-blue, numerous, usualy in terminal bracteate paniculate cymes; pedicels 1.25-2 cm long, slender, hairy, nodding; bracts foliaceous. Calyx divided to the base or nearly so, 5-fid, clothed with soft appressed hairs, rounded at the base; segments .8 cm long at flowering time, lanceolate, acute, with strong midrib, pubscent inside. Corolla-tube .5 cm long, campanulate; lobes 5, about .15 cm long, somewhat obovate, rounded, plicate, with a suden spirally twisted acumination .25 cm long from a triangular base; cone of the anthers .6 cm long, densely hairy at the back; anthers lanceolate, hairy at the base. Ovary 4-lobed, ovoid, glabrous; style .6 cm long, slender, glabrous; stigma minute. Fruit pyramidal; nutlets 4; nutlets .4-.5 cm long, broadly ovoid, subobtuse, faintly margined, the inner face slightly rugose, the back smooth and polished, grey when ripe.

author: L.
description: A straggling herb 30-60 cm high, branched at the base; stem and branches hairy. Leaves opposite, 2.5-4.5 by 2-2.5 cm, ovate-elliptic, acute, deeply inciso-dentate or pinnatisect, clothed on both sides with short hairs from glandular bases, base acute; petioles 1-1.25 cm long, densely hairy. Heads 1.25-1.5 cm in diam., solitary; peduncles very long, sometimes exceeding 30-35 cm long, slender, sparsely clothed with weak spreading white hairs. Outer invol.-bracts very hairy, ovate, acuminate; inner bracts membranous, oblong, slightly longer than the outer, pubescent on the back. Ray-flowers ligulate, the ligules yellow, deeply 3-pertile, the middle lobe the smallest; the upper lip obsolete; tube of the corolla hairy. Pappus of numerous slightly unequal aristate feathery bristles. Achenes .2 cm long, oblong, densely silky-hairy, black.
phenology: Flowers: more or less throughout the year.
chemical_composition: Juice from leaves (1 ml/day, i.p.) resembled dexamethasone in depressing wound contraction and granulation process of wounds in rabbits (Indian J. Physiol. Pharmacik, 1983,27,32).
