Leaves simple, variable, stipules subulate; lower leaves 5-7.5 cm in diam., usually 3-lobed, irregularly serrate, clothed with simple and stellate hairs on both surfaces and simple hairs on the nerves beneath, base, cordate or both surfaces and simple hairs on the beneath, base cordate or cuneate, the petioles up to 3.75 cm long, more or less hairy; upper leaves usually simple, with very short petioles. Flowers .6 cm across, yellow, dense terminal and leaf-opposed cymes; buds oblong apiculate; peduncles and pedicels very short; bracts subulate. Sepals 5, oblong, hooded and apiculate at the apex. Petals 5, shorter than the sepals, obovate-oblong, ciliate at the base; claw very long. Stamens 8-15, inserted on the glandular torus, free. Ovary 5-celled; ovules 2 in each cell; style filiform. Fruit .4 cm in diameter, the surface at the base of the spines araneously pubescent; spines glabrous, the bristle points hooked, very slender, transparent.

author: Wall. ex Wight & Arn.
description: A large tree; young parts glabrous; branches terete. Leaves compound, 15-38 cm long, opposite, stipulate, usually imparipinnate; rhachis glabrous; stipules intrapetiolar, triangular, caducous; leaflets 3-9, opposite, 6.25-20 by 2.5-7.5 cm oblong-lanceolate, shortly acuminate, finely serrate, glabrous and shining; main nerves 5-6 pairs, distant, ascending; petiolules of the lateral leaflets .6-.8 cm, of the terminal ones upto 5 cm long; stipels lanceolate-subulate, caducous. Flowers numerous, near the ends of the branches, in lax axillary and terminal panicles shorter than the leaves; pedicels glabrous. Flowers white, small, regular, hermaphrodite. Calyx 5-fid, imbricate, persistent, lobes oblong, obtuse ciliate. Petals 5, sessile, imbricate, white, oblong, obtuse, slightly exceeding the calyx, ciliate. Disk raised, crenate or lobed. Stamens 5, inserted outside the disk between the lobes; filaments flattened. Stamens about equaling the petals or a little shorter; filaments glabrous. Ovary sessile, 3-lobed, 3-celled; broadly ovoid, glabrous, furrowed, tapering into a stout style. Fruit globose, smooth, purplish-black, 1.25-2.5 cm in diam.; pericarp fleshy. Seeds angular, shining, dark brown.

pharmacology: The major alkaloid of I11T. indicaI11, tylophorine, was found to produce CNS depression characterized by ptosis, sedation, decreased motor activity, staggering gait; potentiation of pentobarbitone sleeping time, antiinflammatory activity in cotton pellet implantation technique and granuloma pouch. It inhibited the primary and secondary response of adjuvant-induced arthritis in rats. In a double blind trail of bronchial asthma and allergic rhinitis patients, I11T. indicaI11was found to be useful. The phenanthroindolizidine alkaloids showed activity against hepatic and intestinal amoebiasis. View Reference
chemical_composition: Tylophorine, kaempferol, S224-amyrin and quercetin, other major alkaloids like tylophorinine, tylophorinidine, anhydrodehydrotylophorinine, (+)- Septicine and (+)-isotylocrebrine from fresh leaf . Three alkaloids A,B and C isolated; alkaloids B and C characterised as desmethylylophorine and desmethyltylophorinine respectively; crystal structure of tylophorinidine and relative stereochemistry of tylophorinine and tylophorinidine; (+)septicine and (+)isotylocrebrine also isolated from fresh leaves; dehydrotylophorine, anhydrodehydrotylophorinine and anhydrodehydrotylophorinidine isolated; stereochemistry of tylophorinine and tylophorinidine; absolute configuration of tylophorine; tylophorine and tylophorinine content in leaves is a function of plant growth phase and is highest during flowering period; S226-fagarine and skimmianine isolated from roots and aerial parts.

author: (L.) Bross Wal.
description: Herbaceous, erect, .5-1.25 m high. Leaves usually broader than long, upto 11.25 by 15 cm cordate, serrate or toothed, stellately hairy on both surfaces, roundish, angled; lobes generally acute or acuminate varying in size and number (3-10 or more), not extending half way down, sometimes nearly obsolete; nerves 5-7, prominent beneath, with often a gland at the base of the midrib and sometimes on the 2 adjacent nerves; petioles variable in length, 1.25-15 cm long, hairy. Flowers clustered. Pedicels hairy, involucral bracts 5, equaling or slightly exceeding the calyx and alternate with its lobes, linear-oblong, acute, united at the base into a cup, clothed with rigid hairs. Calyx deeply divided; lobes 5, less than .6 cm long, lanceolate, ciliate. Corolla 1.5 cm long, petals 5, connate below, united to the staminal tube, pink. Staminal-tube bearing short filaments or subsessile anthers below the truncate or 5-toothed apex. Ovary 5-celled; cells 1-ovuled; branches of the style 10; stigmas capitate. Capsules pubescent, covered with blunt spines, each spine having 2 straight bristles in the back, wedge-shaped on the inner side, smooth.
chemical_composition: Mangiferin and quercetin isolated from aerial parts.

author: (L.) Bross. Wal.
description: Shrubby, .5-1.25 m high. locations.vegetation: Tropical semi evergreen to evergreen forest

pharmacology: Antiinflammatory, antibacterial, moderate CNS depressant, antifertility, antispasmodic, analgesic, hepatoprotective, estrogenic, anticonvulsant, antiarthritic, diuretic, antimicrobial, antiparkinsonian, antipsychotic, antidepressant, antihistamine releasing activity, mosquito repellent activity, antifeedant, antifilarial, juvenomimetic, antiandrogenic. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 In a clinical study 30 cases of Vatavyadhis (20 trial cases and 10 control cases) were treated with Nirgundi. The drug was found more efficacious in Sandhigata vata (non-inflammatory type joint pain), but not much useful in the treatment of Amavata (inflammatory i.e. rheumatoid arthrites). 22 patients of Girva Hundanam (cervical spondylosis) were treated for 21 days in 3 groups viz., Suddha Guggulu (Commiphora mukul) group and mixed group. Improvement was observed 66.66% in NPPS, 73.3% in Guggulu and 100% in mixed group. Dry powder of I11V. negundoI11 leaf (250 mg) was fed everyday with little cold water to patients suffering from low sperm count for 120 days regularly. After 25 days, sharp increment in sperm count was found on every 15th day check up since the commencement of the therapy to the patients lying under rest condition. After 75 days, optimum increment of nearly 3.5 times in a sperm count has been seen. The ratio of live and dead sperm is also increased to optimum level by 60 days from 1:1 to nearly 4:1 level. Withdrawal of the drug affects the sperm count and its slopes down to base level within another 120 days. Clinical studies were made in refractive error and cataract cases with a herbal preparation containing I11Vitex negundoI11 as one of the constituents. Some improvements were noted in associated symptoms bringing a general amelioration of the eyes. A subjective improvement of vision was reported by some cases of refractive errors. No side effect was reported. A clinical trial was conducted with proprietary gel consisting of I11Vitex negundo, Curcuma longa, Azadirachta indica, Elettaria cardamomum, Cedrus deodara, Boerhavia diffusaI11 and I11Nelumbium spesiosumI11 on 31 patients with vaginitis. All the patients were advised to apply the gel twice daily for a period of two weeks. Complete relief symptoms was observed in 73% patients within 7-14 days with no untoward manifestations. Vranshodhan taila, having Karanji oil as base, was tried in 78 patients suffering from dandruff. Observations were made after 10 applications. 57 patients were completely cured as there was no dandruff. 18 patients needed 20 applications. In 3 patients dandruff was present in considerable amount even after 20 applications. After six months rechecking, 32 patients had recurrence which indicates that periodic application of oil is needed. Other ingredients of oil were I11Nerium oleander, Terminalia chebula, Azadirachta indica, Vitex negundoI11 and I11Datura fastuosa.I11 View Reference

author: (Dalz.) Wight
description: A robust woody climber; branches armed with numerous recurved prickles. Leaves 2-pinnate, 23-30 cm long; main rhachis armed with recurved prickles; pinnae 4-6 pairs, 7.5-5 cm long, the rhachis terete, puberulous; stipules inconspicuous. Leaflets 5-7 pairs, 2.5-4.5 by 1.25-2 cm, coriaceous, oblong, obtuse or subacute, dark green, glabrous and shining above, paler beneath. Inflorescence often armed with recurved prickles. Flowers nearly sessile, in dense spicate racemes sometimes reaching 60 cm long; Calyx densely puberulous, 1-1.25 cm long, scarlet; segments oblong or subspathulate, obtuse, equaling the campanulate tube. Petals 5, subequal, 1-1.25 cm long. inserted on the top of the calyx-tube obovate-spathulate, reticulately veined, dark orange. Stamens 10, equaling the petals, alternately long and short; filaments flattened and densely pilose at the base. Ovary densely pubescent; ovules 4-6; style as long as the filaments and the petals; stigma 2-lobed, oblique. Pods 3.75-6.25 by 1.25-1.5 cm, linear-oblongwith swollen sutures. Seeds 3-4, obovate-oblong, transverse; testa hard, thick, bony.

author: Dunal
description: A branched erect, succulent undershrub 1-1.5 m high; branches terete, usually clothed with mealy stellate hoary tomentum. Leaves 5-10 by 2.5-5 cm, ovate, subacute, entire, more or less minutely stellately pubescent, and base acute; main nerves about 6 pairs, stout, conspicuous; petiols .6-1.25 cm long, stellately tomentose. Flowers white or very pale pink, usually about 5 together in a sessile or nearly sessile umbellate cyme; pedicels 0-.4 cm long, linear, acute, from a deltoid base. Calyx campanulate, 5-6 toothed, accrescent in fruit. Corolla campanulate, .8 cm long, divided rather more than Â½ waydown; lobes lanceolate, acute, pubescent outside. Stamens 5, attached near the base of the corolla; anthers dehiscing longitudinally. Filaments .3 cm long, slender, glabrous; anthers braoadly elliptic (almost orbicular), .12 cm long. Ovary glabrous, 2-celled; ovules numerous; style glabrous stigma shortly 2-fid. Berry red, smooth, globose, .6 cm in diam., enclosed in the inflated calyx which reaches more than 2.5 cm in diam., and is globose, slightly 5-angled, pointed with the connevent calyx-teeth and scurfy-pubescent outside. Seeds .25 cm in diam., yellow, somewhat scurfy.

author: (L.) Kurz
description: A straggling leafy shrub reaching 4 m high; branches long, spreading; bark smooth, cinnamon-brown, peeling off in fibres; young shoots terete, often clothed with fine white pubescence. Leaves 5-9 by 1.25-2.5 cm, opposite or subopposite, sometimes in whorls of 3 sessile, ovate-lanceolate, acute, softly velvety above, usually hoary and always nigro-punctate beneath, base rounded or cordate; main nerves 6-12 pairs, arcuate, prominent beneath, uniting in a distinct intramarginal nerve. Flowers numerous, in short 2-15-(rarely 1-) flowered cymes from the axils of former,less commonly of present leaves; pedicels short, glandular-pubescent. Calyx 1.5 cm long, striate, covered with glandular dots, with a small campanulate base and a long slightly curved bright-red tube which is slightly contracted above the included capsule; mouth oblique; teeth 6, about .25 cm long, triangular, acute. Petals slightly longer than the calyx-teeth, narrowly linear, produced at the apex to a long fine point. Stamens 12, inserted near the bottom of the calyx-tube, much exserted, the alternate ones longer; filaments filiform; anthers broadly ovate or subrotund. Ovary sessile, cylindric, 2-celled (sometimes incompletely so); ovules numerous, minute, inserted on thick placentas adnate to the axis of the ovary; style filiform, longer than the ovary, slightly longer than the stamens, sometimes narrowed at the apex; stigma punctiform. Capsule 1 cm long, usually splitting the calyx near the base, irregularly dehiscent. Seeds cuneate-obovoid, brown, smooth.
pharmacology: Antipyretic, antibiotic, abortifacient, antifungal, antitumour, antiviral. C11Therapeutic EvaluationC11 Varunadi kwatha (a composite Ayurvedic drug containing I11Crataeva religiosa, Tribulus terrestris, Zingiber officinale, Bergenia ligulata, Woodfordia fruticosaI11 and jaggery) was given in dose of 20 ml with water before lunch and dinner to 50 patients having urinary complaints. Excellent results were obtained in 64% of the patients and 26% showed moderate relief. Sailan-ur-Rehman (vaginal discharge) is very common ailment in all age of groups of females. Powder of I11Areca catechu, Salmalia malabarica, Mimusops Elengi, Woodfordia floribundaI11 and I11Cichorium intybusI11were used in the form of vaginal tablets. These drugs are used as haemostatic, astringent, anti-inflammatory and analgesic in Unani system of medicine. The drug was used in single blind technique in forty five patients; twenty five in the test group and twenty in control group. Tablets were given intra-vaginally at a time for fifteen days. Significant improvement was observed. View Reference

author: (Wight & Arn.) Arn.
description: Slender monoceous climber with an oblong, perennial, flattened tuberous root. Stems deeply striate, glabrous. Tendrils simple, striate, glabrous. Leaves broadly ovate in outline, 4.5-9 cm long and as broad or sometimes broader than long, acute or shortly acuminate and mucronate at the apex, usually 5-angled, the angles at the base rounded, the margins distantly toothed, the upper side usually rough with scabrous spots, the lower side smooth and prominently veined, base subcordate or nearly truncate; petioles 2-2.5 cm long. MALE FLOWERS: Inflorescence a capitate or subumbellate raceme with 3-10 flowers at the apex of a peduncle; pedicels short, filiform. Calyx-tube .12-.15 cm long, campanulate, rounded at the base; 5-toothed; teeth very short, recurved. Corolla hairy within the throat; deeply 5-partite; segments entire. Stamens 3, inserted on the tube (rarely at the base) of the calyx; filaments free; anthers free or rarely slightly cohering, one 1-celled, the others 2-celled or sometimes all 2-celled, the cells straight, rarely curved, annular, rarely 3-lobed. Filaments hairy. FEMALE FLOWERS: Soliatary, peduncled; peduncles .6-.8 cm long, in the same axils as the males. Calyx and corolla as in the male. Ovary globose. Fruit smooth, globose, minutely pitted, red when ripe. 1-1.5 cm in diam., Seeds many, much flattened, smooth.

author: Roscoe
description: An herbaceous rhizomatous perennial, upto 60cm in height when fully grown. The herb develops several lateral shoots in clumps. Leaves 15-30 cm long and 2-3 cm broad, with sheathing bases, the blade gradually tapering to a point. The rhizomes are aromatic, thick lobed pale yellow, bearing simple alternate distichous narrow, oblong lanceolate leaves.
pharmacology: Anti-inflammatory activity in carrageenin-induced rat paw oedema has been shown. The active principles- (6) â gingerol, (6) â and (10) â dehydrogingerdione and (6) and (10) â gingerdione were shown to be potent inhibitors of prostaglandin synthesis â confirming the mechanism of anti-inflammatory effect. The antirheumatic effects were further confirmed by other investigators antihistaminic activity has also been shown in vitro. The plant inhibits the virion toxic factor production in infected chorioallantoin membrane and also inhibits the growth of W. M. - 250 malignant cell-lines. Cardiac inotropic activity has been shown in dogs and guinea pigs. C11Clinical UsageC11 Ginger was shown to have significant antiemetic and antivertigo effects like Dramamine. It has been used effectively along with I11Piper nigrumI11 and I11Piper longumI11 in viral hepatitis. Ginger forms an important constituent of many ayurvedic formulations. It is chiefy used as a home remedy for nausea and dyspepsia. View Reference
chemical_composition: The rhizome contains 1-4% essential oil and an oleoresin. The composition of the essential oil varies as function of geographical origin, but the chief constituent sesquiterpene hydrocarbons (responsible for the aroma) seem to remain constant. These compounds include (-)-zingiberene, (+)-ar-curcumene, (-) âÃ -sesquiphellandrene, and Ã-bisabolene, Monoterpene aldehydes and alcohols are also present. The constituents are responsible for the pungent taste of the drug and possibly part of its anti-emetic properties have been identified as 1-(3â-methoxy-4â-hydroxyphenyl)-5-hydroxyalkan -3-ones, known as [3-6]-, [8]-[10]-, and [12]-gingerols (having a side chain with 7-10, 12, 14, or 16 carbon atoms, respectively) and their corresponding dehydration products, which are known as shogaols (1, 4, 6, 14, 19).

Basic Description of Plant : An herbaceous rhizomatous perennial, upto 60cm in height when fully grown. The herb develops several lateral shoots in clumps. Leaves 15-30 cm long and 2-3 cm broad, with sheathing bases, the blade gradually tapering to a point. The rhizomes are aromatic, thick lobed pale yellow, bearing simple alternate distichous narrow, oblong lanceolate leaves.

author: (L.) Gaertn.
description: A small much-branched tree or large shrub armed with sharp prickles; young branches softly pubescent. Leaves alternate 2.5-6.25 by 2-3.75 cm, bifarious, ovate-elliptic, rounded at both ends, slightly inequilateral at the base, faintly and irregularly denticulate, glabrous above, covered beneath with a dense whitish or buff tomentum, stongly 3-nerved from the base; petioles .6-1.25 cm long; prickles soliatary or in pairs. Flowers greenish-yellow, in small axillary clusters or short peduncled axillary cymes. Calyx 4-fid, pubescent or woolly outside, glabrous within, cleft about half way down; lobes triangular, prominently keeled on the inner face for about half their length. Petals 5, cucullate, rounded at the apex, deflexed with the stamens between the calyx-lobes; pedicels short, hairy. Stamens 5, enclosed in the petals, but not exserted beyond them; filaments 5.5 cm long, slightly dilated at the base, ovoid; ovary immersed in the disk and confluent with it at the base, 2-4 celledl; styles 2, stigmas small, papillose. Styles 2, connate for about half their length. Fruit a drupe, globose or oblong, with a woody or bony 1-4 celled 1-4 seeded stone, edible, .8 cm in diam., glabrous, red when ripe.
chemical_composition: Structure of peptide alkaloid-zizyphinine-elucidated; structure of zizyphine A, a peptide alkaloid from bark; zizyphines C, D and E isolated from stem bark along with zizyphines A and B, Abyssinines A and B.

author: (L.) Miller
description: A straggling shrub often semi-scandent by its prickles; young branches rusty-tomentose. Leaves numerous, distichous, 2.5-6.25 by 2-2.5 cm, ovate or ovate lanceolate, acute or subacuminate, with pubescent or tomentose tips, minutely denticulate, glabrous or pubescent above, densely silky with appressed rufous hairs beneath, base very oblique; main basal nerves usually 3, with numerous ascending branches, the lowest branch on the large side of the leaf starting almost, from the base; petioles .6-.8 cm long; stipular prickle 1, stout, short, hooked, pubescent except the tip. Flowers 12-20, in subsessile pubescent paniculate cymes which are slightly longer than the petioles. Calyx hairy outside; lobes ovate, cuneate, shorter than the calyx-lobes, exceeding the stamens. Disk with 10 short deeply pitted lobes, glabrous. Styles united almost to the apex. Drupe edible, .6 cm in diam., globose or obovoid, 1- (rarely 2-) celled, black, shining; pulp scanty; stone woody or bony.

author: Lam.
description: A large straggling armed shrub sometimes climbing; young branches clothed with fulvous tomentum. Leaves alternate, 5-12.5 cm long. Broadly elliptic, shortly acuminate, denticulate, glabrous above, fuvous-tomentose beneath, base oblique, often cordate; petioles .6-1.25 cm long, tomentose; prickles from a broad base, solitary, short, recurved, tomentose except the tips. Flowers in long-peduncles tomentose cymes arranged along usually leafless spinous branches forming a panicle (the cymes sometimes turned one side); buds globose and as well as the peduncles and pedicels densely tomentose. Calyx 5-fid; pubescent outside; lobes ovate acute. Petals 5, cucullate, deflexed. Disk 5-10 lobed, flat or pitted, the margin free. Stamens 5, enclosed by the petals and longer than them. Ovary immersed in the disk and confluent with it at the base. Drupe .6-.8 cm in diam., globose or pyriform, white when ripe; stone thin, 1-celled, 1-seeded.
chemical_composition: A new glycoside âzizyphoside âisolated along with betulic, oleanolic, alphitolic and 2S224 -hydroxyursolic acids; zizyphoside pn hydrolysis yielded altered aglycone, ebelin lactone.

author: (L.) Pers.
description: Annual, much branched herbs; branches prostrate or ascending, glabrous or puberulous. Leaves 2-foliolate; petioles .6-2 cm long; stipules subfoliaceous, often punctuate, 1 cm long, lanceolate, acute, strongly nerved, produced below the insertion into a triangular spur. Leaflets usually dotted, exstipellate, variable in size and shape, 1.25-3 by .3-1.5 cm, sessile, often unequal sided, linear-lanceolate or occasionally linear, dotted with black glands beneath glabrous, rigid. Flowers small, in 3-12-flowered spicate racemes 2.5-10 cm long; peduncles slender, terete; bracts foliaceous, reaching 1.25 cm long, ovate-lanceolate, acute, ciliate, sprinkled with black dots, produced below the insertion into a triangular spur, strongly nerved from the base, completely enclosing the flower and often the entire pod. Calyx membranous, .3 cm long, the 2 upper teeth broad, obtuse, deeply connate, ciliate at the apex, the 2 lateral teeth small deltoid, the lowest tooth the longest, lanceolate, acute, ciliate. Corolla much exserted, twice as long as the calyx; standard orbicular, with a long claw. Stamens monadelphous; anthers dimorphous. Ovary sessile; ovules many; style filiform; stigma small, terminal.Pods 1-6 jointed, either quite enclosed by the bracts or exserted; joints about .2 cm long, compressed, indehiscent, covered with numerous short straight fulvous spines.
chemical_composition: The leaves contain 13.12% of protein, of which 6.80% is extractable. Leaf protein preparations contain 38.43% protein (Pandey, Plant Food Hum Nutr, 1994, 46, 313). The seeds contain: moisture, 7.9; crude protein, 36.3; pentosan, 10.5; and water soluble gum, 1.6% (Kapoor et al, J Sci Ind Res, 1992, 51, 10).
